HEADLINE: Putnam's Mysterious Chambers of Stone 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

DATELINE: KENT CLIFFS 

 BODY:
MARTIN BRECH stepped cleanly through the woods here, stopped and pointed to an odd stone cavern built into the hillside like something out of a J. R. R. Tolkien novel.
 Its roof, a series of huge rock slabs, rested on arched walls made of large stones that fit together so precisely they did not need mortar. 
 It was the early morning of March 20, the spring equinox, and the sun was just creeping over the horizon. Its rays darted through the doorway and down the length of the long narrow chamber onto the back wall. The sunlight illuminated the interior as it does only once a year. 
Archaeoastronomy, the alignment of structures with the heavens, is usually associated with such ancient wonders as Machu Picchu in Peru or Newgrange chamber in Ireland.
In fact, this chamber tucked away in the woods of Putnam County resembles the neolithic stone monuments of the ancient Celts. So do the roughly 100 similar stone chambers in Putnam.
Mr. Brech, the Hudson Valley coordinator for the New England Antiquities Research Association, is convinced that stone structures like this one were built by ancient European explorers, possibly Celts, who sailed to the New World centuries before Columbus.
Critics dismiss these theories as based more on imagination than evidence, and locals have long considered these structures the handiwork of 18th-century farmers who they say built them to store meat, dairy products and vegetables on farms that have since gone back to forest.
But Mr. Brech calls it preposterous that some farmer would -- or could -- haul multi-ton slabs of granite just to make a shed. "You don't need to go to these lengths for a storage space," he said. "You'd only do something like this for religious purposes."
For years the chambers, many of which are aligned with equinox and solstice sunrises, have inspired debate among amateur historians. But now they have come center stage amid renewed controversy over their history and an effort to preserve them that would include millions of dollars in county funds.
Similar stone structures exist in Connecticut, Vermont and New Hampshire, where the strange rock formations on Mystery Hill are a tourist attraction called America's Stonehenge because of the claim that ancient Celts built them during a long visit some 2,000 years ago.
But curiously, the highest concentration of them lies in Putnam County. They have long mystified local history buffs and archaeologists, and spawned a proliferation of theories about explorers (ancient Celts or Irish monks, Libyan sailors, Iberian adventurers or Phoenician traders) being lured by Putnam's rich iron reserves, and hypothetical uses of the chambers: Viking dwellings, Celtic cathedrals, Indian burial tombs, runaway slave hideouts and witches' hovels.
In recent years, enthusiasts have mapped most of the chambers as part of a serious preservation campaign. Many have been destroyed by developers and property owners who do not regard them as historic, Mr. Brech said.
The chambers have figured heavily in several books published since the mid-1970's supporting the theory of pre-Columbus settlement, including "Bronze Age America" (Little, Brown, 1982) and "America B.C.: Ancient Settlers in the New World," (Simon & Schuster, 1976) both by Barry Fell, a Harvard biology professor who identified inscriptions on similar structures in New England as Ogam, an ancient Irish language.
In another book, "The Search for Lost America," (Penguin Books, 1979) Salvatore Michael Trento writes that the Putnam chambers "appear to be the congregated structures of a social community; they are strangely different from any that have been built since colonial times."
And a book published last year, "Celtic Mysteries in New England" (Llewellyn Worldwide) by Philip Imbrogno and Marianne Horrigan was devoted mostly to the Putnam chambers, calling them the work of ancient explorers. Since its publication, students writing book reports all across the country have been writing to libraries and historical groups in Putnam requesting more information.
But there is little material available locally. Most Putnam residents know the huts simply as root cellars built to store farmers' perishables. Few have heard the elaborate theories about Druid temples. And many locals are puzzled by the surge of interest in these structures that often serve as yard sheds or smelly trash dumps.
Most mainstream historians and archaeologists dismiss the revisionist theories for lack of evidence. The chambers exist almost exclusively in Putnam, they say, because this Hudson Highlands area is rich with large slabs and boulders. As far as the chambers facing east, they say, the farmers needed the morning light to use the cellars.
"I don't want to rain on anybody's parade, but we know through interviews that there was a group of guys who went around building these things for the early farmers," said Jim Baker, a local environmentalist and planning chairman for the town of Kent. "They made ramps of earth and used oxen to pull the stones up."
Mr. Baker pointed to a written interview with a Putnam Valley farmer, Lucas Barger, whose forebears helped settle the area. Mr. Barger recalled relatives' descriptions of how the chambers were built. (Mr. Brech calls Mr. Barger's account a "yarn" that does not describe the chambers accurately.)
Dr. Kenneth L. Feder, an anthropology professor at Central Connecticut State University, said, "Just because they are very interesting and cool and make us go 'Wow' has no bearing on who made them."
"The fact that it's possible don't make it so," said Dr. Feder, who has researched similar structures in Connecticut and written several books including "Frauds, Myths, and Mysteries: Science and Pseudoscience in Archaeology" (Mayfield Publishing Company, 1998).
"If people from England, Ireland or Scotland were in Putnam 2,000 years ago long enough to build these structures, they'd have left some sort of evidence," he said. "But there's just no physical evidence in the form of artifacts."
Putnam is dotted with these stone structures, whether tucked deep in the woods, on the main roads or presiding over grassy backyards.
"To most people, they're just part of the landscape," said Marilyn Schlansky, director of the Carmel library. "For a lot of the kids, they're a place out in the woods to smoke and drink."
One chamber stands several feet from the whizzing traffic on Route 6 in Mahopac, diagonally across from the Kmart and the Grand Union. Inside are leaves and trash and a faint smell of urine. On the walls there are indeciperable inscriptions, not in ancient Ogam, but in black spray paint.
Henry Grosskamp, 69, of Dutchess, owns the property and grew up there. His family once used the chamber to store the apples and vegetables they grew. But now it's useless, he said.
"I could see saving these things if they meant anything, but they're just root cellars," he said. "I'm waiting for the day the town widens the road and knocks it down."
And that may not take long; there is brisk development in Putnam, one of the state's fastest growing counties.
Mr. Brech has capitalized on the pace of development and on public interest in the chambers to gain support and publicity for a proposal he hopes to see on the November ballot. The measure, now being considered by the Putnam County legislature's environmental committee, would ask for voter approval to use tax dollars to buy historic land and structures facing demolition by developers. The money would be provided as matching funds to towns and villages wishing to make the purchases.
The structures have been the topic of discussions at historical societies, exhibits at libraries and even formal debates in front of the chambers. The meetings draw a diverse audience, including hikers, historians, environmentalists, professors, politicians and self-proclaimed witches.
"They bring out interesting people," said Sallie Sypher, a former Putnam County historian. "We had a man up from New York City to one of our symposiums, with high boots and britches and long frock coat and ponytail. He said he was a healer and came because of the chambers' healing properties."
In the early 1990's, Mr. Brech said, a student on a class trip to a Putnam Valley chamber found an artifact, an obsidian knife, that scientists say must have originally come from Greenland.
Mr. Brech said it was unlikely that farmers built the chambers because Putnam has more than anywhere else but had fewer farms than neighboring areas. He notes that no farmers' artifacts have been found around the chambers. And he said there are no written records of building them.
But, Mrs. Sypher countered, "They didn't write about building their outhouses either.
"Early explorers wouldn't have had oxen, and human labor alone couldn't have made these," she said. "Yes, they're similar to early England, but how many different ways can you do post and lintel building?"
Still, she added: "Whatever they are, they're worth preserving. There are so many in this area, and they're really part of the charm here."
Mr. Brech says that more and more locals are picking up on his theory.
Sam Oliverio Jr., a Putnam County legislator and chairman of the legislature's environmental committee, is a believer. He is sponsoring Mr. Brech's proposal.
"Farmers wrote in diaries about building stone walls and farmhouse foundations, barns, orchards, but nothing about building these stone structures," said Mr. Oliverio, who represents the town of Putnam Valley. "It's not far-fetched to think that instead of 1492, maybe in 500 A.D., explorers came ashore and built them."
Mr. Oliverio said he has tried to get the county to protect the structures but "it's always knocked down with 'What do you want to save a root cellar for?'
"Sure, I'm scoffed at," he said, "but there's more to it than just root cellars. A real study has never been done because too many people dismiss it. But somebody should really commission one."
In years past, preservationists have rallied around the structures when they were threatened. In the late 1980's, the Ginsburg Development Corporation planned to build 430 units of housing in Kent Hills, the site of several chambers. Preservationists rejoiced when the project stalled because of the recession. New York City has since bought the land to use as watershed.
Then, in the mid-1990's, the Foley Development Corporation of White Plains planned 418 homes in the Lake Point section of Carmel. The stone chambers were central to homeowners' opposition to the project, which collapsed. The land was also bought by New York City.
Mr. Brech said that they are often demolished out of pure ignorance of their history.
Chip Marks, who runs tours of archaeological sites in the Hudson Valley, lamented that often in the county, "I look and there's another chamber bulldozed to make way for a new house."
Nonetheless, some see commercial value in the chambers.
Roseanne Verlen, a real estate agent with Houlihan-Lawrence who lives in Putnam Valley, has sold several houses with chambers on the property. She usually mentions the chamber when advertising the property because it tends to increase the sale price.
"People want that," she said. "They add to the authenticity of historic homes. When you explain that they're colonial root cellars, they're intrigued. Of course, they wind up keeping wheelbarrows and lawnmowers in them."
Celtic theorists point to other apparent megalithic structures in the Hudson Valley to support their beliefs. For example, the red-granite Balanced Rock, resting on five smaller conical rocks on Route 116 in North Salem, weighs some 80 tons. A sign at the site erected by local historians describes it as having been deposited by a glacier in the Ice Age. But in recent years, an alternate description has been added to the sign: that it could be a dolmen, or ceremonial stone, erected by Celts who visited the area more than 2,000 years ago.
Elsewhere, too, there seems to be growing acceptance of the possibility that the chambers are ancient.
"We always called them root cellars, but now we're trying to call them stone chambers so we're not judgmental," Mrs. Sypher said. When she takes students on field trips to the chambers, she said: "I tell them different points of view about them and they can believe what they want. Of course, they don't know what Druids are."
Mr. Brech, who teaches ancient and medieval philosophy at Westchester Community College, lectures widely about the chambers and has given tours of them. He is 74 and lives in a geodesic dome house built around a tree on a dead end in Mahopac. It is cluttered with philosophy books, infrared heaters and health food products.
He contends that the structures served as spiritual centers for the ancients who once lived in Putnam. Their religious leaders recharged their spiritual energy inside by meditating through the solstice and equinox illumination. 
Several years ago, Mr. Brech himself spent the night in a Kent chamber in December and had a "profound mystical experience" at sunrise, he said.
That, and climbing Mount Whitney in California, converted him from an atheist to a mystic. Now he's a Unitarian minister with a master's degree from Columbia University and degrees in forestry, theology and library science. He is also a political gadfly and ran for county executive as the Green Party candidate in the 1990's, promising to preserve the stone chambers.
He attends meetings of the legislature and sends letters to legislators, especially Robert J. Pozzi, of Mahopac, who is chairman of the Economic Development Committee.
"He, uh, continues to educate us on these chambers," Mr. Pozzi said, declining to speculate on the pedigree of the chambers.
U.F.O. enthusiasts, too, have taken an interest in the chambers.
In the 1990's, preservationists invited a U.F.O. expert, Dr. Bruce Cornet, then a staff geologist at the Lamont Doherty Observatory, to bring a proton procession magnetometer to measure slight variations in the earth's magnetic field. Dr. Cornet visited four chambers and said he recorded "the strangest readings I ever got in this area."
"It was strong enough to reverse a compass," he said. "Each stone chamber had a significant magnetic pull right in front of the door. This magnetic anomaly is a true clue that they are much older than the early colonists." He speculated that builders put metallic material below the chamber's doorstep plate either to aid in finding the chambers with early compasses or to help early religious leaders perform magnetic tricks during ritual ceremonies to convince people of their special powers."
Dr. Cornet also said that the chambers could be "sensing platforms to search for extraterrestrial visitation."
Many similar fringe theories have cropped up. The book "Celtic Mysteries," for example, alternates between conventional scientific methods and an "X-Files" approach. It calls the chambers centers of "high strangeness" and sites of paranormal activity and ghost sightings, and it quotes a local psychic who argues that the chambers are "portals to the other side used for traveling out of body."
The chambers hold a particular fascination for many believers in Wicca, or the practice of witchcraft. They hold ceremonies at the chambers because of their astronomical alignment and the belief that they may have been used by ancient Celts, said Lady Lorraine, who owns Dancing Moon, a New Age shop in Carmel.
"Equinoxes, solstices," she said, her black cat, Nimew, rubbing against her leg. "Full moons are popular too."
Robert E. Funk, chief archaeologist for the New York State Museum from 1971 to 1993, said the chambers have "never been seriously investigated because nobody has ever produced any evidence of anything but colonial origin."
"There are no Celtic ruins in the New World and certainly not in Putnam County," he said. "It's a romantic idea and people want to believe this almost like a religion. These structures may be historical as colonial constructs, and not enough attention has been given to that, but Putnam has always been kind of neglected that way."
Eleanor Fitchen, 88, founder of the Landmarks Preservation Society of South East, said at least some of the chambers were built by colonial farmers because there are some written accounts.
"I don't deny the possibility of some them having been from Norse times," she said. "We know they were here before the European settlers. But to arbitrarily say these are all temples, I don't buy it. 
"But it's been believed by a lot of people for a long time. So if it makes them feel better to believe that, fine. They are amazing historic structures no matter who built them, and the more reason to save them, the better."

One Theory: Indians Built Them
"This is a true American mystery right under New Yorkers' noses," said Salvatore Michael Trento, who conducted perhaps the most extensive research of the region's stone chambers. In the mid-1970's he created the Middletown Archaeological Research Center and with a large staff excavated 12 chambers throughout the Northeast. In the end, there were still few answers.
"I was sure we would know after a couple years. That's how it usually goes with a dig, but these are the most puzzling thing I've come across in the eastern United States," said Mr. Trento, who studied at Oxford, worked for the National Geographic Society and excavated ancient megaliths all over the world.
He theorizes that the chambers were built by American Indians, all conforming to a similar style.
"They're not made by Celts or aliens," he said. "It's actually more interesting than that. You can trace every bit of non-Indian architecture in this country to models in Europe, everything from stone walls to barns. But there is nothing like these chambers in Europe. They are a homegrown, vernacular piece of native architecture. And after all these years, no one has any idea what they are.
"I find it astonishing that we have these incredible pieces of architecture and nobody is looking at them."
He said that fantastic theories keep away serious archaeologists.
"It's the kiss of death academically," he said. "Tenured N.Y.U. and Harvard professors are not going to study places that have all these loopy people offering fringe archaeological theories on them."
He added: "It is so extraordinarily unusual that there are no artifacts there. I've looked at sites around the world, and there's always something left behind, but these have been literally swept clean.
"They're part of our history, and if you're going to start bulldozing them to build housing developments, you're stupid."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Click and Win: Inventors Cash In on Their Ideas

BYLINE:  By DEBORAH KONG

 BODY:
MICHAEL SMITHSON'S epiphany came about 10 minutes into his career as an inventor. While reading about a Coca-Cola contest to dream up an entertaining and healthy drink for children, he recalled how his 9-year-old grandson had trouble keeping track of his tackle, rods, snacks and sunscreen on a fishing trip last summer. Because children are prone to losing things, Mr. Smithson suggested a frozen drink in a container that children can wear on their wrists, as they would a bracelet, and sip as it thaws. He found out a few weeks ago that he had won the $5,000 prize.
 Albert Muller struck pay dirt, too, but it took 28 years. Mr. Muller, a retired Boeing engineer, spent that time perfecting a better nozzle for heavy-duty vacuum cleaners, but he dreaded the process of selling his invention to appliance makers. Then he heard that Sears, Roebuck was offering $5,000 for the best idea for "the next hot tool," and he pitched the nozzle. Sears bought it. 
 Both men connected with the companies through Ideas.com, a Mountain View, Calif., company whose Web site helps people who fancy themselves as the next Thomas Edison to send their ideas directly to corporate decision makers. Mr. Smithson and Mr. Muller are among the first winners of innovation contests that Ideas.com began when it went online in November. 
Ideas.com, one of several new sites that buy, sell or solicit intellectual property, may be a win-win solution for companies and inventors. "Companies are scrambling all the time to come up with new ideas" because of faster product cycles, said Sanjay Goel, the site's founder and chief executive. The Internet is a natural place to look, because many people who use it are technologically knowledgeable and naturally curious. And the sites provide an easy way to gauge consumer trends.
"It used to be we would come up with an idea, and consumers would help us evaluate it, refine it" in focus groups, said Tom LaForge, director of innovations at Coca-Cola. "Now we're getting to consumers one step earlier, and they're coming up with the ideas."
With the economy slowing, the time is certainly ripe. "In many ways, companies are going to be trying to sell themselves out of this downturn," said John Fontanella, an analyst at AMR Research in Boston. 
Mr. Goel started Ideas.com a year ago after struggling to find a home for his own idea for a new car gadget. He envisioned a site where large corporations could collect ideas from people around the world, saving individuals the headache and expense of patenting and developing ideas on their own and sparing companies the bother and potential legal liability of sifting through a flood of unsolicited ideas.
There is a tradeoff. On the site, would-be inventors must accept an agreement intended to protect companies from lawsuits accusing them of stealing inventions. Steven L. Smith, a Sacramento patent lawyer, cautioned that inventors might be relinquishing the rights to their ideas simply by submitting them, and said he advises inventors to require companies to sign nondisclosure and noncompetition agreements.
MR. GOEL quit his job as an investment banker at Citibank in late 1999 after receiving a $1.2 million investment from Venky Harinarayan, a former classmate at the University of California at Los Angeles, and Anand Rajaraman and Rakesh Mathur. The three men were among the founders of the Junglee Corporation, which made software to help consumers find the best prices for products on the Internet; Junglee was sold to Amazon.com in 1998 for about $250 million.
Mr. Goel then persuaded a former New York University classmate and skydiving pal, Sharat Singh, to quit his job as a lead program manager at Microsoft and to become president and chief technology officer of Ideas.com. They secured the backing of Coca-Cola, Sears, Roebuck, S. C. Johnson & Son and International Paper, which agreed to pay an undisclosed membership fee. Ideas.com also receives a commission of about 30 percent from the idea contest awards, paid by the companies.
Coca-Cola and Sears said that they were impressed with the quality of ideas from the first contests.
A Coke competition seeking innovative ideas in packaging, for example, was won by Spencer Wolf, who proposed a drink container that illuminates itself when squeezed. Mr. Wolf, who studied mechanical engineering at Cornell and is now pursuing a master's degree in business administration at U.C.L.A., said his idea went back to when he asked his father what caused fireflies to glow without the benefit of electrical outlet or batteries. The invention uses piezoelectricity, a mechanical phenomenon that replicates that effect with crystals.
Coca-Cola said that it was evaluating Mr. Smithson's idea for the wrist-worn container and that Mr. Wolf's proposal for the self-illuminating container might be explored later. Other ideas, from doctors, college students, professors, children and parents, have confirmed some consumer trends that the company is exploring.
"A lot of consumers were asking for healthier drinks that had to do with soy," Mr. LaForge said. "I didn't realize how many people would be interested in that type of product." Other ideas, like packaging drinks with tablets that add vitamins or flavors, suggest "people are really looking for more customization," he said.
In judging the ideas for drinks, Coke was looking for a unique, healthy product with innovative packaging. Entries in a separate packaging contest had to be cost-effective, technically sound, easy to make and use, and meet safety, health and environmental standards. Judges included employees from Coke's legal, marketing, technical engineering and new product development departments. The company plans to post all 889 contest ideas on its internal Web site.
Mr. Smithson, 46, an insurance salesman from Leesburg, Fla., is among many people who have submitted ideas but have not previously considered themselves professional inventors. "In day-to-day life, you don't really get poked and prodded into having a lot of ideas," he said. "Something like this, it makes you think."
But Mr. Muller, who lives in Houston, has long taken innovation seriously. He belongs to the Houston Inventors Association, whose members share experiences and tips on developing ideas into products. 
He noted that raking leaves 28 years ago, on the patio of his former home in Southern California, spurred him to look for an easier solution. "I'm always looking at things to see how they work," he said.
Sears said it was reviewing patent documents and prototypes of Mr. Muller's invention to help decide if it wants to sell the product.
The Sears contest, which drew 135 entries, was also a way to channel some of the thousands of unsolicited ideas that the company receives each year. Invention proposals sometimes arrive on handwritten letters and home videos addressed to the chief executive's office, on scraps of paper handed to sales representatives or -- in the case of a pink lawn mower designed as part of a lawn-and-garden set for women -- carried into the company's headquarters in Hoffman Estates, Ill.
"In the midst of that disorderliness, we have the sense that there may be some terrific ideas out there," said Steve Kirn, vice president for innovation and organizational development at Sears. In October, Sears sought refrigerator improvement ideas through a competing site, www.brightidea.com. Companies pay the site $50,000 to be the host of such contests.
OTHER sites that solicit consumer ideas, like www.ideadollar.com and www.brainhead.com, are developing a few of them into products, offering inventors a stake if the idea turns into a new company or a share of royalties or sales. Ideadollar said one idea, for waterproof shower posters, has been turned into a product that will be in stores next month. Among ideas it received, said its chief executive, Mark Turrell, "we are probably sitting on the next Razor scooter."
Business-oriented sites, like www.yet2.com and www.pl-x.com, operated by the Patent & License Exchange, also function as marketplaces where companies buy and sell intellectual property. Honeywell International, for example, lists almost 100 technologies on yet2.com, hoping to attract new licensing revenue.
At Ideas.com, which has grown from 2 to 10 employees in the last year, the biggest challenge is to persuade more companies to conduct idea contests and to pay membership fees. The site is also trying to license software that will let companies collect ideas from their employees.
Mr. Goel asks companies to use his site to contract out some of their innovation, just as they might rely on outsiders for public relations or market research. They may find the next multibillion-dollar idea there, he said, reeling off a list of possibilities. "It could be the new Coke," he said. "It could be a new way of distributing foods. It could be a new form of energy."

HEADLINE: Listing Lack Buoys Second Home Prices 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
IF the prosperity of the second home market is tethered to the gyrations of Wall Street, then it would be logical to assume that prices of houses from East Hampton to Kennebunkport, Bucks County to the Berkshires had been sinking in recent months in tandem with the Dow Jones and Nasdaq indexes.
 But though the cutthroat bidding wars of last year have subsided, prospective buyers who assume they will be able to snatch up prime beach or country properties at fire sale prices are being unrealistic, according to second-home specialists. 
 What they are likely to confront instead are price tags that have not risen since last year but have dipped little, if at all, as demand continues to outstrip supply up and down the East Coast. 
Thomas B. Anderson, an executive vice president of Sotheby's International Realty who oversees country home sales from Connecticut to Virginia, said that the market, which soared last year, was simply catching up with itself. Historically, the real estate market has lagged about a year behind the financial markets. 
"There were so many individuals who acquired an enormous capability to purchase homes over the last several years and there was an enormous level of activity in the country home market, which left us with little inventory," he said. "The few homes that did come on the market sold quickly. So now despite the financial market, there remains a pent-up demand. When I call my affiliate brokers with lists of purchasers looking for properties, they all tell me they have nothing to show." 
However, the force of pent-up demand varies from one area to another. In some places like the Hamptons, in many ways a bellwether for the resort world, prices reached such extravagant heights last year that current reverses don't signify softening as much as correction, brokers and other observers say. In others, prices have not decreased at all. 
What has changed, even in the face of continuing shortages, Mr. Anderson said, is the attitude of sellers entering the market. "They recognize that the bidding-war frenzy has quieted and that they must ask prices that are realistic," he said. 
In addition, where there might have been multiple bidders trying to outdo one another in the past, there are more likely to be one or two now. 
"This is part of the natural ebb and flow of business," Judi Desiderio, the vice president of Cook Pony Farm, an agency that has seven offices throughout the Hamptons and three on the North Fork of Long Island. "We have had 10 years of incredible growth, with the last two years a little out of control. Beginning with the stock market glitch in September, the number of inquiries, offers, acceptances and sales have slowed down in all price ranges, and that has continued for the first quarter of 2001." 
There are exceptions, she added. "Westhampton, Amagansett, Sag Harbor and the North Fork, where you don't see the $50 million houses that skew your figures, have taken off," she said. That the second home market is wedded to Wall Street seems beyond question. "When Wall Street has a banner year, we have a banner year, and when Wall Street pulls back, so do we," Ms. Desiderio said. "Most of our customer base has something to do with it, whether they are employed by the street or their retirement portfolio is invested in the street or they are simply economically sensitive."
Kathleen F. Schwartz, a lawyer who handles real estate transactions from Westhampton to Amagansett, said: "The market may be a little strange right now and definitely slower, but there are sellers. All the sales I have handled this year have gone at the asking price, and I haven't seen any deals fall through. People who work on Wall Street are putting their bonuses into the ground." 
ON Martha's Vineyard, where buying has been as feverish in the last few years as it has been in the Hamptons, Fred Roven, a broker who deals exclusively with buyers, said prices, which had escalated by 40 percent in 1999 and 2000, were now more flexible. 
"People were trying to cash in and prices were so inflated a year ago," he said. "There were houses in the $3 million to $5 million range that were overpriced because of the stock market. They are settling a bit now and are more negotiable." 
Still, he said, he is aware of more than 50 listings over $1 million, along with an increased supply of properties crossing all price ranges from $275,000 for inland Cape Cods to $15 million for a house on five acres of oceanfront land.
Farther south, on the New Jersey shore, Diane Turton, president of a company that bears her name, said recently that she had detected not the slightest tremors in the market nor any moderation in prices. In fact, her recent experience seems to contradict the trends elsewhere. 
"Last year, we did about $100 million in secondary housing, and this year we are right on target," said Ms. Turton, who has 11 offices in New Jersey and two in Palm Beach. "I tell people that even if they have all cash, they might not get the house they want. One house recently had 18 offers and inventory is so low that we joke that agents must sell their own houses." 
A few days later, Lynn Miller, who is in charge of production for Kasper A.S.L., a women's suit manufacturer, signed a contract on a 2,100-square-foot three-bedroom house that sits on a lagoon in Toms River on which five other buyers had placed bids. She will pay $210,000 for the house, which was listed at $174,000. 
"It needs a lot of work, but it is exactly what I wanted," said Ms. Miller, who has been scouting weekend houses for about a year and made several unsuccessful bids. "In some cases, a person's dreams really do come true."
On the southern coast of Maine, "10 years ago, they would shut down the traffic lights on Labor Day," said Steven Weigel, owner of DeWolfe Y-Gull & Associates in Wells, who has been in business in the Kittery-York-Ogunquit-Kennebunkport area for 18 years. "Now people keep coming right through Jan. 1 and this is a hot location, particularly since two lanes are being added to the highway." 
In fact, he continued: "Prices really jumped in the last two years. In some places they are up $100,000 over last year. Anything out there even half reasonably priced is under contract." 
Beach or shoreline houses are listed at $700,000 to $3 million, and those a block away from the beach have risen to $500,000. "Inland, you can still buy something for under $200,000 that is a 10 minute drive to the beach," Mr. Weigel said.
One of the more spectacular offerings in his area is a $900,000 two-bedroom house put up on speculation that has a pool, a sauna and a home theater. "It is on a half an acre in the York area and barely has an ocean view," Mr. Weigel said. 
But for those who can't -- or won't -- spend such sums, he emphasized, "We are also selling condos that are former rental cottages or studios between $40,000 and $90,000." 
John Harney, an agent with Elyse Harney Real Estate, which is owned by his mother and which has three offices in the northwest corner of Connecticut and also does business in nearby New York and the Berkshires, said he had been surprised by the unbroken pace of sales in recent months. 
"We expected the winter to be slow, but it was not," he said as he recently toured colonial and contemporary houses in the historic villages of Sharon and Salisbury, Conn. "Quite frankly, there are more buyers than agents to serve them, and everyone is scrambling."
The average price in the historic area, where 300-year-old houses are not uncommon, runs between $400,000 and $500,000. But with privacy and sweeping vistas of land prized, there are also numerous estates and $1 million buys much more land there than it does in beach communities. 
"The biggest properties we sold this past year flipped into the $3 million category," Ms. Harney said. "We had a listing for a 100-acre property for some time that was $3.5 million. People are very resistant to crossing into the $4 million range." 
Dennis Kaylor and Tracey Young seemed comfortably confident that they would get their asking price, $2.4 million, for the 10,000-square-foot, 22-room 1772 Colonial house on 6.9 acres in what is known as Millionaire's Row in Sharon, which they recently put up for sale.
"How many playgrounds are there that are two to three hours from New York City?" asked Mr. Kaylor, who as a result of his experience with the house became a contractor after being a business partner in his wife's medical device consulting business. "When the brand new model of the Lexus sells out, we don't have to worry about selling houses. I feel very positive about the market this year." 
They restored the house, which was in shambles when they bought it on Halloween of 1996, without the aid of an architect. Besides numerous luxuries, they put in some uniquely practical amenities, like a faucet over the stove so that heavy pots can easily be filled with water and dim bedroom floor lights that go on automatically when an occupant gets up at night. 
Why would they leave a house into which they had poured so much labor?
"I have the attention span of a 5-year-old," said Ms. Young, a corporate strategist who also runs an antique garden ornament business out of the great hall of the house. "Now we want to build a U- or H-shaped farm around a courtyard." 
No matter the locale, serious buyers must be prepared to move fast, as Ed Mufson, who helps small and middle-size companies raise funds, learned recently. Mr. Mufson, who has been going to the Berkshires since childhood, has long yearned to buy a house there. 
"I started looking in July last year and must have looked at every house from the low to the high end of the price range," he said the other day. It had to be fairly isolated, have at least three bedrooms and be priced between the high $200,000's and low $400,000's. Most of what I saw was totally inappropriate, and I was despairing."
He had just about resigned himself to renting again when he got a call from Elaine Steinert, an associate broker with Cohen & White Associates in Lenox, Mass. 
"I was on vacation in Turks and Caicos," he said. "She announced, 'I've got a house for you, and you have to buy it.' "
"I said, 'I can't buy a house I've never seen.' I took my chances for three days, came home on a Saturday, drove up Sunday morning and called a bid in." 
Next week he will close on the house, which is situated on three acres in Richmond, Mass., paying just under $400,000. "I didn't look to fully exploit the downturn," he said. "I probably could have gotten it for a little less, but I think it is a good investment and it has everything I wanted."
Money seems to be no obstacle to the people who buy the one or two houses put up annually in East Hampton or Bridgehampton by John Shanholt, a designer and builder. 
"If a house is over $8 million and someone wants to buy it, they just do," Mr. Shanholt said. He is now building a spec house in Bridgehampton with pool, tennis court, spa, waterfall and several golf greens and anticipates getting $4 million to $5 million without any resistance. 
"I'm not even sure that a small downturn in the economy will affect my clients," he said. "After all, if you're worth $100 million and two weeks later you're worth $95 million, you can still afford a house. It is the middle part of the market that is most deeply affected." What constitutes a middle-range property depends on the locale and varies widely from the Hamptons, where $1 million is routine, to under $500,000 in Ulster County, N.Y. In the Lenox area of the Berkshires, Ellen Cohen said, "The middle range is from $350,000 to $600,000, and the upper end goes from $650,000 up."
In Ulster County, known for mountain climbing, hiking, trail biking and proximity to the State University of New York at New Paltz. "There is a fair inventory of houses in the $500,000 and up category, but there is a small group of people who can afford that or want to spend it," said George Danskin, an associate broker with Studley Real Estate in New Paltz. "There are not a lot of houses in the $150,000 to $275,000 range."
"But I don't want people with less than $200,000 to think they can't come here at all," he went on. "I have one new listing for a three-bedroom, 2,000-square-foot farmhouse with lots of architectural detail on four and a half acres for $194,000. That one will be snapped up fast. " 
It is also in the more moderate categories that the recent Federal Reserve interest rate reductions are most deeply felt. 
"It's still a seller's market, and in my opinion that is due to the lowered interest rate," said Tom Panepinto, a lawyer in Bayonne and Wall Township, N.J., who has been handling closings on the shore for 25 years. "When interest rates go down, that motivates people. When I started out in 1975, interest rates for mortgages were about 8 percent. Now they are 6 1/2 to 7 percent. People don't mind if they are paying $10,000 more than they expected if the 30-year payout is $68 extra a month."
This week's surprise cut by the Federal Reserve in short-term interest rates, the fourth this year, is considered likely to lead to further reductions in mortgage rates. 
DAVIS R. CHANT, chairman of a six-office realty firm in the Delaware River region of Pennsylvania, Sussex County in New Jersey and Sullivan County in the Catskills, agreed that interest rates were driving new business.
Describing his market as "not booming but very active," Mr. Chant said: "The interest rates are wonderful. They allow someone who maybe had a $2,000-a-month discretionary income for a second home that might someday be a retirement home to buy a substantially larger property. They have shaken a lot of people loose. They know interest rates won't be at this level forever."
His organization is currently marketing 34 lots for Lake Wallenpaupack in the Poconos in eastern Pennsylvania. 
"With no advertising we have 22 of those properties under contract with house-land packages running from $300,000 to $1 million," he said. Though they can bring in their own architects, buyers must commit to conform to certain aesthetic and construction standards and to use Joybeck Builders.
Like other brokers, Mr. Chant has had clients tell him they have decided to put their investments into real estate rather than into financial markets. And while they're at it, they figure they may as well reap some pleasure as well. 
"We're seeing a lot of people who got out of the stock market early and decided that investing in a piece of land on a lake, a mountain, a golf course is a better investment," he said. "I am also seeing people who didn't get out of the market. They have taken their licking and with what's left may buy their dream home. They're not necessarily liquidating their portfolios but are thinking maybe it's a good time to make an investment of some cash in a mortgage and buy a country home."
Elyse Harney agreed. "Some of our recent buys have come from the idea that money in property is safer," she said. "No matter what the stock market does, you can put your money here, touch, see and enjoy the real worth. It is not paper. It does not evaporate on a whim or a news story."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.; 
New EcoComplex Is All Kinds of Green

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS 

 BODY:
ABOUT a thousand feet from a landfill in this Burlington County hamlet is a large building that is green in more ways than one. Its color is a deep forest green but it is green in an ecological sense as well, having been built, for example, with beams that were created from recycled metal and sun panels that provide natural heating and light. 
 More important, its purpose is to serve as a research center and incubator for companies tackling environmental problems like reducing methane and carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and in that way spur economic development. 
 The New Jersey EcoComplex -- which is being dedicated tomorrow at ceremonies attended by state officials, including Acting Governor Donald DiFrancesco -- is being trumpeted by its creators as the nation's first statewide environmental research and technology development center. 
"We need to be able to provide assistance to entrepreneurs who are focusing on environmental problems," said Harry W. Janes, a biochemist with Rutgers' Cook College who serves as director. "And we believe New Jersey is sort of a microcosm of the nation in that, because of our industrial base and because of our high population density, we will see environmental challenges first."
Two companies that are experimenting with landfill gas, Acrion Technologies Inc., based in Cleveland, and Carbozyme Inc., which recently relocated from Houston, have taken up residence in the two-and- a-half-story, 32,000-square-foot facility.
A joint venture of Rutgers' New Jersey Agricultural Experiment Station, Stevens Institute of Technology and the Burlington County Board of Chosen Freeholders, the center is also developing environmental education programs including courses for children in kindergarten through eighth grade and workshops for teachers.
The center is an extension of the Agricultural Experiment Station concept, Dr. Janes said. The stations were created in the late 1800's by the federal government and based at state universities, like Rutgers, to provide research and information for small farmers.
"We need to have a clean environment but we also need industry," Dr. Janes said. 
"What we can do at the state university," he added, "is we can begin working with the state and with industry to find solutions to those problems that are providing negative impacts onto our environment. And that's kind of why we began developing the EcoComplex along the same lines as agricultural experiment stations but more towards environmental issues."
The EcoCenter cost $6 million to build, of which $5 million came from the State Higher Education Facility Trust Fund and $1 million from Burlington County.
On one side of a large atrium is a 120-seat auditorium and two adjacent 30-seat classrooms with partitions that can be removed so the rooms can become part of the auditorium. On the other side are offices, labs and other work space. The second floor on one end of the building houses the offices of the landfill, the Burlington County Resource Recovery Center. The EcoCenter is working with the Resource Recovery Center in a landfill mining project to see what material can be reprocessed.
Other projects include doing research for NASA on growing and processing food and recycling waste on long space flights, exploring how to recycle material dredged from the Delaware River, and exploring with the state Department of Environmental Protection the quality of some watersheds.
Michael Trachtenberg, chief executive of Carbozyme Inc., which is trying to reduce carbon dioxide in the atmosphere by by attaching enzymes to artificial membranes, said he knew of no other environmental research and technology development center like the EcoCenter in the country.
"And I'm aware of lots of incubators that universities have and development centers," Mr. Trachtenberg said. "I think this one is pretty unique. And the emphasis on developing green technologies is very much on the cutting edge."
One way the center is special, he said, is that it provides laboratory and development space that allows an entrepreneur to perform a large-scale demonstration of his technology.
"The ability to go from a laboratory scale into a field test unit is one of the real keys in moving technology from just a bright idea," Mr. Trachtenberg said.
Acrion, for example, has built a model of a processing unit, three stories high, in a large room at the center, to experiment with separating landfill gas into pure methane, which can be used as fuel, and pure carbon dioxide, which will be tested as a way to enhance the growth of plants in the Burlington County Research and Demonstration Greenhouse. The greenhouse, a half mile away, has been in operation five years and is part of the EcoCenter.
Lawrence A. Siwajek, senior engineer for Acrion, said the Ohio company chose to test its process at this complex in New Jersey because of the large space for scale-up demonstration, proximity to the landfill and the technical assistance available from scientists at Rutgers and Stevens. 
"It's just the right place to conduct this study," Mr. Siwajek said. "We've done research like this in the laboratory and we've operated units very similar to this, but this one can be operated with continuous landfill gas. So it's the real thing."
Dr. Janes said that once companies have gone from lab testing to commercial use -- what he calls "the valley of death" where many business fail -- they would move out of the EcoCenter.
"You get a technology to a point where if you have it working at a reputable facility," Dr. Janes said, "people are going to come in and see it and hopefully going to be more likely to invest and buy and license it."
So where others see garbage when they look at the landfill in the EcoCenter's backyard, Dr. Janes sees business opportunity combined with a chance to safeguard the environment.
"Because of the fact we're here at a landfill," he said, "we have a real-world lab to which these companies can come and experiment."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Every Vote Counts, but Not Everyone Votes

BYLINE:  By STEVEN STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
AS a student at New York Law School, Stephanie Weaver has a lot on her mind. Not Jersey City politics, though.
 Although Ms. Weaver, 24, a native of Austin, Tex., has lived in Jersey City for a year and a half, she is like many of her 9,000 or so neighbors on the waterfront in the sprawling Newport development in that she is not registered to vote here. 
 "I don't consider it my permanent address," Ms. Weaver said. 
A group of more politically minded Newport residents, calling themselves the Waterfront Association, did try to set up voter registration tables in lobbies of the development's high-rise apartment buildings last month, although the Queens-based developer of the 600-acre complex, the Lefrak Organization, would not allow it. And while a mayoral candidate in the city's May 8 election did manage to convince Lefrak to slip 3,145 voter registration forms under tenants' doors two weeks ago, only 200 were filled out and left with a concierge for delivery to the Hudson County commissioner of registration before the registration deadline of 9 p.m. on April 9.
Ms. Weaver, for example, ignored hers. A neighbor, Casper Sorensen, said he could not even remember getting one. "I probably did, but I didn't pay attention," said Mr. Sorensen, 27, a Newport resident since 1998, who, as a Danish citizen, cannot vote. "I outsource that to my wife." 
Since a $40 million federal urban development grant helped Lefrak begin developing Newport in the 1980's on a blighted stretch of Hudson River waterfront, it has been a community largely isolated physically and in civic life from the rest of Jersey City. A huge parking garage for the Newport Center mall acts as a great wall separating Newport from historic downtown neighborhoods, whose brick and brownstone townhouses look nothing like Newport's nine apartment towers and three high-rise office buildings.
The residents of Newport are also viewed by the rest of the city and at least somewhat by themselves as a politically, socially and economically disengaged group. They beat a path to the PATH in the morning, then head straight back home after work or a night out in New York. "I guess part of that is true," said Min Lu, a 20-something stock analyst for a Manhattan firm who moved to Newport a year ago from Denver. 
Like Ms. Lu, who is Chinese, and Mr. Sorensen, many of Newport's residents are not citizens, and therefore could not vote if they wanted to. Edward Cortese, a vice president of the Lefrak Organization, which also built Lefrak City in Queens and much of Battery Park City in Manhattan, said 10 percent of Newport residents moved in from other countries. An additional 80 percent moved from New York City, he said. 
Socioeconomics also separate Newport residents from other residents of the city. Rents for the newest two-bedroom apartments at Newport range from $2,450 to $3,400 a month, much higher than most of Jersey City, which, beyond its growing waterfront skyline and its gentrifying downtown neighborhoods, remains essentially a working-class town. 
Nearly 90 percent of Newport's occupants are renters, a relatively transient group that is less likely to vote, with only 445 condominiums among Newport's 3,600 apartments. While there are plenty of baby strollers around Newport, there are relatively few school-age children. So the two biggest issues in local politics -- property taxes and the quality of the schools -- are of little concern to most Newport residents. 
But they are not without their complaints: constant building is eliminating any open space; roads are constantly closed to make way for construction; heating bills are high; there are few shops outside the mall, which is several blocks from the residences. And, say members of the Waterfront Association, Newport's management and city officials have been unresponsive to residents' concerns because of their lack of clout at the ballot box. 
"Everybody's saying we don't vote," said Eleanor Capograsso, a 41-year-old Manhattan lawyer and co-founder of the association. "I finally said, enough is enough."
So last month, the association put up fliers indicating voter registration tables would be set up in the lobbies of Newport apartment buildings. But on March 11, the day before the tables were to be set up, Lefrak's management company subsidiary, Presidential Management Corporation, countered with its own fliers warning residents that no such activity was allowed. The intent, the notice said, was "to promote the safety of our residents as well as to preserve the character of our buildings."
Mr. Cortese, the Lefrak vice president, said the developer was not trying to suppress voter registration but rather to discourage strangers from making their way onto residential floors.
James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said it was unlikely a large developer would want to suppress his own tenants' voting rights, and thereby minimize the development's clout at city hall, because often a landlord's and tenants' interests overlap.
For example, eleven Newport properties have city tax abatements, which contribute a total of $13.1 million a year to city coffers, but also save the developer -- and indirectly, the supposition goes, his tenants -- millions of dollars a year compared with what would be paid under standard property tax assessments. 
But even the abatements are a source of resentment among individual commercial and residential property owners, some of whom feel they are subsidizing the abated properties. Councilman Robert Cavanaugh, the mayoral candidate who asked Lefrak to distribute the voter registration forms, said he had been angered by Lefrak's refusal to allow voter registration tables in Newport lobbies. "How can they argue that this is private property, when by virtue of the tax abatements we are a partner with them?" Mr. Cavanaugh said. "I don't care whether it's common areas or private property or whatever, it's a free speech issue."
In fact, the Waterfront Association contacted the New Jersey Tenants Organization, which supplied it case law the organization said established apartment lobbies as public space where voter registration should be allowed.
But no suit was ever filed. Instead, Newport consented to Mr. Cavanaugh's request and distributed the voter registration forms on Thursday, April 5, four days including the Passover and Easter holidays before the registration deadline for the May 8 council and mayoral election. 
Others may register by May 7 for the June 5 primary for governor, state Senate and Assembly, and county sheriff. Jersey City's mayor, Bret D. Schundler, is seeking the Republican gubernatorial nomination. 
Mr. Schundler, once a city newcomer himself, said it was understandable that the newcomers of Newport would tend not to vote. But Tom DeGise, a Jersey City native who is the city council president and a mayoral candidate, said, "I think that the Newport people do have an obligation to become part of our community and go through our institutions."
To some residents of Guttenberg, just up the river from Jersey City, aggressive participation in local politics by the relative newcomers at the Galaxy Towers condominium complex has been a source of resentment for years.
"We had to literally register voters to create the power block to overcome the town's initial inertia in giving us municipal services," said Sanford Simon, president of the Galaxy Towers Condominium Association. But, he added, "we have found that both the town and certain Galaxy residents are reaching across Boulevard East and recognizing that we live in the same town." 
Of course, as tax-paying condominium owners, Galaxy residents have a strong motivation to vote that most Newport residents lack. 
It may simply be that, when it comes to getting involved in local affairs, newcomers are darned if they do and darned if they don't. As Professor Hughes at Rutgers put it, "If residents of Newport started getting active and, say, they wanted to get involved in the school system, there might be an attitude of, 'Why don't they butt out?' "

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Happier Days Here Again For the State's Democrats

BYLINE:  By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
It looks like more good news for the Democrats. For a change.
 The latest polls show that allegations of double-dealing by the acting governor, Donald T. DiFrancesco, are starting to bite into his poll numbers and into his support among county chairmen, while Bret Schundler, the only other Republican in sight in the race for governor, is of doubtful electability, however much he mutes some of his conservative positions. 
 The Democrats, meanwhile, having won both past United States Senate races and having narrowed the Republican majorities in the State House, seem set to win the decennial struggle to draw the new state legislative districts as well. A victory there would put the Republicans' ability to hold the Assembly in serious doubt, at the least. 
This is a change from the drumbeat of bad news the Democrats have had to endure over the past decade, ever since they tried to balance the books with an actual tax increase and were cast into the darkness by the Republicans. 
The G.O.P. has had control of the State House for 10 years now, and it was not so very long ago when the deep thinkers who wrote stuff like this column were saying that the combination of general prosperity, the spread of suburban political piety, and a dutifully moderate Republican Party had given the Republicans a lock on New Jersey for the foreseeable future.
Well, the near future, at least, is a little more seeable now and it looks better for the Democrats. 
In the reapportionment debate, the Democrats managed to get through a new legislative district map that unpacks the majority black Newark districts in the current map to create a handful of part-city, part-suburban districts containing solid blocs of reliably Democratic-voting minorities.
The Republicans, expressing a tender concern for black voting rights, want to keep the old system, on the ground that it at least guaranteed a handful of minority legislators in Trenton. That the old system made it easier for Republicans to be elected from Newark's suburbs is not stressed, but with a federal court hearing set for tomorrow, the Democrats appear to have the upper hand.
If the map goes the Democrats' way, it could cost the Republicans three or four seats, representing a big chunk of the G.O.P.'s 45-35 plurality in the Assembly. The Republicans maintain that unless a district is overwhelmingly black, an African-American candidate has no chance of being elected. They cite the case of Cardell Cooper, a black Democrat who ran and lost for Essex County executive in 1994. The Republicans' analysis shows that Democratic voters worked their way around Mr. Cooper on the ballot, favoring fellow-Democrats in other offices but jumping to the Republican side against Mr. Cooper for executive. 
The Democrats seem on the surface to have the better of the argument when they point to senators like Wayne Bryant of Camden County and Shirley Turner of Mercer, both blacks who won in white majority districts. But a closer look at the returns shows that both of them ran behind other white candidates in the districts, a fact that the Republicans are certain to point out to the three-judge federal panel in tomorrow's arguments.
Meanwhile, Mr. DiFrancesco, the acting governor, is hardly turning out to be the dream date many Republicans had expected to waltz them back into the governorship and control of the Legislature. As a 21-year veteran of the statehouse, a moderate and considerate politician, Mr. DiFrancesco had seemed to be the polished and professional insider they needed to win. But now it seems that Mr. DiFrancesco has been a little too much of an insider, as he finds himself fending off disclosures last week that, in addition to taking $225,000 from a developer, he violated ethics law by favoring his family's real estate interests over those of Scotch Plains, when he was the town attorney, in 1998.
A Star-Ledger/Eagleton poll released Thursday found that not many New Jerseyans had heard about the brewing scandal, but that those who had thought less of him for it.
Mr. Schundler, the mayor of Jersey City and a defender of free-market economies and the freedom to own guns, but not the freedom to have abortions, is still a long shot, despite Mr. DiFrancesco's efforts to paint him as presiding over a dangerous and corrupt city. But as Mr. Schundler found out in his race for the United States Senate last year, he is too conservative for New Jersey, and so he is far from the favorite of the party leaders.
The Republicans cannot even take heart from the evident availability of Bob Franks, the former United States Representative who ran such a strong and brave race against Senator John Corzine last year: even though he was in all the papers and all over television not seven months ago, the latest Eagleton poll shows that few voters even remember him.
The Democrats will eventually have to deal with the problems their champion, Senator Robert Torricelli, has become enmeshed in, but not until next year. In the meantime, the Democrats are all smiles and confidence.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 23, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The "On Politics" column in the New Jersey section yesterday, about the outlook for the state's Democratic politicians, misstated the role of Jersey City's mayor, Bret D. Schundler, in last year's Republican contest for United States Senate. Mr. Schundler did not run; he supported James W. Treffinger, the Essex County executive.

HEADLINE: Bon Appetit!, Jersey-Style; 
A Bounty of Choices And Connections Too

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
CREAM cheese or creme brulee, it doesn't much matter. When New Jersey's power brokers break bread, the real hunger is for a prime slice of the Boardwalk, a better legislative committee assignment or an inside track on a land deal. Sometimes, money has even been known to change hands -- above the table or underneath (this is New Jersey, after all). The food happens to be on the table.
 The deal-making usually begins not long after sunrise, almost certainly over coffee and perhaps a sunny-side-up egg winking up at the mayor in a local diner. 
 When it comes to lunch or dinner, chances are the menu will have an Italian flavor: at Solari's in Hackensack or Pronto Cena in Jersey City.
That is also true in Atlantic City, which has seen its centers of power dining change with the skyline. Old-timers remember the Stanley for lunch and Orsatti's for dinner on Friday night, where kissing the ring of Senator Frank (Hap) Farley was much more important than the catch of the day. Today, the G & S Italian Supermarket at lunch is the place to see and be seen.
But some things never change. As long as there is power -- to be flexed, to be savored or both -- there will be power dining. Here's a look at some of the places where it takes place in New Jersey.

NEWARK
BEHIND the plate-glass windows of the Commerce Food Court, ringed as it is in frequently fogged blue neon, the diversity of the customers is matched only by that of the 72-item menu that runs well past soup to nuts to sushi, brioche and collard greens.
On any given day you stand a good chance of running into a former mayor (Kenneth Gibson) or a former senator (Frank R. Lautenberg) or a current state senator (Ronald Rice) as well as the people who run the Newark Performing Arts Center and the city's well-known jazz radio station, WBGO-FM. They are seated amid New Jersey Transit workers from the agency's headquarters three blocks away, Drug Enforcement Agency employees from across the street and workers from the nearby Newark Board of Education or Housing Authority.
Feldman Middleton, an owner of the restaurant, likes to say it is a democratic place "with both a capital 'D' and a small 'd'." Mr. Middleton and his partner, Lee Hew, decided in 1997 to take a chance on stirrings of revitalization in the city's downtown and opened the buffet-style restaurant in what was formerly a beauty college.
Larry Goldman, president of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which is two blocks away, said that while he is a sucker for the Commerce Food Court's spare ribs, that's not the No. 1 reason n he goes there frequently.
"It's like getting lost in the crowd and a crowd where everyone is concentrating on their lunch," he said. "I don't experience a half a dozen interruptions from someone saying they enjoyed a performance at the center or are having trouble getting tickets. Of course I usually like that sort of thing, but sometimes I go there with someone so we can just talk without interruptions."
For others such as Christian Benedetto, a partner in and director of real estate services for the local realty firm National Redevelopment, it is the crowds and traffic that are the lure. He said that on some days when he is having trouble connecting with someone by telephone, he can end the phone tag by dropping into the food court for 10 minutes or so around lunchtime.
Cephas Bowles, the general manager of WBGO-FM, has also found himself doing business at the food court, but that's not its main attraction for him.
"It's a homey place where you can unwind from the stress of the morning," he said. "It's clean with homecooked meals and you can let your hair down a bit."
 RONALD SMOTHERS
Commerce Food Court, 1136 Raymond Boulevard, Newark (973) 242-1778.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ENVIRONMENT; 
LAND SAVED IN MONMOUTH

BYLINE:  By Kirsty Sucato 

 BODY:
One of the largest remaining undeveloped properties in Monmouth County will be preserved as open space under a $19 million deal announced last week.
 The 416-acre tract off Holmdel Road in Holmdel includes two working farms and a historic farmhouse. 
The owner, Chase Manhattan Bank, had agreed to sell the land to a developer, Howard Shoor, who sought permission to build a 475-home retirement community. But after opposition from residents, the bank agreed to sell the land to conservationists. 
 Under the deal, the state Agriculture Development Committee will spend $8.7 million; the state Green Acres program, $4.3 million; Holmdel, $3.5 million; Monmouth County, $2 million; and local conservation groups, $500,000. About 226 acres will be used as a park. An additional 190 acres will be sold as farmland, officials said. Kirsty Sucato

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
MetLife Is Offered Incentives To Add Workers in County

BYLINE:  By Robert Worth 

 BODY:
Westchester County has offered $307,000 in sales tax abatements to MetLife, the nation's largest life insurer, in an effort to persuade the company to move more than 100 of its employees to White Plains. 
 MetLife has expressed interest in moving into several floors at 445 Hamilton Avenue, a vacant building the company already owns. 
 In addition to the tax abatements, the county could offer MetLife reduced rates for parking and electricity, said Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of economic development. 
MetLife, which already has about 100 people in an office on North Broadway, is moving as many as 1,700 employees out of its headquarters in New York City and is considering other locations in the metropolitan area.
If the company does move a group to White Plains, it will invest $6 million in renovations and new equipment over the next two years, said John Calagna, a spokesman for MetLife.
But Mr. Calagna said such a move would not be a precursor to moving a significant number of additional employees from Manhattan to the county.
 Robert Worth

HEADLINE: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; 
Out of the Office, Looking In

BYLINE:  By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
 ISAK DINESEN had a farm in Africa. I had a desk in the meat-packing district. It was a July to December 2000 office romance -- the first office job I'd had in 10 years, and the perfect moment for it, because offices were the new hotel lobbies way back then. Even now, they promote the lost optimism of the days when new economy companies seduced employees with on-site basketball courts, Ping-Pong tables and massages. 
 In the view of "Workspheres," which closes today at the Museum of Modern Art, the new office promotes individuality and creativity. Indeed, what could have been more creative than my gig assigning fun articles for a magazine called Fuse? 
In a big white studio, phones rang and messengers darted: intrigue, thin people with good hair, collaboration and the urgency of a war room and a sandbox. It was the perfect cure for my office envy.
What is office envy? It's not just coveting offices cooler than your own -- that's old school. These days, it's the envy of having any office at all. "Up until now, I never had to wait on a line at a post office in New York," said Charla Krupp, who left Glamour for Eve.com, which imploded, leaving her to freelance from her apartment. "I mean, do you know how disgusting that is?"
For those who have always worked at home, it isn't convenience we envy as much as the vibe. Rodney Rothman even wrote a fictionalized nonfiction New Yorker piece last winter about moving into a dot-com office without a job. Tom Beller, another writer, finds himself lingering when visiting friends at work. "My own schedule with its freedom and vagueness is without boundaries," he said. "And boundaries are things against which you can define yourself." 
At Fuse, I defined myself as an editor at large. Oh, the chic of that title on our chic business cards! And oh, my desk -- expensive, minimal, with steel legs and laminated top a minty Prada green. We sat in rows, as if in a classroom where you didn't have to raise your hand before interrupting.
We yelled. We threw cookies and ideas around. It was seductive, like childhood, a polymorphously playful time. And now it's gone, after a single issue. 
Last Monday, when those who still have offices to go to were in them, syngergizing, my envy became overwhelming. So I got on my bike and visited Oxygen Media in the Chelsea Market Building, with its "Star Wars" elevator, "convergence lab" for new technology and flexible space, which its architects say, promotes "controlled accidents" among the staff. Then I hit 435 Hudson Street in Greenwich Village, where Radical Media's airy offices, designed by the fun-loving architect David Rockwell, sent me into an apoplexy of desire. "It's a socialized space for the cross-pollenization of talent," Jon Kamen, a founder, explained. Hey, I can cross-pollenize, I wanted to say. I didn't get a space out of it. But I got a delicious lunch in the dining area, catered by a full-time food manager on the staff.
"I keep wondering when they'll give us an omelet station," another manager said.
Later, in the uber-groovy Starrett Lehigh Building on West 26th Street, I toured the gorgeous white offices of a new arts management company, Mixed Greens. The view is far too commanding for the Gen Y-sters on the staff if you ask me. I got a tour from someone on the "art team," who offered me chocolates and Scotch. She invited me to take off my shoes and climb onto a "personal perch" for perspective, too.
"There's a real commitment to personal fulfillment here," she told me. O.K., we all know how casual companies have become, inspired more by tribal villages than by flow charts. But was this a business or a kindergarten? Never mind that its very existence seemed out of step with this morning-after moment. What I wanted to know was, how could I get in on it without actually working there? Could I be an installation?
Back home, feeling cheated and alone, I sat at my desk opening mail. A summons to jury duty. Hmmm. It'll do, I guess.
