HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Hyundai XG300 and Kia Optima; 
Out of the Cheap Seats, Into the Luxury Box

BYLINE:  By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
HEY, honey, I didn't know they were loaning you a Jaguar!" my wife exclaimed as I pulled in the driveway. Actually, I thought the Hyundai XG300, its generic "near luxury" aura only slightly marred by excessive chrome, looked more like a Lincoln LS. And if Infiniti pressed charges over the theft of its grille, what jury wouldn't convict?
 Any of these comparisons, though, should delight Hyundai's marketers. After a decade spent trying to erase the image of their products as Korea's answer to the Yugo, they finally have a car capable of grabbing a chunk of the upscale American market. 
 Hyundai, you may recall, hit the beaches of California in 1986 with its Excel subcompact. Americans were initially inclined to assume that South Korean automobiles would share the design and workmanship of cars from Japan. The Excel sold well initially -- the 186,000 vehicles it delivered in one year was an American record for a new car company -- and was followed by other models with irresistible sticker prices. 
But Hyundai's growing pains were, well, painful. Its cars, never much to look at, were dogged with quality and reliability problems, and the company lost whatever good will it had inadvertently gained from misplaced association with the Japanese.
Kia's origins as a bicycle maker in the late 1940's were humbler than Hyundai's. And it remained dependent on foreign technology longer, assembling cars for Peugeot, Fiat and Ford. But Korea's mania for global growth, fueled by a banking system eager to provide capital to any well-connected company with export plans, enveloped Kia, too.
But by the time Kia products arrived in the mid-1990's, Americans were less ready, to say the least, to embrace Korean cars. The small Sephia sedan and the Sportage mini-sport utility made their debuts to cool, even hostile, reviews that took note of their shabby materials, primitive drivetrains, third-world workmanship and even the acrid odor of their plastics.
Kia Motors was effectively forced to establish a beachhead by pricing low and selling to people with bad credit, plus 20-somethings on shoestring budgets. The Kia Rio sedan pushes this marketing approach to the limit: a stripped version, with a surprisingly peppy 96-horsepower engine, can be had for about $9,000.
The Asian financial crisis, on top of the global auto industry's hugely excessive production capacity, doomed Korean conglomerates' plans to expand on the basis of volume, rather than profits. In late 1998, Hyundai absorbed the bankrupt Kia and set about reorganizing the combined businesses.
Hyundai is keeping Kia separate for marketing purposes, at least for now, but the merged company is committed to reducing costs by cutting its vehicle platforms to just 8 by 2005, from 23 now. This means that Hyundai and Kia will be sharing underbodies and drivetrains, just as American and Japanese carmakers often do, to spread development costs over more products.
And management seems to have concluded that Hyundai's long-term success depends on going upscale, holding customers in rapidly developing economies while hitting the sweet, high-margin spot with affluent Americans and Europeans.
The first step, of course, was to transform the made-in-Korea label from a liability into something approaching an asset. Hyundai (followed by Kia) took a big step by offering the best warranty in the industry: bumper-to-bumper coverage of 5 years or 60,000 miles, and 10 years or 100,000 miles on the drivetrain, plus 5 years of roadside assistance. Judging by the figures, this confidence-building warranty is working: Hyundai sales, a wretched 90,000 in 1998, jumped nearly 50 percent last year, to 244,000. They have risen 26 percent so far in 2001.
It may be an even greater challenge to move Hyundai up to the middle of the rich American market, which brings us back to the XG300. Study this car, and you know Hyundai is aiming high. The exterior looks substantial and quietly handsome; the interior is exceptionally well finished with expensive-looking materials -- more Infiniti I30 or Acura TL than Toyota Camry or Honda Accord.
The XG300 comes in two finishes, basic and L. They share a 3-liter V-6, a five-speed automatic transmission with a Tiptronic-like manual override, electronic traction control, four-wheel antilock disc brakes, front and side air bags, leather seats, heated mirrors, automatic climate control, six-speaker sound system and keyless entry. Indeed, the only additions of consequence on the L model are a power sunroof and an auto-dimming rear-view mirror.
The XG300's leather front seats are as comfortable as most in the near-luxury crowd, though a lack of headroom makes it impractical to raise the driver's seat as high as I would like. The rear fits three adequately, with enough legroom and almost enough shoulder room for a daylong outing. And the sense of luxury increases when the car is in motion: noise levels -- from wind, tires and engine -- are very low, if not quite Lexus-silent. Rough-road vibration is nicely dampened without the riding-on-a-down-cushion feel of, say, the Toyota Avalon.
The XG300 is not for driving enthusiasts. Acceleration from the 192-horse engine is more than adequate -- a more powerful 3.5-liter V-6 is said to be on the way -- but the front-drive sedan protests mildly in hard turns. Bigger wheels with low-profile tires might help -- 15-inch alloy wheels are standard -- but at some sacrifice in ride. In any event, the handling complaints probably won't mean much to buyers, who are likely to be more concerned with comfort and safety than with agile road manners.
Did I mention value? The base-model XG300, which is a lot more than basic, lists for $23,994. Edmunds.com, which provides buying information online, estimates that you can get one for about $22,700. That's $3,700 less than a comparably equipped V-6 Camry and $2,500 less than the Nissan Maxima GLE. The XG300 L is selling for $23,900, Edmunds says, which is $3,500 less than a loaded Diamante from Mitsubishi, another brand that needs to build some good will.
Hyundai may have something even bigger up its sleeves. At the New York auto show, it is displaying the LZ450, a Korean-market luxury sedan that appears to be aimed at the largest Lexus. While the company says it currently has no plans to import that car, it is sending a clear message that it can't be taken lightly any longer.
The other new Korean car on the block, the Kia Optima, also displays its virtues with diffidence. The vaguely Japanese styling looks a bit like a Mitsubishi Galant's. It seats four (but not five) nicely, like the Hyundai Sonata. That is no coincidence, since the Optima and Sonata share their architecture and mechanical parts, though Kia assembles the Optima in its own plant.
Those who associate Kia with bare-bones Sephias or Rios are in for a surprise. This is nobody's idea of lowest-common-denominator transportation. A medium-plain LX is available, with a 149-horsepower four-cylinder engine and five-speed manual, but I drove the fancier SE with a 170-horsepower V-6. This engine was more than adequate for freeway ramps and such. And while the smooth four-speed automatic was occasionally pokey in downshifting, one can compensate by using the Sportmatic manual override, also standard with the V-6.
The car's finish was surprisingly good, and the power-adjustable driver's seat, borrowed from the XG300, was a pleasure. The Optima isn't nearly as quiet as the XG300, but with less weight, a stiffer suspension and a shorter wheelbase, it handles better.
The Optima is no sports car, of course. Nor is it the equal of a Volkswagen Passat in the handling department. But its tight, predictable steering and lack of body roll on curves make it a lot less boring to drive on a twisty road than, say, a Camry.
Once you get over the surprise that this lithe, civilized midsize car is a Kia, you're in for another: the price. Optimas start at $15,794, and the sticker of an SE with standard air-conditioning, six-speaker stereo, cruise control, remote locking, front and side air bags and power sunroof, along with optional leather seats and antilock brakes, is $22,300. Edmunds estimates the actual price at $20,600 -- about $2,600 less than a comparably equipped Saturn L300.
At a minimum, the Hyundai XG300 and Kia Optima SE prove that Korea can build competitive mid-market cars and sell them at supercompetitive prices. One has to wonder, though, whether they can make money doing it -- especially when the cost of the warranties is factored in. But that's Hyundai Motor's problem, not yours.
From the consumer's perspective, the risks of buying one of these new Korean models are threefold.
First, Kia and Hyundai have yet to prove that their cars are as reliable and durable as the ones rolling off the assembly lines of Detroit's Big Three, let alone those of Honda, Nissan and Toyota. It is great to be protected by a long warranty, but nobody wins when you have to invoke it.
Second, in light of the general skepticism about Korean cars, there is every reason to believe that the Optima and XG300 will depreciate faster than their gold-standard counterparts from Japan. So the real cost of a lease or a short trade-in cycle may be greater than the sticker price suggests.
The third risk is that your in-laws will think you cannot afford something classy from Japan or Germany. But that may be an opportunity; after all, otherwise sensible people once stuck up their noses at cars with funny names like Honda and Toyota.
INSIDE TRACK: "Classy Korean car" is no longer an oxymoron.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Persuading Consumers The Economy Is Still 'New'

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
THE "new economy" seems to have lasted for three years. From about 1997 until late 2000, economic pundits proclaimed that a new era had begun. Technology, they said, was making America's companies more productive, allowing the country to grow quickly without causing inflation.
 But when a slowdown occurred with almost no warning, and goods piled up in warehouses and stores, businesses cut spending and laid off workers. None of it seemed very new anymore. 
 During the last month, "new economy" has appeared in a sample of 10 large newspapers 27 percent less often than it did six months ago, a database search showed. That is true even though those same newspapers are publishing much more economic news today than they were last autumn. 
It would be a mistake, however, to consign "new economy" to lexicographical history. Last week brought clear evidence that the concept of a changed economy still had true believers: Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve, who lowered interest rates on Wednesday for the fourth time in about 100 days. 
In their announcement, the Fed's policy makers said the "impressive" productivity gains of recent years remained "largely intact" despite the slowdown. But businesses are now investing less in new equipment. Consumer spending, after holding up fairly well in January and February, has weakened, threatening to remove the final barrier to recession.
With its move, the Fed hoped to persuade people to be a little looser with their money. A few million beach vacations here and a few thousand new manufacturing plants there, and suddenly the economy would be growing at a healthy pace again.
The size of the task, however, should not be underestimated. The Fed is trying to effect a shift in attitude that has not been accomplished in the last 30 years. 
Go back to last summer, when Americans' optimism about the economy came close to a 50-year high, according to the University of Michigan. In the nine months since, Michigan's index of consumer confidence has fallen from 108.3 to 87.8, the lowest since 1993. 
Even as the good feelings have waned, consumers have been willing to spend at a fairly brisk pace, and analysts have said that the contrast cannot last long. "It is a remarkable gap," said Neal M. Soss, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
But the only way for its outcome to be remarkable would be for the economy to avoid a recession. Since 1969, the index has dropped by at least one-sixth on seven other occasions. A recession followed, or was under way, every time. 
In each case, the pattern was similar, said Richard T. Curtin, Michigan's director of consumer surveys. As the media talked of economic weakness, people looked for evidence. They followed the news and talked to friends. But if they were shopping for a new car or house, they continued as if nothing had changed. "At the first whiff the economy may be weaker, people are not going to reverse all of their plans," Mr. Curtin said. 
INSTEAD, he said, people cut some marginal spending, say, for restaurant meals. If they hear about layoffs among their friends or cannot work as much overtime as they once did, they become more conservative. Those who have debt begin paying it off.
This is the chain of events that occurred in each of the past recessions. In the third quarter of 1979, for example, consumer spending rose 3.8 percent, even though the confidence index had dropped 25 percent below its late-1978 level. By 1980, spending was falling, and the downturn was under way.
Mr. Curtin says the current gap has received an unusual amount of attention because information circulates more widely now. When Michigan's index began to drop sharply late last year, television and newspapers paid far more attention than they had to previous declines. "It raised the expectations for an immediate drop in spending, and that didn't happen," he said.
Fed officials also say that information flow is different now and that the outcome will be, too. Mr. Greenspan has said that companies today can react to changes in business conditions faster than their predecessors did. As the economy slowed last year, they cut production sharply. Those reductions played a crucial role in consumers' new pessimism. 
This time, however, the cuts will not last for months. Corporate America took its medicine and, with lower interest rates encouraging spending, the economy can return to growth in the second half of 2001. If the plan works, the Fed will have defied recent history. In that case, one might even say there is a new economy.

HEADLINE: MIRROR, MIRROR; 
Rhode Island Noir: A State's Dark, Gothic Heart

BYLINE:  By Penelope Green 

 BODY:
I SPENT the week before last in Rhode Island. For most of it, the sun shone, the birds sang, and the airwaves were full of Buddy. Cianci, that is -- the charismatic, criminally convicted, six-term mayor of Providence, who had been freshly hit with a 97-page federal indictment charging bribery and racketeering.
 Fragments of his appearance Tuesday on his pal Don Imus's radio show were replayed all week on the radio and on MSNBC, along with his public avowal of innocence: "Ninety-seven times zero is zero!" You could see photographs of Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., self-proclaimed architect of his city's renaissance -- Money magazine named Providence the best place to live in the Northeast last year -- being arraigned without his famous toupee. 
 The indictment, the final act in the federal Operation Plunder Dome, took aim at characters with nicknames like Buckles and Cha Cha. In a prime example of Rhode Island weirdness, an assistant United States attorney admitted he had shown surveillance tapes taken by the F.B.I. to friends and family last summer. 
The hubbub drove home to me that Rhode Island's biggest tourist attraction is not so much its glittering coastline, but its seedy, gothic heart -- an element less accurately portrayed in Edith Wharton's high-brow novels than by the Farrelly brothers ("Dumb and Dumber") and Barbet Schroeder ("Reversal of Fortune").
"What's intriguing about Rhode Island is this undercurrent of petty crime, and what makes it delicious is that it's set against this incredible beauty," said Maria Flook, whose darkly comic novel "Open Water" (Pantheon, 1994) was a Rhode Island postcard, an opera of small cons and dashed hopes. The book was set in Newport, with its historic houses, "a polish or a bright corrosion on the famous coastline." 
What makes that corrosion glare so is Rhode Island's loveliness and very real tradition of thoughtful, enlightened leadership, as embodied in the Senate careers of Claiborne Pell and the late John Chafee. But the state's noirish side always manages to intrude.
M. Charles Bakst, who has covered Rhode Island politics for The Providence Journal since 1972, ticked off a few civic low points, the currants in his cake. "When I think back over the years, there are these landmarks in corruption," he said drily. "You had two Supreme Court justices forced to resign; you had Ed DiPrete, the former governor, who went to jail; and Brian Sarault, the mayor of Pawtucket, who also went to jail. Mayor Cianci's first regime, in the early 80's, was of course marred by corruption and fiscal chaos. I must say I've never lacked for copy."
A few years ago, Mr. Bakst led a "rogues' tour" of the state, as a prize in a charity benefit. "Let's see," he remembered, "we started at a Dumpster outside Walt's Roast Beef, where the former governor had tossed his sandwich wrapper, and a $10,000 bribe. Then, we went to Mercy Stadium, in Pawtucket, which was associated with a lot of corruption, and of course City Hall and the mayor's office there. We went to the state house, to the Bevilacqua hearing -- he was one of the two Supreme Court justices to bring shame on his office -- and so on. It was a lot of fun."
Wait, there's more. The stories about public fiascos unfold like the gross-out scenes in a Farrelly brothers movie -- the stuck zipper, the fish hook, the hair-gel-that-isn't -- each more repulsive than the last. As Chip Young, a satirist for The Providence Phoenix, a local alternative weekly, put it: "We have a wonderful visual history. Once again, The Providence Journal did everybody the service of publishing a photograph of Joseph Bevilacqua coming out of a motel zipping up his fly." Mr. Young -- half of the duo that produces "Phillipe and Jorge's Cool Cool World" -- added: "The political side here has more fodder than the Ponderosa. Every year, we thank the gods for Buddy because we're set for another year."
On a wind-blown, rainy Thursday, I drove up to Providence from my house in Newport. I had seen Mr. Cianci's beloved downtown in more flattering lights: the fruits of its $740 million facelift of recent years backlighted by the setting sun on a hot summer night; its artists' housing in the beautiful turn-of-the-century factory buildings; the landscaping on the banks of the Providence River, which separates the downtown from College Hill, home of Brown University and the Rhode Island School of Design.
I had also seen the bulbous faces of some of the 45 Mr. Potato Head sculptures that had sprouted around Rhode Island in the last year -- very Farrelly brothers, though actually germinated by the State Economic Development Council in homage to Hasbro, the toy's maker and the state's largest employer. You can buy the sculptures now on eBay: "Eric the Head! Six Feet Tall, One of a Kind Statue!" Their time on display was up last week. "Later, Taters," The Providence Journal mourned.
"One of the things about Rhode Island is, there isn't one single defining characteristic," said Mark Van Noppen, an owner of the Armory Revival Company, one of a growing number of developers active in revitalizing Providence's neighborhoods. Trained at Brown as an anthropologist, Mr. Van Noppen has lived in Providence since 1977.
"It's this wonderful mix of that dark core and this really enlightened vision for the world," he said, adding: "Buddy embodies these two elements. His style is gangsterish, humorous, personal. He makes no bones about strong-arming people. Yet, his vision for the city has been inspired, high-flown. That's a kind of greatness."
In a state 48 miles long from north to south and 37 miles wide from east to west, "you can be in Newport and throw a rock and hit someone's cousin in Providence," said Jim Gillis, a columnist at The Newport Daily News since 1986. "Are we any worse than other states? I wonder. We think we have the market on corruption and general mayhem, but I think it's our size that makes things seem more distinct."
I think he's right. You distill something down to its essence and things grow sharper, more piquant. You see the extremes, the yin and the yang: Lincoln Chafee, who was elected to his father's Senate seat last year, at one end; Buddy Cianci at the other.
Darrell West, a political science professor at Brown, who has been conducting opinion polls in Providence for 17 years, said the mayor's job approval rating was 61 percent last month. "That's a number most politicians would kill for, and it comes two years into an investigation of his administration," Mr. West said. "There's no question that Buddy has created a cult of personality surrounding himself. He is the city, the city is him. That's a rationale last used by Louis XIV."
Yet, a high job approval rating doesn't always mean personal popularity. One night last week, at the East Side Market back in Newport, I searched in vain for the Mayor's Own Marinara Sauce, "benefiting Providence schoolchildren," according to the label. I finally flagged down a manager, who went away and came back with two jars, their labels enlivened by a photograph of the mayor's smiling face squinting into the sun, or a too-bright flash. "We took the sauce off the shelves a few weeks ago," the manager told me. "It wasn't selling so well." 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 29, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Mirror, Mirror column last Sunday, contrasting Rhode Island's scenic beauty with its sometimes colorful corruption scandals, referred incorrectly to an investigation in Providence in which characters nicknamed Buckles and Cha Cha figured. They were targets of an investigation in the 1980's, not in Operation Plunder Dome, the federal investigation that led on April 2 to the indictment of Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. on racketeering charges.
The article also misidentified a stadium in Pawtucket that was a stop on a "rogue's tour" of corruption sites led by a reporter for The Providence Journal as a prize in a charity benefit. It was McCoy Stadium, not Mercy Stadium. In addition, the article referred incorrectly to a second tour stop at the Providence state house, site of hearings into misdeeds by Joseph Bevilacqua, a Supreme Court justice. The tour visited the room where the hearings had been held years earlier, not the hearings themselves.

HEADLINE: BENDING ELBOW; 
An Undergraduate Den of Karaoke, Not Kerouac

BYLINE:  DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
Diana Trilling called the West End bar, on Broadway opposite Columbia University, a "dim waystation of undergraduate debauchery." 
 There's not much debauchery tonight. Several B-school grandees, snaggles of undergrads and a few locals people the large U-shaped bar. 
 A gong hangs over the bottles in the middle of the bar. Imax, the night bartender, says it sounds to commemorate lousy karaoke acts, big tips, moments of maximum hilarity.
This is definitely a college bar, where Gown slides by Town, the two rarely colliding. But it is a college bar with history. Jack Kerouac wrote novels here, Allen Ginsberg read poetry here. It once was a major uptown jazz outpost.
Potential debauchery enters in the form of three women in black leather, one in a front-laced leather corset. "God bless you, sweetie," Anthony, a local, tells Ms. Corset.
Ms. Corset is Courtney. Her friends are Colleen and Cresta. They are Columbia students, members of Alpha Delta Phi fraternity/sorority, and they are celebrating victory in a Greek Week lip-synch contest. They performed Madonna's "Human Nature," hence the outfits. They say there really isn't much interaction with the locals for "socio-economic" reasons. 
Anthony (Johnny rocks) and Juan (rum and coke) are regulars too, but they grew up around here. "I used to come when they had the comedies," says Juan, referring to the 80's, when the West End featured stand-up. "I used to ride my bike through Columbia, go to toga parties." Ever think of attending? "No. After high school -- that's all."
The West End dispenses its own wisdom. Jay, the day bartender, has put this thought on a chalkboard: "Age is in the mind. Unfortunately, it creeps down into the rest of the body."
Does Imax have any pithy thoughts?
"The key to success is sincerity," he shoots back. "Once you learn to fake that, you're good to go." It is sound barkeep wisdom. 
He talks about his eight years of serving students from a population 75 percent below the drinking age. "I'm a father figure for them," says Imax, who looks a little young for that. "They asked me to sign their yearbook last year. I almost cried."
The West End is mostly the same crossroads as always. But one glory is gone: the regular jazz evenings, featuring old-time greats in the 1970's and 80's like Earl Warren (alto man, not the justice), Eddie Durham, Jimmy Butts (The Face on the Bass), Jo Jones. Buck Clayton, Roy Eldridge and Max Roach could be found in the audience.
Jeff, a junior majoring in political science, knows nothing of this. "I love jazz," he said. "But I don't know stuff from the 70's." DANIEL J. WAKIN

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Joel C. Tillinghast; 
Fidelity Low-Priced Stock Fund

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

 BODY:
SELLING zucchini door to door is not a common path to Wall Street wizardry, but it worked for Joel C. Tillinghast. 
 At the age of 9, Mr. Tillinghast, now manager of the Fidelity Low-Priced Stock fund, was an unusual child. Some boys like G.I. Joes; some like firetrucks. But he liked numerically dense investment tomes. "I really like numbers and statistics," he said. "My parents had a copy of the Value Line Investment Survey that they kept and I just loved it." 
 The young Joel, thus empowered, felt a need to get in the game. To raise cash, he helped harvest zucchini in the family garden in Durham, N.H., and peddled it in the neighborhood.
With the proceeds, he bought two stocks in a custodial account set up by his parents: Central Maine Power, a utility, and Beckman Instruments, which made scientific instruments used by Mr. Tillinghast's father, a biology professor. Mr. Tillinghast never sold either stock.
He chalks up Central Maine Power as a disappointment: "I made no money over 31 years, except for the dividends," he said. But Beckman turned into a lucrative takeover play, acquired by SmithKline Beecham, which itself merged with Glaxo Wellcome, forming Glaxo-SmithKline. 
The lesson, he said, is to be a value manager who seeks companies that are not just cheap, but also have potential for growth. 
Mr. Tillinghast, now 42, designed the Low-Priced Stock fund, which is highly unusual in the investment industry. The fund, up 26.8 percent over the last year through Thursday, began in 1989 by investing in stocks priced at $15 or less, but it has since raised that ceiling to $35. Why such a seemingly arbitrary figure, given that a $70 stock one day can split two for one and be $35 the next? Wouldn't a fixed valuation measure, say a P/E ratio, be a better guide?
"Any fixed valuation is arbitrary," responded Mr. Tillinghast, adding that a price-to-earnings criterion would be "just a proxy for neglect." Using P/E ratios, he added, means forgoing companies that might be only temporarily unprofitable.
"Stocks like Cisco, Lucent and Motorola are down sharply," he said. "Some of them, especially after you write off $2.5 billion, don't have earnings," he added, referring to the grim announcement by Cisco Systems last week. 
The Low-Priced fund is categorized as a small-company value fund, which traditionally means that it sticks to stocks with market capitalizations of less than $2 billion and uses a bargain-hunting style. But Mr. Tillinghast's style is a challenge to categorize. He buys mostly small-cap stocks but also those of any size, if their prices are no more than $35 a share. The $7.8 billion fund now holds 727 stocks, a number made possible, he said, by the support of Fidelity's five analysts who concentrate on small-cap stocks and 200 analysts of specific industries.
Mr. Tillinghast considers Peter Lynch, former manager of Fidelity Magellan, as his chief influence. "It's a growth-at-a-reasonable-price approach," he said of the style that Mr. Lynch made famous. "I look for companies that are leaders in a niche. They stick to their niche instead of deciding that, say, apparel shops are boring and buying a savings and loan in Hawaii. Di-worse-ification, as Peter Lynch called it."
AFTER graduating in 1980 from Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., Mr. Tillinghast worked briefly for the company responsible for his favorite childhood reading, Value Line. In 1986, he went to Fidelity, where he is known for his cerebral personality in a profession more characterized by alpha males. 
Recently, he has been moving counter to the current Magellan manager, Robert Stansky. Magellan's weighting in technology stocks was slashed in the first quarter, as were the weightings of many big growth funds that rode technology stocks in the bull market. But Mr. Tillinghast and other value fund managers who looked tame in 1999 are now buying battered technology issues, though not dot-coms.
"I keep looking to tech stocks that are either producing growing earnings, or ones that are stupid cheap," he said. "It's still hard to find lots of either, but I'm still finding more in both categories." 
Two stocks he has bought in the last six months are CDW Computer Centers and Insight Enterprises, both of which sell computers to small businesses and home-office users, a market that appeals to him. 
"Bigger businesses expect much skinnier markups," he said. CDW has gained 53.3 percent this year, while Insight is up 25.7 percent.
A recent favorite group is restaurants. He added Applebee's International and Outback Steakhouse to his top 10 holdings in the first quarter.
Of late, he has been on a hot streak in a chilly market, something he has done before. "Climbing out of the '90 recession, he was tremendous," said James Lowell, editor of Fidelity Investor, an independent newsletter that tracks Fidelity funds. "This is a perfectly pitched fund for this time."
Indeed, Low-Priced Stock performed well in the early 90's, but lagged far behind big growth funds in the latter part of the decade. Growth-enamored investors withdrew billions of dollars, as they did from other value portfolios, prompting the fund, which had closed to new investors several times during the decade, to again re-open its doors. Now, the tide has turned toward value again. 
"The fund has gotten inflows, which is a change from a year ago, when the fund lost half of its assets to redemptions," said Mr. Tillinghast, calling it "extremely frustrating" to operate under such pressure.
Now that money is coming back in, will Fidelity decide to close the fund again for lack of attractive investment outlets? "We don't have any plans to do it now," he said.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Why the World Is Better For Jesse Helms

BYLINE:  By WALTER RUSSELL MEAD; Walter Russell Mead, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, is the author of "Mortal Splendor: The American Empire in Transition."

 BODY:
LAST week's joint meeting of the foreign policy committees of the American and Mexican senates served as a reminder of the unique position that Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, holds in American foreign policy today. Cranky, unilateralist, unwilling to yield American sovereignty for the sake of international cooperation, quick to impose economic sanctions, a defender of traditional Southern values, pro-gun, pro-death penalty and anti-abortion, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman is the man American internationalists love to hate.
 Presidents and secretaries of state court the powerful Senator Helms the way Harry S. Truman and Dean Acheson courted Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg in the 1940's -- or curse his name the way Lyndon B. Johnson and his secretary of state, Dean Rusk, cursed Senator J. William Fulbright during the Vietnam War. Liberal internationalists hate Senator Helms for his resourceful opposition to the Kyoto Protocol, the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, the international criminal court and the international land mine treaty. Business internationalists hate him because of his support for unilateral American economic sanctions against Cuba and Iran, and skepticism about China. 
 But while hating Jesse Helms remains a parlor sport in Georgetown, Cambridge and Manhattan, a longer view of American history would demonstrate that Jesse Helms is a necessary part of the process: If he didn't exist, America would have to invent him.
"You have to have both yin and yang in American foreign policy, and Jesse Helms provides the yang," said Douglas Brinkley, a professor of history and the director of the Eisenhower Center at the University of New Orleans. "He respects his hard-line constituency but is willing to explore centrist possibilities. This is what makes him so important to the foreign-policy process."
Senator Helms plays two roles in American foreign policy -- both profoundly unpopular and even detestable from the standpoint of most of the foreign-policy establishment, but critical to the success of American foreign policy.
First, as chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, Mr. Helms upholds the power and prerogatives of the legislative branch in the foreign-policy process. Most foreign-policy professionals consider Congress, at best, a necessary evil in foreign policy, but the founding fathers thought otherwise and gave the Senate power to confirm ambassadors and ratify treaties.
These powers have frustrated presidents since George Washington worked to get the Jay Treaty with Britain through the Senate in 1794. A resentful Senate tried to humble President Andrew Jackson by refusing to confirm Martin Van Buren as minister to Britain in 1832. When the Senate amended the first Hay-Pauncefote agreement with Britain over the Panama Canal in 1900 so drastically that Britain rejected the revised treaty, John Hay had to sit down with Lord Pauncefote for a second round of talks to produce a second treaty.
While political scientists and foreign-policy practitioners often criticize the constitutional division of power between the executive and legislative branches for causing excessive confusion, American foreign policy benefits from checks and balances. Think of Senator Fulbright's criticism of the Vietnam War. Think of the role congressional investigations played during the Iran-contra scandal. Presidents can confuse personal political advantage with the national interest; congressional oversight -- even congressional obstruction -- helps keep American foreign policy on an even keel. 
THERE is another role Mr. Helms plays that infuriates internationalists but also strengthens the country's ability to conduct an active international policy: He is the key populist, conservative skeptic of the foreign-policy establishment's pet schemes for international cooperation and intervention.
Liberal internationalists would seemingly like to forget that suspicion of the foreign-policy establishment -- the pundits, fellows at policy institutes and corporate lawyers -- is a powerful force in the American heartland. For the elite is usually convinced it knows better than mass public opinion what foreign policy should be. Occasionally, it is even proved right.
But American public opinion will not take foreign policy on faith. It therefore falls to Senator Helms to infuriate well-meaning internationalists by subjecting the Kyoto Protocol or the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty or other key projects of liberal internationalists to acid skepticism. In doing this, Senator Helms not only speaks for the tens of millions of Americans who don't trust the foreign-policy establishment; he also opens the door to a true national consensus behind important foreign-policy goals.
THIS role of broker between a skeptical public opinion and an insistent internationalist elite is one of the most important in American foreign policy. This is the role Senator Vandenberg played in the 1940's. As James Chace, the author of "Acheson: The Secretary of State Who Created the American World," explained, "Having a Republican chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee with strong former isolationist credentials was indispensable to winning support for the Truman Doctrine and, above all, for the Marshall Plan."
Henry Cabot Lodge's reservations to Woodrow Wilson's draft Treaty of Versailles were also partly an attempt to win wider support for a controversial international initiative. Unfortunately, Wilson did not understand the game as well as Truman and Acheson; had Wilson compromised with Lodge's reservations, the Versailles Treaty would have been ratified and the United States would have joined the League of Nations.
When Senator Helms addressed the United Nations Security Council last year, he quoted Lodge. Like Lodge, Mr. Helms seems skeptical about international organizations but not flat-out opposed; the compromise in which he agreed to support the payment of America's back dues to the United Nations in exchange for reforms and a reduction in Washington's contribution was a classic example of a brokered compromise between internationalists and skeptics.
He played a broker's role again last week when he took the Foreign Relations Committee to Mexico, showing that Senate conservatives are open to a deeper relationship with a more democratic Mexico.
Professor Brinkley, who followed the debate on the United Nations, said Mr. Helms's flexibility is real, though limited. "You can't sway Helms ideologically," he said, "but you can work out a pragmatic agenda if you can meet his basic concerns." 
The politics of American foreign policy has been divided on regional and cultural lines at least since the South and the West forced the War of 1812 on a sullen New England. The Senate and the White House have been squabbling over foreign policy since George Washington, stung by sharp Senate questioning over a proposed Indian treaty, decided he would never return to seek its advice and consent in person.
Some hope and others fear that Mr. Helms, now 79, will decide against running for re-election in 2002. Either Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, or Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, would be favored to succeed him as chairman, depending on which party controls the Senate. Either could make a less prickly partner for the second half of the Bush administration.
Yet the ideological, cultural and institutional interests that Mr. Helms represents are not going away, and in his absence, the administration could find itself regretting the loss of a visible conservative foreign-policy leader with the credibility and clout to deliver a solid foreign-policy consensus on the right.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Jesse Helms fielded questions in Mexico City. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: The World; 
What It Takes to Stop Slavery

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
FIRST, there were reports of a ship off the coast of Benin carrying more than 200 children into slavery in West Africa. When the ship docked, however, only a few dozen were on board. There was speculation that the captain had abandoned the others on some coastal outcrop, or even thrown them overboard. 
 No clear answers about what happened on the ship may ever be known. But the case, and the international attention it drew, threw light on a troubling phenomenon: the modern slave trade. 
 The current definition of a slave, according to Beth Herzfeld of the London watchdog group Anti-Slavery International, is someone "forced to work under physical or mental threat, and where the owner or employer controls the person completely -- where a person is bought or sold." It includes, she said, restrictions on freedom of movement, no pay or very little and no say over hours, holidays or rest. 
By that measure, 27 million people or more are enslaved today, said Kevin Bales, the author of "Disposable People: New Slavery in the Global Economy" and an adviser to the United Nations on forced labor. In contrast, the trans-Atlantic slave trade is estimated at about 15 million people over 150 years.
In West Africa, experts say as many as tens of thousands of children are transported from country to country to fill a demand for cheap labor. Around the world, the International Labor Organization says, 250 million children who should be in school are at work instead, many in conditions of slavery in mines, factories and plantations. With another 500 million young people expected to enter the labor market in coming decades -- most from the poorest parts of the developing world -- children will only be more vulnerable.
Mr. Bales and other experts say that unlike those in the 18th and 19th centuries, today's peddlers of servitude seek out not the strong but the weak: women and children. Whether providing labor for the sex trade or the carpet industry, "You want people you can capture easily and conceal easily," Mr. Bales said. "Child slaves are very, very cheap, and they are disposable." 
Benin's mystery ship, brought to world attention by officials there, raises important questions. What moves societies to take action against a social or political evil, an industrial danger or even the potential for natural catastrophe? 
Sometimes a single event becomes the catalyst for transforming movements. In 1911, a fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory in Manhattan killed 146 workers, most of them women trapped in a locked, 10th-floor sweatshop. Those who jumped to escape the flames died on the sidewalk below. Frances Perkins, who became secretary of labor under President Franklin D. Roosevelt, called it "the torch that lit up the whole industrial scene." Decades of labor legislation and reforms followed.
MORE than half a century later, a chemical company's toxic contamination of the Love Canal neighborhood of Niagara Falls led to Congressional enactment of the Superfund law. Last year, after concluding that the international sex trade in women and girls included the trafficking of up to 100,000 women into the United States each year, the Clinton administration and Congress worked together to pass the Trafficking and Violence Victims Protection Act.
So-called tipping points are not confined to industry. The recent deaths of 43 South Africans in a soccer-match stampede opened debate there on the safe handling of crowds at sports events. Similar stampedes have changed laws and practices in Europe and Latin America. The most recent earthquake in India, which left nearly 2,000 confirmed dead, prompted calls for an effective crackdown on the flouting of building codes.
Sadly, calamities do not always cause change. Overloaded ferries sink with miserable regularity in a dozen poor countries, sometimes killing hundreds. Shoddy houses, schools and hospitals are still built along known fault lines. A fire not unlike the Triangle Shirtwaist killed 52 last year in Bangladesh, where women sew for less than $50 a month. It was only one of the country's many fatal fires. 
What makes the difference between a Triangle Shirtwaist fire and a Bangladeshi sweatshop fire? Officials at international agencies, who in an age of globalization now deal with borderless problems, say critical factors include governmental will, callousness or corruption among local or national officials and the strength of nongovernmental organizations pressing for change (as well as the inability of monied lobbies to prevent it). 
Sometimes a single person can make a difference. The late Diana, princess of Wales, focused world attention on the human devastation caused by land mines. The internationally known Senegalese musician Youssou N'Dour gives concerts around the world to campaign against child labor. In Thailand, a popular former government minister, Mechai Viravaidya, did more than anyone to help cut both rapid population growth and AIDS infections with clever public campaigns to promote condom use.
"YOU have to move forward in a parallel manner on different fronts, and then one of them sometimes produces the breakthrough," said Juan Somavia, director general of the International Labor Organization in Geneva, which is beginning a campaign to eliminate the worst forms of child labor, with initial programs in El Salvador, Nepal, Tanzania and West Africa. Most important, he said, is awareness-raising and community involvement. Legislation, labor courts and labor inspections are other forces for change. So are the companies that use child labor themselves, said Mr. Somavia, a former Chilean diplomat. "A basic element for companies today is image," he said. "That's a leverage." 
Add to that market activism. "This has been done in the U.S. traditionally through shareholder resolutions," he said. "Today it is moving into fair trade initiatives and socially responsible investment funds." And a related concept is consumer choice: child labor in India's carpet industry is now monitored by Rugmark, an organization in Washington supported by Unicef. 
"Local N.G.O.'s are key," Mr. Somavia said. "International N.G.O.'s bring attention to the issue because they have access to global media. But local N.G.O.'s make it happen."
Opposition to child slavery may be reaching a turning point. From the grass roots up in Benin, Mali and the Ivory Coast, determination to halt the trade has been rising. 
"Benin is a good example of a country that has made good progress," said Alfred Ironside, a Unicef spokesman. "They have developed a system of community watches. The watchdog system has helped to prevent the abduction or spiriting away of some 3,000 children in the last three years. It may sound like a small number, but that's 3,000 kids who didn't end up in something like bonded labor."

HEADLINE: The World: Fruits of Democracy; 
Guess Who's a Chinese Nationalist Now?

BYLINE:  By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

 BODY:
FOR Americans, the "bad guys" in China seem easily identifiable: they are the aging, grim-faced Communist hard-liners in Mao jackets, wagging their trembling fingers at the world. They squelch democratic opinion, detain American airplane crews and ferociously repress Tibet.
 But that conclusion is thoroughly misleading. Increasingly, the real hard-liners toward the West are simply ordinary people. 
 They wear blue jeans and T-shirts with risque English phrases. They trade gossip about how to get American visas. They read Danielle Steele novels and revere a man they call Qiao Dan, also known as Michael Jordan. But many also believe that the United States is a bully, that Beijing should stand up more firmly to Tokyo and Washington alike, that Tibetan monks should be tossed in jail if necessary and that any move by Taiwan toward independence should result in a Chinese military attack. 
"A more democratic China is not necessarily a less nationalistic China," said Xiao Qiang, the executive director of Human Rights in China, a New York-based group. "It could take a very hard line, too."
Indeed, if China had been a more democratic country, the recent stalemate over the American spy plane might have been much more difficult to resolve. As China has become more open in recent years, allowing citizens to tap out their thoughts in Internet chat rooms or even call them in to talk radio shows, public opinion has come to matter more. Ultimately, this may make China more complex, nationalistic and obdurate. Think of France, cubed.
The accompanying comments by university students give a taste of the feelings many young Chinese have toward the United States. There is fascination, respect and envy, but also perplexity about and resentment of those high-handed and inscrutable Americans.
This growing Chinese nationalism did not arise by accident. In the aftermath of the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown on the student democracy movement, Chinese leaders consciously cultivated nationalism as a new glue to unite the country. Communism was discredited, so President Jiang Zemin and others used the education system and the propaganda apparatus to nurture a prickly national pride and suspicion of the outside world. As He Xin, a commentator with close ties to hard-liners, said at the time: "The new unifying force in China is patriotism."
Wu Jiaxiang, a former senior official who was imprisoned after Tiananmen and now lives in Boston, puts it differently. "Chinese nationalism is something that the Communist Party started after Tiananmen," he said. "They use nationalism to replace Communism. They invented it. There was some in the 1980's, but it has become much stronger since the 1990's."
The upshot was that the government toned down its propaganda about the virtues of socialism -- which nobody believed anyway, since the children of the leaders were busy raking in money as capitalists -- and focused on warnings about the duplicitous and predatory West. Those warnings fell on fertile ground, partly because China has been pushed around, plundered and carved up by one country after another, ever since Britain went to war with China in 1839, in part to force it to buy opium.
SUCH predations created ferocious waves of nationalism. In 1899-1900 an ultra-nationalist group known as the Boxers rampaged against foreigners, declaring in one statement: "Foreign devils are not produced by mankind. If you do not believe it, look at them carefully. The eyes of all the foreign devils are bluish." Shouting, "Protect the country, destroy the foreigner," the Boxers slaughtered foreign missionaries, hacked off the breasts of their wives, and, of less concern in the West, killed a far greater number of Chinese Christians.
The ruling Qing dynasty, which was at the time disintegrating in a way that some find comparable to the travails of today's Communist dynasty, seized upon that nationalism to try to bolster its own legitimacy, without much success. The Communist Party has been rather more clever so far in nurturing nationalism since the 1990's, and in staying on top of the nationalist tiger.
Yu Renqiu, an expert on United States-China relations at the State University of New York in Purchase, recalls that when he came to the United States in 1980 he and his fellow Chinese students were not terribly nationalistic. But in the last half-dozen years, he said, Chinese students have become much more inclined to stand up for their country and vent outrage at the United States.
"I worry about it," Professor Yu said. "I worry that this popular nationalism may get out of control."
While misinformation in China's state-controlled media is often blamed for the nationalist response during incidents like the spy plane standoff, the reality is more complex. In 1999, for example, when the American bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade provoked outrage in China, many Chinese students in America were also furious, even though they were relying for their information on American television and newspapers. Likewise, the Hong Kong public has periodically been whipped into a nationalistic fervor over Japan's occupation of the disputed Senkaku islands.
Part of the reason seems to be that, where Americans see individual incidents, the Chinese see one more in a 200-year string of "guochi" -- a term familiar to all Chinese, meaning national humiliation. Americans see an air collision, or the jockeying among competing cities to get the Olympics; the Chinese see another insidious attempt by foreign powers to weaken China and hold it back.
This perspective has been encouraged not just by the Chinese government but also, paradoxically, by the advent of quasi-capitalism in the news media. Often the most jingoistic publications in China are not the official ones but those unsubsidized magazines and tabloids that must fight for readers any way they can, including peddling nationalism much as William Randolph Hearst did in America in the run-up to the Spanish-American War.
While some observers worry that the American and Chinese peoples -- and not just their governments -- may come to regard themselves as antagonists, they also note that China's growing market economy could, over time, have the opposite effect.
"Many Chinese are very practical," notes Xu Pei, a Chinese-language journalist in Washington. "They understand that they have to trade with the U.S. and that if relations with the U.S. were damaged, then their living standard would be damaged. They know that very clearly."
The Chinese leadership also has an incentive to keep the nationalism in check. President Jiang, who as much as anybody helped nurture today's mood, has lately been hurt by it, since his decision to return the American air crew is seen by many Chinese as evidence of weakness and a willingness to toady to America.
All in all, the government in China today often seems more afraid of the people than the other way around. The leaders know that protests by students, workers or even peasants could paralyze the country, and that either unrest or high levels of popular discontent could provoke a coup d'etat.
SO the authorities go to tremendous lengths -- through propaganda and through cash payments -- to appease unemployed workers and the army. All this makes nationalism a particularly interesting force in China, given its potential not just for conferring legitimacy on the government but also for taking it away.
"Nationalism is very dangerous for the Communist Party," said Mr. Wu, the former senior official. "Because after you've created it, it grows stronger and stronger on its own until it is difficult to control."

HEADLINE: Chinese Youths' Darkening View of U.S. 

BYLINE:  By CRAIG S. SMITH 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, April 21 

 BODY:
Zhou Jing's view of the United States as dangerous and domineering has hardened since American warplanes bombed China's embassy in Belgrade two years ago and an American spy plane more recently collided with a Chinese fighter jet off this country's southern coast.
 "The embassy bombing had a huge impact on me," said Mr. Zhou, 21, sitting in an American-style cafe across from Fudan University, where he is a student. Though he hopes to study in the United States someday and has no quibble with the American public, he said the bombing confirmed his view of the American government as unreasonable and arrogant. 
 "And there's no fundamental difference between that event and the spy plane incident," he added. 
Mr. Zhou's growing ambivalence toward the United States highlights a change in generational attitudes over the last 10 years. It has left those coming of age now with the most negative feelings about the United States of any generation since the 1970's.
Then China was emerging from the Cultural Revolution and began shedding its view of the United States as evil incarnate, a caricature that had its roots in the Korean War, when Chinese troops and American G.I.'s fought. And a decade ago Chinese youth looked up to America.
But since then, year by year, they have turned increasingly wary of the United States.
That is particularly true of those now in their early 20's, for whom the killing of demonstrators in Beijing on June 4, 1989, is a historical reference as remote as the Vietnam War was to the generation of Americans that came of age during the Reagan administration.
Those attitudes are worrying, not only because they are shared by a generation that will one day be responsible for managing Chinese-American relations but also because more immediate changes in Chinese society are giving them added weight.
"One of the major concerns to us should be what average people think about us, because public opinion is playing an increasingly important role in the country," said Kenneth Lieberthal, a China scholar and former Asian affairs expert on the National Security Council.
Mr. Zhou and his classmates at Fudan, one of the country's finest schools, tend to be more politically detached than their counterparts in Beijing and less emotional than elsewhere in the country. And they are relatively affluent. Shaggy-haired young men in blue jeans and untucked shirts roam along a strip of bookstores, coffee houses and bars adjoining the leafy campus each evening, like students in the United States.
The negative sentiments they expressed, tempered by privilege, tend to be even stronger among students at less cosmopolitan schools in the poorer provinces.
"When I was young, my impressions of America came from newspaper reports, which were mostly negative," said Zhu Yunxia, a friend of Mr. Zhou's wearing a Harvard T-shirt. He said events since then have not improved his view.
"America's foreign policy is based on domestic interests, rather than what's good for the whole world," he said, adding that the United States sees China as an adversary for reasons of its own. "With the Soviet Union gone, America's military needs an imagined enemy so that Congress will increase defense spending." 
Those attitudes may change as this new generation grows older, but prospects for a softening of their views have dimmed since the Bush administration cast China as a "strategic competitor" and indicated it would offer more assertive support for an autonomous Taiwan. Many young Chinese are suspicious of Mr. Bush's rhetorical step back from regarding China as the potential "strategic partner" seen by the Clinton administration.
The likelihood of future conflicts like the spy plane incident, in which a Chinese pilot died, suggests that Chinese suspicions will only deepen in still younger generations.
The most immediate irritant is the Pentagon's suggestion that, following the recent midair collision, President Bush might order American fighter jets to escort future United States surveillance aircraft flying off China's coast.
"Even without escorts, a resumption of the surveillance flights will upset people, but if fighter planes accompany future surveillance flights, it will be very difficult to control anti-American emotions," Mr. Zhou said.
"China shouldn't hesitate to use missiles if Bush sends fighter escorts," another student said.
China is changing so fast, a generation gap exists not only between young and old, but between Chinese entering and leaving their early 20's.
Huang Hongye, a 26-year-old event organizer waiting for his girlfriend at a Shanghai Starbucks, said recent events have done little to shake his enthusiasm, and that of his friends, for the economic superpower.
"It's natural that the Bush administration would try to make the United States look strong and that the Chinese government would try to save face," he said. Mr. Huang wears Lee jeans and tan Reebok boots, smokes State Express 555 British cigarettes and checks in with his girlfriend on a Siemens mobile phone. He reads e-mail messages on a Philips Nino palm-size computer, which, along with all of the computers at his office, is loaded with Microsoft software.
"We like the American style," Mr. Huang said. "We look at things less emotionally than the younger generation." Mr. Huang is just five years older than Mr. Zhou and his circle.
The current generation of college students grew up during a period of unprecedented economic growth that has been virtually devoid of political contention. Communications and the freedom of personal expression are largely unfettered.
And these youths have little knowledge of the turbulent Cultural Revolution, which is virtually ignored in Chinese schools and is rarely spoken of by older generations who are eager to forget the past and move on.
This is the first generation under the one-child policy to reach maturity, and many have enjoyed the devotion -- if not indulgence -- of parents with an only child.
Government-set limits are widely supported by today's young people as necessary to the country's continued development. Most support China's frequent use of the death penalty and many view curbs on freedom, such as the crackdown on the Falun Gong spiritual movement, as essential to maintaining social order.
"China's younger generation matured in the 1990's, a period when U.S. policy and U.S. rhetoric sought to change the way China is governed, in part by making strong accusations against the Chinese leadership on human rights and other issues," said Dr. Lieberthal, the China scholar. But those accusations ignored developments that gradually produced a growing middle class and greater freedoms of speech and mobility, he added, changes that are very real to most Chinese.
Chinese attitudes toward America are first set by mandatory "current affairs" classes that Chinese students attend from primary school through high school and even into college. The classes focus on salient news and act as a mechanism for communicating the Communist Party's interpretation of events, particularly for those of a political nature.
Pamphlets distributed by universities as part of that education program, for example, condemned the American-led bombing campaign in Kosovo. And Mr. Zhou recalls during high school studying criticism of the United States' threat of trade sanctions and charges of Western influence in blocking China's effort to serve as the host to the 2008 Summer Olympics.
China's state-run news media also manipulate public opinion. The Chinese press waited several days to report President Clinton's apology after American warplanes bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, and it has not reported the United States explanation of how the recent midair collision occurred.
Many young people here deride America as the "Pacific policeman." And the word "hegemony," a favorite in the Communist Party propaganda, is on everyone's lips. After the spy-plane incident, even young laborers on Hainan island were using the word, though few could explain what it meant.
Still, except for Beijing's territorial claims to Tibet and Taiwan or brief border disputes with Vietnam and India, the country throughout its recent history has been focused inward without expansionist aims.
"China has always adopted a moderate foreign policy and never been aggressive, either politically or economically," said Hong Danyi, a Fudan student from southern China. "We've never claimed to be a great power or pretended to be the guardian of the world."
Such sentiments do not spring from simple nationalism as it exists in the West, but are rooted in a much deeper cultural identity that transcends the Communist Party's 52 years in power. Part of China's frustration comes from America's failure to understand the depth of that feeling.
The United States and China have had a difficult relationship ever since American traders arrived on the country's coast in 1784. America piggybacked on concessions won by European colonial powers, and backed the losing side of the civil war that brought the Communists to power in 1949 and made America the country's prime enemy.
After President Richard Nixon set the stage for normalized relations, Chinese schools stopped teaching Russian in favor of English, and a love affair with America began. America's reputation among China's youth peaked during the pro-democracy protests of 1989, when many students regarded the United States as a model and champion.
But since the bloody suppression of those protests, a barrage of anti-American propaganda has set the tone for young people.
The breakup of the Soviet Union and Russia's subsequent economic decline have since been accepted as a cautionary tale by many young Chinese who support the government's brutal 1989 crackdown.
"When the Soviet Union was undergoing drastic changes, they took the American political system as their goal," Mr. Zhou said. "But compare China with what Russia looks like now."
Many young people still want to study, if not live, in the United States. But attitudes may sour further with America's decision, due this week, on what new weapons to sell to Taiwan.
More friction will come when President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan stops by the United States in May on his way to Latin America, and when the Dalai Lama visits Washington several days later.
And in July, the Olympic committee will announce the winner of the competition to be the host of the 2008 Summer Olympics. If China does not win, America will be blamed.

HEADLINE: In Hong Kong, Scholars Keep Safe Distance From Trouble 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 21 

 BODY:
It has been a tense spring for scholars who study China from this former colony on its doorstep.
 Beijing's recent detention of several Chinese academics -- two of whom are residents of Hong Kong -- has led a growing number of scholars here to cancel trips to mainland China. They say the secrecy surrounding the detentions has made them nervous that they could be swept up in the same net. 
 "It is not wise to go now because we don't know what's permissible and what's not," said X. L. Ding, an expert in the Chinese economy and legal system at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. "People got into trouble before, but the reasons were quite clear. Now it's not clear at all." 
Professor Ding, a Chinese national with a Ph.D. from Harvard, usually makes about five trips a year to China to study economic reform and the rule of law, relying on field work and access to statistics from official sources.
But Professor Ding said he had put his travel plans on hold, as have several other China experts at Hong Kong's major universities.
He and other academics said they believed that the crackdown was motivated, in part, by the publication in January of the "The Tiananmen Papers," an insider's account of the deliberations of the Chinese leaders that led to the crackdown on the democracy movement in Beijing in June 1989. That edition came out in English.
The first Chinese-language edition of the book, which is based on the same supposed government transcripts, was published in Hong Kong on April 15. The first print run of the book, retitled "June Fourth: The True Story," sold out in bookstores and on street corners in two days.
"The Chinese seem to be singling out a few people in the wake of the book to stop this leakage of information," said Lau Siu-kai, a professor of sociology at the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
Xu Zerong, the first Hong Kong resident to be detained, disappeared on a trip to neighboring Guangdong Province last August, five months before the English publication of the book. But his detention came to light only last month, and the pace of detentions has quickened since then.
Li Shaomin, an American citizen who teaches business at the City University of Hong Kong, was detained Feb. 25 by security agents while visiting a friend in China, his wife said. China has not confirmed the report.
Chinese authorities also arrested Gao Zhan, a researcher at American University in Washington, charging her with espionage. On Friday, Beijing confirmed that it had detained a Chinese-American author, Wu Jianmin. A human rights group here said he was suspected of helping leak the Tiananmen papers.
The detentions are casting a pall over Hong Kong's universities, which have become a popular base in the last decade for scholars to study China. The former British colony offers a hard-to-beat combination of high salaries, proximity to the mainland and relative academic freedom.
But Hong Kong's more open system unnerves the Chinese. They worry that the city could be used as a staging ground for subversive activities, fears that are fanned by the brisk sales of the Tiananmen book.
Three pro-Beijing bookstores here refused to carry the book. But other stores sold out the first 10,000 copies before they were even on the shelves. A second printing will go on sale by the end of the month.
Pro-democracy groups have seized on the book to rekindle interest in the Tiananmen Square crackdown. The Hong Kong Alliance in Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movement in China set up a stall in the Causeway Bay shopping district, where it sold 100 copies in less than two hours.

HEADLINE: In the Streets, Fervor, Fears and a Gamut of Issues 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: QUEBEC, April 21 

 BODY:
For a second day, the old streets of this historic city were mobbed today with people protesting the proceedings of the third Summit of the Americas. The biggest crowd -- a good mile long and a boulevard wide -- marched for hours without incident or trouble yet with evident concern for the panoply of issues that angered, frightened or frustrated them enough to come here. 
 But on the other side of Quebec, police officers used a water cannon, rubber bullets and a continual shower of tear gas to repeatedly push back the front ranks of more than 6,000 protesters at a few key points not far from the meeting site. One of the most prolonged confrontations took place at a weak point in the concrete and chain-link fence around the official summit meeting area that had been breached briefly during protests on Friday afternoon. 
 A police spokesman said the incident began when a few of the protesters threw tear gas canisters at police guarding the fence, but protesters said police fired first. The police pushed the crowds back with water and gas. Then dozens of officers in riot gear advanced, pulling individual protesters out of the group or confiscating the gas masks that allowed them to toss the billowing tear gas canisters back.
The police arrested another 50 people this afternoon, bringing to 150 the number detained this week. One of those arrested, Jaggi Singh, was identified as a leader of the organized protest group the Anti-Capitalist Convergence. Thirty-four police officers have received minor injuries while 45 protesters were hurt. 
But not all the protests were marked by such clashes. Under a brilliant blue sky and some of the first truly springlike temperatures this winter-bound city has seen this year, a vast sea of people from across the Americas -- estimated by the police at more than 20,000 -- set out from the city's riverfront to send a message to the 33 leaders at the meeting. With signs and huge puppets, flags and electronic bullhorns, they criticized the most extreme effects of free trade and the trend toward globalization. 
Some people focused on complex issues in sophisticated ways. "Mexico has already lived with free trade for 35 years through the maquiladoras," said Bob Jeffcott of Toronto, a member of the Maquila Solidarity Network. He said maquilas, the tariff-free assembly plants that have operated along the United States-Mexico border since the 1960's, have created "a democracy-free zone" in Mexico in which the rights of workers to belong to independent unions has been abrogated. 
Some workers belong to unions that are not considered independent because they are linked to the government. "A Free Trade Area of the Americas would extend similar practices to the rest of the hemisphere," Mr. Jeffcott said.
He worried that the widely televised images of the altercations between the police and the protesters on Friday were overshadowing the message of environmentalists, labor rights advocates and others who came to Quebec but did not tangle with the police. "It would be a mistake to extrapolate from those acts of violence and think that they exemplified all of what is happening here," Mr. Jeffcott said. 
Still, the local French-language television network switched repeatedly during the day from scenes of the water cannon pushing over masked protesters on Rene Levesque Boulevard, two blocks from the summit meeting place, to the lively crowds swarming down Boulevard Charest more than a mile away.
Among those at the march was Pedro Vasquez, 30, a Colombian student who fled his country after receiving threats on his life. He was protesting the $1.3 billion in American support for the Colombian government's fight against a long-standing guerrilla uprising and drug trafficking, an initiative called Plan Colombia.
"The money is not helping Colombians because 70 percent of it is going to buy military equipment and the violence is just continuing," Mr. Vasquez said. "To us, Plan Colombia is really Plan Anti-Colombia." 
While many demonstrators expressed concerns about big issues involving faraway countries, a number of people were worried about how free trade on such a vast scale would change the way they live here in North America.
Daniel Baker, a 39-year-old organic soybean grower, had come from Starksboro, Vt., this morning because he was afraid that the intellectual property rights protections that could be included in a hemispheric free trade agreement would benefit the big chemical companies involved in genetic engineering of agricultural products at the expense of small farmers. 
"With a good legal team, the big companies can take a product that has been developed by local farmers for thousands of years -- like basmati rice -- and get an international patent that gives them legal claim to all the profits from that product," Mr. Baker said. 
And Sarah Charette, 20, a student at Carleton University in Ottawa, came to protest the way trade agreements have eroded Canada's national sovereignty by giving corporations the power to challenge government subsidies to entities -- like Canada Post, the country's postal system -- that challenge private enterprises. "I don't like the idea that a company can sue a government for doing something that helps people," she said. "There's got to be some balance between corporate rights and the public good."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Protesters resisted being pushed back by a police water cannon yesterday during the Quebec summit meeting. (Reuters)
