HEADLINE: Torricelli Pressed Hard to Help Big Donor Pursue Korean Deal 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI; This article was reported by David Kocieniewski, Tim Golden and Don Kirk and was written by Mr. Kocieniewski.

 BODY:
When David Chang, a New Jersey businessman, set out to buy one of South Korea's largest insurance companies in 1998, he had no experience in insurance and nowhere near the $1.5 billion being sought for the company. But he did have a friend with some influence in South Korea, Senator Robert G. Torricelli.
 Mr. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat, has insisted that he did no more for Mr. Chang than he would have done for any constituent. One of his aides wrote a letter of introduction for Mr. Chang's company; it was so perfunctory, Mr. Torricelli's office said, that the senator didn't even bother to review it. "Senator Torricelli has never discussed Mr. Chang's business matters with any Korean government officials," the office said in a statement last fall. 
 But a detailed examination of the insurance deal by The New York Times shows that Mr. Torricelli in fact played a busy, behind-the-scenes role in support of Mr. Chang's bid for the insurer -- writing letters to Korean leaders, meeting with senior officials in Korea and recommending Mr. Chang, one of his most generous supporters, and his New Jersey company, Panacom Inc., in glowing terms. 
"I present them to you with my strongest possible recommendation," he wrote in a September 1998 letter to South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, according to a copy of the letter reviewed by The Times.
Mr. Torricelli also ruffled more than a few feathers along the way. After he took Mr. Chang along to a July 7, 1999, briefing on economic issues with South Korea's finance minister and used the occasion to lobby for Panacom, American diplomats in Seoul were so concerned that the United States ambassador later apologized to the minister, one former official said.
What help Mr. Torricelli gave to Mr. Chang, 57, has become a critical question as a wide-ranging federal inquiry into the activities of the senator and his staff has focused on allegations that he took tens of thousands of dollars in unreported cash and gifts from Mr. Chang from 1996 to 1999. Federal law requires that public officials disclose the gifts they receive and strictly limits the value of gifts that legislators can take from any one source, exempting those given by personal friends. It is also illegal to take gifts in exchange for official acts, although such a link is often hard to prove. 
Mr. Torricelli has cast his relationship with Mr. Chang in two ways: as a friendship -- one in which he scarcely lifted an official finger for Mr. Chang -- and as a political relationship typical of those that legislators have with big contributors.
Mr. Chang, who pleaded guilty last June to making $53,700 in illegal donations to the senator's 1996 campaign, was certainly an important Torricelli supporter. Besides his contributions to Mr. Torricelli's Senate race, Mr. Chang gave tens of thousands of dollars to other Democratic political causes in 1998 and 1999, when Mr. Torricelli was heading the Democrats' fund-raising efforts in the Senate, and has told investigators that he made many of them at the senator's request, people involved in the Torricelli case said.
Both Mr. Chang and his former assistant, Audrey Yu, have also told federal prosecutors that Mr. Torricelli stood to realize a financial windfall if they were successful in their bid for the Korean insurance company.
Mr. Chang, who has been cooperating with the government as part of a plea bargain, has told them that he promised the senator a $10 million commission if the deal went through, according to people involved in the inquiry and a former employee of Mr. Chang's. Ms. Yu has confirmed to prosecutors that Mr. Torricelli was to get a commission on the deal, but told prosecutors she believed that it was to be $1 million, these people said. It could not be determined whether prosecutors, who declined to comment on the Torricelli case, have obtained any corroboration of these allegations.
Mr. Torricelli would not discuss his efforts in Korea. One of his lawyers, Ted Wells, also declined to address the discrepancies between the senator's earlier assertions that he had not helped Panacom and the accounts of Korean and American officials and former employees of the company.
Mr. Wells denied that Mr. Torricelli had done anything wrong, but said he could not comment on any matters related to Mr. Chang or the federal investigation because of discussions between prosecutors and the senator's legal team. He added, "We have come to expect not only false and irresponsible charges concerning David Chang, but increasingly bizarre ones." Mr. Chang's lawyer, Bradley D. Simon, said he could not comment because of the continuing federal inquiry, as did a lawyer for Ms. Yu, Alberto Rivas.
Nearly two years after Mr. Chang abandoned his bid for the insurer, Daehan, or Korea Life Insurance Company, what has become clear is that Panacom, which he incorporated in Delaware in 1997, was hardly the enterprise that its executives -- and Mr. Torricelli -- described to Korean officials.
On its Web site, Panacom described itself as an international powerhouse: "Our activities span many industries and include food, medical products, construction, telecommunications, transportation, waste management, water treatment, sewage disposal, consumer electronics, mining, crude oil and gas exploration and development, machinery, heavy equipment and power plant design and equipment."
In fact, several former employees said, Panacom was only somewhat more than a shell. Although Mr. Chang told Korean officials he employed 300 to 400 people, the company actually never had more than a handful of employees. Other than grain trading that Mr. Chang had done with North Korea in the early 1990's (and for which he still claims to be owed tens of millions of dollars by the North Korean government), his primary international financial deals had involved losing large amounts of money on foreign stocks, his former employees said.
What Panacom did have, however, were powerful political connections.
The company's nominal chairman, Daniel J. Murphy, was a retired four-star Navy admiral who had been a deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, chief of staff to George Bush in the early 1980's when he was vice president and a $20,000-a-month lobbyist for Mr. Chang during the 1990's. 
Mr. Chang named another of his lobbyists, James A. Courter, the former six-term Republican congressman from New Jersey, as one of Panacom's two presidents. And for a high-powered consultant, Mr. Chang hired Terry McAuliffe, a close friend of President Clinton and former American trade ambassador in South Korea who has since become chairman of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. Chang himself took the title of vice president and senior adviser.
Asked about his own role in Panacom's efforts, Mr. Torricelli issued a statement last fall suggesting that it had been negligible. 
"Senator Torricelli has never discussed Mr. Chang's business matters with any Korean officials," the statement said. "A few years ago, a staff assistant provided Mr. Chang with a letter of introduction that was nearly identical to similar letters of introduction provided by Governor Christie Whitman and various members of Congress," the statement said. "Such letters are standard and available to any New Jersey company seeking a reference to embassies or foreign governments, and they were not reviewed by the senator personally."
But according to diplomatic cables, letters from Mr. Torricelli, former Panacom employees and United States and Korean officials, the senator took an active part in trying to help Panacom win the bid.
When Mr. Chang set his sights on Daehan in the summer of 1998, he faced formidable competition.
The insurance company, South Korea's third-largest, had huge debts and a bloated work force and -- after the near-collapse of the country's financial system in 1997 -- uncertain prospects for growth. But such was its position in the world's sixth-biggest insurance market that soon after the South Korean government announced that it would be sold, its suitors included such international companies as the American International Group and Metropolitan Life Insurance.
Almost immediately, Panacom turned to Mr. Torricelli for help, and on Sept. 24, 1998, the senator wrote two important letters to Korean officials, documents and interviews show.
One letter, Korean officials said, was addressed to Lee Hun Jai, the director general of the country's Financial Supervisory Commission, the government agency in charge of the nation's financial restructuring. According to Chung Chae Woong, the director of the agency's insurance division, the letter introduced a Panacom official who had visited Korea, Michael S. Kimm, and described the company as "experienced in financial transactions."
A second letter went to Korea's president, Mr. Kim, an old friend of Mr. Torricelli's whom the senator had embraced at a White House state dinner and played host to at a reception in New Jersey barely three months earlier.
"In light of my extensive experience with and knowledge of Korea, I thought it might be of mutual assistance to bring Mr. Kimm and Panacom Inc. to your attention," Mr. Torricelli wrote, according to a copy of that letter viewed by The Times. "I am confident that Mr. Kimm and Panacom can diligently and responsibly handle even the most difficult international financial transactions, and I present them to you with my strongest possible recommendation. I look forward to working with you and your government on issues important to the security and prosperity of our respective countries."
One former Panacom official said that after Mr. Torricelli's letters, Mr. Kimm was soon granted an audience with Mr. Lee, the Financial Supervisory Commission chairman. Mr. Kimm did not respond to several telephone calls asking for comment, but the former Panacom official and two Korean officials described his efforts as highly unsuccessful.
"We knew that they were cheating," a senior Korean finance official, Lee Jong Koo, said of Panacom's bid for the insurance company. "We could feel it."
Former associates of Mr. Chang said he was discouraged enough to decide not to participate in a government-sponsored auction of the company. But when the government voided that auction, Mr. Chang tried again, approaching American International Group and other American insurers about a possible partnership and calling once more on senior Korean officials.
The former associates of Mr. Chang said the Panacom chairman, Mr. Murphy, took the lead, meeting in late June 1999 with the Korean prime minister, Kim Jong Pil, whose brother he had once represented as a lobbyist. In late June 1999, Mr. Murphy and Mr. Chang met with the prime minister and told him they wanted to bid for the insurance company outside the auction process, the former associate said, promising to pay a higher price than the others and to preserve much of the company's work force.
While Mr. Kim appeared receptive, one former Panacom employee said, Korean finance officials pressed to know how Panacom would come up with the money. Mr. Chang responded again with a recommendation from Mr. Torricelli.
At about the same time, according to a State Department cable released under the Freedom of Information Act, the department notified the United States Embassy in Seoul that Mr. Torricelli would be passing through the city on July 6 and 7, 1999, to meet with Prime Minister Kim and the Korean finance minister, Kang Bong Kyoon. The cable said that Mr. Torricelli, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, wanted to meet with them "to discuss the political, economic, and humanitarian developments in North Korea," where he was scheduled to go after his stop in Seoul.
But when Mr. Torricelli walked into Mr. Kang's office, it was with Mr. Chang at his side. In a telephone interview, Mr. Kang suggested that Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Chang pressed him for help on the Korea Life Insurance deal, but that he would have no part of it.
"At the time, I said I could not intervene," and told him nothing substantive," Mr. Kang said in the interview. "I didn't have any detailed information. I just listened and I did not respond."
American diplomats who helped with Mr. Torricelli's visit were sufficiently startled by Mr. Chang's presence at the meeting to alert the United States ambassador, Stephen W. Bosworth. The ambassador, in turn, was concerned enough to contact Mr. Kang to apologize, a former State Department official said.
"The Embassy's impression was that Torricelli was going to go in by himself and talk about North Korea and the state of the South Korean economy," said the former official. "Had the finance minister known that he was going to be lobbied on the Daehan insurance company, he would not have granted the meeting."
Mr. Bosworth later promised Mr. Kang that such an episode "would not happen again," the former official said. "For an elected official of the United States to do it this way was a little out of the ordinary -- to say the least."
Mr. Torricelli sent off yet another letter for Panacom on July 15, Korean officials said, to Prime Minister Kim in praise of the company. Ultimately, though, the efforts of Mr. Torricelli and Panacom's other supporters were for naught. Despite its promises to raise the necessary funds from New Jersey pension funds and other sources and a last-ditch partnership between Panacom and the Korea Life Insurance Company's owners, Korean finance officials intervened in September 1999 to take over the insurer themselves.
Within weeks, Mr. Chang's offices in New Jersey were raided by federal agents. And on Dec. 10, he was arrested on charges that eventually included obstruction of justice, soliciting perjury and illegal campaign contributions to Mr. Torricelli.

The Federal Investigation Into Torricelli
The federal investigation of Senator Robert G. Torricelli began more than three years ago as a relatively modest look at questionable contributions to his 1996 Senate race. It has expanded into an inquiry into the Torricelli campaign's finances and fund-raising, as well as the activities and finances of the senator himself.
In recent months, the investigation has concentrated on allegations that originated with David Chang, a New Jersey businessman who pleaded guilty in the original campaign-contributions case. According to people involved in the case, Mr. Chang has told prosecutors of a close and opportunistic political friendship in which he gave Mr. Torricelli contributions and gifts in return for help -- and promises of help -- in business deals.
The senator has insisted that he did nothing wrong, and that Mr. Chang is a liar seeking leniency from prosecutors.

 BODY:

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
Route 7 Corridor Gaining as Site for Office Buildings

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
EAST of Stamford where Route 7 heads north from Norwalk to the border of Massachusetts, the so-called Route 7 Corridor from Norwalk through Wilton has been coming into its own as a preferred site for office buildings.
 Some new construction is taking place, but more than a million square feet of existing offices along the route have been acquired by a single concern: the 26-year-old Davis Companies of Boston and Wilton. 
 Keeping an eye out particularly for departing corporate headquarters, Davis acquired four properties vacated through mergers and relocations by Emery Air Freight, Dun & Bradstreet, Perkin-Elmer and Purdue Pharma. All but the former Perkin-Elmer headquarters, the most recent acquisition, have been renovated and completely leased or sold to raise investment cash but still managed by Davis. 
Davis bought its first Connecticut property in 1993 at 1250 Post Road in the town of Fairfield, followed in 1996 with the purchase of 35 Nutmeg Drive in Trumbull. In 1997, it bought the former Dun & Bradstreet headquarters at 187 Danbury Road (Route 7) in Wilton and in 1998 built the 158,000-square-foot Reservoir Corporate Center in Shelton, which is now fully leased. "We sold them all," said Paul Marcus, 42, partner and president of the Davis Companies, "retaining management of the Danbury Road and Trumbull buildings, and we are approved to build two office buildings totaling 245,000 square feet on the 20-acre Shelton site." 
The cost of buying and renovating the Trumbull, Fairfield and 187 Danbury Road buildings was $31.7 million. They were sold for $58 million. The money from sales was put into other Wilton and Route 7 purchases.
Davis is a private real estate investment, management and development concern specializing in buying existing buildings at minimal cost and renovating and repositioning them as first-class office space.
Davis bought distressed mortgage loans and parlayed them into apartment ownership during the recession of the late 80's and early 90's. It was following a practice successfully put into place by W&M Properties of Manhattan and Stamford during the Depression of the 1930's. After those moves, both companies were able to buy various commercial properties and turn them into Class A office space. The only major difference is W&M's tendency to hold onto its properties, while Davis sells about half of what it has bought and improved.
"We've carved a niche for ourselves," said Jonathan G. Davis, 48, founder and chairman of the company, "as value-added investors with a long-term view and long-term equity capital available to us." Mr. Davis calls himself "a bootstrap entrepreneur," having jumped into real estate right out of Brandeis University with the purchase of a two-family house in Boston.
"Our 50-50 strategy about buy versus hold has been a great approach," he said, "generating operating capital and a hedge against inflation and market downturns. We're encouraged by the fact that there is so little new supply and sources of capital are relatively disciplined."
Anthony Malkin, president of W&M, which has the same general philosophy as Davis, said: "We pursue the properties we want aggressively, but we are not simply accumulating square footage. We produce a consistent package of amenities: conference rooms, fitness centers, dining facilities and locations near mass transportation. I have a high regard for Davis, and have no problem with their doing the same thing. Private, well-capitalized ownership is good for the real estate market."
W&M, the suburban arm of Wien & Malkin, a fourth-generation family-owned investment, management and development company in Manhattan, has 2.5 million square feet of office, retail and residential properties in Westchester and Fairfield Counties. Wien & Malkin has 8.5 million more square feet in Manhattan, plus divisions operating out of eight offices around the country and in Europe. 
Comparatively a fledgling, the Davis Companies has 4.5 million square feet of office, retail and residential properties in Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New York, Pennsylvania, Texas and Connecticut. 
"The Malkins," said David P. Fiore, 44, senior vice president in charge of Davis's Connecticut properties, "are our closest competitor. We have nothing but admiration for them. Every property they bought we would have bought. We are constantly searching for properties and negotiating for them, and our finished product must meet Class A standards." As many amenities as are appropriate are provided, and locations are sought near public transportation. 
Mr. Marcus, who joined the Davis Companies in 1992, said, "We made a strategic decision to invest in the central Fairfield County-Route 7 corridor versus going into Stamford." The reasons he cited were land available for new homes, the highly rated Wilton and Weston schools, top executives living in Weston, Wilton and New Canaan, and the reverse commute from New York, White Plains and Stamford.
IN 1998, Davis bought 200 Connecticut Avenue (Route 1) in Norwalk, a former Purdue Pharma headquarters now leased to Cendant, and in 1999 it acquired the vacant former Emery Freight building on Route 7 next to the Wilton station and town center. Badly neglected, it was gutted and rebuilt with the addition of a small day care center. It is occupied by Commonfund, a nonprofit institutional money management firm. Davis continues to own both buildings.
Acquisition and transformation of the 33-acre Perkin-Elmer site at 50 Danbury Road (Route 7) in Wilton from its use as a manufacturer of analytical instruments to upscale offices will cost the Davis Companies an estimated $90 million. Its first tenant, A.I.G. Financial Products, a subsidiary of American International Group, has signed a long-term lease for 65,584 square feet. 
Once the remaining Perkin-Elmer employees move out next month, renovation of 260,000 square feet in two brick buildings and construction of an additional 200,000 square feet in two new buildings will begin. The existing cafeteria, 150-seat auditorium, fitness center, outdoor tennis court, volleyball and basketball courts, picnic groves, and jogging-walking trails will be upgraded, and extensive landscaping is under way along the Route 7 frontage, where the company is installing a landscaped 800-foot-long walkway for the public.
In 1999, Perkin-Elmer sold its analytical instrument business and its name to EG&G, a government contractor that changed its name to PerkinElmer Instruments, in Shelton. Perkin-Elmer's life sciences division, based in Foster City, Calif., and its applied biosystems division, based in Rockville, Md., is now called Applera and will move with 130 employees from the Wilton headquarters to the 1.2 million-square-foot Merritt 7 Corporate Park in Norwalk.
About 155,000 square feet of office space at 50 Danbury Road will be available in the fall, Mr. Fiore said, and rents will be at market rates for the area, $30 to $35 a square foot annually, compared with $40 to $45 in Stamford. 
New construction on Route 7 in Norwalk has begun at Merritt 7 on a 255,000-square-foot building at the southern end of its string of five buildings. Building and Land Technologies of Wilton recently completed a 235,000-square-foot conversion of a former Caldor's into offices called Merritt on the River and expects to start work on a new 350,000-square-foot building next to Merritt 7 this month. 
The central Fairfield County market, which includes Norwalk, Wilton, Darien, Weston, New Canaan and Westport, has the potential for adding three million to four million square feet of commercial real estate in the next few years, according to area brokers. Estimates by realty brokerages of current office inventory range from 5.6 million to 8.7 million square feet. The consensus is that growth is migrating east and north of Stamford and Greenwich, to areas where costs are lower and properties available. 
There are always the caveats that zoning restrictions will forbid knocking down an existing building to put up a bigger one, or new construction, renovations and additions will be rejected under zoning regulations. And a town can use its regulations to discourage a developer from pursuing approval of a project in the first place.
In the current uncertain economic climate, brokers are reluctant to talk about market activity for fear of upsetting potential deals. Some say the impact so far has been minimal, others feel that it has become difficult for corporate chiefs to make commitments and still others see slowdowns to dead stops, prompting some owners to increase work allowances and free rent to attract new tenants. 
Central Fairfield County towns, usually conservative about development, have little left to develop. "Weston has no space," said Jeffrey Dunne, senior vice president of investments at CB Richard Ellis in Stamford. "New Canaan, Darien and Westport have very little. Only Norwalk and Stamford are pro-development. Wilton is more neutral. It wants quality and will work with you to get it -- the kind of thing Davis does."

HEADLINE: Seattle Journal; 
The Boom Is Over. Need Furniture?

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, April 21 

 BODY:
A small but telling detail of Seattle's turbulent economy can be found in the changing fortunes of Buff Winderbaum, the owner of Ducky's Office Furniture. 
 A year and a half ago, high-style furniture favored by fledgling Internet companies was flying out the door of Ducky's huge warehouse here, near an entrance to the Interstate. 
 "People weren't even asking about the price," Mr. Winderbaum recalled nostalgically. "They were dealing with O.P.M. -- other people's money -- and the question was never how much it cost. It was always like: 'Can I get the furniture by Monday? I've got 35 people starting on Monday, I've got to get it by Monday.' " 
But these days, with companies closing and downsizing in Seattle and throughout the high-tech corridor of its eastern suburbs, the furniture is headed the other way, back to Ducky's. Mr. Winderbaum's warehouse is crammed with the stuff, so much that he is giving much of it away. 
"I can't even keep up with my voice mail anymore, and it's almost all people wanting to sell," Mr. Winderbaum said. 
And indeed, his mailbox -- "You have 83 new messages and 151 saved messages," the female voice informed him -- was full of offers to sell.
"We're a dot-com that was not able to make it," said a man calling from south King County. "We were an office of 10 people or so, and we have a lot of furniture I'd like to sell. We really need to talk."
A man calling from north Seattle said: "I've got three trailers worth of good, solid office furniture. I'm sure we can strike just one heck of a deal."
From Bellevue, just across Lake Washington from Seattle, came a woman offering to sell seven U-shaped executive desks, 14 chairs and "12 of those divider thingies," evidently the partitions between computer work stations.
"They're all in great shape," she said, "just a little under a year old."
And from this man, who did not give his location but spoke with a familiarity indicating he had once been a big customer of Ducky's: "We've recently gone through a downsizing, kind of a consolidation. We have several articles of office furniture that we are willing to sell. Could you give me a heads-up on whether you're interested or not?"
But the problem is that Mr. Winderbaum is not really looking to buy. 
"I've got 17 storage trailers full of this stuff," he explained. "I've just got literally no place to put it." 
There are other signs of a cooling of Seattle's once white-hot economy. Real estate agents say lease prices are dropping in at least some parts of the area, and architects who were once busy designing stylish offices for new Internet companies say business has fallen off.
Some caterers also detect a downturn, and less lavish budgets for their remaining customers, although Terry Patton, the owner of Espresso Elegance Catering, said he was still doing a great business, wheeling in carts of the speciality coffee and pastries that many Internet companies provide their employees. 
"We still do a ton of that," Mr. Patton said. "These companies see it as a very valuable part of their budget. They seem to want this coffee available, so their employees are not having to take the time to go out to a Starbucks."
The downturn is not bad news for bargain hunters like Dora Lee, a student who drove up from Olympia. For Ms. Lee, Ducky's is the place to be. 
"I heard there were some good prices because of all the dot-coms closing down," she explained, as she and a friend maneuvered a desk chair and a receptionist's chair -- $5 apiece -- into her car. 
Mr. Winderbaum said the furniture glut was good for some nonprofit groups in town, because he was helping to arrange for much of the equipment to be given away as charitable contributions.
Things are busy at Ducky's, even more so since the store was mentioned in a recent article in The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, which in turn prompted a local television news report. "It was like a four-minute infomercial for Ducky's," marveled Mr. Winderbaum, a gregarious man with curly salt-and-pepper hair and a dark green shirt with a duck logo.
Still, that does not mean Ducky's is making a lot of money. It pains Mr. Winderbaum to slash prices, and to tell callers that their trendy furniture is not worth very much these days. 
"I have to go through this speech," he said. "I say the market is inundated with furniture right now, and dealers won't give you anything near what you think. It's only worth what you can find someone to pay for it. Try to find a buyer, and eliminate the middle man if you can. 
"I would tell my best friend the same thing."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Still Hearing 'I Quit' at Work

BYLINE:  By Aaron Donovan

 BODY:
Even with a slowing economy, many businesses are having trouble retaining skilled workers. A survey of 273 companies conducted by Manchester Inc., a career management consulting firm in Jacksonville, Fla., showed that half reported higher employee turnover in 2000. 
And one-third reported that their retention methods were failing.
 Valued employees most apt to leave were predominantly in sales, marketing, customer service and support staff areas, the survey showed. More companies are using financial incentives -- greater pay, benefits, tuition reimbursement and profit-sharing -- to keep employees where turnover is highest. 
 Some are throwing in other inducements, too. Fifty-eight percent of respondents allow a casual dress code, for example, compared with 38 percent in the previous survey three years ago.
Sal Vittolino, a spokesman for Manchester, said the recent spate of layoff announcements and job cutbacks did not detract from the findings of the survey, which was conducted from May to September last year as the economy already was slowing.
"I think it's still a problem to recruit and retain front-line employees," he said.
 Aaron Donovan

HEADLINE: Sitting Pretty: How Baby Bells May Conquer Their World 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL

 BODY:
HERE is what the United States telecommunications industry may well look like in 2004:
 Of the Baby Bell local phone carriers, once seven in number, three remain -- Qwest Communications, SBC Communications and Verizon Communications -- and they are by far the most powerful and important communications companies in the nation. The corporations once known as long-distance carriers, like AT&T, are shells of their former selves. 
 Only 15 percent of the nation's roughly 110 million households have switched their local phone service to a new competitor. But the Bells, which now sell long-distance services in three dozen states, control half of the consumer long-distance market. 
WorldCom, a highflier once worth more than $150 billion, now belongs to one of the Bells, making that company a major force in the business services market. Sprint was acquired by another Bell, or perhaps by a foreign carrier, but only after spinning off its wireless or local phone operations.
One of the Bells tried to acquire AT&T's core business services operation, but was thwarted by regulators. Global Crossing and Level 3 Communications, meanwhile, merged after a titanic clash of egos. Nextel, the big independent wireless carrier, was acquired, too. Only AT&T Wireless and VoiceStream remain as major competitors to the Bells' wireless operations.
The nation is truly wired. Eighty percent of homes have Internet access, and half of those have traded analog modems for high-speed broadband connections. AT&T's consumer operation limps along, having bought Earthlink, the big Internet service provider, though regulators required some spinoffs before allowing that deal. AT&T and the Bells have worked out the kinks in digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., technology, and have split the residential broadband market with the major cable companies.
Satellite carriers continue to sign up households for television service, but they have not made much of a dent in the consumer high-speed Internet market.
Adjusted for inflation, local phone rates in most of the country are barely below where they were in 1984, when the original American Telephone and Telegraph Company was broken up. Nonetheless, Ivan G. Seidenberg, Verizon's chairman, and his Bell counterparts have a new reason to be concerned . . .
Prediction is a risky business. But even if some details change, this is hardly the vision that communications-minded legislators, investors, analysts or executives had in mind when the much-ballyhooed Telecommunications Act of 1996 became law.
By now, and certainly by 2004, AT&T, as well as the company once called MCI and perhaps even Sprint, were expected to be significant forces in local communications markets across the country. New communications companies, lots of them, were supposed to be bringing smiles to both investors and consumers by delivering innovative bundles of services, worrying the old carriers and stealing their customers.
Many people thought that cable companies would be offering local phone service broadly, even as phone companies would be offering television service, adding choices and driving down prices in both markets. The Internet, or at least wireless technology, was supposed to threaten the traditional telecommunications oligopolists with irrelevance.
Consumers were supposed to be able to choose from many new local carriers, leading to better service and lower prices.
Little of that has happened. The Bells -- the race's tortoises -- have won.
The 1996 law was supposed to open wide new vistas of competition in formerly closed communications markets. Instead, the last five years in the communications services industry, whose sales now total more than $200 billion a year, are essentially a story of how competition exploded in a handful of areas -- but left broad sections of the industry, largely the ones that consumers interact with and spend money on every day, almost as cloistered as they had ever been.
But the industry has become a jungle, with companies crawling all over one another in a search for profits. During the last five years, new local communications carriers have raised and invested more than $50 billion. Communications carriers over all have raised about $177 billion, according to Thomson Financial. Now, many if not most of the new companies are in financial trouble and the stocks of many, young and old, have tumbled. Most of the new entrants have had trouble making money. Some are even seeking bankruptcy protection, including, just last week, Winstar Communications.
Still, it would be simplistic to say that the communications act has failed. The billions of dollars of new capital flowed exactly where the contours of the law and of the communications market itself directed them.
Looking at how the industry evolved and why it evolved as it did yields essential lessons about the nature of the communications business, lessons that can help one understand what may be yet to come.
Long-term success in the telecommunications business is built on two pillars: control of networks and relationships with customers. But not all networks or customer relationships are equal.
The importance of a company's owning its own network began to emerge as a fundamental driving force in the communications business soon after the old AT&T broke itself up under pressure from the Justice Department in 1984.
AT&T, as the owner of essentially the only national long-distance network, was forced to sell wholesale long-distance access to upstarts like MCI and the venture that became Sprint. Nonetheless, MCI and Sprint realized that they had to build their own networks to generate sustainable profits. The issue was almost purely financial, not technical. With the right upgrades, AT&T's network would have been more than capable of carrying all of the companies' traffic.
New national long-distance networks do not come cheap, and they require much engineering talent. But the process is relatively straightforward: cobble together rights of way from railroads, pipeline companies, highway authorities and other property owners if necessary and bury fiber optic lines as fast as possible.
To be effective, a long-distance network basically has to connect to only a single point in each market it serves. In Manhattan, for instance, many major domestic long-distance networks meet on Hudson Street. There, they exchange traffic with one another and hand off calls to local carriers to be "terminated" at their destinations.
From 1984 to 1996, however, the Bell companies retained a vise-like grip on most local communications markets because, unlike AT&T, they were not required to share their networks with other companies.
And local networks are far more complicated -- and expensive -- to build and maintain than long-distance networks. Replicating a Bell company's local network would require running wires along every single street in a city or town and into almost every single home and office building.
"The local market is very capital intensive, and there are very high barriers to entry," said Daniel P. Reingold, head communications analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston and one of the only prominent Wall Street analysts who remained focused on fundamentals during the overheated 1990's. "In the long-distance industry, by contrast, the barriers to entry are much lower and so the number of players is much higher."
THOSE realities did not discourage new companies from entering the local communications business. But they did force them to focus, and not on consumers. When a handful of companies, led by MFS Communications and Teleport Communications Group, began to build new local fiber optic networks in the late 1980's and early 90's, they increased their chances of financial success by aiming almost entirely at downtown areas and business customers. One business might spend thousands of dollars a month on communications; many households do not spend even $100.
Running fiber optic lines directly into office buildings made a lot of sense, as things turned out. The communications carriers that jumped early into the market built valuable assets that were later snapped up by long-distance companies trying to reduce their reliance on the Bells. MFS agreed to be acquired by WorldCom in 1996 for about $12 billion. Teleport agreed to be acquired by AT&T in 1998 for $11.3 billion.
By 1994 and 1995, when the Telecommunications Act was being hammered out, long-distance competition had clearly become a big success. Hundreds of companies -- a handful with their own networks, most reselling the use of others' networks -- had entered the market, driving down prices and expanding choices.
But there was still almost no local communications competition, and rates had risen with inflation. A relative handful of business customers were being courted by new companies, but the vast majority of consumers and companies still had no choice in local service.
So Congress set out to replicate the success of long-distance competition in local markets.
Because it was basically impossible for anyone, even AT&T, to fully reproduce the local networks that the Bells had built with monopoly profits over many decades, lawmakers took a different course. They decided to require the big local phone companies to open their networks. The Bells were forced to sell access to pieces of their networks to other companies. If a new company wants to lease the use of a copper wire into a certain home or business, the local Bell company must agree to negotiate such a lease.
In return, the Bells won their long-awaited path into the long-distance market.
After much wrangling among companies and lawmakers, the communications act said the Bells could offer long-distance service when they convinced the Federal Communications Commission that they had met a checklist of technical requirements for opening their systems. No actual competition, however, was required -- and relatively little has materialized.
So far, the Bells have been allowed to sell long-distance service in five states: Kansas, Massachusetts, New York, Oklahoma and Texas. Most people in the communications business expect the Bush administration to open the floodgates for the rest of the country.
The economics of long distance enticed other new entrants, too. Bernard J. Ebbers, perhaps the most successful communications entrepreneur of the last two decades, had built WorldCom into a long-distance powerhouse, generating huge returns for investors by growing fast while keeping costs low. Eager for similar successes, Wall Street financed the construction of at least four new national long-distance networks by at least four new companies: Qwest, Level 3, IXC (now part of Broadwing) and 360networks. Other companies like Frontier Communications, which was acquired by Global Crossing, put together networks using pieces from other companies in addition to their own construction.
In local markets, meanwhile, Wall Street financed dozens, if not hundreds, of new companies, too. And almost all of them concentrated on serving big-spending business customers (the lone significant exception being the RCN Corporation). In most of the nation, local residential phone rates are artificially low, subsidized by rates for business customers that are artificially high. That system encouraged new carriers to "cherry pick" business customers while ignoring consumers.
Somewhat mindful that sustainable profits rest on network ownership, most of these new local carriers built parts of networks. They bought switches, in huge amounts, from companies like Lucent and Cisco Systems. They bought billing systems from companies like Convergys. But very few built end-to-end networks including local fiber optic lines, and most remained to some extent dependent on the Bells. The ability of new carriers to buy access to many parts of the Bells' systems may have even discouraged them from building more extensive networks of their own.
For the carriers, in both long-distance and local business markets, freedom has proved disastrous.
THE original Big Three long-distance carriers -- AT&T, MCI and Sprint -- were already fierce competitors in the long-distance market. As new companies, particularly Qwest, entered that market, rates plummeted even faster. Five years ago, few consumers blinked at paying 20 cents a minute for daytime long-distance calls. Now, rates below 10 cents a minute, 24 hours a day, are common. Just as damaging, price competition in the business long-distance market has become ruinous.
"The long-distance companies have been losing power hourly since 1984, and the local carriers have been gaining power," said Howard Anderson, founder of the Yankee Group, a technology and communications research firm in Boston. "As soon as we did the telecom act, that was the death knell for the long-distance business."
At the same time, the dozens of new companies serving businesses' local needs were also forced to slash prices, simply to generate some return on their billions of dollars of freshly raised capital. With margins thin even at the outset, companies like ICG and E.spire have filed for bankruptcy protection. And more are expected.
In this environment, only the Bells have been sitting relatively pretty, enjoying their bastion of local residential services, even if their growth has been slowed by the economic downturn. Just 17.5 percent of the local lines for big businesses were served by new carriers at the end of last June, according to the most recent F.C.C. data. For residences and small business, the comparable figure was only 3.2 percent.
Even the big companies that tried to crack local residential markets by using pieces of the Bells' network, like MCI and AT&T, found it tough to make money.
That is why, in 1998, AT&T changed strategies and started buying cable systems. Two years later, AT&T had spent about $90 billion acquiring Tele-Communications Inc. and the MediaOne Group. AT&T knows that sustainable profits in the telecommunications business are built on owning networks. AT&T also knows that sustainable profits are built on sustainable customer relationships. In the telecommunications business, a customer is valuable not because she will buy a tangible product and take it home, but rather because she represents an continuing, perhaps perpetual, revenue stream. Better yet, a committed customer is a likely target for buying additional services.
Most of AT&T's revenue traditionally came from the consumer long-distance business, and C. Michael Armstrong, who took over as chairman of AT&T in 1997, saw the writing on the wall. He knew that the Bells would attack AT&T's base in the consumer long-distance market. With continuing relationships with most of the nation's households, the Bells would try to build on those relationships by adding long-distance service to their product menus.
But AT&T could not retaliate. Relying on the Bells' networks to offer local service over the long term was a fool's game. AT&T had been soundly rejected by regulators when the company tried to negotiate a merger with SBC in the summer of 1997.
AT&T's only viable option for getting local residential networks was to acquire cable companies. Unfortunately, perhaps, John C. Malone, the chairman of TCI, the first big cable operator that was bought by AT&T, also knew it. He was able to get AT&T to agree to pay what some analysts viewed as an overly generous price, $31.8 billion, for his systems. The TCI and MediaOne deals contributed to the growth of AT&T's debt, which at the end of January stood at about $46 billion. The company's quarterly interest costs are as much as $1 billion.
WITH its vision of using cable lines to offer local phone service in addition to high-speed Internet access and interactive television, AT&T was the best hope for widespread local residential competition.
Some experts thought that cable and local phone companies would invade each other's markets. That did not happen because cable companies largely concentrated on adding channels and Internet service while phone companies gave up on television and turned their hopes to the long-distance market.
Some experts had thought that the Bells would invade one another's territories. That did not happen because the Bells knew better than anyone that profits rested on network ownership, and they do not own significant networks in the other companies' territories.
With almost all of the new local carriers focused on business customers, that left AT&T. But AT&T appeared to give up on the vision of using the cable systems as a vehicle to sell AT&T's panoply of services to consumers. Under pressure from impatient investors and board members, the company announced last fall that it intended to split into three companies with four separate stocks -- one each for its wireless, cable, business and consumer operations.
Yes, as the company says, there will still be a "family" of AT&T companies, the cable operation intends to continue to expand its telephone operations and the consumer operation intends to keep entering local markets.
BUT none of the remaining AT&T operations will have the strength that the combined company could have had in going head-to-head against the Bells in local markets.
Success in the telecommunications business rests on control of networks and control of customers.
The local phone companies have networks that cannot be duplicated. That is why, lawmakers' rhetoric aside, unfettered deregulation will not lead to more competition. If competition and lower prices are the goal, pro-competition oversight is required to ensure that the companies with essential assets do not use them to stifle others.
"Introducing competition in monopoly markets requires consistent pro-competition intervention by the government," said William E. Kennard, who resigned as the F.C.C.'s chairman earlier this year. "This thought that if the government gets out of the way, competition will somehow spontaneously bloom, I just don't get it."
The local phone companies have direct relationships with almost every household in the United States. Profit margins in the long-distance business have been sliced to the bone, but the Bells can still make money there because their new long-distance customers are already their local phone customers. It is far less expensive to sell a new service to an existing customer than it is to win over a customer with whom you have had no previous relationship. That is Business 101.
And it is probably also taught in Business 101 that markets with more competition have lower prices. Since 1984, the Consumer Price Index has risen 73 percent. Over the same period, local communications prices are up 70.2 percent while long-distance prices are down almost 34 percent.
. . . It is 2004 and Ivan Seidenberg, chairman of Verizon, the nation's biggest communications company, is nervous.
Local network ownership. Direct customer relationships. Those engines have propelled his company and all the big local phone carriers into lucrative new markets and to new financial heights.
But those same engines are strapped to another set of companies: cable operators.
All around Verizon's Manhattan headquarters, the local cable company, AOL Time Warner, is delivering consumers 150 channels of digital television, 50 channels of interactive television, 40 channels of digital music and office-caliber Internet service, all through a single cable line. Telephone wires simply cannot compete with that kind of bandwidth.
Now, after years of anticipation, AOL has announced a multibillion-dollar plan to offer local phone service over cable systems across the nation. Maybe now, the vision of 1996 will be fulfilled.

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: Who's Buried in Grant's Tomb? 

BYLINE:  By Richard Brookhiser; Richard Brookhiser is the author of "Alexander Hamilton, American."

 BODY:
 GRANT
By Jean Edward Smith.
Illustrated. 781 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $35.
 A COMMON historians' stunt is the poll rating presidents. The trinity of excellence at the top is always the same -- Washington, Lincoln, Franklin D. Roosevelt. So is the handful of scoundrels and duds at the bottom, which always includes Ulysses S. Grant. When Bill Clinton left the White House in an inky cloud of pardons, his defenders argued, and many of his critics conceded, that he was not as bad as Buchanan, Harding or Grant. Grant's considerable accomplishments and virtues are never quite enough to remove the stain that his time in the White House has left upon him. In "Grant," Jean Edward Smith, a political scientist at Marshall University and biographer of John Marshall, takes on this large and misshapen reputation, and argues that the 18th president was not only a great general and a great writer but a decent chief executive as well. 
Grant's early life forecast no great things. He was the son of a prosperous Ohio tanner, who pushed him into going to West Point, where his record was fair to poor. Grant was small and quiet -- he looked like a "slouchy little subaltern," according to one acquaintance; another called him "a man who could remain silent in several languages." Only two facts about his youth stand out. He married Julia Dent, a Missouri planter's daughter who was the sister of his West Point roommate, a sensible woman who loved him as deeply as he loved her. He also had a phenomenal way with horses. People came from miles around to watch him break colts; at the academy he rode a nasty beast that no other cadet could handle.
Grant's first experience of battle came in the Mexican War, a conflict in which he believed his country was in the wrong. In his "Personal Memoirs," he makes plain that he modeled himself after one of the two American commanders, the unkempt and laconic Zachary Taylor. But Smith argues that he also learned from the spit-and-polish Winfield Scott, whose 250-mile march from Veracruz to Mexico City showed how a modern army could cut loose from its base and live off the land. Grant would remember that lesson during the Vicksburg campaign.
The 1850's were the locust years for Grant. The peacetime army assigned him to dull postings far from Julia, where he took to drink. After one bout of intemperance, he was forced to resign his commission. He moved to the Midwest, where he failed at various commercial ventures. "He was too tenderhearted to be a rent collector," Smith notes, "and too candid to sell real estate." 
Then came the Civil War, and the world found that Grant was a genius. He went from triumph to triumph, breaking the Confederate hold on the Mississippi River at Vicksburg, restoring the Union's fortunes in Tennessee at Chattanooga and then, after being named general in chief at 41, executing the push to victory in northern Virginia. When Smith comes to write about the war, he must find a way to navigate well-trampled territory. The temptation for Civil War historians is to fall into a kind of lurid sportswriting, in which battalions "hurl" and lines "reel." Smith succumbs here and there, but for the most part he describes the familiar campaigns with an admirable chastity of diction.
Smith's view of his subject is cleareyed. He shows that Grant made a number of mistakes, from being in the wrong place at a crucial moment in the siege of Fort Donelson (only his skill with his mount enabled him to cover seven miles of icy roads fast enough to save the situation) to a tendency, acquired in Mexico, to assume that the enemy would not take the offensive. This vice, however, was related to Grant's greatest virtue, which was his focus on his own goals. "He knew what he wanted," Smith says simply. 
What Grant wanted when he went east to Virginia was to come to grips with Robert E. Lee and the Army of Northern Virginia and not let go. After the Battle of the Wilderness, in which each side lost almost a fifth of its men, it would have been in keeping with Union precedent to pull back north and rebuild before making another thrust. Instead, Grant kept pushing south -- a decision, Smith writes, that "was the final turning point of the war." President Lincoln encouraged him: "Hold on with a bulldog grip, and chew and choke as much as possible." But Grant already had the bulldog's instincts.
LINCOLN'S assassination made Grant the most considerable figure in the shattered nation. After Andrew Johnson, the first president to be impeached, finished his chaotic and disgraceful administration, Grant was the inevitable successor. We all learned in high school that Grant's two terms (1869-77) were a carnival of corruption, presided over by a clueless amateur. Smith shows what is wrong with this picture. He describes the scandals that touched the Grant administration, the worst of which implicated William Belknap, the secretary of war, who took a kickback from a contractor running a military trading post. Grant himself was always beyond suspicion. Hamilton Fish, an upper-crust paragon and Grant's secretary of state, said that it would have been impossible for Grant to tell a lie, "even if he had composed it and written it down."
Smith praises several Grant administration policies. Grant and Fish together pursued an activist foreign policy, befitting the United States' emergence as a world power. Grant put the country back on a sound monetary standard after a bout of wartime inflation. Most important, he fought to make Reconstruction work. Grant had owned a slave before the Civil War, whom he freed in 1859, at considerable financial cost to himself. As president, Grant crushed the Ku Klux Klan, the White Leagues and other white-power banditti in the South. No "associations using arms and violence can be permitted to govern any part of this country," he said. Smith quotes the historian James M. McPherson, who asserts that thanks to Grant's efforts the election of 1872 was "the fairest and most democratic presidential election in the South until 1968."
Given his achievements, how did Grant come to be an image of political incompetence? One source of his bad reputation, Smith shows, was the disdain of upper-class intellectuals, epitomized by Henry Adams. "The progress of evolution from President Washington to President Grant," Adams wrote in a famous crack, "was alone evidence enough to upset Darwin." Another pool of Grant haters was the Dunning school of historians, founded by William A. Dunning, a turn-of-the-last-century professor of history at Columbia, whose graduate students did the first studies of Reconstruction. Their work was written from a white-supremacist point of view -- The Birth of a Nation" with footnotes. Together, the snobs and scholars did what Lee couldn't, and took Grant down.
Occasionally Smith oversells his case. He shows that Grant intended a humane Indian policy, and put Ely Parker, who was both a Union veteran and a chief of the Senecas, in charge of it. But frontier bloodshed continued as before. Early in Grant's term, Jim Fisk and Jay Gould, two sleazy Wall Street operators, tried to corner the gold market by giving the impression that they had an in with the White House through Grant's brother-in-law, who was on their payroll. When the guileless Grant finally realized what they were up to, he ordered the Treasury to sell gold in order to break the corner. Smith calls Grant's tardy act "decisive," but the attempted corner was already collapsing by the time word of Grant's sell order reached Wall Street. Smith's overenthusiasm does not undermine his basic case, however, which is that Grant was a solid, above-average president, not unlike Dwight Eisenhower.
The end of Grant's life was turbulent. He tried unsuccessfully to win a third term in 1880. Four years later, all his savings were wiped out by a crooked investor. Grant wrote a few magazine articles on the war to earn some money and, no doubt, regain touch with early glory. Mark Twain, spotting a good thing, became the publisher of his "Personal Memoirs." A diagnosis of throat cancer gave Grant a literal deadline. Fighting pain and the haze of drugs, he produced 275,000 words in less than a year. Smith does little with the memoirs except to cite the praise of Edmund Wilson and Gertrude Stein. Yet Smith's book tracks Grant's skill with words throughout his life. No one, Smith quotes one Union officer, ever had to read Grant's orders "a second time to understand them."
When Grant was old and broke, he got a check from a stranger for $500, with a note: "General, I owe you this for Appomattox." Jean Edward Smith's "Grant" is another installment of the debt we all still owe him.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Lookout; 
The Peacemaker Takes Up Another Line of Work

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
JUST what is the American responsibility for peace in the Middle East?
 Last week, as Palestinian mortar attacks prompted an Israeli incursion into Gaza, the United States stepped in with a stern reprimand of Israel, playing the familiar American role of mediator despite the Bush administration's desire to resist direct involvement. 
 In recent months, most discussions of the American role have been framed as a clear choice: whether to pursue a final peace or back off and just help damp down violence. But the worse the violence gets, the more everyone agrees that nobody can work on a final peace until the fighting abates.
For now, at least, the United States can no longer consider the exalted goal of a comprehensive peace settlement that was laid out nearly a decade ago in the Oslo agreements. The real question is how to use American influence to keep the violence from spiraling out of control. 
After nearly a decade of playing grand peacemaker, the United States is now trying to simply prevent more serious hostilities, which was its main role in the region at the height of the cold war. 
"There is a real risk of escalation, even of a regional war," says Bruce W. Jentleson, director of the Terry Sanford Institute of Public Policy at Duke University, who was on the State Department's policy planning staff in 1993 and 1994. Mr. Jentleson, and indeed Middle East hands in the administration, don't think the situation is on the brink of war. But it is serious enough that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell has become the prime agent of damage control.
It is a role familiar to Americans. History -- which offers cautions against both too much intervention and too little -- shows that it has been hard for the United States to stay out of the way of the Middle East's periodic eruptions. In fact, from President Truman's critical decision to recognize Israel in 1948 to President Clinton's ill-fated attempt to rush an Israeli-Palestinian peace accord in 2000, the United States has been immersed in helping to set the region's direction.
These days, the lines that divide the Middle East are not nearly as simple as they were in the early days of Israel's existence, when there just seemed to be Arabs on one side and Israelis on the other. Now, decades of American involvement have brought moderate Arab regimes like Jordan and Egypt into a more intricate relationship with Washington. Still, America has always tried to balance ensuring Israel's security and tending to interests that enmesh America's fate with that of the Arabs: access to oil, containing first the Soviet Union and now Iraq, and, more recently, trying to bring the Arabs into the globalized world.
THE American role can be divided fairly neatly into two periods, in neither of which the United States had the luxury of ignoring the conflicts. During the Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon administrations -- from the Suez crisis to the aftermath of the 1973 war -- American diplomacy repeatedly focused on preventing the outbreak of an Arab-Israeli war or stopping hostilities before a war widened to include the major powers. 
After that, until the end of the Clinton years, the focus shifted to trying to fashion peace.
In the first period, the Americans became a critical force for containment when President Dwight D. Eisenhower refused in 1956 to go along with a secret understanding between Israel, France and Britain to occupy the Suez Canal zone. His refusal forced a humiliating withdrawal by the allies and an Israeli retreat from the Sinai. Israel took the lesson to heart and, in 1967, it waited for Lyndon Johnson to exhaust a diplomatic initiative before launching its six-day war in response to Gamal Abdel Nasser's efforts to deny it access to the Red Sea.
 SIX years later, President Richard M. Nixon's foreign policy architect, Henry A. Kissinger, helped contain the 1973 war, securing a truce that ended the possibility of Soviet intervention. 
Then, as an Arab oil embargo stalled the West's economies, Mr. Kissinger carried American policy into a new phase: the active pursuit of peace deals. For the first time, the most senior American officials engaged in shuttle diplomacy, trying to move the region toward an overall settlement through a series of partial military and political agreements. These led the way for President Jimmy Carter to obtain the Camp David peace treaty between Egypt and Israel.
While the commitments Washington made to support Camp David have continued, at times the United States has seemed less certain about its willingness to stay involved in Middle East crises, sometimes paying a penalty when the region interpreted its actions as retreat -- as when American troops left Beirut in the wake of a 1983 bombing that killed 241 servicemen.
More recently, Ambassador April Glaspie's failure to be tough with Saddam Hussein at a critical moment in 1990 was interpreted as sheer weakness by Mr. Hussein, who soon after invaded Kuwait. 
That history hangs over the present. American allies like Egypt and Jordan fear that the initial wariness of the Bush administration to deal with the Israeli-Palestinian conflict could be seen as another American retreat. 
In the 1990's, the first Bush administration organized regional peace talks in Madrid and the Clinton administration adopted the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks begun at Oslo as a cause to be nurtured to fruition. The Clinton administration tried mightily to get the two sides to implement the Oslo accord, but those efforts collapsed last summer, leaving the two sides in conflict.
There was, according to Clinton officials, a surreal period last fall and winter when the United States was trying to make peace one day, and prevent a war the next. 
Today, there is no such confusion. "In the immediate instance, we're trying to prevent escalation that could lead to war through miscalculation," said Edward P. Djerejian, an assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs in the first Bush administration who is in touch with General Powell on Middle East questions. He cites the 1967 and 1973 wars as moments when the United States failed to prevent large-scale wars -- failures he said this administration does not want to repeat. 
But others read the history differently. Mr. Jentleson cites as parallels the crises of 1956 and 1973, because the task at hand is to keep violence that has started from becoming a wider war. He sees five messages that need to be sent: To Israel, reassurances of American steadfastness coupled with clear red-light warnings on its actions toward the Palestinians; to Syria, warnings to rein in Hezbollah; to Egypt and Jordan, admonitions not to feed the angry rhetoric on the Arab side; and to Yasir Arafat, a warning not to add to the violence. Mr. Jentleson is convinced that none of those parties wants a full-scale war, but that sustained violence could play into the hands of Saddam Hussein, who may want one. 
This approach is not very different from the Bush administration's. General Powell's statement chastising the Israelis for "excessive and disproportionate" force last week was the most public face of its diplomacy. President Bush called the Syrian leader, Bashar al-Assad, and could hardly have failed to ask him to curb the activities of Syrian-backed forces in Lebanon. And for weeks, General Powell has made frequent calls to Israel's Prime Minister, Ariel Sharon, and the Palestinian leader, Mr. Arafat, asking them to temper their behavior.
ALL of this presupposes that another time for progress toward peace may come -- and, with it, the debate over how active Americans should be in seeking a deal. 
History suggests that the United States cannot afford to be too meddlesome, as President Clinton proved to be when he called the Camp David summit and pushed for agreement on the most sensitive issues on a short timetable. But the last few weeks have also shown that the United States cannot be as distant as President Bush would have liked. Now, his administration is searching for the right balance.
"America's great successes have been when we have nurtured an environment in which the parties can themselves move toward peace," said Robert Satloff, the executive director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy. This does not mean keeping hands off, he said, but rather creating what he calls a "supportive environment."
A former American ambassador to Israel, Samuel W. Lewis, has written that in all the years of American involvement in the region, there were only a few moments of American "laissez-faire." The Bush White House might prefer such a period now. But it is unlikely to happen.

HEADLINE: The World: Greens and Globalization; 
Declaring Defeat in the Face of Victory

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
REMEMBER all those protesters dressed up as sea turtles and carrying pictures of dolphins as they railed against the World Trade Organization in Seattle in 1999? Well, the W.T.O.-bashers are back, this time in Quebec, where President George W. Bush and 33 other heads of state are gathered this weekend to reaffirm a 2005 deadline for creating a free-trade zone stretching from Canada to Argentina. And once again their target is a global bogeyman that the Humane Society of the United States, speaking for animals, has labeled "the single most destructive international organization ever formed."
 But a close look at several recent rulings by the trade organization suggests that the demonstrators' wrath may be misdirected: in fact, the free-trade group may be turning green. 
 Such a turnabout might sound bizarre, given the chorus of critics who have accused the W.T.O. of favoring the interests of business over those of groups seeking to protect the environment and endangered species. And in fact its goal of promoting open trade often does clash with the protesters' concerns -- usually when countries like the United States block imports that they believe threaten the environment. That was certainly the message environmentalists took from well-publicized cases in which the trade group ruled against the United States over efforts to stop imports of South American gasoline and fish caught in nets that also trap sea turtles. 
But surprisingly, in each case the W.T.O. affirmed the right of countries to impose trade sanctions to protect the environment. What it objected to were essentially administrative details. In other words, environmental groups "lost some battles, but won the war," said John Jackson, a trade expert at the Georgetown University Law School.
In one case, a W.T.O. appeals panel argued that the United States was unfairly blocking gasoline imports from Venezuela and Brazil. The United States maintained that the gasoline violated its clean-air statutes. In its ruling, the panel's reasoning is more important than its final decision. In a huge victory for environmentalists, the panel said the American statutes posed no problem under the 1995 global trade accord, which authorizes countries to establish such safeguards. But the panel went against the United States because it said the the clean-air statutes had been enforced in a discriminatory manner by imposing tougher restrictions on foreign refiners than on domestic refiners. Treating foreign and domestic suppliers alike is a central tenet of international trade agreements, the panel said, and it called on the United States to make administrative fixes -- which it has done.
The trade organization also ruled against efforts by the United States to block imports of shrimp caught with nets that sweep up endangered sea turtles. Again, the decision found no fault with American statutes, finding that the 1995 accord even authorizes trade sanctions when, as in this case, the environmental harm takes place in foreign waters. But the appeals panel ruled against the United States because, once again, it found that Washington had unfairly discriminated against foreign suppliers and provided them inadequate legal safeguards. As in the gasoline case, the appeals panel successfully called on the United States to make modest administrative fixes.
These rulings don't appear to be isolated -- in fact, in another case last year the right of countries to set strict environmental standards won both in principle and, for the first time, in fact. A W.T.O. appeals panel upheld France's right to block Canadian exports of products containing asbestos, a carcinogen. The ruling found that neither the statute nor its implementation discriminated against foreigners.
Taken together, the three rulings embrace the principle that the W.T.O. agreement protects the right of countries to use trade sanctions to protect the environment. This was not always the case. In an inflammatory ruling prior to the creation of the trade organization, an appeals panel rejected efforts by the United States to block imports of tuna caught with nets that also slaughtered dolphins -- the opposite of the principle underlying the organization's ruling on shrimp. Some experts say the language of the 1995 accord paved the way for the new environmental thinking. Others, like Professor Jagdish Bhagwati of Columbia University, attribute the changed interpretation to intense lobbying, especially by the environmental movement. Either way, the environmentalists have gained some measure of success.
SOME environmental groups, like the Natural Resources Defense Council, concede as much. Yet many environmentalists remain firmly opposed to the trade organization. Todd Steiner, director of the Sea Turtle Restoration Project, said: "Every time the environment and trade come into conflict, the environment loses. More insidious, with the W.T.O. rules looming in the background, lawmakers shrink from passing strict environmental protections. Today it is the shy, gentle sea turtles, tomorrow it will be our forests, our right to protect children and prisoners from forced labor, and our very democracy."
Many environmental advocates want to add explicit language to the W.T.O. charter to give special status to environmental concerns. They want deliberations before dispute bodies to be opened to public scrutiny. And they want the trade group to honor trade sanctions imposed against countries that violate international environmental accords, like the one struck in Montreal in 1987 to restrict the use of ozone-depleting chemicals.
Yet the reluctance of some leaders in the environmental movement to cheer the environmental principles newly set forth by the trade organization raises an intriguing question: What would they lose by declaring victory, however limited? Perhaps part of the answer is that if the war were perceived to be going their way, they might have trouble rallying the troops in Quebec and keeping the pressure on.
