HEADLINE: Clash Delays Health Plan For the Poor 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 22 

 BODY:
A dispute between state and federal officials has delayed efforts to provide health insurance for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, and officials say it will be at least several more months until the program begins.
 Gov. George E. Pataki and his aides blame the Clinton administration, which they say dallied for months over the state's request to use Medicaid money. 
 But the record makes clear that both sides have caused delays. New York has refused to give the federal government the reassurances it demands on the use of Medicaid money. And New York lawmakers decided against embarking on the program piecemeal, as other states have done, holding up the entire effort until all of it can go into effect. 
The experience of other states, like New Jersey, shows that states can extend coverage to thousands of people far more quickly than New York has done.
In December 1999, Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders announced an ambitious new effort by the state to cover low-income working people whose employers do not provide insurance and who earn too much to qualify for Medicaid, the federal insurance program for the very poor. The program was supposed to go into effect on Jan. 1 this year, and state officials predicted that it would insure up to a million people.
The core of the proposal was Family Health Plus, which would allow the working poor to buy coverage through existing programs like Medicaid, paying much lower premiums than commercial insurers charge. Poor children in the state are already covered by another program.
It was supposed to help people like Dawn Bowers of Woodside, Queens, one of more than 3 million New Yorkers with no health insurance. She earns $430 a week at a small printing shop in Manhattan, supporting herself, her husband, Jose Quiles, and their 2-year-old daughter, Ashley.
Since a 1996 operation to remove ovarian cysts, she has suffered almost constant pain. But she has not seen a doctor or taken prescribed medication, because, she said, she cannot afford either one. "When I heard about Family Health Plus, I thought, 'That's it, that's what I need,' " she said. "But when I try to sign up, they tell me I can't yet."
The governor and his aides say the fault lies with the Health Care Financing Administration, the federal agency that approves uses of Medicaid money. "A lot of these people from H.C.F.A., the Clinton people, they just weren't interested in doing this for us," said Michael McKeon, the governor's spokesman.
But legislators and health care advocates accuse Mr. Pataki's Republican administration of intransigence. "I really have to question the governor's seriousness about getting this thing done," said Richard Kirsch, of Citizen Action, a liberal advocacy group.
Assemblyman Richard Gottfried, a Democrat and chairman of the Health Committee, said Mr. Pataki may be stalling because of the prospect of a recession and declining revenues -- a view endorsed privately by some Republican lawmakers. "As long as the program isn't up and running, that's hundreds of millions of dollars that they're banking rather than spending," Mr. Gottfried said.
The Pataki administration strenuously denies such charges. "It's obviously a major commitment of ours," said Robert Hinckley, deputy commissioner of the Health Department. "We've put a tremendous amount of time, effort and money into it. The governor has taken a personal interest, telling us to get it done."
The program's importance extends to politics as well as health care. Family Health Plus, like the environmental conservation programs Mr. Pataki supports, appeals to many voters in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans 5 to 3. And failure to get the program running could be used against him in a potentially tough re-election contest next year.
The program cemented Mr. Pataki's relationship with Dennis Rivera, leader of 1199/Service Employees International Union, the 150,000-member health care workers' union, who helped negotiate Family Health Plus. The governor would love to keep the union, which has the state's most potent political operation, neutral next year, or even win Mr. Rivera's endorsement.
Mr. Rivera did not return calls seeking comment. Other officials of the union generally agreed with the governor's faulting of the federal government, but conceded that there had been problems in Albany, too.
New York's program was to be financed in part by the national lawsuit settlement with the tobacco industry and partly by doubling the state's tobacco tax. But to insure childless adults, the state sought to use Medicaid money, which requires a waiver from the Health Care Financing Administration.
There is little disagreement that the federal agency was slow to respond. Many states grew frustrated with the Clinton administration's lethargic responses to Medicaid waiver requests, and the new secretary of health and human services, Tommy Thompson, has vowed to speed up the process.
"We didn't hear anything from them for three months, literally not a word," Mr. Hinckley said. "Then they gave us a long list of questions, and we submitted answers, and then silence again for three months."
Before granting such a waiver, the federal agency requires that a state show that the program will not result in increased Medicaid costs. The Pataki administration has refused to make that promise.
"When we first saw New York's application, our reaction was: 'Is this a joke? Did you mean for this to fail?' " said a Health Care Financing Administration official who insisted that his name not be used, for fear of offending the Bush administration.
The agency, where top jobs have all turned over with the change of administrations, would not make an official available to talk for the record about New York's case.
At Mr. Pataki's insistence, the state law that created Family Health Plus said the state would ask to be exempted from the federal requirement that its program not increase Medicaid costs. The law did not say what would happen if that request was denied, which it was.
Pataki administration officials say the state law still prohibits them from giving the assurances the federal agency sought. Health care advocates, state legislators and officials at the Health Care Financing Administration dismiss that position, saying that the state was free to reverse course once the original request was denied.
"The legislation certainly did not say that unless you get a yes answer, you drop the whole thing," Mr. Gottfried said.
New York also took months to supply Washington with financial information to support its application, and federal and state officials have traded accusations over that.
Mr. Hinckley said that talks with Washington have moved faster since President Bush took office, but that the state still does not expect an answer before summer.
One other state, Arizona, requested the same type of waiver New York did, but it gave the standard assurances on Medicaid costs. Federal health officials concede that New York's case was inherently more complex, but they note that Arizona's program became law in November, and its waiver was granted in January.
Medicaid would pay for only one part of New York's program. The state could have embarked on pieces of the plan without the federal waiver, like covering adults with children. Other states have done this, but New York's state legislation prohibited the start of any part of the plan until all pieces were in place.
When New Jersey created a similar program, Family Care, it sought a simpler, more common federal waiver. Yet even taking that into account, New Jersey moved much faster than New York. The governor at the time, Christie Whitman, signed the program into law last July, and people began receiving coverage just four months later. It has insured more than 80,000 people.
Well before the program began, New Jersey printed applications and signed people up so they could be ready as soon as it went into effect -- something New York has not done. New Jersey asked to use federal money to insure parents, but while waiting for an answer, it insured those people using state money. And New Jersey decided to use only state money to cover childless adults.
Meanwhile, New Yorkers like Ms. Bowers can only wait. "It's not so much me I worry about, it's my little girl," she said. "I've got to get healthy for her."

HEADLINE: In Some Immigrant Enclaves, Loan Shark Is the Local Bank 

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
Juan Luis, a Washington Heights businessman, built a sprawling empire of fried chicken stands in the 1970's and 80's, financing much of it with money borrowed from loan sharks at punishing rates of interest. When much of the business collapsed, the loan sharks took his home in the Dominican Republic and most of his money.
 Yet just last August, when Juan Luis needed $10,000 to pay a tax bill on what remained of his business, he telephoned two of his most reliable loan sharks, bargained for the best interest rate and arranged for a drop at one of the 10 chicken stands in the city that he still owned. The next day, the moneylender double-parked in front of the restaurant and tossed a paper bag full of $20 bills onto a table in front of him. 
 "Bloodsuckers," says Juan Luis, who withheld his last name for fear of retribution. "But everyone in the community uses them." 
This is banking for thousands of Latinos in immigrant neighborhoods in New York and across the country, where loan sharking and other unregulated lending is thriving, often within sight of commercial banks. Unlike the loan sharks of yesteryear, with links to the mob and reputations for brutality, the "prestamistas," as they are known here by the Spanish term for moneylender, often constitute a mainstream institution, financing everything from bodegas to discos for the poor and the middle class alike.
While many prestamistas lend money at illegal interest rates, some compete directly with mainstream banks. They are fast, reliable and often understanding, and in many of New York City's Latino neighborhoods, the prestamistas are the lenders people turn to first.
"Loan sharks are our biggest competitors, and they're killing us," said Dennis Reeder, executive director of the Washington Heights and Inwood Development Corporation, a nonprofit group that makes loans to small businesses.
Mr. Reeder says the vast majority of his clients have borrowed money from loan sharks, often at interest rates as high as 10 percent per week, and his organization often lends money to help people to pay them off. In a study of the Washington Heights area, Mr. Reeder's group concluded that there was a local market of $10 million a year for business loans under $10,000, and that the demand was being met almost entirely by the prestamistas.
"There is a lot of money to made here," said Tony, a prestamista who says he has financed dozens of businesses in Washington Heights and the Bronx. In an interview, Tony refused to reveal his real name.
Informal types of lending like loan sharking have been around for years, but the volume and variety of recent immigration have brought an array of new types.
Korean immigrants, for instance, make wide use of a system called kye (pronounced kay), in which members contribute to a savings pool and take turns borrowing. Some Latino communities use a similar system known as tanda or sociedad.
In many communities, the moneylenders ask fewer questions and prove remarkably flexible when a borrower cannot pay.
"These informal lenders are providing a valuable service," said Jay Rosengard, a faculty member at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government, who has studied informal financial networks in immigrant communities. "People will pay the interest rates, because they want the access to credit." 
Sometimes the lawless financial world turns violent. In May 1998, two well-known moneylenders in the Korean community were murdered as they sat in their Lexus in a Queens neighborhood. A Korean grocer who had allegedly owed the couple $34,694 was charged in the murder, but a jury acquitted him after his lawyer argued that there were many others who may have had a motive to kill.
In New York's Latino neighborhoods, some people say they are following the tradition of their homelands, where the poor often have no banks and little money to save. They say they are reluctant to use regular banks because of questions about their immigration status. Some say they do not keep the detailed financial records needed to qualify for a loan.
One major reason for the prestamistas' popularity may be the lack of success many Latinos have had in trying to borrow from banks. Jose Sanchez recently borrowed $70,000 from a loan shark to take over the lease on a small grocery store in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx. Mr. Sanchez says he was turned down for loans at Citibank and Chase several years ago, and does not bother trying anymore. 
"I don't like the prestamistas, but I use them," he said.
In the world of the impoverished immigrant, where a big telephone bill can shatter a month's budget, the speed and certainty of loan shark money often matter more than the high interest rate. Maira Gonzalez, a waitress at a restaurant in Washington Heights, recently borrowed $2,000 from a local prestamista to pay for a trip to the Dominican Republic, where her three children live. The weekly interest is 5 percent.
"Nobody wants to borrow money, but we are poor people and sometimes we have to," said Ms. Gonzalez, who earns about $250 a week.
New York law caps interest rates on most bank loans at 25 percent per year, 16 percent on person-to-person loans. The going rate among loan sharks in some Latino neighborhoods is 2 to 5 percent per week -- or about 104 to 260 percent per year.
Loan sharking in New York's Latino neighborhoods appears to be flourishing despite law enforcement efforts. Daniel J. Castleman, the chief of the Manhattan district attorney's investigations division, said loan sharking prosecutions were traditionally spun off from inquiries into illegal gambling and often associated with organized crime. Loan sharking in New York's newly arrived immigrant communities, he said, is a different phenomenon and hard to pursue.
"There is an ingrained money lending business," he said. "I've always understood that it worked pretty well. People respect the rules. We don't get a lot of reports about intimidation."
The business of private lending is also thriving despite the presence of large banks, which have made mixed efforts to penetrate the city's poorer neighborhoods. Some public interest groups say bank mergers in recent years have diminished the number of banks and the quality of services in poor neighborhoods, making it harder for people to borrow money and all but forcing them into the hands of the loan sharks.
The big banks say that they have made efforts to penetrate the city's poorer neighborhoods, but that they face formidable obstacles -- cultural and financial -- to attracting customers. Federal banking records show, for instance, that the number of bank loans to businesses with revenues of less $1 million per year in poor areas of the Bronx nearly doubled from 1996 to 1999 and that the total dollar value of those loans rose by about 140 percent, to nearly $38 million.
Another reason may be that some prestamistas are willing to drop interest rates for their best customers. Mr. Sanchez, who recently borrowed $70,000 for the store in the Bronx, got the money at a 20 percent annual rate for being a loyal client of his prestamista.
The loan sharks portray themselves as ordinary businessmen providing a service where their mainstream competitors fear to tread. Tony, the loan shark active in Washington Heights, says that he and his two partners have lent millions of dollars to mostly Dominican clients to help start area businesses. One of his biggest loans, he said, was $2.5 million to start a supermarket in Washington Heights.
"We do about eight deals a week," said Tony, dressed in an expensive suit. "Every one of them has been denied at a bank."
Tony, who spoke during an interview at a friend's office in Washington Heights, said his "bank" was worth about $20 million. He said that he and his partners disguised their business behind a legitimate mortgage brokering business, and that they reported little of the income they made from the loans. Tony deals only in cash and usually charges 5 percent a week.
Tony, like other prestamistas interviewed, said that he did not use coercion to force repayment from defaulting clients.
Instead, he said that much like a bank, he and his partners secured collateral to seize if the loan failed -- often property the borrower is trying to lease or buy. Tony said that was usually accomplished by holding the title of the property until the loan was repaid. Such an agreement may not be legally enforceable, he said, but the practice works, even if sometimes it is accompanied by threats.
"We're not going to break any legs," Tony said, "but we have taken property back."
Carlos, a South Bronx prestamista who says he lends no more than $3,000 to any one person, keeps a safety deposit box full of collateral like gold chains and wristwatches. To ensure that his clients do not disappear, Carlos says he often holds a borrower's immigration papers until the loan is repaid.
"I know my people," he said. "They get some money, they'll go to Santo Domingo, especially at Christmas, spend it all and come back with nothing."
Even with loan sharking thriving in the city's Latino neighborhoods, leaders of local nonprofit groups say they try to coax people into banking's mainstream.
Milton Balcacer, who operates a tiny grocery store on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, said he borrowed $14,000 from prestamistas over the years, and paid back $28,000 with interest. Then, in 1999, Mr. Balcacer saw an ad in a local Spanish-language newspaper for Neighborhood Trust, a nonprofit credit union in Washington Heights, from which he has borrowed several thousand dollars to spruce up his store.
The interest rates are wonderfully low, he says. "I'll never use the prestamistas again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tony, a loan shark in Washington Heights, said he dealt only in cash and usually charged 5 percent a week. Property often is used as security. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)(pg. B5)

HEADLINE: Intel Product Could Set Off A Price War 

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
Intel plans to use its newest, fastest microprocessor as a weapon against its chief rival, Advanced Micro Devices, in what could be a price war delighting consumers but cutting into each company's bottom line.
 Intel is expected today to introduce its 1.7-gigahertz Pentium 4 microprocessor, the fastest chip yet for desktop personal computers, for $352 in volume purchases by PC makers. That is less than half the introductory price of the chip's predecessor, which Intel released only five months ago. Accordingly, the company plans deep discounts on the rest of its Pentium 4 line. 
 Intel and Advanced Micro, which hold a virtual duopoly in the desktop PC microprocessor market, have said they wanted to avoid a price war. Yet neither appeared ready to back down. 
Intel said it had improved its production efficiency and would continue to pass along those savings to customers, as it undertakes an aggressive rollout for the new chip in hopes of luring PC users to replace their older machines. For its part, Advanced Micro has said it intends to match or beat Intel's pricing at each speed level at which the companies compete.
Both proclamations spell trouble for investors, who have watched the companies' profit margins as the economy slows. Indeed, in its forecast last week for the current quarter, Intel cited the accelerating rollout of its Pentium 4 line as a prime reason for shrinking gross margins.
The $352 price for Intel's 1.7 gigahertz model apply to chips bought by the thousand. Beginning next week, Intel said, it would discount the slightly slower 1.5 gigahertz version, which it introduced in November for $637, to $256. The 1.3-gigahertz chip, released in November at $332, will cost $193, Intel said.
"The objective is to stimulate PC demand and strengthen the Pentium 4 product line," said Mark Edelstone, managing director of semiconductor research for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, who had predicted the discounts. "These price points will make that happen, but there's a cost associated with that." 
Quarterly PC sales in the United States declined for the first time ever the last three months, according to market research firms. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said last week that it expected sales to flatten out in the current quarter and begin creeping upward again in the second half of the year. Intel sees the Pentium 4 as its strongest chance to tempt consumers and corporations to upgrade their computers. 
Though many other factors contribute to overall computing speed, consumers generally buy PC's based on the megahertz of the microprocessor, known as clock speed. Round numbers appeal most strongly to buyers, and Advanced Micro became the first mass producer to reach the one-gigahertz mark with its Athlon chip in March 2000. 
Intel countered with a one-gigahertz Pentium 3, but the chip's design hit a performance ceiling there. In a disastrous introduction last summer, Intel released the 1.13-gigahertz Pentium 3 but was forced to recall the line because of a design flaw. Intel also failed to meet demand for its chips, in large part because of a shortage of memory components among its suppliers.
Advanced Micro took advantage of Intel's troubles to gain market share. In the first three months of 2000, Intel held 82.3 percent of the market share, compared with Advanced Micro's 16.8 percent, according to Mercury Research Inc., a market research firm in Scottsdale, Ariz. By the beginning of April this year, Intel had dropped to 77.5 percent, with Advanced Micro holding a 20.8 percent share. 
But after a troubled few years, Mr. Ragsdale and other analysts believe that Intel is prepared to regain lost ground on the strength of the Pentium 4. The microprocessor relies on a new design, or microarchitecture, from the Pentium 2 and 3 lines. 
Some analysts question whether the Pentium 4 outperforms the Athlon, or even the Pentium 3, despite the higher clock speed. Nevertheless, Intel expects to break the 2-gigahertz barrier by this summer, when Advanced Micro expects to release its 1.5-gigahertz Athlon chip. By next year, when Advanced Micro intends to introduce its new microarchitecture to match the Pentium 4's clock speed, Intel expects to have produced more than 20 million Pentium 4 chips and switched to a less expensive memory system, further reducing the price of the Intel product line.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
A Four A's official suggests a defense for slow times; another looks at standards of taste.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla. 

 BODY:
THE 83rd annual management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, which ended here on Saturday, closed with spirited discussions of how difficult it can be to walk various fine lines: between being valued by clients and being deemed dispensable, between tastefulness and indecency, between creativity and self-indulgence and between profit and loss.
 "More and more clients are losing faith in the most fundamental principle of our business: run good advertising, sell more stuff, build brands better, make more profits," warned Brendan Ryan, the 2000-01 chairman of the association, known as the Four A's, who is the chairman and chief executive of FCB Worldwide in New York, part of True North Communications. 
 "They are underestimating the value of what we do," he added, "and focusing too much on what they pay us." 
That becomes particularly important, Mr. Ryan said, when the economic climate "gets tough" and marketers are tempted to cut ad spending, which has already taken place during the current downturn. "If advertising grows sales and profitability, why would you take your best weapon off the table when you need it most?" Mr. Ryan said. "It's like during a critical point in a baseball game, sitting down your .350 hitter and sending up a .100 hitter." 
He added, "Advertising is not being seen for what I think it is -- the single most powerful tool to produce profitable sales growth and to increase brand value, which in turn should further dramatically improve client profitability." 
Too often, advertisers will say "if we're having a good year, we'll advertise in the fourth quarter," Mr. Ryan said.
"Duh," he added. "The way to get a great year is to advertise in the first quarter." 
Agency leaders are partly to blame, Mr. Ryan said, because they "too rarely speak about effectiveness" of the campaigns their shops produce.
The industry must "work to develop methodologies to measure the effectiveness of our ideas," he said.
"As an industry," he said, "we have dodged measured accountability for too long. Creativity is at the heart of what we do, but creativity with a purpose, to sell our clients' stuff." 
Another speech focused on the issue of the boundaries of creativity in the realms of taste and decency as agencies seek to gain attention for their clients. Keith Reinhard, chairman at DDB Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, said he titled his talk "De Gustibus Non est Disputandum," or "About taste we cannot argue," because it is "very much a matter of individual choice." 
Mr. Reinhard disclosed that the Four A's, along with other industry organizations, turned down a request in July made by The Wall Street Journal, owned by Dow Jones & Company, to draft guidelines "about the kinds of things that cross the line of decency and taste" as well as to consider forming a review board to screen advertising on those grounds.
O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the Four A's, said that The Journal's concerns were prompted by frequent instances last year of "having to reject ads at the last minute" particularly from dot-coms that had hoped to stand out by being provocative.
Mr. Reinhard said that other industry organizations joined with the Four A's in agreeing "that such a plan was unfeasible." The groups were the Association of National Advertisers, the American Advertising Federation, the Magazine Publishers of America and the Newspaper Association of America. 
"Decency cannot be commissioned," Mr. Reinhard said, referring to the formation by Rudolph W. Giuliani, mayor of New York, of an arts decency commission. "We either choose to be decent, or we choose not to be." 
"I hesitate to attack my subject because so many emotional land mines lie just below its surface," Mr. Reinhard said. "On the one hand, I defend the right of anyone to say anything and show anything. I know that advertising needs to be provocative, and I freely acknowledge that the appeal of certain legitimate products is intrinsically sensual." 
On the other hand, he added, "too often, by the ads we honor, we send a message to our aspiring creative stars that is disturbingly clear," that "the more rude and shocking you can be," and the more "potty humor or prurient sex you can get away with, the more successful you'll be in advertising." 
"Taste and decency is a choice we have to make," Mr. Reinhard said. "And we can't keep copping out by saying that, compared with what goes on in prime-time television, or the movies or in the pages of magazines, we in advertising still look pretty good." 
"About taste we cannot argue," he added. "But as agency leaders, we're still on the hook for it." 
Mr. Reinhard offered five criteria by which to help make the right choice, including intent, relevance, context, artfulness and pride, as in "would I be proud to have my name associated with this ad or campaign?" 
He also called on the judges and juries of awards competitions to think twice about whether to "give the highest honors to the lowest appeals."
And he asked the journalists who cover the ad business to provide "clear-eyed critiques when we stumble into the gutter." 
Always glad to help, Mr. Reinhard. How about those two commercials your Chicago office produced for the last two Super Bowls for Bud Light beer, brewed by Anheuser-Busch? The spots had punch lines centered on the insertion of objects into the nether parts of an elephant and an annoying boss.

HEADLINE: Time Inc. Staff Adjusts Warily to Life Within AOL 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
Norman Pearlstine opened his speech at a private lunch last month for Time Inc. journalists with a joke. 
 The occasion was the Henry R. Luce awards, in-house prizes given to the magazine's reporters and editors. Gerald M. Levin, the chief executive of AOL Time Warner, praised Time Inc.'s journalism in a rousing and confident talk. Then Mr. Pearlstine, Time Inc.'s editor in chief, gave his speech. 
 Here they were sitting in the Rainbow Room, Mr. Pearlstine said, his eyes sweeping the Art Deco ballroom overlooking Rockefeller Center, and he could not guarantee that next year at these awards "we won't be on the eighth floor eating pizza." 
The remark did not lift spirits, Time Inc. executives said -- especially given the fact that the eighth floor of Time Inc. has traditionally been the gathering place for layoff announcements. And if it struck some as unseemly that the editor in chief would open an awards speech on a note like that, even jokingly, the notion of an awards luncheon that comes in paper boxes rather than on gilt-edged plates did not appear to many staff members to be beyond the realm of possibility. 
This year has been brutal to the magazine industry at large, but it has been especially tricky for Time Inc., the world's largest magazine publisher, which has not only had to flourish in a much tougher economic environment -- helping to prompt everything from staff reductions to the less draconian elimination of free Snapple at the office -- it has also been navigating the merging of cultures with America Online. 
Mr. Pearlstine, editor in chief since 1994, is perhaps the most visible symbol of the premerger world of Time Inc. Now, Time Inc. executives, avid as storefront fortune tellers scrutinizing tea leaves, are watching the moves of Mr. Pearlstine and his newly installed team of deputies, particularly Walter Isaacson, Time Inc.'s editorial director, as the company shifts strategic pace, ponders layoffs and, most important, tries to adjust to AOL's authority during an inopportune economic period, which only magnifies the rocky patches.
Merging with AOL has brought some encouraging news on the corporate front. The company reported last week that cash flow for the first quarter at the publishing division -- which includes the now more than 60 magazines at Time Inc. and the book publisher Little, Brown -- rose by 20 percent to $113 million and revenue rose 3 percent, to $966 million. (It was not clear, however, how much came from the performance of Times Mirror magazines, which Time Inc. bought in December.)
And the alliance with AOL appears to have had practical benefits for the magazine division. Jeremy Koch, Time Inc.'s senior vice president for consumer marketing, said AOL Web sites bring in 100,000 subscribers every month to add the total pool of roughly 42 million subscribers to all Time Inc. magazines. Assuming that figure remains steady, it would represent annually about 2.8 percent of subscriptions to Time Inc. magazines, a healthy and welcome boost, but a long way from having a major impact on the subscription outlook.
Merging with AOL in the current economy has also been demanding, and has some Time Inc. executives wondering if the influence of AOL will somehow chip away at the esprit de corps of Time Inc. 
"Time Inc. was always the old-fashioned part of the company, even when it was Time Warner, before AOL came along, and that was always O.K.," one senior editorial executive said. "And the mood now is that it is no longer cool to be old-fashioned."
Last month, Mr. Pearlstine -- under budgetary pressure from Time Inc.'s chief executive, Don Logan, who reports to Robert W. Pittman, AOL Time Warner's co-chief operating officer -- had to renegotiate contracts with several of the company's editors at large, Mr. Pearlstine's personally handpicked team of wideranging journalists. 
Those who have not resigned are now working for specific magazines, not roaming the Time Inc. landscape, as Mr. Pearlstine originally intended, as editorially savvy knight errants. The dismantling of the team of editors at large was seen in the company as a blow to Mr. Pearlstine's style of addressing problems by not limiting editorial budget and by drawing on a wide variety of talent. 
"I think there were some flaws in the way I envisioned the editor at large program," Mr. Pearlstine said last week in a telephone interview from his part-time home in Key West, Fla. "I think it works best if you attach people to specific titles." 
Life has changed in another way. Under Mr. Pearlstine, Time Inc. has introduced more than a dozen new titles, including the spectacularly successful In Style and Teen People, magazines Mr. Pearlstine worked on with special intensity and which have cemented his reputation as an editor with especially keen instincts in the mercurial business of start-up magazines. Now, the corporate strategy is to continue to build the company by buying already profitable magazines at prices whittled by the economy -- like the $475 million purchase of Times Mirror magazines, or the continuing negotiations to buy Business 2.0. 
"It is my observation that there is more of a bias for acquisitions and against start-ups," Mr. Pearlstine said. "I cannot myself define clearly whether that is a function of AOL and the merger or changed business conditions, or both." Mr. Pearlstine, however, said he in no way intends to stop developing new publications and that he sees special opportunities for titles that can draw on AOL's resources and users.
And Mr. Pearlstine has also had to baby sit the company's collective psyche at a time when the mood at the Time-Life building in New York is downbeat -- as it is at many magazine publishing companies, which are also laying off staff members. At Fortune, voluntary resignations have been sought from more than a dozen editorial staff members, and more are expected to be asked to resign next week. Significant staff cuts are also expected at Time magazine and Sports Illustrated, several Time Inc. executives said. The final number of staff reductions is expected to reach into several hundreds at Time Inc., the executives said. There are 13,000 employees at Time Inc. 
"It is a tougher year for us than the last few have been," Mr. Pearlstine said. "Every magazine has a different set of circumstances. Fortune put out something like 4,600 editorial pages last year, and this year it will put out somewhat less than that, so staff size is being adjusted to reflect that." 
Those adjustments have caused some Time Inc. employees and executives to say that they feel threatened by the nonjournalist culture of America Online and the pressure to meet AOL Time Warner's financial goals despite the forbidding advertising climate. One former Time Inc. executive said that he resigned because he began to feel that cuts advocated by executives from the AOL side were "eating into the muscle, not the fat of the company."
A current Time Inc. executive said that the perception at Time Inc. is that AOL executives view Time Inc. as "a turnaround operation" when it is, in fact, the most successful and largest magazine publisher in the world and one that has had sustained growth under Mr. Logan since 1993, when he became chief executive. 
AOL executives maintain a close watch on all the divisions; at Time Inc., as at AOL Time Warner's other divisions, the company's chief financial officer, Richard Atkinson, reports to Mr. Pittman on whether the division has met its targets for the week. If the division has not met its targets, J. Michael Kelly, the chief financial officer of AOL, calls in to talk specifics. A Time Inc. executive described the process as a kind of psychological jujitsu akin to a "good cop, bad cop routine" -- with Mr. Pittman in the good cop role and Mr. Kelly serving up the reprimands. 
Mr. Pearlstine said that since joining with AOL, the company's editorial vision and journalism had not changed. 
"In no way has the merger affected the commitment to editorial independence, nor has it restricted the journalism," he said. 
Mr. Pearlstine sits atop a decentralized structure, overseeing three deputies who in turn supervise the managing editors of each magazine: Mr. Isaacson, who oversees Time, People and Entertainment Weekly, as well as serving as a liaison between Time Inc., CNN and AOL; Isolde Motley, the corporate editor, who works with the women's magazines Real Simple, In Style and the Southern Progress titles; and John Huey, the former managing editor of Fortune, who now oversees Fortune and the other business magazines.
Mr. Pearlstine said he was working with Sports Illustrated and with the former Times Mirror magazines, which include Popular Science and Field & Stream. (The chief executive of the Times Mirror magazines, Jason Klein, resigned on Friday.) 
Mr. Isaacson, who worked with AOL in a previous role supervising Time Inc.'s new media in the mid-1990's, has seen his role expand. So while he has been known to proclaim his excitement to Time executives about his ability to put Nicole Kidman on the cover of People, he is also doing some of the tactical synergy work with other divisions that is seen as key to the combined company's future.
When In Style magazine executives wanted to start a new site on AOL and explore the possibility of a regular program on CNN, Mr. Isaacson made the inquiries with AOL and CNN. Because his scope is broader, his job is considered far more influential than that of his predecessor, Henry Muller, Time Inc. senior executives said. 
And since Mr. Isaacson was named editorial director of Time Inc. last November, Mr. Pearlstine's duties have also shifted and no longer include the direct supervision of Time magazine, the company's flagship title with a circulation of four million. 
Senior Time Inc. executives said that the new reporting arrangement, along with Mr. Pearlstine's diminished role at the company's core title, distances Mr. Pearlstine from the company's magazine editors and direct operations.
"My feeling is the opposite," Mr. Pearlstine. "It enables me to be involved with the things I want to be involved in, while creating some areas of responsibility for people that involve more than one title." 
He conceded that there have been stylistic differences between executives from both the Time and AOL sides.
For example, when executives from AOL and Time Warner drew up a mission statement for the joined company last year, Mr. Pearlstine said that a critical tension was the emphasis on the notion of "teamwork" in the original draft. He said that to him it suggested the possibility of a less solid line between editorial and business operations. 
"I had some concern as an editor that we want to be collegial and cooperative with business colleagues, but an important part of our mandate is to cover AOL and Time Warner, and that might be at odds with the teamwork mantra," he said. "It's one thing if you're General Motors, but this company has so many moving parts that coming up with values that are common to all of them is nearly impossible." 
Ultimately, Mr. Levin stepped in and added a clause about preserving editorial integrity -- "so I backed down on the teamwork issue," Mr. Pearlstine said. 
And Mr. Pearlstine said there was disagreement over whether to use the phrase "customers" or "readers" when it came to the audience for Time Inc. magazines. 
"Yes, readers are customers," he said, "but as an editor I like to think of readers from the editorial perspective, even if they are customers from the business perspective." 
In the final corporate mission statement that covers all the company's divisions, the term "customers" won.

HEADLINE: Hevesi Counters His Quiet Image; 
Comptroller Picking More Fights With Giuliani

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
For eight years, Alan G. Hevesi has been the city comptroller, making him one of just three elected citywide officials in New York. He has a sprawling fifth-floor office in the Municipal Building with a view of a wide sweep of southern Manhattan, an 800-person staff, a $56.8 million budget, a security contingent and a car with a driver. He has, in short, the kind of platform that should make him a visible power in the daily political life of New York.
 But Mr. Hevesi, 61, a Democratic candidate for mayor, has hardly been visible these last seven years. By design or by nature, he has settled for the side of the stage during his two terms in office, tending to his job as the city's chief financial officer, but mostly steering clear of the daily dust-ups of City Hall. He has largely avoided encounters with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, even as his Democratic colleagues have enthusiastically chased them. 
 "I never elbowed my way into the cameras. I never did the Sunday afternoon press conferences," Mr. Hevesi said evenly the other day, adding, "My job is not to pick fights with the mayor or embarrass the mayor." 
His is a style that even supporters suggest seems more fitting for a circumspect comptroller than a man seeking to become the successor to this of all mayors. And it is his approach to public life that accounts for some initial difficulties he has encountered in his campaign, particularly among some blacks and liberal Democrats, as well as his rivals, who have described him as accommodating and too conservative to lead the Democratic Party back into City Hall.
These days, Mr. Hevesi suddenly seems to be everywhere. He is holding news conferences (even on Sundays), giving speeches, broadcasting television and radio advertisements, talking tough and tussling, almost daily, with Mr. Giuliani. He is the first candidate to have staged a full-fledged announcement speech. Mr. Hevesi has unveiled a campaign theme: that his experience as comptroller, a State Assembly leader and a college professor has given him the management and fiscal grounding to succeed Mr. Giuliani.
And through it all, Mr. Hevesi is trying to force a re-examination of his own history. He is seeking to alter two perceptions that have shadowed his candidacy: that he was, by design, too kind to Mr. Giuliani, in what many Democrats view as a calculated move to win the support of Giuliani voters; and that he was indifferent to the complaints of many black New Yorkers about Police Department abuses in minority neighborhoods.
After an announcement speech in which he declared that New York was heading in the right direction under Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Hevesi has since appeared to be recalibrating his views of the mayor.
He is now forever talking about the number of fights he has had with Mr. Giuliani -- and never mind that those he invokes might appear less than titanic. (The mild Mr. Hevesi likes to cite, for example, their quarrels over the use of watershed property in upstate New York.) Mr. Hevesi was just six seconds into answering a general question about his ideology during an interview in his office a few evenings ago when, suddenly, he dropped himself back in the boxing ring again.
"I've had a couple of dozen of fights with the mayor," Mr. Hevesi volunteered, upping the number from just three weeks earlier, when he announced at a Democratic forum that he and the mayor had had exactly 14 fights, "some of them pretty nasty." By Friday, at a news conference, he had put the total at "about 25."
Mr. Hevesi continued in the interview: "One in which we had a personal dispute -- in raised voices -- the mayor wanted to do a bond refunding that would save $150 million in that fiscal year, the remainder of the fiscal year, but would have cost us $50 million extra for eight consecutive years. . . ."
Well, you get the idea.
Some Democrats argue that Mr. Hevesi's decision to start an expensive television campaign this early was born of necessity, to tamp down the whispering -- fair or not -- about the viability of his candidacy, given early polls showing him in the single digits. It was, to a certain degree, a risky maneuver given that the city's campaign finance laws place a $5.23 million limit on primary campaign spending. He has spent about $1 million on television ads so far. 
But there are signs of this strategy's initial success, if measured only by the level of concern among his opponents. Mr. Hevesi is finding his way into the headlines, drawing mayoral attacks that raise his profile and that his supporters argue help to counter the notion that he has been too cozy with Mr. Giuliani. Some polls that Mr. Hevesi's opponents used to argue that his candidacy was collapsing now show him ticking up a bit. 
Mr. Hevesi's campaign so far reflects the extent to which he and his chief adviser, Hank Morris, believe that mayoral politics has shifted, after eight years of a Republican mayor who sought to demonstrate that he could govern a city that was once deemed ungovernable.
Accordingly, Mr. Hevesi has built his appeal less on political ideology and more on the nuts and bolts of his resume. His campaign is built on the motto "most experienced, best qualified," often clunkily shorthanded as M.E.B.Q. The phrase drifts through his television advertisements, speeches and even daily conversation.
"There are some ideological differences, some differences in issues," Mr. Hevesi said of his opponents. "But I think what we're talking about is a job that involves such complexity, in technical terms, in human terms, in understanding the diversity of this city, that I really -- we have this slogan: most experienced, best qualified. I believe it is accurate."
As an assemblyman for 22 years, Mr. Hevesi led the annual debate against the death penalty, was one of the earliest supporters of a gay rights bill and abortion rights, and supported the decriminalization of marijuana for possession of small amounts. But as a candidate for mayor, his emphasis is more on the simple fact of his legislative experience: "I'm the author of 108 laws," he says. He is more likely to mention his legislation forbidding emergency rooms to turn away patients than his opposition to the death penalty.
Like all the candidates, Mr. Hevesi identifies education as the top issue facing the city. He has called for longer school days and longer school years, as well as large salary increases and free MetroCards and parking for teachers (whose support he is actively seeking in this campaign) to recruit and retain high-quality educators. Mr. Hevesi said he was willing to consider a tax increase to pay the $500 million annual cost he put on his education program, though he said he did not believe it would be necessary.
Notwithstanding his expertise in the city's finances, Mr. Hevesi said he had not thought through what programs he would seek to cut should the economy take a downturn, other than to maintain the size of the Police Department and push ahead with increased school spending.
Mr. Hevesi's most difficult sledding so far has been on issues of race and police misconduct. He went out of his way during the 1997 mayoral race to announce that he would not support the Rev. Al Sharpton for mayor, a position that many Democrats viewed as self-serving and disruptive to the hopes of Ruth W. Messinger, who became her party's nominee against Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Hevesi's television advertisements include a promise to put an end to racial profiling by the police, a pledge that has drawn a barrage of attacks from Mr. Giuliani. But unlike many other Democrats, Mr. Hevesi was largely silent during a series of incidents involving minority residents in which police misconduct was widely alleged. He was booed when he appeared in the Bronx at a memorial service for Amadou Diallo, an unarmed black man who was killed in February 1999 by police officers as he stood in the vestibule of his apartment building.
At Mr. Sharpton's headquarters in January, he drew shouts of astonishment as he sought to explain the evolution of his thinking on the issue. Mr. Hevesi told the audience that even immediately after the shooting, "I didn't get it. I got it later." 
In an interview, Mr. Hevesi said he was aware of sporadic police misconduct in the city before the Diallo shooting, but "didn't get" that it was "much more systematic in certain communities in the city -- the stop-and-frisk, the harassments and so on."
"I made a diligent effort to sort of educate myself," Mr. Hevesi said, explaining why he was more critical of the Police Department's handling of the issue after talking to black officials. "I also come from a generation, and an ethnicity, where this never happened to me. And maybe if I was 15 years younger and been at Haight-Ashbury, I would have had a different attitude. But you know, I always wore a tie."
To demonstrate his appreciation of the problem, Mr. Hevesi reverted to his role as city comptroller. "Let me be precise about what I intended and what I said," he said. "It wasn't that I didn't get police brutality. I'm the claims officer. We pay out claims -- and they are substantial."
And then, it was back -- once again -- to Mr. Giuliani, as the comptroller heatedly disputed the suggestion that his reticence on the issue might be an attempt to ingratiate himself with a popular mayor. "I've never had a meal with Rudy Giuliani," Mr. Hevesi said. "He's not my friend. He's not my political ally." 
In fact, Mr. Hevesi said, the only time he hears from Mr. Giuliani these days is when the mayor calls a news conference to denounce him. And Mr. Hevesi smiled at that.

HEADLINE: Talks Tie Trade In the Americas To Democracy 

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: QUEBEC, April 22 

 BODY:
Pledging equal support to democracy and free trade, 34 leaders of the Western Hemisphere closed a summit meeting today by reinforcing their commitment to a vast Free Trade Area of the Americas, vowing to ensure that its benefits are shared by the hemisphere's 800 million people. 
 "There's no question in my mind that we have challenges ahead of us, but there's also no question in my mind that we can meet those challenges," President Bush said after he and the other leaders signed a closing declaration. 
 The 34 nations vowed to uphold democratic principles or risk losing economic and political support, even though some participants may have trouble meeting that standard.
Unlike the previous two Summit of the Americas meetings, where free trade and economic development were heartily embraced but soon ignored, the leaders proposed "an action plan" backed by billions of dollars in support from international financial institutions. 
The World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank committed more than $20 billion to strengthen democratic foundations in the Americas and prepare for free trade despite disparate levels of development. 
The leaders also agreed to release a draft of the agreement as it stands after seven years of talks, giving environmentalists, labor unions and others who have opposed it a chance to review it for the first time.
Mr. Bush and the other leaders clearly wanted the meeting to end on a concordant note, but sharp differences were evident. And in fact a brew of street protests, domestic politics and foreign policy merged for Mr. Bush during the weekend. News analysis, Page A6. 
For example, Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada made a pointed reference to the flawed elections last year in Haiti, which returned President Jean-Baptiste Aristede to power, when he said in closing remarks, "In some countries, democracy remains fragile." 
The leaders will send a fact-finding mission to Port-au-Prince later this year and pressed Mr. Aristede to act quickly to strengthen Haiti's democracy. 
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil, who has expressed reservations about the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, did not participate in a closing news conference with Mr. Bush and seven other leaders.
And Venezuela refused to accept the schedule for putting the hemispheric trade pact into operation: no later than 2005. President Hugo Chavez said he lacked constitutional authority to instruct legislators to endorse a trade pact by a certain date. But since that same restriction applies to other leaders, he seemed to be reflecting deeper objections that may arise as negotiations continue. 
In contrast to the differences on display inside the meeting hall, Quebec itself was comparatively quiet after a night of the worst violence since the meeting began, but the police arrested more than 250 people.
But a combination of chilling rains and blistering winds seemed to keep most protesters off the streets as the meeting came to a close this afternoon. Within a few hours, the police started removing barricades.
Most of the invective poured out on the streets of this 400-year-old city this weekend was directed at the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, which would reduce or eliminate traiffs in all 34 nations, except for Cuba, which, not being a democracy, was not included. The leaders reaffirmed their support of the idea but they put forward a clause on democracy as their most important achievement. 
"Today we begin a new era in hemispheric participation," said Mr. Chretien in the closing remarks. 
The declaration signed today commits the nations to respond to military coups or anti-democratic actions, a mechanism that already exists within the Mercosur customs union of Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay.
The Quebec declaration says: "Any unconstitutional alteration or interruption of the democratic order in a state of the hemisphere constitutes an insurmountable obstacle to the participation of that state's government in the Summit of the Americas process." 
Invoking the clause could prevent a country from taking part in continuing talks on the free-trade pact or receiving support from the major international institutions.
"This is an affirmation of common will," said President Fernando de la Rua of Argentina, where the next summit meeting will be held, in 2004. Mr. De la Rua, whose country is still coming to terms with its epoch of military dictators, said pursuing a common goal of progress and the equitable distribution of prosperity in the Americas represents an unheralded step, a "continental vision." 
President Bush said meeting the hemisphere's leaders had helped him develop a better understanding of the most important issues in the part of the world he has pledged to make a priority. 
"It's clear to me that ours is a hemisphere united by freedom," Mr. Bush said. "It's a partnership that will help us tackle the big challenges that we all face -- the education of our children, H.I.V.-AIDS, protecting our environment. It's a strong partnership." 
This was Mr. Bush's first close-up view of the passions that can be inflamed by the proposed free trade area. But he said none of the images of tear gas or the powerful spray of water cannons had weakened his resolve to move a trade pact forward, nor would opposition to the deal at home.
He has said trade legislation will be introduced soon to give him the power to present a negotiated deal to Congress without the chance of its being amended before a final vote. The administration may try to round up enough votes to pass the measure by packaging it with smaller trade deals. "I am confident I will have tradepromotion authority by the end of the year because I think most people in the United States Congress understand that trade is beneficial to our hemisphere," Mr. Bush said at the closing news conference. 
Opponents say the images of street protesters clashing with the police this weekend have heightened awareness of the trade pact and will make it more difficult for Mr. Bush to garner the support he needs. 
"Regular folks in key Congressional districts who care about the environment now understand that a Free Trade Area of the Americas will imperil the environment at home and in other countries," said Daniel Seligman, director of the responsible trade program at the Sierra Club and a participant in an alternative People's Summit here this week. "Free trade was always going to be a tough fight for George Bush. What happened in Quebec will make it that much tougher." 
The meeting represented a foreign policy milestone for Mr. Bush, and a turning point in how Washington and its allies referred to another controversial trade pact, the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was started by former President George Bush. 
"When we started negotiating Nafta, people met in closed meetings and behind doors," said President Vicente Fox of Mexico. "You had a sense that people were ashamed of what they had done. But today we are proud of Nafta."
Mr. Bush and several other leaders now eagerly refer to the hemispheric trade proposal as an extension of Nafta, which has already produced results.
In separate talks after the summit meeting, the leaders of the Nafta countries discussed migration and a continental energy policy. Mr. Bush said oil from Canada and natural gas from Mexico said would help relieve energy supply problems in California and other parts of the United States. 
"It is important for our hemisphere to not only trade liberally, but to move energy throughout the hemisphere as needed," Mr. Bush said, "and it starts with the cooperation between Mexico, Canada and the United States."

HEADLINE: Green Calls for More Work In Unifying City of Minorities 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
New York City has become such a melange of ethnic, religious and racial groups that today, all its residents are essentially minorities, Public Advocate Mark Green told a predominantly black congregation at a Harlem church yesterday morning.
 Mr. Green, who plans to formally announce his mayoral candidacy tomorrow, told about 250 worshipers at St. Luke's A.M.E. Church on Amsterdam Avenue that the next mayor must recognize this reality and, in a not-so-subtle criticism of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, do a better job in unifying the city's disparate groups. 
 "After a decade of division by race, by class, by ethnicity and by borough, it is now essential we unite as a city," Mr. Green said, his notes resting on an open Bible at the pulpit. "We have to cross racial and class lines to speak to one New York."
His church appearance came on what was yet another busy Sunday of campaigning by the Democratic candidates for mayor. 
City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone made at least six stops yesterday, across Manhattan and Brooklyn. Like Mr. Green, he made his schedule serve as a tribute of sorts to the city's diversity, attending separate ceremonies commemorating the mass killings of Jews during World War II and of Armenians 86 years ago in what today is Turkey. He also stopped at City Hall for an Earth Day-inspired news conference to urge more energy conservation by city residents and businesses.
The Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, speaking at a mayoral candidates' forum sponsored by the 504 Democratic Club, a group that focuses on the rights of the disabled, talked about what he called the "two New Yorks," one where hotels are full, trash gets picked up and crime has declined, and the other where the schools are failing, health care is difficult to get and housing is not affordable, said his spokesman John Del Cecheo. Mr. Ferrer said he comes from the second New York.
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi held his own news conference outside City Hall to criticize a plan by the Water Board to increase water and sewer rates by 3.5 percent next year.
And Mr. Green, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Hevesi also appeared at the 504 Democratic Club forum. George N. Spitz, a fifth Democrat running for mayor, also spoke at that event.
Mr. Green's comments at St. Luke's, one of Manhattan's largest African Methodist Episcopal churches, touched on themes that already have become central to his soon-to-be-official campaign. He criticized the Giuliani administration for not doing enough to ensure that police officers guilty of abuse or misconduct are punished. And he talked about how a city that thrived in many ways during the 1990's still has room for improvement and inclusion.
"If you can work with me in a coalition of change, diversity and unity, the greatest city on earth is about to get better," said Mr. Green, citing Robert F. Kennedy as a role model.
Speaking at his Earth Day news conference on the steps of City Hall yesterday, Mr. Vallone seemed to reach a bit to gain his share of the day's news coverage: he held up an energy-efficient light bulb that he said could help cut electricity use and improve air quality in the region.
"If we just change to these kinds of bulbs over the next year, we would reduce the demand for energy enormously," Mr. Vallone said, adding that he hoped to introduce legislation that would give companies and residents tax breaks for buying energy efficient products.
At his own City Hall Park news conference, Mr. Hevesi said that the proposed rate increase by the Water Board, which would cost the average metered household about $16 a year, is needed only because of inaccurate budget projections and the poor job the city does collecting delinquent water and sewer bills.
In the last 15 years, Mr. Hevesi said, city water and sewer rates have gone up 251 percent, or four times the rate of inflation. And rate increases are now planned every year through at least 2006.
"They are not managing their money as appropriately as they should," Mr. Hevesi said.

HEADLINE: Biggest Obstacle to Selling Trade Pact: Sovereignty 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: QUEBEC, April 22 

 BODY:
Midway through President Bush's first summit meeting, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he was unfazed by the raucous demonstrations that greeted the 34 leaders trying to turn the Western Hemisphere into a single market.
 "An old infantryman always remembers what tear gas and pot smell like when you walk in the barracks," he joked with reporters, recalling his days as a young Army officer. 
 But for Mr. Bush's new administration, the odors may be the only familiar element of a brew of street protests, domestic politics and foreign policy that merged this weekend at the Summit of the Americas. 
The meeting represented the third try in seven years to create a giant free-trade alliance from the Arctic Circle to Tierra del Fuego. 
As Mr. Bush found, a lot happened at the intersection of trade and politics in the eight years when the Republicans were out of the White House. When Mr. Bush's father left office the term globalization had barely entered the lexicon. Nafta -- the North American Free Trade Agreement -- was still under negotiation. The Seattle protests of 1999 were six years away.
So starting this weekend, the new president found himself playing what his predecessor once called the "three-dimensional chess" of trade. He knows he must respond to the swelling emotions on the street that captivate the television cameras, at the same time addressing the fears of developing nations that the Free Trade Area of the Americas is a neutral-sounding term for an imperialist world in which the United States sets the rules and gets the benefits.
And more immediately, Mr. Bush must deal with a Congress that is so divided on trade that it is unclear whether the president will get the authority he would need to negotiate the pact he came here to promote. 
Nor is it obvious how much political capital Mr. Bush will expend on trade in a year when tax cuts and education are higher on his agenda.
Mr. Bush brushed that aside today when, appearing with several Latin American leaders and the prime minister of Canada, Jean Chretien, he made his bottom-line case for the trade pact.
In a comment unlikely to strengthen his friendships among America's European and Asian allies, he said he was focusing on a regional accord so that "we can combine in a common market so we can compete in the long term against the Far East and Europe." 
And he revived one of President Clinton's favorite arguments, that democracy and American-style capitalism are now intertwined. In fact, the communique issued today states that any country in the hemisphere that suffers an "unconstitutional alteration or interruption of the democratic order" will be banned from negotiations over a free trade area.
Turning such lofty principles into a real agreement will be a complex task. The biggest problem comes down to one word: sovereignty.
The protesters on the street had any number of complaints. Some came to argue that free trade puts the interests of industry ahead of the environment, or that it does nothing to assure that workers get higher wages and the right to unionize, or that it concentrates wealth in the hands of the rich. 
They said Nafta, which Mr. Bush repeatedly cited as the model for the hemisphere, was actually a disaster for the people who work for low wages in the factories on the Mexican-United States border and for the environment.
But among the serious critics of free trade accords, the fundamental problem is that they have no control over the forces that set environmental or labor rules. 
And they believe that they have been excluded from setting those rules, a feeling reinforced by a recent report by the Leadership Council for Inter-American Summitry, a group of academics and economists. It concluded that "the gap between summit promises and accomplishments is so wide as to have created a public crisis of confidence."
Mr. Bush said today that he hoped to address that concern by publishing the text of the lengthy document that will eventually form the basis of the Free Trade Area of the Americas. The idea is to answer charges that such accords are written in secret.
But Mr. Bush made clear that he would not be deterred, and his tone all weekend conveyed the sense that he was willing to entertain ideas about protecting workers or the environment, as long as they did not slow the pace of commerce.
"There are some people in my country that want to shut down free trade," he said. "And they're welcome to express their opinions." But, he added, "it's not going to change my opinion about the benefits of free trade."
Sovereignty, though, is not only a worry on the street. It is a concern among Latin America's elected leaders as well, and several made clear that they planned to proceed with enormous care. 
Brazil's president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, showed no more enthusiasm for a quick free trade area than he has before. His country has deep doubts that the United States would really allow Brazilian orange juice, steel, shoes and other products into the American market with virtually no duties, competing with American workers.
Venezuela's president, Hugo Chavez, a populist whom Mr. Bush approaches warily, took exception to several clauses in the communique, indicating problems to come. 
Even Canada objects to provisions that would let international investors challenge any nation's laws on the grounds that they threaten the profitability of those investments. Under the Nafta, United Parcel Service is already challenging Canada's subsidies for its postal service.
Such concerns are only going to get more intense. Latin America has made progress in the last decade, but its many American-inspired economic reforms have had limited effect. Growth has been a modest 3 percent, unemployment is up and a third of the population of 180 million people earns $2 a day.
For Latin leaders, "selling this at home won't be easy," said Richard Feinberg of the University of California, a former Clinton administration official who studied the topic.
It will not be easy for Mr. Bush, either. Congress declined to give Mr. Clinton the authority to negotiate trade agreements that cannot be amended when they reach the House and Senate floors, where lobbyists from every industry will try to reopen negotiations. Mr. Bush said today that he was committed to getting such authority this year. The 33 countries he is negotiating with are waiting to see if he succeeds; only then will serious bargaining begin.
Mr. Bush's trade representative, Robert Zoellick, wants to bridge the gap between Democrats who insist that any trade accord impose penalties on countries that fail to protect workers and the environment, and Republicans who see such requirements as a form of protectionism.
Mr. Zoellick said he wanted to include "incentives," not sanctions, for countries to respect workers' rights and the environment. That is unlikely to satisfy Congressional Democrats. But any provisions that imposes sanctions are bound to raise cries from Latin America.
So Mr. Bush is going to have to convince Congress that he is not giving up America's power to shape the rules, and convince the Western Hemisphere that he is acting as a "humble" superpower, the phrase he has used many times. 
That will take years. Along the way, he and Mr. Powell are likely smell some more tear gas.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Protesting for Whom?

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana 

 BODY:
I thought about going to the Quebec Summit of the Americas, but I lost my gas mask so I decided to go to Africa instead. It's interesting listening to Africans talk about globalization. While the protesters in Quebec were busy denouncing globalization in the name of Africans and the world's poor, Africans themselves will tell you that their problem with globalization is not that they are getting too much of it, but too little.
 That's not surprising, because if you actually look around Africa you see that the countries that are the most democratic, where the people have the most freedom to choose -- South Africa, Nigeria, Ghana -- are the most pro-trade, the most integrated in the world economy and the most globalized. The countries that are led by dictators, are the least open and where the people have the least freedom to choose -- Sudan, Zimbabwe, Liberia, Libya etc. -- are those most hostile to globalization, openness and trade in goods and services. 
 So if you were wondering why you saw so few Africans joining the anti-globalization "festival" in Quebec, it's because they understand that -- with the exception of the environmentalists -- this anti-globalization movement is largely the well intentioned but ill informed being led around by the ill intentioned and well informed (protectionist unions and anarchists), who do not serve Africa's interests. 
Last year this same anti-globalization gang, in its most shameful hour, tried to block Congressional passage of the African Growth and Opportunity Act -- a bill enabling Africa's poorest countries to export textiles to the U.S. with little or no tariffs, which is critical for creating lots of low-skilled jobs. Eventually the bill squeaked through. The early result? Madagascar's textile exports to the U.S. are up 120 percent, Malawi's are up 1,000 percent, Nigeria's are up 1,000 percent and South Africa's are up 47 percent. Real jobs for real people. 
Ghana, like so many African countries, has largely lived off aid and the export of raw materials. But for the first time it is developing an information sector to do data processing for American Express and Aetna, which is providing jobs that pay much higher than average Ghanaian salaries. "People here want into the global marketplace; they know it's the only way out of poverty," says George Apenteng, director of Ghana's Institute for Economic Affairs. "But people here are also worried they won't be able to compete and that Western markets aren't as open to what we can sell, like agriculture, as ours are to what they sell."
Which is why Jagdish Bhagwati, the Indian-born Columbia University trade economist, insists that: "The civil society groups who are concerned about the poor should actually be working to extend the benefits of globalization and freer trade to the truly poor in Africa, not denying them these opportunities. Simultaneously, they should be working for adjustment assistance and retraining for our workers, so they are not abandoned to the unregulated forces of international competition."
Face it, says Jeff Sachs, the Harvard development economist. Africans today are literally dying of poverty -- not simply AIDS, but diseases that could easily be eradicated but aren't because there is so little economic growth Africans don't have the resources. Mr. Sachs notes that one of the main reasons Africa has fallen so far behind East Asia, Mexico or Brazil is because it has been stuck just exporting raw materials, and has failed to create the legal and tax incentives to attract the global investment and factories that would create sustainable, diversified jobs. Africa's only hope is that through globalization its coastal cities might one day become the sort of export platforms, tourism and service centers that China's are today. "There is not a single example in modern history of a country successfully developing without trading and integrating with the global economy," says Mr. Sachs. 
The fact is, virtually all the leaders who met in Quebec to expand trade were democratically elected, while "the people" in the streets clamoring for "justice" were self-appointed or paid union activists. There is nothing romantic about them. By inhibiting global trade expansion they are choking the only route out of poverty for the world's poor. Which is why these "protesters" should be called by their real name: The Coalition to Keep Poor People Poor.
