HEADLINE: Mayor to Unveil Budget Plan as Talk of Compromise Takes Confrontational Turn 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
In a year in which the city's political calendar is already jammed with headline-grabbing events, the Giuliani administration and City Council leaders have begun to prepare for what might yet turn into another blockbuster: a full-scale budget war.
 Today, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is scheduled to issue his eighth and final budget plan, a $39 billion package for the 2002 fiscal year that cuts more than $150 million in spending in certain city programs while also advocating about $500 million in new tax cuts, among other changes. 
 Such a plan may well serve a Republican mayor who City Hall officials say is trying, in his last year in office, to reassert his credentials as a fiscal conservative. But City Council leaders have their own agenda in this election year: they are calling for an extra $548 million for city schools and other new spending in services for youths and the elderly, while also offering working-class voters a different and much less expensive set of tax cuts. 
Mayor Giuliani and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, a Democratic candidate for mayor, have indicated a willingness to try to reach a compromise before a planned final vote in early June. But their staff members used terms like "showdown" and "collision course" yesterday to describe the state of affairs.
Talk has already started to return to 1998, the first time in city history that the Council adopted its own budget, a step that drew a quick mayoral veto and then months of venom-filled wrangling.
"If there aren't sufficient tax cuts in the budget, I will not be able to approve the budget," Mr. Giuliani declared yesterday at his daily news conference in City Hall. "I have done that once before. I did not approve the budget, and we saved more money that year than any year that I was the mayor. So from my point of view that would not be an undesirable result."
Such tough talk at this point in the budget process could be construed as merely the opening maneuvers for negotiations. But complicating the picture this year is the political backdrop, with some officials bluntly acknowledging that a robust budget fight might help Mr. Vallone, who is one of four main Democrats in the mayoral race. 
"We are on the side of angels," said one City Council official, referring to spending and tax cut programs that are carefully tailored to benefit Mr. Vallone's target voting audience: middle-class residents, parents of school-age children and the elderly. "Sometimes getting into a fight with the mayor is a good thing. Talk to the Brooklyn Museum."
If the 1998 budget impasse is any guide, the outcome this year will depend less upon the substance of the budget and more upon the political points the two sides are trying to make. In 1998, the mayor asserted that the Council was endangering the city's future fiscal stability by phasing out an income tax surcharge that he now likes to claim credit for eliminating. Another factor in the fight was the Council's insistence that a referendum be held if the mayor wanted to spend city tax dollars to build a new Yankees ballpark on the West Side of Manhattan, a plan Mr. Giuliani has since abandoned. 
What is clear is that the budget talks this year are off to a much more confrontational start than a year ago. Last April, even before budget negotiations began, Mr. Giuliani restored many of the cuts he had first proposed in January 2000 for city libraries, cultural institutions, parks and other programs.
Today, he is expected to back down on a small piece of his $155 million in cuts for 2002, perhaps, for example, agreeing to continue a program that provides weekend meals to low-income elderly residents. But at the same time, he has said he intends to add tens of millions more in spending reductions, citing the downturn in the national economy. 
On the tax side, there is a similar reversal in strategy. A year ago, after initially proposing a tax cut in January that critics called too expensive, the mayor in April scaled back his tax cut plan. This year, he intends to add about $180 million in proposed city personal income tax cuts, increasing his entire tax cut plan for 2002 to $494 million, 23 percent more than he first proposed in January, officials have said.
The result is that he is squeezing the Council on both the revenue and spending ends, which is not welcome at a time when Mr. Vallone is running for mayor and many other Council members facing term limits are vying for offices including comptroller, public advocate and borough president.
"The last budget that you do is the budget you will be longest remembered by, so he is trying to make sure he is remembered as a fiscally responsible conservative," said Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Council Finance Committee and a candidate for city comptroller. "But for the Council, the agenda is quite different: many of the members are trying to appeal to constituency groups that vary depending on what office they are running for."
Tensions have already been heightened between the two sides in recent weeks. Today, for example, the heavily Democratic Council is going to vote on overriding four mayoral vetoes related to matters as varied as the city's campaign finance program and a so-called anti-sweatshop law limiting companies the city contracts with to buy uniforms.
Mr. Giuliani made clear yesterday that he is willing to negotiate about the mix of tax cuts that end up in the final approved budget. He hinted that at some point, he would, as he always has, acquiesce to restoring some of his proposed spending cuts to items like libraries and programs for the elderly. But his aides were still talking tough.
"You can rest assured the mayor won't flinch first," one senior Giuliani administration official said. "It comes down to a battle over priorities: tax cuts or pork."
Mr. Vallone added yesterday that "both sides may be flexing their muscles a little bit," right now, but that he remains hopeful the Council and mayor will reach a compromise.
"Last year was a much more congenial, agreed-upon process," Mr. Vallone said. "But my major concern is not as mayoral contender, it is speaker. I want to make sure we leave this house in the same kind of order we placed it in over the last decade. I am not going to leave it a mess."

HEADLINE: NYC; 
A Wondrous Season of Announcements Takes Hold

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
THIS just in: Mark Green is running for mayor. Mr. Green, the public advocate, made the official announcement yesterday in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Thank goodness he finally came clean. Until yesterday, no one in New York could figure out what he was up to.
 Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, made his own official announcement a month ago. Yup, he's running for mayor, too, he said. Until then, no one had a clue about his ambitions, either. 
 They are wondrous events, these formal announcements by political candidates: grand orchestrations that allow the obvious to drape itself in the garb of the momentous, enabled by news organizations that make themselves eager partners in what essentially is their own kidnapping.
Before long, in case you had doubts about their mayoral ambitions, similar statements may be expected from Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, and Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president. Maybe George N. Spitz, a fifth Democrat in the race, will make a formal announcement, too. Or maybe he won't. It seemed wise to mention him if only because when Mr. Spitz's name is omitted, he is given to calling in protest. Life is short enough.
Then there is Michael Bloomberg, the gazillionaire with a fondness for slapping his name on tote bags and pocket radios. He is officially not running. Or is it more accurate to say he is not officially running? It gets so confusing. Better put him down as exploring. When you are worth more than the gross domestic product of some small countries, you have license to explore whatever you want.
Mr. Bloomberg, a Democrat who became a Republican because it was the expedient thing to do, made a small splash the other day when he told Newsweek that, if elected mayor, he would take only a dollar a year in salary. Apparently the message is that there is a communal interest in electing Croesus to high office.
Perhaps that is so. By installing Mr. Bloomberg, we will be able to save $194,999 that would otherwise be doled out to one of the other guys. Why, that is enough money to keep New York's municipal government operating for all of two and a half minutes.
Say what you will about our politicians, you must admit they are an indefatigable breed. The mayoral election is still far off, more than six months away, and yet we are already hearing the first rumblings of the next election for governor, in November 2002.
THINK about it -- a year and a half of this form of enlightenment. But then, so many burning questions must be answered that we probably need all the time we can get.
Will Gov. George E. Pataki run again, or does he simply get his kicks visiting bombing targets in Puerto Rico? Will H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, reveal what the H stands for? Will Mario M. -- oops, that was supposed to be Andrew M. -- Cuomo prevail? Sorry about that. A natural error.
While Hillary Rodham Clinton cannot be blamed entirely for the extreme length of New York's political campaigns, she did not help matters with a race for senator that, after a while, seemed as if it had been dragging on since the Truman administration.
The political season seems never-ending, not unlike the professional basketball season. One saving grace with the politicians is that they at least spare us anti-Semitic musings of the sort recently offered by the eminent theologian Charlie Ward, who doubles as a player for the New York Knicks.
And to be fair, manufactured events like Mr. Green's day in the park do serve a purpose. They give the candidate an opportunity to establish a unifying theme for his campaign and to send supporters off to battle, all in the presence of more cameras than he is likely to see until election night.
Four-word messages seem to be in this year. Mr. Hevesi's was "most experienced, best qualified." Mr. Green's banner yesterday said, "educating children, protecting families."
You think maybe they fell under the spell of "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon"?
The candidates, all of them, certainly seem to be under the influence of City Hall's present steward, Rudolph W. Giuliani. One way or another, they have tended to define themselves in terms of the incumbent: Rudy Lite, the anti-Rudy, Rudy with a smile, Rudy without the rude. Mr. Green's call yesterday for "one future for one city" carried an echo of Mr. Giuliani's old campaign cry of "one city, one standard."
"Sounds like I'm dominating the campaign," the mayor said the other day. He got that right, for now anyway.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
NBC adopts a package strategy intended to sell advertisers a spot on each of its divisions.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
A CERTAIN television network is seeking to make more "Friends" with marketers and avoid becoming "The Weakest Link" among its peers by stepping up efforts to integrate and coordinate sales of commercial time and advertising space in packages that include sibling media properties.
 Those with a keen knowledge of the current prime-time schedule have guessed that the network in question is NBC, part of the General Electric Company, which is cross-selling its disparate offerings under the banner of NBC Connect. 
 The executives at NBC have recently signed agreements, valued at more than $20 million, with four marketers, covering spots on the TV network, promotional tie-ins, banner ads on Web sites and even a contest that enabled viewers to choose an ending for an episode of the sitcom "Just Shoot Me."
That phrase might someday become the cry of NBC executives if their efforts to package or bundle corporate properties do not stimulate enough growth in ad revenue to compensate for the decline caused by the faltering national economy. It will be interesting to watch next month -- as NBC and the other broadcast networks begin their advance sale of commercial time for the 2001-02 TV season in the upfront market -- whether time and space in other media, particularly the Internet, will be negotiated to complement television schedules. 
The NBC Connect deals are being made with the Nestle Carnation unit of Nestle, the Paramount Pictures unit of Viacom, the delicatessen chain Schlotzsky's Inc. and the Target chain of discount stores. They are indicative of the increasing interest among the media conglomerates in persuading large marketers to focus their purchases of space and time on multiple properties that are tied together.
Other behemoths pursuing that goal include AOL Time Warner, Clear Channel Communications, the Walt Disney Company, the News Corporation and Viacom. That's intensifying with the slowdown in ad spending as the giant media try to sell those packages by playing up their appeal from the standpoints of efficiency and effectiveness at a time when advertising dollars are growing scarcer.
"More advertisers and agencies are talking about one-stop shopping," said Keith Turner, president for sales and marketing at the NBC-TV Network unit of NBC in New York. "We're trying to sell across a number of platforms instead of talking to different people about network, cable, Internet."
The packaging strategy works, he added, "only if it makes sense and there's a fit" among the disparate elements, otherwise "if we're trying to force inventory on someone who doesn't need it, we'll lose ground."
That perspective was echoed by the marketers as well.
"It has to be a win-win for everybody," said Arthur Cohen, president for worldwide marketing at Paramount in Los Angeles. "It's not more complicated than that."
Paramount is buying what Mr. Cohen described as "an explosive combination of assets" through NBC Connect, centered on the network's coverage of the National Basketball Association playoffs. The intent is to build interest among younger men in "Tomb Raider," the action film starring Angelina Jolie that Paramount will release nationally on June 15.
"My job is to galvanize the country for a weekend," Mr. Cohen said. "The concentration of media tends to tell the moviegoer 'This is important, pay attention.' "
In addition to commercials during the playoffs and in other NBC prime-time and late-night programs, there will be a sweepstakes on the league's Web site (www.nba.com) and even spots running on video screens in the stadiums and arenas from which NBC will broadcast its coverage.
"Sometimes, the announcers get so excited, they start to talk about it," Mr. Cohen said, laughing. "Nobody can tell them to do it."
Generating talk was the idea behind the Schlotzsky's deal, which involved sending viewers of "Just Shoot Me" to a Web site where they could pick one of three endings for an episode that ran on March 29.
"We will do this again," said Karl Martin, senior vice president for marketing strategies at Schlotzsky's in Austin, Tex., because "we don't want to run just a schedule" of only TV commercials.
"Everybody knows how difficult it is to reach your target market today," he added. "If you don't explore these relationships and look at other marketing opportunities, e-commerce opportunities, you aren't doing your job."
The Nestle Carnation integrated package, centered on "Passions," an NBC daytime soap opera, involved a sweepstakes for expectant mothers on a Web site to promote the company's Good Start Baby Formula brand. The Target deal calls for the Club Wedd wedding registry at Target to sponsor " 'Today' Throws a Wedding" on the morning show "Today," with a tie-in to the Web site of the MSNBC cable TV network owned by NBC and Microsoft.
Talk about Target marketing.
To fill in the missing parts of the packages in realms like print, where NBC and General Electric have no holdings, NBC Connect "is using outside partners to embellish our offerings," said Ed O'Connell, vice president for marketing at the NBC-TV Network. For instance, there are strategic alliances with InStyle and People magazines, part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner, for programs on NBC and MSNBC.
"Marketers realize they need to hit consumers on multiple platforms," said Marianne Gambelli, executive vice president for sales at the NBC-TV Network.
One platform they will not need to hit is the NBC Internet portal known as NBCi (www.nbci.com), which will be shut down as NBC scales back its ambitious cyberspace plans in the face of the drastic cutback in online advertising. The NBC Connect deals that had offered NBCi as an element will be reconfigured, Mr. O'Donnell said, to offer the Web site run by NBC Entertainment (www.nbc.com).
That's logical. After all, when people hear "i," they think of CBS.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 26, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about efforts by NBC to package sales of commercial time and advertising space across different media properties, gave an incorrect surname at one point for the vice president for marketing at NBC-TV. He is Ed O'Donnell, not O'Connell.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEXT; 
Motion Sensors May Let Everyday Appliances Do More

BYLINE:  By IAN AUSTEN 

 BODY:
ACCELEROMETERS were once arcane devices used by engineers to measure stress and strain on moving aircraft or the G-forces faced by race car drivers. 
 The air bag changed all that. Now even minivans creeping through rush-hour traffic carry one or more accelerometers to detect unusually abrupt changes in motion (in this case, deceleration) and trigger the air bags' inflation. 
 Now, using technologies adapted from the microchip industry, it may soon be possible to make accelerometers so inexpensive that they will creep even further into everyday life. Imagine, for example, a washing machine that senses an imbalanced load, a palmtop computer whose screen the user can scroll simply by tilting it, or a device that will tell you whether a shipping company has really handled your fragile package with care. 
"We now have ways to very cheaply measure the motion of just about anything you want," said Dr. Michael Gaitan, the project leader for microelectromechanical systems, or MEMS, at the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Gaithersburg, Md. 
Even the most sophisticated accelerometers share much in common with what is perhaps the simplest version: a weighted string hanging from a protractor. Inside an accelerating car, the string will swing to the rear as the car speeds off, and it will swing forward when the brakes are applied. The protractor measures the angle through which the string moves as the car accelerates or slows down, and that angle is used to calculate the force of gravity, or G-force, on the driver and passengers. 
Since weighted strings have obvious shortcomings in real-life devices -- like airbag triggers -- sophisticated accelerometers measure the deflection of materials like piezoelectric crystals, which produce electricity when they are bent. In an accelerometer, the crystals are positioned so that acceleration or deceleration puts pressure on them, causing them to bend. 
Greater acceleration or deceleration increases the G-force and causes the crystal to produce more electricity. Microprocessors amplify the electricity and measure it to calculate the G-force. 
Although piezoelectric accelerometers are highly accurate and reliable, they are not for "around the house" use. One installed in a washing machine, for example, could cost more than the washing machine itself. To create low-cost accelerometers for airbags and other uses, Analog Devices, a company based in Norwood, Mass., that makes about 700,000 accelerometers a week, turned to the same photo-etching technology used to create microchips. The company builds up a chip by etching layer after layer of silicon. The result is an extremely small variation of the string and weight. 
At the heart of this tiny accelerometer chip is a microscopic weight of about 0.07 micrograms suspended on springs that are even smaller. The weight has several tiny projections that carry a small electrical charge. Two fixed sensor plates sitting on the base of the chip measure changes in the electrical field as acceleration shifts the spring-loaded weight. Circuits in the chips either translate the result into a G-force or send a command to, say, activate an air bag. 
Christophe Lemaire, an engineer and the product marketing manager for the division of Analog Devices that makes accelerometers, said that the devices cannot be produced as inexpensively as less exotic chips because there are many, many more steps involved in fabrication. 
The company's accelerometers sell in bulk for about $4 each. That is no problem for the makers of airbag systems -- who are by far the biggest purchasers -- and far cheaper than a piezoelectric crystal device. But Mr. Lemaire said that the cost is still about twice what home appliance makers are willing to pay to create washing machines that can sense when their loads are off balance and adjust their spin cycles. With new materials and production techniques, Mr. Lemaire said, his company will be able to reduce prices. 
But in the quest for cheaper accelerometers, Dr. Gaitan's lab at the standards institute is taking a different approach, one developed more by accident than by forethought. His lab develops miniature machines based on electronic technologies. The Navy had financed efforts by Dr. Gaitan's group to develop inexpensive, hand-held microwave detectors that could be used for setting up communications equipment. What it ultimately created, using standard chip-making technology, was a tiny heater that rapidly changed temperature when hit by microwaves. 
There was some concern, however, that because heat rises, readings might be affected by how the measuring device was held. So Dr. Gaitan's group built equipment to study the microscopic convection fields surrounding the heater. 
The group found that moving the chip altered convection patterns, although it had no effect on the accuracy of the microwave readings. But Dr. Gaitan said it was apparent that shifting a heated object might be a way to measure motion. 
"Imagine you have a candle," Dr. Gaitan said. "The flame is always pointing upwards because heat rises. Even if you tilt the candle, the flame keeps pointing upwards." But, he said, the side toward which the candle is tilted will be hotter than the other side. 
In the chip created by Dr. Gaitan's group, the small amount of heat generated by the microheater is used by temperature sensors to track tilting motion. 
It is far easier, Dr. Gaitan said, to make a chip with a microheater than one with a microscopic weight. The result, he said, could be accelerometers that are inexpensive enough to be placed inside boxes to measure the abuse a parcel receives during shipment, although, Dr. Gaitan said, "you might not want to know the results." 
The ultimate consumer use for low-cost accelerometers may be what Mr. Lemaire calls gesture recognition or gesture-based control. Nintendo uses accelerometers from Mr. Lemaire's company in a GameBoy cartridge. The device allows users to manipulate an on-screen character simply by tilting the hand-held GameBoy device. 
Web-connected cell phones and digital organizers, Mr. Lemaire said, could compensate for their tiny displays by using accelerometers to allow users to scroll up and down and from side to side on Web pages by simply tilting their gadgets. 
That said, accelerometers may not be such good news for workers. A cell phone system developed by Hitachi that combines accelerometers and Global Positioning System data can allow employers to track not only where workers are but how fast they are -- or are not -- moving.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Mother Knows Worst: Apron Strings That Bind and Strangle

BYLINE:  By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
SON OF A GRIFTER
The Twisted Tale of Sante and Kenny Kimes, the Most Notorious Con Artists in America. A Memoir by the Other Son
By Kent Walker with Mark Schone
Illustrated. 405 pages. William Morrow. $25.
 Kent Walker says he was interrogated by two detectives, part of a joint task force representing the F.B.I., the Los Angeles Police Department, the New York Police Department and other agencies that had cleverly tracked him down through telephone records. He had been phoned a lot by the notorious mother-and-son con team Sante and Kenny Kimes, who had just been arrested on charges of murdering a wealthy widow named Irene Silverman, and the authorities wanted to know why. 
 Mr. Walker, whose link to the case was already well known to the press, then explained the obvious: Sante Kimes had been calling him because she is his mother. Kenny Kimes is his younger half-brother. And as he now sets forth in a colorful guide to Kimes family values, it wasn't easy growing up in houses that had a habit of burning down (Mom had a way with arson), or watching "Davy Crockett" while Mom winged Dad with a butcher knife. It was hard to live with siblings, like a third brother, Kerian, who did not happen to exist, or to know what to make of birthdays when Mom's big gift for little Kenny was a stolen pony.
"Son of a Grifter," brightly ghostwritten by Mark Schone as a fluent first-person account of Mr. Walker's weird formative years, is not an effort to soft-pedal this family's misdeeds. It's a little late for that. Besides, Ms. Kimes's earlier conviction on charges of enslaving her maids pretty much rules out the prospect of reader sympathy. Instead, Mr. Walker explains why the crime against Mrs. Silverman, which takes up only a small part of the book, was so fully in keeping with his mother's behavior that he was sadly unsurprised to hear about it. She had, as the book explains in wild detail, been scheming like this her whole life.
Sante, who was plain Sandy Chambers growing up and later claimed so many affected spellings and pronunciations of her first name that Mr. Walker has no idea what his family ancestry may be (East Indian? American Indian?), took early to crime. Her elder son was visiting her behind bars before he was in kindergarten (credit card fraud). And he watched her try to shoot his father in the stomach when he was 7. Not surprisingly, his father opted for a less eventful life elsewhere and little Kent was soon pressed into service mixing screwdrivers for his mother's dates. Sante lured these prospects by trying to look like Elizabeth Taylor, and once gave a photo of the star to her family, autographing it "Mom."
Under Sante's tutelage, Mr. Walker learned one way to acquire a new car: take it for a test drive, then tell the salesman, "Why don't you pop inside and get the paperwork, while I practice parking?" He watched his mother, caught shoplifting by a store manager, simply turn around and hit her son in the mouth, then accuse the manager of having slugged the boy. And he watched her send him into a house to retrieve a manila folder, cautioning him to move quickly. Why? Because as Sante well knew, the place was about to burst into flames.
Amazingly, Mr. Walker's family is good for a whole book's worth of such stories, especially after Sante married Ken Kimes, a wealthy real estate developer, and dragged him into her plans. It was under Mr. Kimes's aegis that his wife began enslaving household help, first driving down to Mexico to load young women into the trunk of her Cadillac and later recruiting servants from homeless shelters.
Why? Apparently, according to a memo printed here, because "Mama likes starch on her ruffles" and "Kenny's shirts should be ironed like Papa's, perfectly." Mr. Walker thinks his mother would have made a good cult leader, and there is real evidence for that in her frightful dealings with underlings. And when he asked the lawyer Howard Weitzman, "Have you ever had a client as evil as my mother," Mr. Weitzman replied "Charles Manson." 
Some of Ms. Kimes's criminal escapades with her husband have the ring of black comedy, as when they went on a coat-stealing jag. Although plenty of witnesses saw her put her on her own fur coat over someone else's mink in a Washington Hotel lobby, Ms. Kimes managed to drag out the case, bring in fake witnesses and even step in front of a suspiciously slow-moving Fiat in efforts to avoid prosecution. 
In another attention-getting maneuver, the Kimeses got dressed for a party and crashed four of them on a single night in Washington, including one given by Vice President Gerald Ford and one given by the Belgian ambassador. When The Washington Post exposed them as frauds, Sante simply tried to hide the article from her husband until teenage Kent mentioned it ("You know, Mom, the real big one") as loudly as he could.
This book's overall effect is to keep the Kimeses' spree, in the annals of true crime stories, from rising above the grifting in Mr. Walker's title. The relentlessness and pettiness described here kept Mr. Walker's mother a small-time crook, despite her phenomenal energy. And they turned his spoiled younger brother ("Kenny, though unemployable, was an expert by inclination") into her pliant stooge. Day by day, in a family in which Kent, as a vacuum cleaner salesman, sounds like the best-adjusted individual by far -- well, it is his book -- it just took little lies to make the world go round. Like the time Sante described Kent as a straight-A student. "I stifled a gasp. The only A on my report card was in my last name."

HEADLINE: Furniture Fair Looks for Comforting Economic Cushions 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP NOBEL 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C. 

 BODY:
ON April 18, when the Federal Reserve announced its surprise rate cut and Wall Street soared on cue, few places were as joyful as the wicker- and upholstery-lined streets of this one-note Piedmont town.
 The news came on the eve of the semiannual International Home Furnishings Market here, just as 80,000 wholesale buyers and sales representatives began jostling through 10 million square feet of furniture and accessories showrooms, signing the deals that will determine which love seats, wall units and dinette sets will land in stores this fall. 
 Elsa Klensch, the fashion commentator, was flown in to rally the news media on that first, optimistic day. "A stylish home gives comfort to life," she said. "Even as the Dow and the Nasdaq rise, and plunge, and rise again." 
For the furnishings industry, whose health depends on new home starts and sales and big empty rooms to fill, lower interest rates brought a dose of optimism. But after a long, lean year, with stores steeling themselves for frugality and many of the 2,700 exhibitors trimming their lines, could the furniture companies now look forward to a market bounce of their own? 
Amid a swirl of contradictory indications, economic and stylistic, the spring market has been a study in stasis: wait and see, look and learn, proceed with caution. In short, don't look for big surprises at the mall.
While debate continues over whether the downturn is an aberration or an abyss, the industry is in the third quarter of a bona fide recession. Jerry Epperson, a leading industry analyst, said December was one of the worst months ever recorded for furniture sales; there was some relief in January; February was slow; and last month sales were "as bad as December."
Other ominous news overshadowed chipper displays of deck chairs and roaming costumed pitchmen. A week earlier, Heilig-Myers, the furniture chain, announced that it was closing 375 stores. Add to this the shadow over relations with China, where many furniture companies have invested heavily in factories, and a possible leather shortage because of the foot-and-mouth outbreak, and it is easy to see why many at High Point allowed hopes to rise with the Greenspan-induced market blip.
Still, Mr. Epperson was looking to more unorthodox forms of economic stimulus. "If you're not married, please don't get married -- two separate homes are much more important to us," he said at a well-attended presentation in High Point. "And if you are married, please consider getting a divorce."
Throughout the High Point market, which closes today, economic jitters translated into uninspired design. Thomasville buttressed its successful Ernest Hemingway collection with only three new pieces, including a bar stool modeled after the fighting chair on Hemingway's fishing boat, and a version of an existing glass-topped side table. The new table has a brass swordfish in its base, replacing a rainbow trout.
Many companies came to High Point with old furniture dressed in bright new clothes. Hickory Chair freshened up some of its older upholstery with Shades of Hickory Chair, a palette that mixes deep colors and metallic threads with a shot of iridescence.
Even the John Widdicomb Company, which often showcases boldface talent, throttled back with the Widdicomb Studio collection, five new pieces inspired by 18th-century English models. But the designer and High Point impresario Larry Laslo enlivened the Widdicomb showroom by balancing a salon painted Hermes-orange with an elegant black and white living room inspired by the 1930's designs of Gio Ponti.
Mr. Laslo was also on hand to dispel concern about the economy. "I'm not buying into this recession nonsense," he said. "We create the fear, and it's hard to be creative when you're afraid. Next thing you know they'll be asking me to do beige." 
Instead, Widdicomb will be asking Mr. Laslo to continue experimenting with 20th-century styles, possibly even catching up to the present. Robert Dillon, president of Widdicomb, said the living room represented "a bridge to where we're going" -- a place, presumably, with less chinoiserie. 
Baker Furniture crossed that same bridge with a clean but sumptuous collection by William Sofield. Even before the market opened, his designs, which marry dark woods and exotic surface treatments with a deft handling of spare, prismatic details -- call it High Chelsea Moderne -- were pegged buzz-worthy. It is a testament to the furniture's quality that it was still being talked up as the week bore on. 
A chestnut-painted bedroom (Mr. Sofield called it his glamour bachelor pad) had a copy of "The Gentleman's Companion" and a pack of Lucky Strikes on a five-leg, two-tier walnut side table. A dog collar worthy of a Great Dane lay coiled on a matching bench at the foot of the leather-lined bed. 
Among the few other wave makers were Ralph Lauren Home, which showed eclectic furnishings in unusual materials like leather-wrapped steel and shagreen (made from the skin of sting rays), and Century, whose elaborate but absurd Matilda Bay collection at last brought together two long-running trends: English country and island exotic. The result was heavy, distressed pieces inspired by the Australian outback. 
Despite the general state of paralysis, one segment of the industry -- motion furniture -- continued to ascend. Recliners were everywhere -- and not just at La-Z-Boy, where current models lack only an eject button and a parachute. Natuzzi introduced an elegant, somewhat retro modular sofa by Mario Bellini with adjustable headrests and rolling, attached spring-loaded ottomans.
American Leather introduced Style in Motion, a line of recliner sofas and sectionals for upscale consumers, and Mitchell Gold offered the Lazy Mitchell line, six recliners named for well-known sloths like Archie Bunker and Chandler Bing. They seem ideal for e-commerce castoffs, as they contemplate the new economy's future. 
Indeed, Mitchell Gold's strategy seems built around a shrewd "buy on the dips" approach. A poster in its showroom asked: "What does 2001 hold for the economy? Are the Clinton Good Times over?" It went on to exhort buyers to be brave: "We're all smart enough to ride the Nasdaq roller coaster."

GRAPHIC: Photos: AWAITING CUSTOMERS -- A salesman in wait-and-see posture at the international furniture show in High Point (far left). Natuzzi sofa and attached ottoman (top); Hemingway fish-fighting chair from Thomasville (left); Ralph Lauren shagreen-surfaced armoire (above). (Chris English)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
At colleges, as elsewhere, employers' prosperity lifts workers' expectations.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu

 BODY:
WHO says student activism on campus is dead? Students at Princeton, Harvard, Brown and other schools have staged protests this spring to rally support for better treatment of workers. But in contrast to years past, the workers they have in mind are not in South Africa or third-world sweatshops -- they are right on campus.
 At most Ivy League campuses, organized groups of students have demanded better treatment of the workers who prepare their meals, tend their grounds and clean their dorms and classrooms. Their demands point to the importance of morale, fairness and profit-sharing -- in addition to market forces -- in setting wages. 
 When Lawrence H. Summers was named president of Harvard at a ceremony in Loeb House, for example, the Harvard Progressive Student Labor Movement held a protest outside, chanting, "Hey, hey, ho, ho, plutocracy has got to go." For the last week, Harvard students have staged a sit-in at Massachusetts Hall. Their demands? That Harvard pay its lowest-wage workers more than poverty-level wages and then index pay to inflation. "Workers can't eat prestige," they say.
The issues vary across colleges. At Harvard and Cornell, minimum pay is the main issue; at Princeton, cost-of-living adjustments, casual work and contracting out; at Brown, Columbia and Yale, a "living wage" and collective bargaining.
Still, there is a common thread. "The thing that has gotten students engaged," said Nicholas Guyatt, a student leader at Princeton, "is the massively engorged endowments." My informal survey of 27 private colleges is consistent with this view: student protests on behalf of workers are almost twice as likely at schools with endowments exceeding $500,000 per student than at schools with lesser endowments, although other factors may contribute.
As far as I can tell, this movement has sprung more or less spontaneously from students across elite colleges, with little or no instigation from unions. Except at Yale and Columbia, students are not trying to unionize workers or themselves. Instead, they are seeking what they consider a more equitable division of the riches universities amassed in recent years. "This is also an issue of lack of union power," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard economist. "Students are acting as the voice of people who should have their own voice through unions."
Are the students simply naive? Do they not realize that better pay would mean higher tuition or reduced services? Perhaps, but they recognize that the added costs of their demands are likely to be quite small relative to operating budgets. Regardless of who will bear the additional costs, many students question the ethics of universities raising room and board charges while the inflation-adjusted income of the workers involved is declining, especially in a period of record endowment growth.
Economists fall into two camps when it comes to worker pay. One believes that over the course of a worker's career, total compensation must equal the value of that worker's contribution to output. If one worker is paid more than another, then she must contribute more to the bottom line. Thus, Milton Friedman declared, "To each according to what he and the instruments he owns produces."
The other camp believes that pay does not exactly mirror productivity. In fact, determining a worker's unique contribution to output is often impossible. Managers also have a desire to share an organization's "rents," or excess profits, with workers. This is why large, profitable companies tend to pay higher salaries to seemingly identical workers than do those with less ability to pay. In addition, worker effort, retention and recruitment are enhanced if workers are treated better, so employers have an incentive to pay more than the bare minimum needed to increase productivity. These enhancements, known as efficiency wage effects, cut the cost of rent sharing.
Ironically, as an academic economist Mr. Summers clearly identified with the second camp. In an article we wrote together, for example, he emphasized: "Whether firms share rents because of managers' desire to help workers or because of the threat that workers will withhold effort is an open question. In all likelihood both elements are present in most settings."
The evidence suggests there is a "range of indeterminacy" in wages. And the range is large. Salary surveys routinely find that wages vary 20 percent or more in the same occupation and geographic area. Indeed, if there were a uniquely determined market wage, it would not be necessary to conduct a salary survey; one comparison wage would do.
Different companies choose to set pay at different parts of the range, depending on their financial health, willingness to make do with high turnover and vacancies, and desire for a loyal, self-motivated work force. Traditionally, universities "try at best to be in the middle of the pack" when it comes to staff pay, said Arnold Weber, an economist and former president of Northwestern.
Universities are now in an awkward position. It will be hard for them to keep paying wages toward the bottom of the range if workers, seeing a run-up in endowments, raise their expectations of what constitutes a fair wage.
Ability to pay already enters into the equation at universities. The pay of university presidents, for example, is higher at schools with larger endowments, according to a new study by Ronald Ehrenberg, John Cheslock and Julia Epifantseva of Cornell. The average pay of presidents at research universities increased 35 percent from 1993 to 1998, when endowments soared. The researchers find, however, that presidents' pay increases are unrelated to their job performance, at least as measured by improvement in a university's academic standing.
This much is clear: when an employer's ability to pay increases, workers and their allies expect pay to increase as well. Failure to anticipate and address this reaction could result in unionization, low morale, poor productivity and public relations problems.
Richard Freeman also sees a warning for the Bush administration in all this. Only recently did lower-paid workers start to experience wage gains from the remarkable prosperity of the 1990's, and these gains may be cut short by the economic slowdown. "If we go into deep recession, there will be much more protest than in previous recent downturns," he predicted.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
Treasury Prices Post Decline As Equities Draw Investors

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as a solid rebound in equity markets drew investors away from government debt and as dealers shed holdings to make room for new government and agency debt.
 By contrast, stocks rose yesterday on positive economic data. The April rally in stocks has pulled money out of Treasuries, which had been a haven for investors during several months of stock market turmoil. 
 "Some days we exist as the opposite of the stock market," said Gib Clark, head trader at Zions First National Bank Capital Markets.
A large amount of new debt issuance by agencies, an auction of new two-year notes and preparations for an upcoming announcement of future supply in intermediate Treasuries also hurt bonds as investors made room for the new supply.
Traders said some investors also cashed in on gains in short-term notes that had materialized since the Federal Reserve shocked financial markets last week with an unexpected half-percentage-point rate cut, its fourth reduction this year. 
Investors have been selling Treasuries to shift money into higher-yielding agency and corporate paper, analysts said.
The Federal Home Loan Bank sold another $2 billion of a recent issue of two-year global notes, while Federal Farm Credit sold $1 billion of new paper. Fannie Mae sold $5.5 billion in 5-year notes and 30-year bonds on Tuesday and had heavy demand for the issue.
The 10-year Treasury note declined 11/32 , to a price of 98 1/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.26 percent from 5.21 percent on Tuesday. The 30-year Treasury bond slid 5/32 , to 94 12/32 . Its yield rose to 5.77 percent from 5.76 on Tuesday.
Earlier, the Treasury said that tomorrow it would buy back up to $2.0 billion of 30-year debt that matures February 2019 to February 2023.

HEADLINE: U.S. Home Sales Surge Despite Slowing Economy 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25 

 BODY:
Home sales unexpectedly surged in March, data released today showed, indicating that real estate and construction are showing resilience as the rest of the economy slows.
 Sales of new homes rose 4.2 percent, to a record annual rate of 1.02 million from 980,000 in February, the Commerce Department said. A separate industry report showed sales of previously owned homes rose in March to the second-highest level on record. 
 Another report showed factory orders for durable goods excluding transportation equipment fell to the lowest level since June 1999.
A jobless rate of 4.3 percent, close to a 30-year low, and mortgage rates that have fallen almost two percentage points since last May are bolstering home sales.
Sales of previously owned homes rose 4.8 percent in March, to an annual pace of 5.44 million units from 5.19 million a month earlier, the National Association of Realtors said. The March sales rate was second only to the record 5.45 million in June 1999. Sales increased in all regions except the Midwest.
Home resales account for about 85 percent of all houses sold, while new homes account for the rest. Sales of new homes averaged 989,667 for the first three months of this year. The record year was 1999, when 907,000 new homes were sold. New-home sales increased in all regions except the West.
Lower mortgage rates underpinned home sales last month. Thirty-year fixed mortgage rates averaged 6.95 percent in March, the lowest monthly average since 6.92 percent in April 1999, according to data from Freddie Mac, the big buyer of mortgages.
The median price of a new home was $164,900 in March, little changed from $165,000 in February. The supply of new homes for sale shrank in March to 3.6 months' worth -- the lowest since a 3.5 months' supply in November 1998 -- from 3.7 months in February.
The median price of a previously owned home rose 3.5 percent, to $143,500 last month -- the highest on record -- from $138,600 in February.
The Commerce Department said durable goods orders excluding transportation equipment fell 1.8 percent in March, to $154.5 billion, the lowest level in almost two years. All orders for big-ticket goods increased 3 percent after falling 0.3 percent in February and 7.3 percent in January.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, an indication of business investment in new equipment, fell 0.7 percent after falling 4.9 percent in February. That was the fifth decline in six months.

HEADLINE: In America; 
Championing Cities

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
As American cities continue to recover from their long period of decay and demoralization, a new group is hoping to accelerate the comeback.
 Crime is down in cities from coast to coast. Home ownership is increasing. School attendance is up. And some of the worst neighborhoods in America, havens of extreme violence and hopelessness, have been quietly transformed in recent years into viable and safe communities. 
 Paul Grogan, an urban expert and a vice president at Harvard, explored the forces underlying this fragile revival in a book he wrote with Tony Proscio, "Comeback Cities." 
Now Mr. Grogan has pulled together a group of mayors, corporate executives, university presidents and others who will try to build on the recent successes. The group, called CEOs for Cities, will be launched publicly in Washington next week. It's headed by Mr. Grogan, the founder and president, and a "leadership team" that includes, among others, Mayor Richard Daley of Chicago; the president of Columbia University, Dr. George Rupp; and the chief executive officer of Forest City Enterprises, Chuck Ratner.
CEOs for Cities will try to spread the word about the good things that are happening in urban America, and focus more attention on the important role that cities play as engines of economic growth for their regions and for the national economy. 
The decline of the nation's major industrial cities over the past half-century was so precipitous and so devastating it fostered the idea that they were, for the most part, useless -- unworthy of any significant investment. 
But that view is changing as cities continue to improve and their increasing economic significance becomes more widely recognized.
The fundamental importance of cities is emphasized in a report to be released by CEOs for Cities at its launching next Thursday. It says: "Cities are hubs for metropolitan areas. Cities disproportionately house assets on which their metropolitan economies particularly depend. These include intellectual and institutional assets, such as universities and hospitals; infrastructure assets, such as transportation and communications; social assets (tourism, entertainment, culture); and core service assets (financial, legal)."
A key member of the new organization is Mayor Thomas Menino of Boston, who said yesterday that he expects CEOs for Cities to fill the need for "a national organization that focuses on building the economic competitiveness of cities and that constantly draws on the broad perspectives of government and business and the universities."
He said it was essential to sustain this "new vitality" in the nation's cities and he thought that CEOs for Cities could help do that.
"I'm going to use it as a think tank for my city," he said. "We'll have the best minds in the country working with the mayors to come up with solutions to some of our problems."
Mr. Grogan hopes his group will have some influence on federal policies that affect urban areas. While much of the revitalization of the cities has been locally driven, nearly all local initiatives are affected to some degree by policies originating in Washington. For example, attacks on redlining and the virtual revolution in commercial lending practices sparked by the federal Community Reinvestment Act were crucial components of the remarkable surge in urban economic activity over the last decade.
Mr. Grogan and his colleagues are committed to the idea that vibrant cities are essential to the long-term health of the U.S., not just economically but socially and culturally as well. And they have said that the concentration of poverty in the cities, along with the related issues of racial isolation and social pathology, may well be the nation's number one problem. 
The cities have long been in need of effective new voices of leadership, and CEOs for Cities believes it can become one.
"I've been involved from the very beginning," said Columbia's Dr. Rupp. "Urban universities and cities are very closely connected. Our fates are tied to each other and we have to figure out the best way that we can move forward together. What I liked about CEOs for Cities was that it was looking at the upside. It didn't just talk about 50 years of decline and hopelessness."

HEADLINE: Developer Scrambles to Save World Trade Center Deal 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In an 11th-hour attempt to resurrect his bid for control of the World Trade Center, a developer rushed back to the bargaining table yesterday evening, vowing to sign a $3.22 billion deal and to put down a hefty deposit for the 10.6 million-square-foot office complex.
 The developer, a group led by Larry A. Silverstein, had been negotiating with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for the last 36 days over a 99-year lease for the 110-story towers and the Trade Center. 
 But in recent days, Port Authority officials became increasingly concerned about the group's financial viability, especially as Mr. Silverstein appeared to retreat on a number of issues, including reducing his $800 million down payment. The four Port Authority commissioners in charge of the sale decided yesterday to end negotiations, but relented when Mr. Silverstein asked for a final opportunity to complete a deal. 
According to top executives at the Port Authority, Mr. Silverstein must sign a contract and put down a $100 million deposit by this afternoon when the Port Authority board meets, or he is out.
"They're going down there this evening in an effort to close the deal," Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Silverstein, said late yesterday afternoon. "They'll take as long as it takes to get it done."
Mr. Silverstein's partners include GMAC; Westfield America Inc., a shopping center developer; and Lloyd Goldman, an investor. Mr. Silverstein has long expressed his desire to operate the World Trade Center, an office complex he considers to be "the prize of all prizes." But many real estate executives and Port Authority executives remain skeptical that the developer will be able to capture his prize.
The Trade Center is full and generating income of about $200 million a year, but if the present negotiations fail, it would be a major setback for plans to privatize the complex. In 1998, the two states hoped to get about $1.5 billion, but a rocketing real estate market ultimately drove the bidding over $3 billion.
Both the economy and the real estate market have cooled down significantly in recent weeks. The Port Authority could turn to another bidder, a joint venture of Boston Properties and Brookfield Financial Properties. The Port Authority has lost leverage, though.
The Silverstein group would be the second bidder to collapse within sight of the finish line. Last month, Vornado Realty Trust, which had offered $3.25 billion for a 99-year lease, failed to sign a contract after a 20-day negotiating period.
On March 21, the Port Authority opened talks with the second-place bidder, the Silverstein group. Negotiations appeared to be going well, so the Port Authority allowed its April 14 deadline to pass without comment. According to top Port Authority officials, Mr. Silverstein sought to reopen several important issues, including the size of his down payment. Some officials also questioned whether the Silverstein group had a large enough operations group to run the Trade Center properly. They said the developer also sought to get the Port Authority to pay for $200 million in improvements to the complex. 
That may have been a last-minute bargaining tactic, because Mr. Silverstein appeared to have relented yesterday afternoon. The closing scenario was reminiscent of what happened in the Vornado negotiations.
"I don't mean to sound naive," said Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority, "but it's astonishing to me that they believe they can play a game of chicken with us."

HEADLINE: Little Change Forecast for Election Process 

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25 

 BODY:
Despite the outcry over last year's presidential election, the next national election will probably occur under virtually the same circumstances as the last, with the same unreliable voting systems and under the same dizzying hodgepodge of rules that vary from county to county across the nation.
 The reasons vary, from a lack of cash to partisan positioning and difficulties in interpreting the United States Supreme Court decision that finally ended the presidential contest. Those studying how to overhaul the system have found that it is exceedingly complex. 
 "There is no technical fix to the problem," said Thomas Mann, a scholar at the Brookings Institution. "There's no possibility of a uniform national ballot. There are contradictory findings on the accuracy of different voting equipment." 
And so far, there is no money. At a hearing on Capitol Hill, state elections officials today painted a bleak picture of the improvements they might be able to achieve by the midterm elections in 2002, particularly if Congress and the White House continued to sidestep the issue.
Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, whom some voters blamed more than they blamed the voting machines for last year's debacle in her state, spoke for her fellow secretaries of state today when she challenged Congress to come up with cash for new machines.
"Currently in Florida, and I suspect many other states, we have the will but not the financial wherewithal," Ms. Harris said. "The problems affecting the American electoral system cannot be solved by local and state governments alone. And as much as we all appreciate words of encouragement, they will fail to make our system of elections fairer, freer, more accurate and more accessible."
J. Kenneth Blackwell, the Ohio secretary of state, said election reform was one of the first casualties of the economic downturn, which has undercut state budgets.
"While election reform continues to have widespread public support, the resources to implement these costly upgrades are few or nonexistent," Mr. Blackwell said. "Dollars for voting system upgrades, while desperately needed, are competing with funds for mental health services, road construction, welfare and Medicaid."
To be sure, states have clearly been eager to immunize themselves from the problems that afflicted Florida last year. Lawmakers have introduced more than 1,500 election reform bills in state legislatures this year. And just today, the Florida House passed measures that would ban voting machines that use punch cards and would enable counties to borrow money to buy optical scanners before the 2002 elections. The Senate will consider similar legislation this week.
Tim Storey, an elections specialist at the National Conference of State Legislatures, said 120 such bills had been passed in the 10 states where the legislatures had adjourned for the year.
Georgia has taken the lead for comprehensive action. Prodded by Cathy Cox, the secretary of state, Gov. Roy Barnes has signed legislation to place touch-screen voting systems, which work like automatic teller machines, in all precincts. The law calls for pilot projects of the systems this fall and then replacement of the punch-card systems used by about one-third of Georgia voters by the 2002 elections and installation of new machines in all precincts by 2004.
But Georgia, too, is waiting for money.
"The bill says, Do it -- subject to funding," Ms. Cox said. "Our State Legislature hasn't funded it because they are waiting to see how much money the feds will put up."
Maryland, too, has passed a bill requiring the state and counties to split the costs of a new system.
Most of the bills passed in other states are not likely to make big impressions on voters. Virginia, for example, has set standards for reviewing punch card ballots that are not accepted by a counting machine because chads are dangling. South Dakota has enacted a law to implement a statewide voter database that will allow more efficient administration on Election Day.
Researchers have reached conflicting conclusions on what technology is best. Even if they could agree on a machine with the lowest error rate, would voters easily adapt? Examinations of ballots in Florida show that some people failed to register their choices, whether from ignorance or hostility to the candidates or the system.
Elections officials are reluctant to formalize means to call voters' errors to their attention at the polling place, for fear of violating the privacy of the ballot.
Newspapers conducting recounts of the Florida vote seem to have only added to the confusion. Published accounts so far have found the ballots so confounding and the rules in Florida so patchwork that they have not been able to determine with certainty the number of votes won by George W. Bush or Al Gore.
Moreover, ideas that once seemed panaceas -- Internet voting, scrapping the Electoral College, even uniform poll-closing hours nationwide -- have been discredited. And those with a stake in the process -- political parties and officials from federal, state and county governments -- are lapsing into predictable squabbles over advantage and turf.
Looming over these nuts-and-bolts questions are important unknowns, like whether the Supreme Court ruling that ended the presidential election applies to future elections.
Trevor Potter, former chairman of the Federal Election Commission and an adviser to Senator John McCain's presidential campaign, considered the ruling and said: "The majority of the court said, essentially, 'This is a railroad ticket for this day, this train only, this has no precedential value.' Personally, I don't think they get away with that."
"Once you use the equal protection argument, which everyone thought was a reach, it's there," Mr. Potter added. "Does equal protection require some degree of standardization, and what is that degree? Is it statewide ballots? Is it only statewide recount systems? The lawsuits say no, it's the same type of machinery or access to low error rates. The question we're all walking around -- because we don't know the answer -- is, to what extent are the courts going to upset the apple cart by saying the way you've always done business is no longer constitutionally permissible?"
Citing the Supreme Court decision, the American Civil Liberties Union filed suit last week in federal court in California -- its fourth such suit in the nation since the election -- alleging that that state's multiple voting systems created discriminatory results and that its lack of legally binding standards for recounts aggravated the unconstitutional disparities.
Setting national or state standards for ballots and recounts might have seemed a logical response to the mess in Florida. But it is becoming increasingly clear that elections officials are resistant to giving up turf. And untangling the roles of federal, state and local officials is emerging as a central obstacle.
Sharon Priest, secretary of state in Arkansas and president of the National Association of Secretaries of State, said she could accept statewide standards but she rejected national standards.
"Frankly," Ms. Priest said, "we don't have to have the feds tell us everything that we have to do." 
She gave perhaps the gloomiest assessment on the future of election reform:
"Unless there's a real uprising on the part of people in this country who will call their congressmen and senators and say, 'Elections are important to us and democracy comes at a price, and we're willing to pay that price -- do something!' then I'm not sure, running into budgets now, that anything's going to get done."

HEADLINE: Moving Tax Simplification Toward Front Burner 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
While there is wide disagreement on whether, and how much, to cut taxes, there is wide agreement that the tax system must be simplified.
 The issue has received little attention in Congress this year, but this morning the Senate Finance Committee will hold a hearing on tax simplification for individuals. 
 Tax experts from various political and economic viewpoints said the task would be difficult. "We need tax simplification," said Nina E. Olson, the taxpayer advocate at the Internal Revenue Service. "But simplification will not be simple." 
These experts emphasized many of the same solutions: ease the rules defining family status or tax individuals instead of families, revise the alternative minimum tax so it again applies to the rich instead of the middle class, eliminate all but one of the rules that phase out tax breaks as income rises, and replace the complicated form used to report capital gains with a single line on tax returns.
The issue is complex because a complicated tax system is not without its benefits, said William G. Gale, a tax scholar at the Brookings Institution, a nonprofit research organization in Washington.
"In an ideal world we would have no pollution," he said, "but to do what we want to do, like drive cars, we have to tolerate some pollution. Tax complexity is like that; sometimes it lets you do things you want, but some is just a pure waste and we should focus on getting rid of complexity with no value."
The first place to address complexity is to try to get the tax system out of the business of deciding who is a family, said William A. Niskanen, chairman of the Cato Institute, a libertarian research group in Washington.
"We ought to move from taxing a family unit to taxing individuals," said Mr. Niskanen, who was a senior Reagan administration tax official. "If we do that we do not need special provisions on marriage penalties."
Ms. Olson said that whether one is married, single or head of a household, and who gets the tax credits and deductions for children after a marriage collapses, add unnecessary burdens on taxpayers and on the Internal Revenue Service.
Many tax experts say that the area most in need of reform is the alternative minimum tax, which no longer applies to the people it was designed for, wealthy individuals who make aggressive use of tax shelters and deductions to live tax free. Congress abolished most tax shelters for individuals in 1986, but it did not adjust the minimum tax for inflation so today it does not apply to those making more than $350,000 or so.
But it does apply to a small but growing segment of the middle and upper-middle classes as well as some single mothers making just $28,000.
Last year a million people paid the tax, Treasury Department specialists estimate. Under current law the tax will apply to 21 million taxpayers, nearly one in five, by 2010. That would grow to 36 million under President Bush's tax cut plan, according to an analysis by Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation, including about 80 percent of those making $80,000 to $200,000 annually. 
The alternative minimum tax limits deductions and, once they are taken away, adds the minimum tax.
Under Mr. Bush's plan families with more than four children, people who live in higher-tax states like New York and California, and people who spend more than 7.5 percent of their income on medical bills would be affected by the alternative minimum tax. But the alternative minimum tax does not apply to those who would get the biggest tax breaks under Mr. Bush's plan, the top 1 percent of taxpayers, who would receive in full the tax breaks he favors.
A variety of experts said that treating children as tax shelters, as the alternative minimum tax does, was unjustified. "I don't think anyone believes children are a tax shelter," said Charles Davenport, a Rutgers University law professor and editor in chief of Tax Notes, a weekly magazine. 
A White House spokesman, Ken Lisaius, said, "It is very clear a problem exists with the alternative minimum tax, and the president is very sympathetic about the problem, but he believes Congress should tackle first the priorities he has set" to reduce marriage penalties and marginal tax rates and repeal the estate tax.
"After that is done he will go back and take a look and see if other priorities remain," Mr. Lisaius said, noting that Mr. Bush would exempt his child tax credit, which would eventually reach $1,000 a child, from the alternative minimum tax at a cost of $60 billion over 10 years.
Congress has handed out tax breaks to parents, college students and the working poor, but each break has its own income limits and its own rules, which often conflict with other rules. A result is that many people are denied these breaks or cannot figure out how to get them or, if they do, join the dwindling number of taxpayers who are audited.
Mr. Niskanen and Mr. Gale said they would eliminate the rules that phase out these credits. If Congress wants to give a tax credit for a child it should do so without regard to whether the child's parents are rich or poor, Mr. Gale said.
The phasing out of personal exemptions and tax credits pushes people into higher tax brackets than the six official rates of 0, 15, 28, 31, 36 and 39.6 percent. Some middle-class taxpayers, however, pay 80 cents in taxes on their last dollar of income, according to a comprehensive study of these phase-out rules and marginal tax rates by Elliott Manning, a law professor in Coral Gables, Fla.
One phase-out rule is needed, both men said. That would be for the earned-income tax credit, which gives the working poor a tax break. "You have to phase it out because we don't want to subsidize everyone's income," Mr. Niskanen said.
Ms. Olson, the taxpayer advocate, said her years running a clinic for low-income taxpayers taught her that the earned-income tax credit is unnecessarily complex. The combination of low-income workers and an especially complex tax form contributes to a large rate of errors in applying for the credit.
An easy target for simplification, experts said, is capital gains taxes.
Anyone who sells a stock, bond, apartment building or other investment asset must complete a form known as a Schedule D. For years it was a simple exercise, but since 1997, even longtime tax preparers say, it has been numbingly complex.
Schedule D will become more complex next year because Congress decided that nine different tax rates for capital gains were not enough and added two. Now the tax rate on a profitable investment may be 0, 8, 10, 15, 18, 20, 25, 28, 31, 36 or 39.6 percent.
Mr. Gale said he would just lump all long-term gains and tax a percentage of them. "You just put down your gains and multiply by something between the zero percent Jack Kemp would favor or the 100 percent I favor, so Congress picks, say, 50 percent," he said. "If your tax rate on your pay is 39.6 percent then you would pay that on half your capital gains and if your tax rate is 15 percent you would pay half of that."
Ms. Olson said as taxpayer advocate she had her own simplification plan for her report to Congress later this year. "Instead of proposing 38 changes we are going to simplify the list and have maybe five of them."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Daimler Reports a Loss, Dragged Down by Chrysler
DaimlerChrysler said it had an operating loss of $3.3 billion in the first quarter, virtually all of that stemming from problems at Chrysler and at the truck-making subsidiary Freightliner.
 Excluding $2.7 billion in one-time charges, the corporation as a whole lost 610 million euros, or about $545.6 million. That was a smaller loss than Daimler had forecast in February. Still, shares of DaimlerChrysler fell 12 cents, to $49.79. Page C4. 

Price Controls on California Power
Federal regulators reversed themselves and decided to impose broad price controls on electricity sales in California, contradicting the Bush administration's opposition to federal intervention in the state's energy market. A14.

Busiest Airports Are Oversubscribed
At eight of the busiest airports, airlines have scheduled substantially more flights than runways can handle in bad weather, and at four of them, more than they can handle even in perfect weather, a study found. A16.

Healthy Rise in March Home Sales
Sales of new homes rose 4.2 percent in March, to a record annual rate of 1.02 million from 980,000 in February. A separate report showed sales of previously owned homes rose to the second-highest level on record in March. C4.

A Rebound for Stocks After Skid
Stocks gained for the first time in four days. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 19.28 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,228.75. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 170.86 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,625.20. The Nasdaq composite index advanced 43.19 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,059.80. C9.

VoiceStream Purchase Is Approved
Regulators approved Deutsche Telekom's $34 billion purchase of VoiceStream Wireless, rejecting objections of lawmakers. C10.

Recovery Plans Set for SAirGroup
The management of the struggling SAirGroup laid out the details of plans to restore its financial health. The effort involves undoing major parts of the failed expansion strategy that plunged the company into losses and cost the previous chief executive his job. The new chief, Mario Corti, delivered the news at the annual meeting. World Business, Section W.

Guilty Pleas in Stock Fraud Case
Seven defendants in a stock fraud case pleaded guilty to attempted enterprise corruption and face prison terms of one to six years. C4.

WPP in Custom Publishing Venture
WPP Group is teaming up with the magazine publisher Forbes to form a joint venture in the growing field known as custom publishing. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C7.

Double-Digit Gains for Drug Makers
American Home Products, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Pharmacia reported double-digit increases in operating profits. C7.

New Generation of College Protests
At most Ivy League campuses, organized students have demanded better treatment of the workers who prepare their meals, tend their grounds and clean their dorms and classrooms. They are seeking a more equitable division of the riches universities have amassed. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: DaimlerChrysler Posts Big Quarterly Loss 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 25 

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler said today that it lost another $1.2 billion at Chrysler in the first quarter, not including nearly $3 billion in revamping charges, but its results were slightly better than both the company and most analysts had predicted.
 Over all, the German-American automobile company said it had an operating loss of $3.3 billion, virtually all of that stemming from problems at Chrysler and at the American truck-making subsidiary, Freightliner. 
 Excluding $2.7 billion in one-time charges, the corporation as a whole lost 610 million euros, or about $545.6 million. That was a smaller loss than Daimler had forecast in February, when it predicted a loss, excluding the charges, of 800 million euros to 1 billion euros. 
Chrysler remained the main source of heartburn. But the company was also hit by a plunge in truck sales at Freightliner, which like Chrysler has been hit by an acute slump in the American market.
Truck and bus sales in North America sank nearly 50 percent, compared with the period a year earlier.
As a result, DaimlerChrysler said, its commercial vehicles division lost $100 million. Freightliner is in the process of eliminating 9,000 jobs.
Analysts said the results were broadly in line with expectations. "What it shows is that the targets set by the company were conservative, that they were realistic," said Joseph Harrigan, an automobile analyst in London at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Shares of DaimlerChrysler fell 12 cents in New York, to $49.79. In Frankfurt, its shares fell 0.87 euro, to 55.21 euro.
Chrysler's sales were 28 percent lower in the first quarter, compared with the period a year earlier, as it shut down production at seven plants to reduce the huge inventories of unsold cars that had built up at dealers across the United States. 
Dieter Zetsche, who took over as Chrysler's chief executive last fall, was cautious in his assessment.
"All the improvement we saw clearly came from the cost side," he told reporters in a telephone news conference from Detroit. "The revenue side is harder to control."
By contrast, results at Mercedes were better than ever. Despite an extremely weak automobile market in Germany and the United States, sales of Mercedes and other luxury brands have held up well. Mercedes sales increased 13 percent from the first quarter last year, reaching 11.2 billion euros, or $9.8 billion. Operating profit at Mercedes also climbed 13 percent, to 700 million euros, or $600 million.
DaimlerChrysler predicted in February that Chrysler would lose $2 billion to $2.5 billion this year, before it begins to break even early next year. By that yardstick, Chrysler has used up about half the anticipated loss. Company officials are hoping that sales and profits will pick up with the introduction of a renovated Jeep, the Liberty, as well as a new version of the Durango truck. 
But success also depends on a recovery in the American car market and the American economy as a whole. 
"If the world collapsed, we would need to set up a new plan," Mr. Zetsche said today. "But that's nothing we expect."
