HEADLINE: Good Faith Appears Missing in Offer of Parish Aid 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN with LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
It was the kind of chance encounter that inevitably prompts talk of divine intervention and, in the end, is too good to be true. 
 The Rev. George Carlin, a Roman Catholic priest, was in a pub on the West Side on a Tuesday night earlier this month talking to a stranger about the Church of St. Bernard, the down-on-its-luck parish where he currently lives and works on West 14th Street in Manhattan. The Archdiocese of New York had marked the parish elementary school as one of six under consideration for closing because of budget cuts. 
 The stranger in the bar identified himself as Edward Michael Beagan, the wealthy owner of a high-tech telecommunications firm named Computersat with offices in Rockefeller Center. According to Father Carlin, Mr. Beagan said he had been planning to set up a charitable foundation and wanted to make a major donation to save the financially failing Catholic schools. 
As Father Carlin recalls it, Mr. Beagan had been boasting of his financial success, so the priest made a pitch: "If you have all these millions, do you want to give a couple hundred thousand to keep St. Bernard's open?" He hastened to add, "Actually, the pastor involved said we need $4.5 million." 
According to Father Carlin, Mr. Beagan lifted his glass and said: "Done!" 
The donation, estimated by the archdiocese at more than $150 million in stock, was hailed as an Easter miracle and created a buzz in New York's large Catholic community. Word of the donation had sharply lifted hopes not just at St. Bernard but at the five other elementary schools and at John A. Coleman High School in Hurley, N.Y., which is also marked for closing. At a meeting with parents on April 11, the Rev. Kenneth J. Smith, the pastor of the Church of St. Bernard, had predicted that the donation would save all the schools. 
In recent weeks, Mr. Beagan telephoned the archdiocese twice to repeat his pledge. But now, it seems, the offer was at best a flight of fancy. 
Mr. Beagan has been sanctioned twice by the federal Securities and Exchange Commission since 1980 for fraud and now faces judgments and penalties of more than $500,000. In each case, according to court documents, Mr. Beagan denied the government's allegations and blamed his troubles on conspiracies.
Mr. Beagan did not return phone calls seeking comment on Tuesday. Yesterday, a doorman at his apartment building in Guttenberg, N.J., said he was told to say that Mr. Beagan was in Japan and that no further information was available. 
In 1980, according to court records, federal regulators charged Mr. Beagan with securities fraud in connection with Teltronics, a company that went bankrupt. Mr. Beagan settled the case without admitting guilt by agreeing not to violate securities laws. 
But in the mid-1990's, Mr. Beagan met a scientist at a bar called Finnegans Wake on First Avenue and impressed him with talk of his business expertise, according to a lawsuit filed against him in 1995 by the S.E.C. Mr. Beagan offered to help the scientist raise money to develop cancer treatments. 
Mr. Beagan raised about $300,000 from investors in Kuwait as well as from people he met in New York bars and restaurants, from neighborhood doormen and from his landlord, Ed Reiss, according to the S.E.C. He assured them that his company, Cancer Minus, had developed an effective cancer drug.
There was no drug, nor did the scientist get any money, according to court documents. Mr. Beagan used it for personal expenses. A judge ruled in favor of the S.E.C. in 1999 and Mr. Beagan appealed.
Father Carlin met Mr. Beagan just five days after the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit rejected his appeal in the Cancer Minus case. 
It is unclear if Mr. Beagan now owns a business or even has any money. Recently, he has represented himself in court. And his former landlord, Mr. Reiss, said he had evicted Mr. Beagan from a brownstone apartment on the Upper East Side. "He never paid the rent," Mr. Reiss said, adding that Mr. Beagan had destroyed the apartment.
There is no record that Mr. Beagan actually owns Computersat or that the company is even an active business. It shares space in a suite of offices in Rockefeller Center, but there was no one there yesterday or Tuesday. Phone calls are taken by an answering service. And the company's Web site lists no names of officers or employees. 
Archdiocesan officials had said all along that talks about the gift were preliminary and had warned the schools not to focus on fund-raising in the business plans they each submitted this week. The potential school closings, which should be decided by Tuesday, are part of a wide effort by Cardinal Edward M. Egan to cut spending. 
The account of how the church became entangled with Mr. Beagan seems to be a sad tale of a clergyman, trained to see and expect the best in everyone, who trusted the wrong man. Desperate for a windfall of cash to save his school, Father Carlin apparently had the bad luck to run across a man who has made a habit of promising people windfalls. 
On the night of April 10, Father Carlin was at a pub on Ninth Avenue near West 55th Street, near St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center, where he had worked for several years as a chaplain. In the bar, Father Carlin, a former copy editor at The Daily News and The New York Post, met Mr. Beagan.
"He was kind of on a roll and he was very expansive telling me the story of his life," Father Carlin said. Mr. Beagan boasted that he helped design a satellite for NASA, attended Harvard Business School with President George W. Bush and had been an economic adviser to Japan, the priest said. "He was a great talker, dropped a lot of names." 
Father Carlin said that Mr. Beagan told him his usual drink was Grand Marnier. But as the priest remembers it, the man was drinking draft beer. 
The next morning, Father Carlin said, he telephoned Mr. Beagan and asked whether he really wanted to be "St. Bernard's savior." At the meeting with parents that night to strategize about how to save the St. Bernard/St. Xavier school, Father Smith, the pastor, announced that he was close to securing a major gift that would save all the schools. 
Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the archdiocese, said that there was no set protocol for how priests handle such offers. "There is not a guideline," Mr. Zwilling said. "We allow the common sense of the pastors to dictate the situation." 
Sitting at a table in the kitchen of the St. Bernard rectory yesterday afternoon, Father Smith and Father Carlin said that they believed that Mr. Beagan was sincere. "I still cling to the possibility that Ed does have some substance, that all of this is not just talk," Father Carlin said as he puffed on a cigarette. "I really like him and I still want to believe in him."

HEADLINE: Board Orders Limited Price Caps for California Power 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25 

 BODY:
Federal regulators decided tonight to impose broad price controls on electricity sales in California, reversing their previous stance and contradicting the Bush administration's steadfast opposition to federal intervention in the state's energy market.
 In a compromise, two of three commissioners of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission voted to cap electricity prices whenever supplies fall to within 7.5 percent of demand in the state's volatile electricity market. 
 The caps are to go into effect on May 1 and last a year. The controls should help California save billions of dollars it would otherwise pay to electricity generators that state officials have accused of price-gouging. 
"California consumers can rest assured that the commission has been attentive to their problems, and has worked tirelessly to ensure that they receive necessary relief," said Curt L. Hebert Jr., the commission's chairman.
California's flawed attempt at electricity deregulation has led to skyrocketing prices and left the leading utilities in the state near insolvency. State officials have urged the commission to corral prices until new power plants are built.
The intervention announced tonight will affect far more electricity sales than an earlier plan under consideration by the regulatory commission. But California officials and one of the agency's commissioners had sought more sweeping caps that could be applied even if supply levels were comfortably above demand.
The order was harshly criticized by that commissioner, William L. Massey, as falling short of what was needed to stem the economic damage caused by high prices in California and neighboring states.
"Generators are exercising their market power in that state 24 hours a day, seven days a week," Mr. Massey, a Democrat, said after the vote. "It is much too late in the game for this agency to settle for a 'half a loaf' solution to the problem."
But Mr. Hebert, the Republican chairman, and Commissioner Linda Key Breathitt, a Democrat, defended the order as a balanced approach, preserving competitive markets while offering cost relief.
The agency has the authority to set "just and reasonable" prices for electricity wholesale markets, but has generally declined to intervene in nascent energy markets it helped to create. The agency had maintained this hands-off approach even as prices soared and the California market became dysfunctional.
The Bush administration has opposed price restraints on electricity, arguing that they distort the market. 
But commissioners have come under heavy pressure from members of Congress, California officials and some industry executives to play a more active role. California is paying 10 to 20 times as much to buy power this year as it did a year ago.
A bipartisan group of senators has introduced legislation that would require the regulatory commission to enact price caps for California and neighboring states. They argue that the agency has refused to fulfill its mandate to ensure "just and reasonable" electricity prices. 
"We have to make F.E.R.C. show up to work and do its job," said Senator Dianne Feinstein, a California Democrat and a cosponsor of the legislation.
Senator Gordon H. Smith, an Oregon Republican and another cosponsor, said he was a strong supporter of the free market. But, he argued, the electricity market in the West today "doesn't exist."
Industry officials have also put pressure on the agency to do more to stabilize the giant California market. Many generating companies selling electricity there are not getting paid because the utilities in the state are billions of dollars in debt.
Keith E. Bailey, chairman and chief executive of the Williams Companies of Tulsa, Okla., a leading electricity supplier in California, said today that price controls under some circumstances could help. Mr. Bailey predicted that controls would eliminate some of the higher prices that generators are demanding for fear that they will not get paid.
"The combination of short-term regional price controls during emergency periods," Mr. Bailey said in a statement, "along with the elimination of credit risk, should provide the market a respite while creating incentive for the private sector to invest with confidence." 
Under its new plan, the commission has authorized California's electricity market monitors to impose price caps when they find that the available supply of electricity falls to within 7.5 percent of demand, a level the state calls a Stage 1 emergency.
The caps would be based on what federal and state officials determine to be the highest costs of generation by the least efficient power plants serving the market at the time. That level is likely to be high enough so that the majority of generating companies earn sizable profits even when price caps are enacted.
Had the system been in place in recent months, it might have knocked several billions dollars off California's electricity bill, people at the federal agency said. California officials say generating companies overcharged more than $6 billion since last summer, a figure the companies say is wildly inflated.
The agency's staff first proposed to set a price monitoring and mitigation formula that was much more restrictive than the one adopted today. It would have limited price caps to Stage 3 emergencies, when supply fell to within 1.5 percent of demand.
But the two Democratic commissioners pushed for a plan that would impose price controls even if shortages were not acute, arguing that exorbitant prices were charged even when supplies were relatively ample, officials involved in the talks said.

HEADLINE: Using an Informer, U.S. Agents Charge 45 in Mafia Crimes 

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER 

 BODY:
A Mafia turncoat who secretly recorded thousands of hours of gangland conversations helped the authorities file charges yesterday against 45 men accused of committing a smorgasbord of savage and small-time mob crimes, from murder to stock fraud to shaking down two competing delicatessens.
 The arrests occurred before daylight as more than 300 federal agents and police officers swept through New York, New Jersey and Miami. The three-year investigation was one of the longest and most extensive undercover mob inquiries in a decade, the authorities said. Its main target was the secretive Genovese family, the largest Mafia group in New York City, which the government called the "Rolls-Royce of organized crime." 
 The arraignment section of Federal District Court in Brooklyn was packed with federal agents in dark blue nylon jackets stenciled with the yellow letters F.B.I. The agents drew cool stares from the elderly men in velour track suits who sat outside the arraignment court or spoke with their lawyers, some of whom had been awakened at 5:30 a.m. by panicked calls.
At a news conference across the street, federal officials released a three-inch stack of paperwork, including indictments, with details on the men arrested in the case. While prosecutors accused 32 of being connected to the Genovese family, not all had traditional Mafia backgrounds. Among them were two retired police officers, a certified public accountant, a lawyer and a Hasidic man accused of joining in a Brooklyn labor bribery scheme.
Despite the voluminous court filings, there was little information about the informer in the case. Federal prosecutors said only that he was a well-placed Genovese associate who had developed the trust of the men he was betraying to the point where they freely discussed their crimes. 
In one recorded conversation, court papers show, a defendant uttered this Mafia truism: "Hurting people. That's what this is about. If you're not capable of doing that, you might as well stay at home."
In another, a suspect in the case explained the chain of command for gangland murders: "No matter who you are killing, it's from the boss."
The authorities said that among the Genovese members taken into custody were Frank Serpico, a former acting boss (and no relation to the whistle-blowing police officer in the famous 1970's corruption case); Alan Longo and Rosario Gangi, two captains; and Salvatore Aparo and Peter DiChiara, two acting captains.
The remaining defendants were described as members or associates of New York's four other crime families -- the Bonannos, the Colombos, the Gambinos and the Lucheses.
"These arrests open a window into the shadow economy of the mob," said Loretta E. Lynch, the United States attorney in Brooklyn. "They have cracked down on a criminal industry that operated from Little Italy to Miami to offshore accounts in the Bahamas."
A single sentence from the statement released by Ms. Lynch captured the sweeping nature of the accusations: "The crimes discussed, planned and carried out by the defendants included murder, loan sharking, illegal gambling, extortion of businesses, drug trafficking, bank robberies, firearms possession, mail fraud, wire fraud, stock fraud, money laundering, obstruction of justice and labor bribery."
The core group of defendants is an eclectic Genovese crew led by Mr. Aparo, 72, and Mr. DiChiara, 58, the government said. The crew included Michael Norrito, a retired police detective who specialized in collecting debts, and Joseph Savarese Sr., a retired patrolman accused of helping to run a Lower Manhattan gambling den, according to court papers. Another member of the crew, the government said, was an accountant named Peter Tarangelo, known as the tax doctor, who was an expert on hiding money in overseas accounts.
The Hasidic man, Abe Weider, was charged with paying bribes to a building workers' union so that cheaper, mob-connected maintenance men could work in a Brooklyn apartment complex he owned without complaints from the union.
There were so many defendants that the government included thumbnail biographies of many in its court filings. Mr. Aparo, for instance, was described as a man who "constantly plans obstruction of justice, is armed with automatic weapons and stands ready to order murder." And his son, Vincent, 50, "is a prolific loan shark who quickly assaults victims who are unable to pay, and who stockpiles firearms to be used for organized crime," the papers said.
The indictments were a lightning blow to the Genovese family, which until now seemed to have escaped a recent spate of Brooklyn mob prosecutions. The authorities said the new case was the most substantial infiltration of the family since Peter Savino, another Genovese turncoat, worked undercover a decade ago, recording conversations that eventually led to the 1997 conviction of Vincent Gigante, the family's boss.
Prosecutors say that while Mr. Gigante, known as Chin, still runs the clan from prison, the family has a small committee of ranking members that oversees day-to-day operations. With at least 250 made members, it is the city's largest mob family, the authorities said. It stands to reason, then, that the crimes it is accused of committing are myriad, from the brutal to the mundane.
The indictments, for instance, charge that three men helped plan the 1996 murder of John Borelli, a Gambino family associate who was gunned down in his car on a street in Queens. But they also charge five other men with clogging city sewers with sand and concrete, then calling in a mob-connected contractor to make emergency repairs. 
Then there was the accusation that the Genovese family extorted $25,000 a year from a deli in Queens. "This payment was in return for providing protection to Gourmet Boutique from a rival business known as John's Gourmet Salads," court papers said, somewhat cryptically. "John's Gourmet Salads, in turn, enlisted members and associates of the Colombo family to protect it from Gourmet Boutique."

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; 
TURKEY: ECONOMIC MEASURE PASSES

BYLINE:  Dow Jones 

 BODY:
 Turkey's Parliament passed a law granting autonomy to the Central Bank, one of 15 measures that the economy minister, Kemal Dervis, said were vital to underpin a crisis-recovery program. The new law will make the Central Bank independent of the government and entrust it with running monetary policy to meet inflation targets. Mr. Dervis departed for the United States to seek international support for his recovery program.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Share Prices Gain on Better-Than-Expected Housing Sales

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks gained yesterday for the first time in four days after housing sales rose faster than expected in March, lifting investor optimism that the economic slowdown may end soon.
 Pulte and other home builders were among the biggest gainers in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. General Electric led the advance on optimism that it would soon complete the purchase of Honeywell International. Philip Morris rallied on a report that the Justice Department might not have adequate financing for its lawsuit against the tobacco industry. 
 "The home sales were a positive note; it shows that the consumer hasn't gone away," said William Rutherford, president of Rutherford Investment Management in Portland, Ore., which manages about $100 million.
The S.& P. 500 climbed 19.28 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,228.75. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 170.86 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,625.20.
The Nasdaq composite index advanced 43.19 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,059.80 after losing 7.6 percent over the previous three sessions. The Dow has climbed 26 percent since April 4, when it touched its year-to-date low.
Stocks, which had fallen when trading began, rebounded after the National Association of Realtors released its report on sales of previously owned homes in March, which showed the second-highest level on record.
The report suggested that "the consumer is holding the economy up right now," Mr. Rutherford said. Investors will "feel more confident when the C.E.O.'s stand up and start saying our order book is building," he added.
Pulte rallied $2.43, to $47.01; KB Home gained $1.88, to $31.11; and Centex rose 86 cents, to $42.54.
General Electric gained $1.82, to $47.81. The company may change its pricing and sales policies to overcome European regulatory opposition to its planned purchase of Honeywell, according to people close to the transaction. Honeywell rose $2.12, to $47.51.
Philip Morris, the biggest tobacco company, advanced $2.75, to $50.70. Justice Department lawyers have warned that the budget proposed by President Bush does not include enough money for the government's lawsuit against the tobacco industry, The Washington Post reported, citing a confidential memo.
Philip Morris also said it would raise the wholesale price of cigarettes about 14 cents a pack.
R. J. Reynolds Tobacco gained $2.61, to $57.86.
With 67 percent of S.& P. 500 companies having reported earnings, first-quarter profits are now projected to fall 6.4 percent, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. For the full year, profits are expected to fall 2.5 percent. At the beginning of the year, analysts were forecasting first-quarter earnings growth of 5.1 percent and a gain of 9.2 percent for the year.
Walt Disney rose $2.23, to $30.81. Disney reported that fiscal second-quarter profit, excluding one-time items, rose 36 percent from a year earlier. Analysts had forecast a decline.
Phone company stocks rose. Verizon Communications gained $2.37, to $55.18, after it earned 72 cents a share in the first quarter, beating analysts' estimates by a penny.
SBC Communications rose $1.09, to $40.79, and Qwest Communications International advanced $1.60, to $38.90.
Newport News Shipbuilding jumped $9.05, to $64.10. General Dynamics, the largest shipbuilder for the Navy, agreed to buy Newport News for $2.1 billion. The company will pay $67.50 for each share of its rival, 23 percent more than the Tuesday closing price.
General Dynamics lost $1.38, to $72.73. Newport News also said its first-quarter profit rose more than had been forecast.
Pharmacia, the maker of the painkiller Celebrex, and American Home Products, the maker of the antidepressant Effexor XR, reported profit that matched analysts' estimates. Bristol-Myers Squibb reported earnings that were a penny ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Pharmacia gained $1.09, to $49.10; American Home rose $1.73, to $56.08; and Bristol-Myers Squibb, the No. 1 maker of cancer medicines, advanced $1.96, to $56.86.

HEADLINE: Qualcomm Reports A Healthy Quarter 

 BODY:
Qualcomm, the big developer of wireless communications technology, met Wall Street's earning estimates yesterday but warned of weakness ahead. 
 The company, based in San Diego, reported second-quarter earnings of $232.6 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $206.82 million, or 26 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. 
 Softening demand for its chips and communications licenses, however, will hurt earnings in the coming quarters, Qualcomm said.
"Uncertainty in global economic conditions, however, has resulted in recent reductions in chip demand from our customers in the third and fourth fiscal quarters," said Irwin M. Jacobs, the chief executive.
The key to Qualcomm's recent strength has been the rapid adoption by telecommunications companies of its code division multiple access technology, Qualcomm's proprietary wireless technology that competes with two other global standards.
But the company is reducing its estimates of both the number of C.D.M.A. phones that are likely to be sold and the average selling price of such phones.

HEADLINE: Slower Growth Seen in Europe, Held Back by German Woes 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 25 

 BODY:
Acknowledging that the slowdown in the United States will retard European economic growth after all, the European Commission cut its 2001 forecast for growth in the 12 nations adopting the euro currency by 0.4 percentage point today, to 2.8 percent. The commission said it expected a slight uptick in 2002, to 2.9 percent.
 Pedro Solbes, the economic and monetary affairs commissioner, said the negative impact from the United States was modest so far, but the commission warned in a statement that there could be "a reaction beyond a mere limited growth pause" in Europe if the situation in the United States grew any worse. 
 The commission said it expected Germany, the largest of the 12 euro-zone economies, to slow the most, to 2.2 percent this year from about 3 percent in 2000. 
Mr. Solbes said the German economy was much more exposed to the United States than its 11 euro-zone neighbors. And it is in shakier fiscal shape than its partners: relative to the size of the economy, Germany's budget deficit this year is expected to be the largest in the European Union, at 1.7 percent of gross domestic product. Mr. Solbes said tax cuts made necessary by tepid economic conditions and other factors were responsible for the growing deficit, but he added, "This has to be temporary and must be reversed in 2002."
The commission's report foresaw average inflation of 2.2 percent this year in the euro zone, slightly above the European Central Bank's target of 2 percent, but it forecast a fall to 1.8 percent in 2002. Unemployment was seen falling from about 8.9 percent in 2000 to 8.5 percent in 2001 and 7.9 percent in 2002.
Analysts said the rosy inflation forecast was optimistic and perhaps meant to push the bank to cut interest rates. "Our methodology does give rise to more optimistic results than other institutions," Mr. Solbes acknowledged. "But often these are closer to reality."

HEADLINE: Big Grant Proposed for Ailey Home 

BYLINE:  By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, known more for his passion for opera than for dance, yesterday proposed a matching city grant of $7.5 million toward a plan by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater to build a glittering new home of glass and metal in Manhattan. 
 The building, at Ninth Avenue and 55th Street, would be the largest space in the country devoted exclusively to dance, Ailey officials said. 
 In the last eight months, the 43-year-old dance institution has intensively searched for new quarters in Manhattan to replace its crowded, rented studios at 211 West 61st Street. The city pledge is intended to jump-start the company's ambitious plans, disclosed yesterday, to develop a $47.5 million building on a site now occupied by WNET's old television studios. 
One board member said the dance troupe had already collected $20 million in pledges, making it almost certain that the company would get the city money under a complicated matching formula.
"This will give us visibility in the dance capital of the world," said Sharon Gersten Luckman, the executive director of the Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation, which includes the principal and junior performing groups and a growing school. When completed in spring 2004, she said, the building will include eight floors of studios, a small theater and offices.
The commitment to the Ailey was included in the mayor's revised budget proposal for the next fiscal year, released yesterday. But Mr. Giuliani expressed confidence that the dance company would get the money. He predicted that the City Council might add more. 
"The major benefit to the city is to anchor a great New York institution and the economic development that it can bring," said Mr. Guiliani, who has attended performances of the company, but said, "I have to admit I'm much more of an opera fan."
"One of the things I tried to change in the budget is that the arts institutions are good for business," he said. "They bring lots of jobs and they bring lots of tax revenues."
The Alvin Ailey company's efforts to find a new home mark the steady transformation of one of the most prominent African-American cultural institutions. The company was founded in 1958 by Mr. Ailey, a tall Texas-born dancer, whose work features pieces like "Blues Suite," a dance of pain and anger associated with the blues and the African-American experience. His most popular works fuse modern, jazz, and classical dance into performances that continue to draw large numbers of young dance fans.
Still, less than 10 years ago, the Ailey was a company struggling to pay its bills. It had a $1.5 million deficit and contributions were meager. But by 1993, several donors like the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Arts Stabilization Initiative and the Doll Foundation provided money to steady the organization, which embarked on a relentless campaign to increase its visibility.
The company also created a wide assortment of programs to nurture new audiences with an Alvin Ailey summer day camp and an Ailey Dance Kids program that takes dancers into New York City's public schools. 
In recent years, the company has maintained stable cash reserves and has sold out performances at City Center. Its list of contributors has been dominated by foundations, which last year gave more than $2 million, compared with $507,000 from government grants. So Mr. Giuliani's proposal is an enormous sum for an arts institution accustomed to receiving $90,000 to $135,000 a year from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs.
"It's magnificent," said Arthur J. Mirante, a member of the Ailey board and the chief executive of Cushman & Wakefield, which volunteered last year to find new quarters for the company. "This money from the city is exactly the kind of bridge we needed to give us a sense of financial security."
The design for the company's new headquarters will nearly double the dance space for the company to 71,000 square feet, with a transparent building of glass and metal that will allow pedestrians to glimpse dancers rehearsing. "It's going to feel like a lantern on the street," said the building's architect, Natan Bibliowicz. "It's going to feel so energetic." 
The new building would have 12 studios, including a theater, with a seating capacity for 300, that can also be converted into two studios. The dance space will consist of so-called floating floors, whose composition makes them soft to the feet. "When you jump on this floor it has a little give," Mr. Bibliowicz said.
Ms. Luckman, the company's executive director, said the group would rent studios to other dance troupes at reduced rates to soften the jolt of rents that have soared as high as $50 an hour in Manhattan. 
The company's school of 3,500 students has been growing at an annual rate of about 10 percent a year, Ms. Luckman said, adding that there are waiting lists for some classes.
With a budget last year of $13 million, the construction of a new building is an enormous undertaking for Alvin Ailey. In addition to the $47.5 million cost of demolition and construction, the troupe also intends to create a $12.5 million endowment fund to subsidize new productions. 
Mr. Mirante said that even before drawings of the new building were created, donors had pledged almost $20 million for construction.
"There will be a big announcement and we are in the early stages of our campaign," said the board's new chairwoman, Joan Weill. She and her husband, Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, have given heavily to Carnegie Hall, where Mr. Weill is chairman of the board. 
Michael M. Kaiser, the president of the Kennedy Center in Washington, who as its top administrator helped restore the Ailey troupe to financial stability in the early 1990's, said the company was capable of achieving its ambitions.
"The company is so well run and the board has such strength," he said, "that I am absolutely confident that the Alvin Ailey organization, which is the leading African-American cultural institution, must and can find the resources to find a permanent home."

HEADLINE: 28 in Queens Are Charged In Pollution At Junkyards 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
A yearlong investigation into environmental crimes at Queens junkyards ended yesterday with the arrests of 28 workers charged with dumping thousands of gallons of toxic car fluids that poisoned the land and poured into Flushing Bay.
 A team of city police officers and state investigators raided 21 junkyards in the large commercial strip on Willets Point near Shea Stadium, arresting owners and employees and seizing millions of dollars in assets, including bank accounts and machinery. The charges could lead to sentences of four years in prison, heavy fines and multimillion-dollar payments to clean up brownfields and Flushing Bay, the state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, said. Thirty-two junkyard workers were charged; four have not been arrested. 
 "This is a massive environmental debacle," he said. "These businesses have been dumping fluids that leave our environment in horrendous shape, and leaving the public to pay for the cleanup. They've created brownfields that lie fallow, that nobody wants. That forestalls economic development and creates wastelands in the middle of the city."
Mr. Spitzer said the workers poured antifreeze, brake fluid and other toxic fluids onto the ground, where they leached into the water system. They cut concrete trenches to channel the waste into Flushing Bay, he said, and pumped fluids through hoses that emptied into storm water drains or the bay. 
"They deliberately punctured holes in tanks so that gas and oil and antifreeze ran all over the place," said Mary Ellen Kris, the New York City director of the State Department of Environmental Conservation. "They were renegades when it came to environmental law. They've caused extensive damage to the soil and the bay." 
The investigation, carried out by city police, the attorney general's office and the Department of Environmental Conservation, began when undercover police officers opened a scrap metal shop to investigate the junkyards for unrelated crimes. A city police detective, Joseph Wedge, got in touch with the other agencies when he saw the greasy blackened soil and oil-slicked puddles around the shops. That evidence allowed state investigators to obtain search warrants. 
Mr. Spitzer said charging the junkyard workers with felonies and civil violations of state environmental regulations was significant because polluters are usually charged with misdemeanors.
"The judges impose a $500 fine," Mr. Spitzer said. "It's like a ticket. It isn't much of a deterrent." 
The junkyards, which cover most of the 55-acre Willets Point area, have long been an eyesore, the Queens borough president, Claire Shulman, said. She hopes to have them all condemned this year, violators and law-abiders alike, to make room for an urban renewal project. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 28, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article and a picture caption on Thursday about arrests for environmental crimes at junkyards near Shea Stadium misidentified the section of Queens. It is Corona, not Willets Point.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Hints Deals Are Near For Ballparks 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON with RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dangled a tantalizing surprise before city residents yesterday as he released his $39.5 billion city budget, hinting once again that new baseball stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets would be built soon.
 "We are negotiating with both the Yankees and the Mets and we are very, very close and we will tell you everything in about two weeks, maybe three," he said. 
 But before the afternoon had turned into evening, Mr. Giuliani's aides were playing down his comments, saying that in fact much work remained before any kind of announcement could be made about long-debated new or renovated stadiums for the Mets or Yankees. 
"It could be two or three weeks, it could be a month; it could be four months away," one administration official said. "There is no deal."
What prompted the mayor to segue from budgetary matters into one of his favorite subjects -- new and improved stadiums -- became apparent a bit later in the day. Mr. Giuliani ventured into that territory when he was asked about one of the most pressing questions in this year's budget. 
How would the administration cut taxes next year by about $525 million, as the mayor has proposed, and find the money to give union employees a 4 percent raise, the terms of a tentative settlement reached with the city's largest union? The answer, according to one administration official, was a clever solution that had not been previously disclosed. The city found some extra money for labor costs by raiding a stadium fund of $194 million that had been set aside in previous financial plans. 
The mayor's budget also contained a passing hint of an alternative method the city might use to help pay for $600 million in stadium construction costs in the future. It could use so-called lease appropriation debt, most likely relying on a quasi-government entity like the Industrial Development Agency to pay for the construction and then use tax revenues generated by the stadium and nearby properties to help repay the debt.
Yesterday, when Mr. Giuliani was asked to explain the financing -- building new Mets and Yankee stadiums would cost an estimated $1.5 billion -- he declined to elaborate, instead hedging a bit on his earlier boast. 
"You can be really close to finishing the negotiations and then you never finish it," he said yesterday. "So I don't want to say anything else about it."
And by late yesterday afternoon, during an interview on WABC radio, he backpedaled even more, although he was still promising a brand new stadium in the Bronx for the Yankees, which many of his critics believe is highly unlikely.
"We don't have a deal yet on any one of the stadiums, but we are closer than we have been in the past," he said.
"There is a lot to be done," one administration official said.
The budgetary maneuver and others like it that were released yesterday show just how tight the city's budget is this year, as city tax revenue grows more slowly, given the slowdown in the economy.
Mr. Giuliani, in addition to eliminating the sports facilities from the fiscal 2002 budget, advocated tens of millions of dollars in other new cuts in various city departments, including a total of $46.3 million from city libraries, $23.3 million from city museums and other cultural institutions and $23 million in a variety of city health programs.
Given those cuts -- and a tax cut package that the City Council has already objected to --Giuliani administration officials have already predicted tougher-than-normal negotiations with the Council, which intends to either approve the mayor's budget or adopt its own by early June.
The $39.5 billion budget the mayor unveiled yesterday, his eighth and final spending plan, includes a sprinkling of new programs. There is $34 million to provide weekend science and English classes to tens of thousands of city public school students, another $33 million to intensify the war against drugs in high-crime neighborhoods and $67 million to finance a new Health and Hospitals Corporation program that will reimburse the city hospitals for care that, to a large extent, it already provides to uninsured immigrants.
On the bricks-and-mortar side, known as the capital budget, the mayor has included money to build, over the coming years, new courthouses in Brooklyn and the Bronx, new schools across the city, a new Willis Avenue Bridge and for improvements in many city buildings. There is also a large increase in spending on new museums and other cultural institutions, including large grants for Lincoln Center, the Guggenheim Museum and the Museum of Modern Art, all of which are undertaking expansion or renovation projects in the next several years.
But in the 2002 fiscal year, which starts July 1, there was a fair share of belt tightening needed to balance the budget while also covering about $525 million in tax cuts that mayor wants, as well as the labor settlement. The settlement alone would cost the city about $1.7 billion in fiscal 2002, assuming somewhat optimistically that teachers, police officers and unions that represent other workers accept the same package tentatively agreed to earlier this month by the 125,000-member District Council 37 union.
Spending has been tightened at many agencies, and City Council officials bluntly stated yesterday that they would move to block many of those cuts.
"With the stroke of a pen, the mayor has cut vital services to seniors, children, and the poor," said Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone.
Council leaders also objected yesterday to the mayor's tax cut package, which they said is too expensive and not beneficial enough to middle- and lower-income residents. The mayor proposed four different tax cuts yesterday for 2002, including the elimination of the city sales tax on clothing and shoes and a reduction in the city's personal income tax that would save a family of four that earns $100,000 about $89 a year.
The Council has its own tax-reduction package, which would offer tax breaks for child-care costs, on mortgages taken out by first-time homebuyers and to lower-income working families, instead of the across-the-board income tax cut the mayor has proposed. The Council's package would also cost much less, a total of $366 million in the 2002 fiscal year.
Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he is confident he is leaving the next mayor with a city that is in strong fiscal shape, and able, if necessary, to weather an economic downturn.
But Mr. Vallone and several budget watchdog groups warned yesterday that Mr. Giuliani's spending plan still threatens to leave the city with large future budget deficits.

HEADLINE: Bush Fails to Win Over Moderate Democrats on Tax Plan 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25 

 BODY:
With Congress heading toward a decision about how much to scale back his $1.6 trillion tax cut, President Bush met with moderate Democratic senators today in search of support but made no apparent headway.
 Acknowledging explicitly that he was unlikely to get his full plan passed, Mr. Bush pressed ahead as negotiators from the House and Senate staged a brief public meeting to kick off their effort to find a middle ground between the budget plan passed by the House, which provided for Mr. Bush's full tax cut, and the plan adopted by the Senate, which reduced the tax cut to $1.2 trillion over the next decade. 
 But the real negotiations are not so much between the House and Senate as among the White House, the Republican leadership in the Senate and moderate Democrats who might be persuaded to vote for a tax cut in the range of $1.4 trillion, a level that Mr. Bush signaled today that he could accept.
With the Senate divided 50-50, those Democrats have proved to hold the balance of power on budget issues, especially since two Republicans, James M. Jeffords of Vermont and Lincoln D. Chafee of Rhode Island, have said they will not support a tax cut bigger than $1.2 trillion.
So far, though, the seven moderate Democrats most widely seen as the swing votes have held firm against increasing the tax cut above $1.2 trillion, frustrating Mr. Bush on the centerpiece of his agenda.
Mr. Bush invited a number of the Democrats, including Senators Max Baucus of Montana, Ben Nelson of Nebraska, Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey and Max Cleland of Georgia, to the White House this morning to discuss the situation. Mr. Bush also had dinner on Tuesday night with Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana.
Afterward, Mr. Bush said he recognized that there would have to be a compromise between $1.2 trillion and $1.6 trillion.
"The way I like to describe it is, we've come from the ideological to the practical and I'm a practical man," Mr. Bush said in an interview with the Associated Press. "I want to get it done."
The politics of tax cutting this year are particularly complex. There is broad support in both parties for pushing through a quick and substantial tax cut for this year to give a boost to the faltering economy. 
There is also bipartisan backing for many specific types of tax cuts. Just today, the House Ways and Means Committee approved an expansion of the 401(k) and individual retirement account programs. Separately, Republicans in the House fell short in their effort to push through a measure that would require a two-thirds vote in each chamber to raise taxes, rather than a simple majority. 
The real debate has been over how big a tax cut is affordable and politically viable, and which components should be included. The prevailing view around the Capitol today was that no deal would be struck on the size of the tax cut or spending levels until next week at the earliest.
Mr. Chafee said the leaders should be careful about increasing the tax cut above the $1.2 trillion over 10 years that the Senate approved three weeks ago. "If we start edging our way up," he said, "we're going to start to lose senators."
There was no indication that Mr. Bush had changed the minds of any of the Democratic senators, but several said they had been impressed by his apparent flexibility.
"He's looking for partnership that's not partisanship," Mr. Nelson said. 
Earlier this month when the budget plan was before the Senate, Mr. Nelson said, the strategy of the White House seemed to be "to pick off one or two of us." That was not his sense at the White House today, Mr. Nelson said. "I felt more comfortable coming out that we would have an opportunity for a solution."
The senators said the president implied that he was looking for a compromise tax cut in the range of $1.4 trillion. 
But none of the senators agreed to accept such a compromise, and aides to several of them said later there was a consensus in the group to stand by their support for nothing bigger than $1.2 trillion.

HEADLINE: U.S. WOULD DEFEND TAIWAN, BUSH SAYS 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 25 

 BODY:
President Bush, offering a more explicit commitment to Taiwan than his recent predecessors, said in a television interview broadcast today that if the island came under attack from China, he would order "whatever it took" to help Taiwan defend itself. 
 Mr. Bush did not go so far as to say he would send American forces into battle with China. During his presidential campaign, however, he questioned the wisdom of the policy of maintaining "strategic ambiguity" about how the United States would react if hostilities broke out across the Taiwan Strait, and said repeatedly that, in contrast, his administration would be "clear about Taiwan." 
 While the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act commits the United States to help Taiwan defend itself, presidents have deliberately kept vague how they would respond in the case of an armed conflict. The policy was designed so as not to encourage Taiwan to be bolder in its own statements, and to contain the political factions on the island that have argued for declaring independence, a move China says would prompt an armed response. 
Asked on ABC's "Good Morning America" if the United States had an obligation to defend Taiwan if it was attacked by China, Mr. Bush replied: "Yes, we do, and the Chinese must understand that. Yes, I would." 
The interviewer, Charlie Gibson, pressed further, asking, "With the full force of American military?"
Mr. Bush said, "Whatever it took to help Taiwan defend theirself." He did not elaborate.
Mr. Bush's comments seemed to trigger some confusion on Capitol Hill and among China experts over what the president meant and what signal he was sending to Taiwan. But his aides said tonight he had chosen his words quite carefully.
Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, who traveled here with Mr. Bush for a Republican fund-raising event, said tonight that he was not changing policy. But she made clear that he was deliberate in his choice of words. "What he said clearly is how seriously and resolutely he takes this obligation," she said. "A secure Taiwan will be better able to engage in a cross-straits dialogue."
The Taiwan Relations Act says: The president is directed to inform the Congress promptly of any threat to the security or the social or economic system of the people on Taiwan and any danger to the interests of the United States arising therefrom. The president and the Congress shall determine, in accordance with constitutional processes, appropriate action by the United States in response to any such danger.
Mr. Bush's statement was part of what his aides say is a "rebalancing" of American policy away from Beijing -- where Mr. Bush's aides believe President Clinton veered -- and back toward Taiwan. 
That is bound to gratify the conservative wing of his party, which has grumbled that his arms sales to Taiwan on Tuesday should have included the sophisticated Aegis radar system. It is also sure to further inflame Beijing. In that regard, it seemed similar to his statements about North Korea in the first weeks of his presidency, when he appeared to turn his back on missile talks that President Clinton had begun, to the discomfort of South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, and take a harder line toward the Communist regime in Pyongyang. Those comments essentially froze peace talks between North and South Korea.
Earlier today, Chinese officials denounced Mr. Bush's decision to sell destroyers, submarines, helicopters and other military hardware to Taiwan even though the Aegis had been excluded from the list. Admr. Joseph W. Prueher, the American ambassador to Beijing, was summoned by the deputy foreign minister, Li Zhaoxing, and according to state television was asked to tell Mr. Bush to "immediately withdraw this mistaken decision and stop selling arms to Taiwan to avoid new grave damage to China-U.S. relations."
Mr. Bush's statements about Taiwan came in the course of a series of television interviews marking the approach of his 100th day in office. The interviews were taped at the White House on Tuesday, though they were broadcast just before Mr. Bush came here for a rally in support of his tax plan and his budget.
Within hours of the broadcast the State Department said there had been no change in the American policy. "Our policy hasn't changed today, it didn't change yesterday, and it didn't change last year, it hasn't changed in terms of what we have followed since 1979 with the passage of the Taiwan Relations Act," Philip T. Reeker, a State Department spokesman, told reporters today. "And the president was very clear on our position, and I think he reiterated what we've always said." 
But to many of Mr. Bush's own aides and allies, his statement today sounded much like what George W. Bush the candidate had said, but not what past presidents including his father or American diplomats had said in carefully worded statements.
Until now, the essence of American policy has been to keep the peace by keeping both sides guessing. Presidents from Richard Nixon to Bill Clinton have wanted Beijing to believe that the United States would defend Taiwan, but also to leave Taiwan wondering about the extent of that commitment. Washington has always feared that if the Taiwanese believed the American commitment to their security was ironclad, they would be emboldened in their dealings with Beijing, perhaps to the point of provoking a conflict.
But Mr. Bush's advisers during the campaign said they viewed that policy as outmoded. Taiwan is now a full-fledged democracy, they said, and has elected a longtime opposition leader as the president. Moreover, they argued that Beijing's military buildup in recent years made it imperative for Washington to be more explicit about supporting the island.
Outside experts on China and Asia policy said that while Mr. Bush has changed the language, he may not have changed the understanding of both sides about how the United States would react.
"He covered both sides of the argument," said Richard H. Solomon, president of the United States Institute of Peace, and a longtime Republican foreign policy adviser, though he has not advised this White House.
"He said we'll defend Taiwan, but he doesn't want Taiwan to precipitate a crisis," said Mr. Solomon, referring to comments Mr. Bush made in an interview with CNN today.
Mr. Solomon noted that "the big issue that's not being discussed is whether Taiwan is to be dealt with as a military problem or a political problem." President Nixon, he noted, had converted the Taiwan issue to a political question when he opened up relations with Beijing. Mao said at that time that Taiwan was a long-term problem, taking the immediacy out of the issue of how it might reunify with China.
But during Mr. Clinton's term, the conflict became remilitarized. President Jiang Zemin made it clear, during Taiwan's 1996 presidential election, that China would not wait indefinitely, and triggered a crisis by conducting military tests off Taiwan's coast. Mr. Clinton sent two carriers into the area, though not directly into the Taiwan Strait, as a show of resolve. China backed off.
Mr. Bush's comments triggered an immediate reaction on Capitol Hill. Senator John F. Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat who is considered a possible presidential contender in 2004, took to the Senate floor this afternoon to speak out against Mr. Bush's comment on Taiwan.
"If what the president said is in fact what he means or if it is indeed the new policy of the United States, it has profound implications for our country," Mr. Kerry said. "He made a far-reaching comment this morning on the American defense of Taiwan, a comment that suggests that without any consultation with Congress, without any prior notice to the Congress, that a policy that has been in place for 30 years is now being changed with implications that I believe are serious."
Mr. Kerry said that the United States had never said what it would do if Beijing tried to use force to reclaim Taiwan because "we understood the danger of doing so."
He said that if Mr. Bush had decided to abandon the "so-called strategic ambiguity," it was a "major policy change" that "serves neither our interest nor Taiwan's."
Mr. Kerry noted that any situation that resulted in the use of force across the Taiwan Strait was unlikely to be black and white. "For example, if China attacked in response to what it sees as a Taiwanese provocation would we then respond?" he asked. "Apparently so, according to President Bush."
Representative Gary Ackerman, a New York Democrat and member of the International Relations Committee, said that Mr. Bush had apparently confused a policy of providing Taiwan with defensive weapons with a broader defense commitment.
"Has this become a unilateral defense treaty?" Mr. Ackerman asked. " 'Whatever it takes' means you will do anything to defend Taiwan," Mr. Ackerman said. "Does it mean that if Taiwan attacks China, we are at war with China?"

PERSON: Rev. Leon H. Sullivan 

HEADLINE: Leon Sullivan, 78, Dies; Fought Apartheid 

BYLINE:  By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
The Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, the clergyman and civil rights leader who drew up the Sullivan Principles, guidelines for American businesses operating in South Africa under apartheid, died yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 78.
 The cause was leukemia, his family said. 
 In 1977, Mr. Sullivan drafted his guidelines to help persuade American companies with investments in South Africa to treat their workers there in the same way that they treated their workers in the United States. He later worked with the United Nations on drawing up a code of ethical conduct for multinational corporations.
As originally stated, the Sullivan Principles called for racial nonsegregation on the factory floor and in company eating and washing facilities; fair employment practices; equal pay for equal work; training for blacks and other nonwhites so they could advance to better jobs; promotion of more blacks and other nonwhites to supervisory positions, and improved housing, schooling, recreation and health facilities for workers.
In an interview in 1999, Mr. Sullivan recalled an experience a quarter of a century before that helped give birth to his effort.
"In 1974 I met with hundreds in South Africa and I realized that apartheid was sinful," he said. "When I was getting on the plane to go home, the police took me to a room and told me to remove my clothes. A man with the biggest .45 I'd ever seen said, 'We do to you what we have to.'
"I stood there in my underwear, thinking, 'I'm the head of the largest black church in Philadelphia and I'm on the board of directors of General Motors. When I get home, I'll do to you what I have to.' " 
In 1984, after Mr. Sullivan had used his position as a member of the board of the General Motors Corporation to persuade virtually all American companies doing business in South Africa to abide by his guidelines, he added several more, saying that American companies should also campaign actively against apartheid, allow black workers full job mobility and provide accommodation closer to work.
By 1987, with apartheid undented by his principles and African leaders like Nelson Mandela still in prison, Mr. Sullivan toughened his approach, urging American corporations to withdraw altogether from South Africa and calling for the United States to impose trade and investment sanctions on that country.
This harsher stance, however, won little support from either the Reagan administration or American business leaders.
In 1999, by now retired as a clergyman, Mr. Sullivan promulgated his own Global Sullivan Principles, ethical guidelines for multinational corporations in the globalized economy; about 100 American corporations have now accepted them.
In this effort, he worked closely with the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, who that year put forth his own Global Compact, another set of ethical guidelines for multinational corporations based on accepted United Nations principles.
Although the Sullivan Principles skirt such labor issues as the right to collective bargaining, the United Nations has accepted them as a practical attempt to put its ideals into practice.
Leon Howard Sullivan was born on Oct. 16, 1922, in Charleston, W. Va. He was brought up by his grandmother after his young parents separated. 
At the age of 10 he conducted a private desegregation drive in his hometown after being told he could not sit at a drugstore counter while drinking a soft drink. He won a first victory when the owner of a segregated restaurant offered him a free meal.
While he was still in the South, he met the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell, who was on a lecture tour. Several years later, he introduced Mr. Sullivan to the Abyssinian Baptist Church in New York with the announcement, "I can take a young man from the hills who looks like he never wore a pair of shoes in his life and make him a leader!"
After graduating from West Virginia State University, he studied theology at Union Theological Seminary in New York and sociology at Columbia, meanwhile working as a coin-box collector for the Bell Telephone Company, the first black to hold such a job. 
In 1945 he married the former Grace Banks and spent the next five years as pastor of the First Baptist Church in South Orange, N.J. In 1950 he became pastor of the Zion Baptist Church in Philadelphia. Here he and other black pastors started a Selective Patronage Program, under which they boycotted enterprises that failed to provide employment for minorities. The highly successful program was copied in many other cities.
In 1962 he founded Zion Investment Associates, a cooperative organization that began investing in profit-making ventures. From modest beginnings it went on to create major real estate ventures, a garment manufacturing company and Progress Aerospace Enterprises, the first black-owned aerospace company.
In 1964 he set up the first in a series of training schools, calling it the Opportunities Industrialization Center. By 1969 about 20,000 minority workers were enrolled in O.I.C.'s around the country.
In 1971 he joined the board of General Motors, the company's first black director. He was instrumental in expanding black employment and creating more black dealerships. He was awarded honorary degrees by Dartmouth, Princeton and Swarthmore, among dozens of other colleges.
In 1988 Mr. Sullivan retired from Zion Baptist Church, moved to Phoenix, and began building bridges between Africa and black America, organizing a series of African and African-American summit meetings, with the first held in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, in 1991.
He is survived by his wife and three children, Howard, Julie and Hope.

HEADLINE: Mr. Giuliani's Risky Budget 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's proposed $39.5 billion budget for the next fiscal year came with a note of caution yesterday. The huge surpluses of recent years cannot be counted on in the future, Mr. Giuliani said, and expenditures for next year will have to be kept under tight control. Unfortunately, the mayor's spending plan does not heed his own advice. Mr. Giuliani would cut taxes and increase spending so heavily that the next New York City mayor, to be elected in November, will immediately face annual deficits approaching $3 billion in following years. Mr. Giuliani and the City Council need to avoid leaving such a damaging legacy. 
 Mr. Giuliani's budget was largely foreshadowed by a financial plan he presented in January. In one new development, the mayor said that the city was "very, very close" to completing negotiations for city financing of new stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets, and possibly for the Jets on the west side of Manhattan. But before endorsing any grand spending plans, New Yorkers need a fuller explanation of the possible precariousness of city finances should the economic slowdown turn much worse. 
 Good times have brought a budget surplus in the current year of $2.8 billion, which Mr. Giuliani irresponsibly proposes to use to plug the deficit next year, putting off for the next mayor the tough decisions about the future. Most of the projected deficits down the road result from the fact that the recent labor settlement with the biggest municipal employees' union, calling for 4 percent annual wage increases, would cost $2 billion next year if applied to all city workers. Unfortunately, Mr. Giuliani did not get any promises from the work force to improve productivity. He would compound the problem ahead by cutting taxes now and letting future mayors find the money for vital services.
An air of unreality about the city's fiscal future is not a problem for Mr. Giuliani alone. The major mayoral candidates are all calling for more spending without saying where the money would come from. In his budget yesterday, Mr. Giuliani again used a bookkeeping gimmick to promote the fiction that he is cutting spending next year. In fact, according to the city's Independent Budget Office, spending would go up 4.4 percent under his budget. It is likely to go up even more because the City Council will almost certainly restore some of the mayor's proposed spending cuts for health, youth services, cultural institutions and libraries.
In his final budget presentation as mayor, Mr. Giuliani said his proudest achievement was keeping expenditures under control and cutting taxes by more than $3 billion a year. It has indeed been an impressive accomplishment, aided significantly by the good fortune of an economic boom, particularly on Wall Street. With rougher economic weather ahead, this should be a time to reassess spending, demand greater productivity from the work force and rethink automatic new rounds of tax cuts. The candidates for mayor should level with the voters that a harsh new reality may lie just ahead.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
E.D.S. Says Its Earnings Met Estimates Of Analysts

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
Saying it felt little of the pain inflicted on its competitors during the economic slowdown, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that met Wall Street's expectations and announced that it expected to do so for the rest of the year.
 E.D.S., a computer service company based in Plano, Tex., said its businesses remained strong in the United States, Europe and Asia in the quarter, which ended March 31. The company said it signed $7.5 billion in contracts in the first three months of the year, the ninth consecutive quarter of record signings. 
 The company reported earnings, excluding one-time gains and charges, of $268.1 million, or 56 cents a share, a 19 percent increase from the period a year before, when it earned 47 cents a share. The quarter produced the eighth consecutive double-digit increase in earnings growth. Analysts had expected earnings of 55 to 59 cents, with a consensus of 56 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
Including a change in its accounting principle and a one-time investment gain of $315.5 million, E.D.S. earned 93 cents a share. Revenue was $5 billion, compared with $4.6 billion in the quarter last year.
In a conference call filled with congratulations by analysts, a rare sound in recent times, Richard H. Brown, the company's chief executive, said he was comfortable with Wall Street's projections for the current quarter and the full year. Analysts expect earnings of 62 cents this quarter and $2.64 for the year, according to First Call.
Mr. Brown said E.D.S. had benefited from the general slowdown in the economy. During the boom, companies hired E.D.S. to help them grow. Today, he said, they hire E.D.S. to streamline their operations and cut operating costs.
"The way we're attacking the market is different today than it was a year ago," Mr. Brown said in an interview. "While E.D.S. is not immune to economic cycles, we are well insulated against the down market."
E.D.S. said that Information Solutions, its outsourcing division and core business, grew 20 percent in the quarter. The company's systems-integration consulting business, E.Solutions, grew 38 percent. Mr. Brown said E.Solutions had benefited from a shakeout in small Internet consulting firms.
But E.D.S. said revenue from its single largest customer, General Motors, declined 7 percent, from $856 million to $791 million, a steeper drop than expected. Revenue from its consulting division, A. T. Kearney, also declined 4 percent.
Adam B. Frisch, an analyst with UBS Warburg, praised Mr. Brown and his management team for improving the company since taking over two years ago. But Mr. Frisch said the stock was trading near the high end of its 52-week peak in expectations of strong quarters, and the General Motors and A. T. Kearney declines indicate that E.D.S. is not as insulated from the general economy at it might say.
"No company is an island unto itself," Mr. Frisch said.
Shares in E.D.S. fell 28 cents, to $63.27, in regular trading, but rose as high as $65 in after-hours trading.

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
Partnership Dissolved
 A year ago, after much fanfare, the Museum of Modern Art in Manhattan and the Tate Gallery in London announced a partnership to create an Internet business for art, culture and design. But this week, in a news release about the venture's new president, the Modern let it slip that the partnership had dissolved. 
 "We've decided to continue alone and are happy to do so," said Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Modern.
Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, said this wasn't the time to proceed with a costly, not to mention risky, venture. "Our decision was based on a combination of the economy and the way in which the Internet itself is developing," he said. "It just didn't seem like a sensible move." He added that the Tate planned to go on developing its nonprofit Web site. 
The Modern is steaming ahead, though the site has changed direction. Rather than focusing heavily on e-commerce, selling products like furniture, design objects and books, it will be more heavily tipped toward educational and editorial content. Because it is a business venture, it will operate separately from the museum, and profits are to be channeled back to help pay the Modern's escalating expenses.
The news that the museum was going it alone came as it announced the appointment of Steven Henry Madoff as the venture's president and editorial director. He has most recently been editorial director of Time Inc. Interactive, responsible for the company's Web properties.

Atrium Attractions
Now that the $151 million expansion of its York Avenue headquarters is complete, Sotheby's has decided to transform its nine-story atrium into a showcase for site-specific contemporary art.
When Christie's completed its Rockefeller Center headquarters two years ago, it commissioned Sol LeWitt to create a mural for the three-story entrance. Sotheby's, on the other hand, is implementing a program called "Art in the Atrium," inviting artists to create works that will be on view for six months.
This week a series of 20 wood lamps 30 inches tall will cascade down the glass-filled atrium. The lamps are the work of Jorge Pardo, the Cuban artist who has tranformed the ground floor of the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea with brightly colored tilework. 
"I wanted the first artist to be someone who deals with architecture," said Tobias Meyer, Sotheby's director of contemporary art worldwide.
Sotheby's said it planned to commission artists to conceive works, and then the Art Production Fund, a nonprofit arts organization in Manhattan, is to organize the projects and see them to completion. After an exhibition the artwork goes back to the artist.
Sotheby's said it planned to pay an undisclosed fee to each artist as well as production costs. If the artist sells his work, Sotheby's is to be reimbursed for the cost of production.
"Since we are a building about art," Mr. Meyer said, "I wanted to express it right at the entrance."

Renaissance Beauties
Although scholars have been fascinated with female Renaissance portraits for decades, no museum exhibition has explored the subject. Of particular interest is the century from 1440 to 1540 in Florence, where portraits no longer depicted only rulers and their consorts but also women of the merchant class whose faces adorned scores of panel paintings, medals and busts by artists like Leonardo, Botticelli and Pontormo.
Now the National Gallery of Art in Washington has put together 47 portraits of women -- paintings, drawings and sculptures -- that are the subject of "Virtue and Beauty: Ginevra de' Benci and Renaissance Portraits of Women," to run from Sept. 30 to Jan. 6. The show will not travel to other museums.
David Brown, curator of Italian Renaissance paintings at the National Gallery, said, "Originally I was going to do a small, focus exhibition on Leonardo's 'Ginevra de' Benci,' " a painting in the gallery's permanent collection. "I had gotten two spectacular loans, one a drawing of Ginevra's hands from Windsor Castle and the other a marble bust by Verrocchio that was clearly Leonardo's model for the painting." But further investigation made it clear that a survey of the century's portraits was needed, he said.
The title of the exhibition was taken from the phrase "beauty adorns virtue," an inscription on the back of the "Ginevra de' Benci."
"The same language was used in a lot of portraits," Mr. Brown said. "It was this paradoxical link between female virtue and female beauty that is the core of the exhibition."
Also at the heart of the show are the social history of the time, when portraiture was still a new genre of painting. Outside Florence, a woman had to be the wife or daughter of a ruler to have her portrait painted.
Most of the works on view are bridal portraits. "Because these women were not famous, we don't know a lot about who commissioned them," Mr. Brown said. "Probably they were commissioned by the husbands or by the bride's family. But we know little about the circumstances or the sitters because they weren't great ladies."
The show will underscore the point that these Renaissance portraits are far different from today's. They are not direct likenesses that try to reveal the inner nature of their subjects but paradigms of the ideal woman. Most women were shown with beautiful long necks, golden hair, pearly white skin, sparkling blue eyes and rosy lips and cheeks: the canon of beauty as derived from literature of the time.
One example is a Botticelli portrait of Simonetta Vespucci, a cousin by marriage of Amerigo Vespucci, the Italian explorer for whom America was named. She died from consumption at 23 and became known as the paragon of idealized beauty.
In the United States a huge vogue for these works started when J. P. Morgan bought Ghirlandaio's portrait of Giovanna degli Albizzi Tornabuoni, wife of a Medici banker. The painting, which the Morgan Library sold to Baron Thyssen in 1935, is now in the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum in Madrid.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Detail of a Botticelli, among the Renaissance portraits in Washington. (National Gallery of Art)

HEADLINE: Chemical Weapons Ban May Suffer for Lack of Dues From Treaty's Parties 

BYLINE:  By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
The international organization charged with verifying the 1997 treaty that bans chemical weapons is in debt and may be forced to cut inspections in half this year because the United States and other key parties to the treaty have not paid their way, arms control experts said Wednesday. 
 Ron G. Manley, director of verification for the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, which is charged with implementing the treaty and ridding the world of chemical weapons, said in an interview that the United States, Russia and other member states were largely responsible for the financial crunch by failing to pay their annual assessments on time and failing to reimburse the group for inspections and other activities. 
 As a result, he said, the organization -- which is based in The Hague, spends about $60 million a year and employs about 500 people -- ran a deficit of $4 million in 2000, and expects a shortfall this year of $5.5 million. 
Mr. Manley said that even with belt-tightening and other economies, the group would probably be able to conduct only 60 to 80 of the 140 inspections planned for this year. 
Earlier predictions about the budget crisis were far more dire. In an internal memorandum in January, Jose M. Bustani, the organization's director general, warned that his group would only be able to conduct 25 inspections of chemical plants this year. 
Mr. Manley discussed the budget crisis and other problems confronting the organization in an interview and at a conference Wednesday in Washington that debated the record of the treaty, which was circulated for signatures in 1993 and entered into force in 1997. The conference was sponsored by the American branch of Green Cross International, a nongovernmental group based in Geneva and headed by former Russian president Mikhail S. Gorbachev. 
Meanwhile, a report on the chemical weapons treaty by the Monterey Institute of International Studies, scheduled to be released yesterday, concludes that while the treaty can claim "significant accomplishments" in recruiting new member states, identifying weapons stockpiles and beginning to destroy them, the United States, during the Clinton administration, undermined the treaty in several important ways. 
Jonathan B. Tucker, the editor of the 72-page report, said that the treaty had yet to fulfill its promise "in large part because of a lack of U.S. leadership." 
Analysts who contributed to the study agreed that the Clinton administration diluted the treaty by, among other things, creating unilateral exemptions to its terms and failing to demand inspections in countries like Iran, which it has accused of violating the treaty. 
The previous administration, concluded Amy E. Smithson, a chemical weapons expert and senior associate at the Henry L. Stimson Center in Washington, "made a mockery" of the treaty by establishing what she called "a separate set of rules for the United States." For instance, Congress gave United States presidents the right to refuse an inspection on grounds that it could "pose a threat" to national security and provided that samples collected during inspections on American soil had to be analyzed by laboratories in the United States. Washington was also three years late in declaring a list of America's chemical factories that could be inspected, the authors noted. 
The report criticizes Russia's implementation of the treaty as well. Alexander A. Pikayev, a scholar at the Carnegie Endowment's center in Moscow, concludes that even if Moscow finds enough money to fulfill its pledge to destroy the 40,000 metric tons of chemical weapons it admits to having produced, which Mr. Tucker calls the world's largest stockpile, Russia might still be "unable to meet its obligations under the treaty." Because of its financial plight and delays in its chemical weapons destruction program, Russia missed the deadline to eliminate one percent of its chemical weapons stocks by April 29, 2000.
John D. Holum, the undersecretary of state for arms control in the Clinton administration, disagreed with the report's conclusions, saying the Clinton team had fought hard, if somewhat belatedly, for the treaty's ratification. The administration was forced to accept the unilateral exemptions to the inspection system to win ratification, he said. In response to the assertion of failing to pay dues on time, Mr. Holum said the United States angered most international organizations by paying dues not in January, when they are due, but at the beginning of the fiscal year some nine months later.
An official in the Bush administration who asked not to be identified said the administration strongly supports the Chemical Weapons Convention and its implementation. 
The official -- noting that the United States still pays the highest dues of the 143 states that have signed and ratified the treaty -- said the administration was "working hard" to find money to reimburse the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons for verification activities. He said that Congress had provided no money for this purpose in fiscal 1999 or fiscal 2000. 
The official also noted that the administration had paid about two-thirds of its 2001 assessment. "It is not our intention to undermine this treaty," he said.
