HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Rise Sharply, And So Does the Cost of Labor 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26 

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing for first-time unemployment benefits rose last week to the highest level in five years, while employment costs climbed in the first quarter, the Labor Department said today.
 Analysts said the reports suggested a weakening job market and more pressure on corporate profit -- both trends that might encourage the Federal Reserve to further cut interest rates in hopes of bolstering the economy. 
 The number of Americans seeking jobless benefits last week rose to 408,000 from 390,000 in the previous week, the Labor Department said. It was the highest level since March 23, 1996, when claims reached 428,000. 
The four-week moving average, which is considered a more reliable barometer of employment conditions, rose to 394,500, the highest in eight and a half years and the fourth consecutive weekly gain.
"That is a sign of weakness," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston.
The Federal Reserve has reduced the benchmark short-term interest rate by half a percentage point four times this year -- a total of two percentage points, to 4.5 percent now. Many think that the Fed will again cut rates at its next meeting, on May 15.
The Labor Department also reported that its cost index, a broad gauge of what employers pay in wages, salaries and benefits, rose 1.1 percent in the three months ended in March, matching expectations. The gain was higher than the 0.9 percent advance in the fourth quarter and amounted to a 4.1 percent increase in the 12 months from March 2000.
"Labor costs are rising," said Paul Kasriel, chief economist of Northern Trust. "Productivity is not rising that rapidly. That means that corporations are seeing their profit margins squeezed from the higher labor costs and energy costs."
A separate survey by the National Association for Business Economics released today found that spending by companies on capital improvements rose in the first quarter at the slowest pace since 1992. The organization's index of capital spending fell to zero from 20 in the fourth quarter of 2000.
The group also said that 55 percent of the 131 members polled this month estimated economic growth of 1 percent or less in the first half of this year. In January, only 10 percent of members surveyed expected growth of less than 1 percent.
The government's report on the gross domestic product for the first quarter will be released on Friday.

HEADLINE: Ukraine Parliament Dismisses Cabinet, in Blow to Reformists 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 26 

 BODY:
Ukraine's political crisis mounted today as Parliament voted overwhelmingly to dismiss Prime Minister Viktor Yushchenko and his government, dealing a blow to the pro-reform movement that Mr. Yushchenko brought into office in December 1999.
 The vote of 263 to 59 marked the end of an uneasy alliance between the prime minister and President Leonid D. Kuchma, the former Soviet rocket factory manager who has governed the country as prime minister and then president since 1994. 
 No successor to the ousted prime minister was appointed. The loss of Mr. Yushchenko at the helm of Ukraine's reform program is likely to jeopardize the support of international lending institutions for the former Soviet republic, a country the size of France that lies strategically between Russia and the rest of Europe and is the one of the largest recipients of American aid. The ouster occurred on the 15th anniversary of the nuclear accident at Chernobyl, whose effects -- in terms of increased illness and radiation contamination -- are said by Ukrainian officials to grow more acute with each year, even as the government lacks funds to deal with the legacy of the catastrophe. 
The no-confidence vote raises the question of whether the dumping of Mr. Yushchenko, orchestrated in large part by Mr. Kuchma and his parliamentary allies over the last year, will drive the popular prime minister to become the standard-bearer of the opposition that seems eager to form around him. The United States has distanced itself from Mr. Kuchma in recent months.
"Democracy in Ukraine has suffered a serious defeat," Mr. Yushchenko said after the stormy meeting of the Parliament. "I am not abandoning politics. I am going away in order to come back." 
The key to his ouster was the decision by Ukraine's Communist deputies, who hold about a quarter of the 450 seats, to join the coalition of oligarch-led parties and Mr. Kuchma's core supporters to shape a new majority. 
As Parliament voted, a crowd estimated at 10,000 Yushchenko supporters -- one of the largest since demonstrations began in Kiev last winter -- chanted "Yushchenko!" and called for Mr. Kuchma's impeachment. A peaceful crowd of about 3,000 people tried to march on Mr. Kuchma's residence, Ukrainian news agencies said, but was blocked by police lines. 
Today's vote is also the culmination of political conflict that intensified last fall with the release of secret recordings made of Mr. Kuchma's private conversations in office. They revealed in graphic and earthy terms his disdain for democracy, freedom of the press and for Mr. Yushchenko's popularity as a pro-Western reformer.
Mr. Yushchenko, 47, an affable former central banker with a slightly ponderous political style, has no natural political base, and Mr. Kuchma sits astride a powerful and well-financed patronage machine that enforces discipline from the national police down to the village chief.
Still, Mr. Yushchenko represents the strongest potential challenger to Mr. Kuchma's rule as parliamentary and presidential elections approach in 2002 and 2003 and as Mr. Kuchma's image in the West flags. Indeed, Mr. Kuchma and his parliamentary allies have hired public relations and lobbying advisers in Washington in recent months to halt the slide in support for his leadership.
The crisis has sent thousands of protesters into the streets since December. It has destabilized -- until today -- any working majority in Parliament, and galvanized a significant coalition of opposition parties under the "Ukraine without Kuchma" banner demanding that Mr. Kuchma resign and call early presidential elections, which he has refused to do.
A key element, which has thrown Mr. Kuchma on the defensive and prompted him to fire his intelligence and security chiefs, was the disappearance of muck-raking journalist Georgy Gongadze in September. Mr. Gongadze's name became linked to Mr. Kuchma after tape recordings made by a presidential bodyguard indicated that the Ukrainian leader had placed the journalist under surveillance and had instructed security forces to "get rid" of him. A headless body, believed to be that of Mr. Gongadze though that is still in dispute, turned up outside the capital, Kiev, in November.
Mr. Kuchma's top security assistants have hampered and delayed the investigation. 
A former presidential bodyguard, Mykola Melnychenko, who says he was motivated by outrage and patriotism in the face of Mr. Kuchma's alleged involvement in corruption, recorded hundreds of hours of Mr. Kuchma's conversations. He then fled to Europe in November and has released the recordings piecemeal ever since. 
This month Mr. Melnychenko and his family were granted political asylum in the United States, a fact Mr. Kuchma's supporters have used to bolster their allegations that the 63-year-old leader's troubles are the result of a conspiracy from abroad.
Mr. Yushchenko, for his part, has appeared eager to champion clean government and economic reform as he also tried to confront Ukraine's endemic and rampant corruption problems. In doing so, Mr. Yushchenko has garnered a national following that has yet to be tested in a popular election.
He has also profited from the stormy confrontation between his former deputy prime minister, Yulia Timoshenko, and the barons of Ukraine's notoriously corrupt state-run energy industries. Ms. Timoshenko, who made her own fortune in the murky gas market, entered Mr. Yushchenko's cabinet last year vowing to bring order to Ukraine's most vital sector, triggering clashes with some of Mr. Kuchma's closest allies.
For her efforts, she was first fired, in January, then arrested in February and charged with corruption in her business dealings. A judge then ordered her release. She is now a leading member of the opposition.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue-Chip Shares Climb, but Technology Suffers Setback

BYLINE:  By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose yesterday as investors' hopes for another interest rate cut grew, but technology shares fell on persistent uncertainty about earnings prospects.
 Economic data released yesterday showed that the number of Americans seeking first-time unemployment benefits rose last week to its highest level in more than five years. Analysts suggested that the report would encourage the Federal Reserve to lower rates further at its next meeting on May 15. 
 "The unemployment rate is going to be rising," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. "But it's giving more room for the Fed to continue doing what they have to do, which is cut rates in May. And they will do that." 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 67.15 points, or 0.63 percent, to end at 10,692.35, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.77 points, or 0.47 percent, at 1,234.52.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 24.92 points, or 1.21 percent, to 2,034.88, after rising 1.5 percent earlier. Investors received a promising outlook from WorldCom but a gloomy forecast from Qualcomm.
Robert Parry, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, put a damper on bullish sentiment yesterday, saying he expected the turnaround in the sluggish economy would take longer than thought. He said the economy would grow at a faster pace by year's end.
This prompted some investors to book profits from the recent surge in technology stocks, which had taken the Nasdaq market up by more than 30 percent after it hit a two-year low early this month on bleak corporate earnings news.
"Parry is reminding us that we are not out of the woods yet," Tom Sparico, stock trader at Bengal Partners in Stamford, Conn., said.
The economic slump is leading to layoffs nationwide. The Labor Department said initial jobless claims rose 18,000, to 408,000, for the April 21 week, the highest level in five years.
The Dow was helped by a surge in interest-rate-influenced financial stocks. Among Dow stocks, American Express rose 80 cents, to $41.90.
General Electric moved up $1.49, to $49.30, and its merger partner Honeywell International climbed $1.68, to $49.19.
G.E.'s chairman, John F. Welch Jr., said late on Wednesday that he was confident 2001 would be a record year for the company and that the proposed acquisition of Honeywell, currently under review by European competition officials, should be completed by July. 
Investors have been scouring corporate scorecards this week -- the busiest period of the earnings season -- for hints the economy is recovering after the Fed's four rate cuts this year. Numerous upbeat earnings reports came from energy companies as they benefited from sharply higher oil and natural gas prices. 
Among those, Halliburton, the oil field services company, jumped $3.51, to $42.13, as its operating profits more than tripled. BJ Services soared $3.58, to $79.48, after its international revenue helped push earnings sharply higher.
The surge in oil shares also came as United States gasoline futures hovered at new post-Gulf War highs as worries lingered that gasoline supplies may not be adequate to prevent price spikes this summer as the driving season starts.
WorldCom, the No. 2 long-distance phone company, posted profits that were in line with forecasts and stood by its 2001 revenue estimates, notable in a time when many telecommunications companies have cut growth estimates sharply. WorldCom rose 35 cents, to $19.74.
But Qualcomm added some gloom to the market with a drop of nearly 8 percent, or $4.87, to $58.05. The company, a wireless technology giant, posted earnings that matched expectations, but warned that future earnings would miss forecasts in a weak global economy.
Treasury bond prices snapped three days of losses yesterday.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 21/32, to a price of 98 22/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 5.17 percent from 5.26 percent on Wednesday. The 30-year Treasury bond surged 1, to 95 12/32. Its yield fell to 5.70 percent from 5.77 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Independence In Computers Is I.B.M. Goal

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
I.B.M. said yesterday that it planned to invest billions of dollars over the next few years in an effort to design computers and networking products that would adjust to changing workloads, recognize faults and repair themselves without human intervention.
 Many of the investments involve projects already under way. Nevertheless, industry analysts said that I.B.M.'s vision, called Project Eliza, is expected to encourage Big Blue's diverse units to focus on the problem and invest more resources. 
 "Several vendors are attacking this from different directions, but I.B.M. is trying to take it to the next step," said Thomas Bittman, a consultant with Gartner Inc. in Stamford, Conn. But what people outside the company would like to see, he said, is I.B.M.'s road map for creating specific product plans and the timetables for delivering them. 
I.B.M. has long been known for pushing the frontiers of machine intelligence. One prominent example was the construction of Deep Blue, the supercomputer that defeated Garry Kasparov, the international chess champion, in 1997.
In recent years, Irving Wladawsky-Berger (pronounced law-DAW-skee berger), I.B.M.'s top hardware technology strategist, became acquainted with the intense interest of government security and systems experts in self-monitoring and healing systems through his participation on the President's Information Technology Advisory Council. And I.B.M.'s research arm had already singled out such technology -- autonomous computing, in the jargon of engineers -- as a major focus for its work.
But, Mr. Wladawsky-Berger said, the company's decision to accelerate efforts to create new self-managing computers and systems grew out of work with big customers that had invested heavily in electronic commerce, an area I.B.M. has identified as the linchpin of its future growth.
Those customers told I.B.M. their No. 1 concern was the growing gap between the amount of technology they had to manage and the number of skilled workers available to do the job.
"There's a ridiculously tiny number of people that really understand what it takes to keep an e-business alive," said Daniel Kaberon, computer resource manager for Hewitt Associates, a human resources consulting company based in Lincolnshire, Ill.
I.B.M. said Hewitt and other members of its Advanced E-Business Council, which includes computer users as varied as Verizon, United Parcel Service and major banks, have said they face a triple-pronged onslaught: rapid growth in the power and sophistication of the processors and data storage equipment they oversee; links to more and more sources of electronic activity inside and outside their companies; and an explosion in the variety of electronic devices.
I.B.M. said the situation was bound to get worse. "Our customers will have roughly 10 to 20 times more technology to manage over the next five years," Mr. Wladawsky-Berger said.
Designing computers for an Internet-driven economy is a major challenge.
"The Internet requires computers to survive much more unpredictable environments than in the past," Mr. Wladawsky-Berger said. "This is a very tough problem."
I.B.M. said that building much more intelligence into machines had become feasible in recent years because new designs for microchips pack previously unimaginable computing power into compact spaces. Now companies like I.B.M. can use some of that capacity for subsystems that monitor electronic behavior and traffic precisely, recognize troubling or foreign patterns and respond appropriately.
For example, Mr. Wladawsky-Berger said, the primary defense system against attempts to disrupt service that is used by I.B.M. and others these days is a software barrier known as a firewall. But I.B.M. is aiming toward something more like the human immune system, with its blood components that find and identify foreign bodies and others that disable them.
In the nearer term, portions of the project will focus on hastening the deployment of technology already used in I.B.M. mainframes into cheaper computers, which often operate in clusters. I.B.M. said the expertise it had accumulated in building mainframes that work for years without failing and with minimal supervision should give it an advantage in building adaptive behavior into less complex equipment. Mr. Wladawsky-Berger went so far as to claim a 10-year lead in the field.
Other vendors scoffed, naturally. "Hewlett-Packard shares the vision I.B.M. is articulating, and it has been a factor in our designs for the past year," said John Miller, a server marketing executive with Hewlett. Mr. Miller noted, for example, that Hewlett's recently introduced Superdome server computer is designed to furnish status reports continuously from the customer's site to Hewlett-Packard's monitoring center. That center can recognize small data-handling errors that could lead to larger problems, and have them fixed before the device breaks down. Increasingly, Mr. Miller said, the fixes will be automated.
Mr. Kaberon of Hewitt Associates said I.B.M. was in the lead in pursuing self-management for complex systems because it has to be. Unlike other vendors, it sells and supports computers with a wide variety of operating systems, as well as both internal and external software applications, he said. "I.B.M. has greater insight because they have a bigger problem," Mr. Kaberon said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs Aid to Turkey Tied to Economic Overhaul 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26 

 BODY:
The United States has pledged to support a fresh $10 billion emergency aid package for Turkey's troubled economy, but Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill has warned the nation's leaders that they will not receive any more international assistance if their latest economic overhaul plan fails, people involved in the negotiations said today.
 The warning is an early example of the Bush administration's vow to practice tough love during emerging-market financial crises. Mr. O'Neill and other senior Bush administration officials have criticized the Clinton administration for backing repeated bailouts of economies in crisis, often with meager results. 
 The International Monetary Fund is preparing to announce that it and the World Bank, its sister agency, will loan Turkey about $10 billion to support a new round of market-oriented changes to its financial system. The new loan program comes just two months after the fund arranged an $11.5 billion rescue package for Turkey, but the nation has continued to experience financial turmoil. 
Mr. O'Neill played an active role in arranging the terms of the fund's latest aid package, reflecting the importance of Turkey as a sizable emerging market and a strategic ally that is a member of NATO. But Mr. O'Neill warned Kemal Dervis, Turkey's economy minister, that he should design the nation's economic program carefully because the international safety net would be withdrawn after this round of aid.
"The U.S. has made clear that it's three strikes and you're out," said one person involved in the negotiations. The latest aid package would be Turkey's third from international lending agencies in recent months.
As one sign that the flow of aid money to Turkey is limited, the Bush administration has declined to offer the nation any direct aid to go along with the fund's program. The United States, European nations and Japan often provide bilateral assistance on top of loans from the fund as a way of demonstrating broad international involvement in a financial rescue, though the fund's money comes largely from taxpayers in the leading industrial nations.
Under pressure from the Bush administration, the fund also has demanded that Turkey enact a series of economic and financial changes before the fund's board of directors formally votes on whether to approve the new loan package, people involved in the talks said.
The fund often makes such changes conditions of its loans. But the Turkey package puts an unusual emphasis on what the fund calls prior actions, meaning that none of the aid money will be distributed until promised changes are implemented by government officials and Parliament. In previous bailouts, the fund often begins distributing aid quickly, though it sometimes suspends a loan program if a client nation fails to adhere to its reform plan.
To receive the $10 billion in new loans, Turkey has agreed to a list of 15 major changes to its financial and economic system, the people involved in the negotiations said. They include a plan to make the central bank more independent of politicians, allow its currency, the lira, to float freely on international markets, restructure its troubled banking systems, reduce government spending, and arrange more privatization of state-owned companies.
Though the fund has yet to release the details of the aid package, the promised changes in Turkey are typical of fund programs during the Clinton administration. The fund often demands austerity measures combined with market-oriented financial overhauls as the price of its assistance.
Turkey has been hobbled by political and economic turmoil for months. The lira, which began trading without limits in international markets two months ago, has lost half its value. And confidence in the banking system has plummeted amid charges of political corruption.
The instability has severely damaged the reputation of Turkey, which had embarked on an ambitious program to bring its economy up to European standards in preparation for joining the European Union.
Turkey's difficulties are expected to be a major topic of discussion this weekend, when world finance ministers gather in Washington to discuss the world economy. They will also review operations of the fund and the World Bank.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING 

 BODY:
 UNITED NATIONS

ANNAN CLOSER TO RE-ELECTION
China has given its backing to a second term for Secretary General Kofi Annan, making it virtually certain that the Security Council will recommend his re-election by the General Assembly in the fall. Diplomats had seen China as the only possible holdout among the five veto-wielding council members, on the argument that it was Asia's turn to hold the office. The United States and France have supported him; Britain and Russia are expected to do so also. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

AUDITORS CLEAR DRUG CZAR
A team of British auditors for the United Nations has cleared Pino Arlacchi, the head of the organization's anti-narcotics office, of charges of impropriety made by a former associate and some politicians in Europe. But the report faulted his office, the United Nations Drug Control Program, in Vienna, for some lapses in recruitment procedures and handling of travel expenses, as well as overambitious programs begun before money was available to see them through. Two other reports on his office are due in coming weeks from the United Nations inspector general's office. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

EUROPE

RUSSIA: LIMITING FOREIGN INFLUENCE
The lower house of Parliament gave overwhelming preliminary approval to a law that would limit foreigners to less than a 50 percent stake in any Russian media company. The bill, which passed its first reading 332 to 22, is intended to protect Russians' freedom of speech and national security, said Aleksandr Chuyev, a member of Parliament from the Unity faction allied with President Vladimir V. Putin. Some foreign companies already own larger shares of Russian media companies and would apparently be forced to sell some of their interests should the bill become law. Michael Wines (NYT)

BRITAIN: GOOD NEWS FOR LIVESTOCK
The government said that because of the drop in the number of new cases of foot-and-mouth disease, it was easing its policy of automatically slaughtering healthy animals on farms next to those with infected cattle. The policy is credited with curbing the spread of the virus but has caused enormous distress to farm owners. Local veterinarians will now have the power to decide whether it is necessary, Agriculture Minister Nick Brown told the House of Commons. Warren Hoge (NYT)

GERMANY: A WAY OUT FOR KOHL
An inquiry into former Chancellor Helmut Kohl over his Christian Democratic Union's slush fund will be closed as soon as he pays a $133,500 fine, prosecutors in Bonn said. Mr. Kohl acknowledged in December 1999 having accepted more than $900,000 in undeclared party contributions between 1993 and 1998 and has repeatedly refused to identify the donors. A deadline of June 8 was set for the payment. Victor Homola (NYT)

FRANCE: ALGERIAN GENERAL FLEES LAWSUIT
Algeria's former defense minister, visiting France to promote his memoirs, fled yesterday after being named in lawsuits charging him with torture. General Khaled Nezzar, who was defense minister from 1990 to 1993 and had a reputation for brutally suppressing Islamic fundamentalists, was sued by three families and French prosecutors agreed to investigate him. It was the first time France has tried to enforce international human rights claims like those under which Britain held the former Chilean dictator, Augusto Pinochet,in custody for months. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

MIDDLE EAST

ISRAEL: A GUARDED CELEBRATION
Israelis celebrated their 53rd Independence Day inside a ring of very tight security, with police officers and soldiers surrounding parks packed with familes picnicking and barbecuing. In Gaza, tens of thousands of Palestinians attended the funerals of four men killed in a blast near the Egyptian border. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

AMERICAS

MEXICO: INDIAN RIGHTS BILL ADVANCES
An Indian rights bill sought by the Zapatista rebels and supported by President Vicente Fox passed its first legal hurdle in a unanimous Senate vote. The bill, a proposed constitutional amendment, requires approval by the lower house and a majority of state legislatures. It would guarantee political and cultural rights to roughly 10 million Indians. Tim Weiner (NYT)

ASIA

TAJIKISTAN: DROUGHT CAUSES FOOD CRISIS
The World Food Program, a United Nations agency, said that a drought that has crippled agriculture in western and central Asia has left more than a million people facing severe food shortages in Tajikistan. The organization is seeking 127,000 tons of food, worth $62 million, to compensate for a collapse of wheat production in large areas of the country, which has 6.2 million people. The United States is traditionally the largest donor of international food relief. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

PHILIPPINES: SUPPORT FOR EX-PRESIDENT
Tens of thousands of predominantly poor people rallied in Manila in support of former President Joseph Estrada, who was arrested and jailed Wednesday on a charge of plundering the economy. Mr. Estrada issued a statement saying, "Don't worry about me here in jail because I remain strong." His lawyers are seeking his release into house arrest. Seth Mydans (NYT)

PAKISTAN: DEMOCRACY CAMPAIGNERS SEIZED
The military government rounded up hundreds of people in an attempt to block a May 1 rally of political parties demanding a return to democracy, according to party officials. The government, which took power in a bloodless coup in October 1999, used large-scale detentions to crack down on a similar rally in Lahore last month. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

HEADLINE: Deaths at Work Fall by Nearly Half in 20 Years 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 26 

 BODY:
Workplace deaths in the United States have dropped by nearly half over the last two decades, the government said today, crediting new technology, stricter safety regulations and a shift in the economy toward safer service-industry jobs.
 The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said 5,285 workers died from on-the-job injuries in 1997, the latest year for which figures were available. That is a rate of 4.1 deaths per 100,000 workers, down 45 percent from 1980, when it was 7.4. 
 "The hazards workers face are considerably different," said Suzanne Marsh, a statistician at the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. "We're moving from an industrial country to a more service-oriented country."
The Centers for Disease Control also attributed the decrease in deaths to new technology and stricter safety regulations.
Car crashes have accounted for one in four on-the-job deaths since 1980, the agency said. Homicides accounted for 14 percent, and machinery accidents 13 percent.
Mining was the most dangerous sector, with 30 deaths per 100,000 workers over the two decades. Agriculture and forestry followed at 19 deaths per 100,000 workers.
The agency cautioned that its numbers probably underestimated the number of deaths in the workplace because it measured them using a nationwide survey of death certificates. The Labor Department issues its own statistics on workplace deaths, tracking them with a more comprehensive method that also scours federal regulatory reports and news clippings.
Those numbers go back only to 1992 but have shown a similar trend -- a steady drop in deaths at work.
"There's been more emphasis on prevention by employers, government and workers," said William Weber, an assistant commissioner at the Labor Department. "People's consciousness was raised."
The C.D.C. report said men accounted for 93 percent of workplace deaths over the two decades.
"They tend to work in the construction industry, in industries that would face a higher danger," Ms. Marsh said.
In a separate report, the C.D.C. said American workers were treated in emergency rooms for 3.6 million work-related injuries in 1998.

HEADLINE: A New Politics of Pain: Japan's Tough Economic Repairmen 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 26 

 BODY:
For Japan's reform-minded new government, the central economic challenge is that almost anything it does to try to fix the long-term problems of an out-of-control budget deficit and a wobbly banking system will almost certainly exacerbate the country's immediate woes and risk pushing the economy into a new recession.
 Just today, the nation's central bank issued a bleak assessment of the economic prospects, predicting meager growth in a range of 0.3 percent to 0.8 percent in the fiscal year that will end next March. 
 Yet Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, and the three-man team he has selected for the leading economic policy posts, have generally favored positions at odds with the stimulative measures that previous governments relied on over the last decade to prop up the ailing economy. If they are to succeed now with a different approach, analysts said, they will need to develop a new kind of power-sharing arrangement. 
Only one of the three economic ministers, Hakuo Yanagisawa -- who will remain as head of Japan's bank regulatory authority, the Financial Services Agency -- has extensive experience in government financial posts.
The reappointment of Mr. Yanagisawa, seen by the markets as a hard-headed proponent of repairing a dysfunctional banking system, was greeted with relief by economists and investors. He represents consistency and underscores Mr. Koizumi's commitment to forge ahead with tough measures to clean up the bad debts of banks and corporations.
Analysts also hailed the choice of Heizo Takenaka, an outspoken economist at Keio University in Tokyo, as economic policy minister. But he has no experience pulling the levers of government, and his advocacy of harsh remedies for Japan's economic ailments is likely to collide with political concerns over important legislative elections in three months. Already, Mr. Koizumi, the new prime minister, has denied that there will be an increase in the much-hated consumption tax, which is one of Mr. Takenaka's chief prescriptions.
The appointment of Masajuro Shiokawa, 79, as finance minister was perhaps the biggest disappointment in the cabinet line-up, and currency traders raced to sell yen. Stock markets had closed by the time his name surfaced. By early Friday afternoon, stocks were down almost 1 percent and the yen sold here at 123.47 to the dollar, weakened from 123.16 in New York the day before. 
Mr. Shiokawa has limited economic or financial credentials, which he demonstrated today when he said that he would leave monetary policy to Mr. Yanagisawa's agency, rather than the central bank, where responsibility for monetary matters lies by law.
But the markets may underestimate Mr. Shiokawa and misunderstand the role he is expected to play. The finance ministry used to be the tail that wagged the dog by its regulatory control over the financial sector, monetary policy and government purse strings. That is no longer true. Administrative reforms have sharply reduced the ministry's scope, leaving it to handle the government's books but assigning responsibility for the financial system to the Financial Services Agency and control over interest rates, the money supply and other monetary affairs to the central bank.
Having served in various government posts and as a chief figure in the ruling party, Mr. Shiokawa knows how to get things done.
"You need a man who actually knows his way around the ministries because the budget is all about line items and getting things done," said Jesper Koll, chief economist at Merrill Lynch here. "The markets have looked at his age and dismissed him as a throwback, but Shiokawa's not about back-pedaling on reform; he's about making sure reforms get done."
And if Mr. Takenaka and Mr. Yanagisawa are permitted to pursue an austerity strategy for economic and financial reform, it will take someone in the finance ministry to ensure that funds flow to the places needed to alleviate the social pain that will accompany such a fiscal overhaul.
To understand how the three might work together as a team, consider the construction industry. Japanese construction companies and related industries provide jobs for roughly 10 percent of the population and are one of the biggest sources of the votes and campaign contributions for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party.
It is not surprising that the construction business has been the biggest beneficiary of government efforts to stimulate the economy with grandiose public works projects. Construction has also dug itself into the deepest hole, requiring the biggest repair effort to overcome the accumulation of bad debts.
Mr. Yanagisawa is apparently prepared to pursue that. Construction was singled out for reform in a recent emergency economic package, and Mr. Yanagisawa has made no secret of his desire to clean it up.
That will mean increased unemployment among a group of workers that has been a reliable source of political support.
It will fall to Mr. Takenaka -- who recently wrote a best seller that explains economic A B C's, using a give-and-take with a famous copywriter as the narrative device -- to convince those workers and the public at large that increased unemployment, at least in the short term, is necessary for long-term health.
"He's what you Americans call a spin doctor," Mr. Koll said. "His job is to sell policy to the people."
Mr. Shiokawa at the finance ministry will have the unenviable task of finding the money to support newly unemployed construction workers and to retrain and redeploy them to more productive sectors of the economy, like telecommunications and health care.
Nor will he have the luxury of tapping a supplemental budget for the money. While there has been much speculation that such a budget will be in place before elections for the upper house of Parliament at the end of July, it would violate Mr. Koizumi's campaign promise to limit government bond issuance to 30 trillion yen -- currently $243 billion.
Only if the three men move in such a concerted fashion can Japan benefit from their tenure in office. The other critical player, the central bank, has already said that it will support such a process with appropriate monetary activity. But it will be up to the new cabinet members to break the political logjam that has blocked such efforts before.

HEADLINE: A New Age In Acne Treatment; 
It's No Longer Just a Market For Teenagers

BYLINE:  By JULIAN E. BARNES 

 BODY:
Although Coleen Rattigan had to treat an occasional pimple as a teenager, she never had serious acne. Then she turned 21. For the last two years she has had to fight off an onslaught of breakouts. Now her face is clear, but she is on two prescription acne drugs and visits the dermatologist almost weekly to get an injection that eliminates individual blemishes.
 "You think once you get into your 20's it is gone, but instead it has come back worse," she said. Ms. Rattigan, a 23-year-old junior account executive at Bear, Stearns, said many of her girlhood friends with skin perfect enough for a Noxzema commercial now battle pimples with an army of prescription and over-the-counter medications at a time when they might be expected to be worrying more about the onset of wrinkles. 
 In fact, doctors say, female adults are seeking treatments much more often than in the past, raising sales of everything from body washes to birth control pills in their quest for clear skin. 
Skin care and drug companies have seized on -- and perhaps exploited -- the trend, bombarding women with ads that play on the insecurities of young adults with less-than-perfect skin and explicitly discuss new, more effective treatments.
"There is a large segment of adult women worried about acne, and skin care companies realize it, and the pharmaceutical companies are also making more products for adult women," said Dr. Diane S. Berson, a dermatologist at the New York University School of Medicine.
The market for prescription acne medications rose 16 percent, to $1.1 billion last year, and 21 percent from 1998 to 1999, to $960 million, according to IMS Health, which tracks sales of prescription drugs. Sales of the drugs most often prescribed for women increased even more rapidly and accounted for nearly two-thirds of the market in 2000. And the overall figures do not include a birth control pill that clears up blemishes and had a 40 percent increase in sales last year.
Sales of acne treatments in supermarkets and drugstores grew 15.5 percent in 2000, to $338 million, says A. C. Nielsen, a market research firm. Sales to adults actually declined slightly last year, but much of that was because of lower sales to men, says the NPD Group, a market research firm.
At department stores, which sell most of their treatments to women, sales of acne remedies rose 73 percent in 1999 and 45 percent last year, to $22 million, NPD said. Over all, adults are about 60 percent of the market for prescription and over-the-counter acne medications, and women's share of the adult market increased from 64 percent in 1997, to 73 percent last year, NPD said.
Some recent surveys suggest that 50 percent of women have breakouts, and one study has put the incidence of mild acne in women as high as 54 percent in 1996, compared with 35 percent in 1979.
But others suspect that women are simply more worried about blemishes than they used to be.
People increasingly perceive clear skin as important, several experts said. Executives are often judged partly on their appearance when they are seeking promotions or new jobs, said John A. Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, an outplacement firm. He said standards were often higher for women, and he counsels female job applicants that they must be better than the men they are competing against, including looking better and more professional.
"If someone comes in and seems to be breaking out all over in acne, that can cause the other person discomfort," he said, adding that having acne can also make the job seeker anxious, undermining the interview.
In many cases, women who have acne never had extensive breakouts as teenagers. But in some 30 percent of cases, acne continues from teenage years, dermatologists say.
"I wasn't looking forward to hitting the three-oh, but I thought this would be one thing that would go away," said Chantal St. Louis, 31, who was recently promoted to marketing manager with New York City Transit. "It didn't. Lately it's gotten worse."
Some skin care companies are profiting from women's growing interest in acne medication. In 1997, Cindy Zielinski, a vice president for marketing at Neutrogena, was flipping through beauty magazines when she paused, surprised by the number of letters and advice columns on women with acne.
The next year, Neutrogena, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, did a study that showed that 59 percent of women 25 to 39 suffered from acne in the previous 12 months. "We never realized so many adult women have acne," Ms. Zielinski said. "It caused us to say this is an amazing opportunity."
Neutrogena began an ad campaign with the none-too-comforting slogan "Unfortunately, acne stands out even more on an adult."
Neutrogena says its own research shows the number of female adults using the company's acne products increased 38 percent from 1998 to 2000. The company's share of the over-the-counter acne medication market rose from 21 percent and second place in 1998 to first place and 24 percent last January, according to Information Resources, a market research organization.
Among the women captured by Neutrogena's ads was Jenny Zhang, a 30-year-old Web developer in Manhattan. About six weeks ago, as stress at her job built, her face broke out, she said. A few weeks later, Ms. Zhang found herself standing in front of a display of Neutrogena acne products that she had seen advertised.
"This is the first time I have had pimples," she said. "I haven't had a breakout like this." 
Doctors have had to adjust, with everyone else, to seeing acne as an adult problem. "Fifty years ago, we were taught that acne was an adolescent disease," said Dr. Albert M. Kligman, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania medical school and author of several books on acne. "That is no longer the case."
Dermatologists like Dr. Kligman who say that female adults have more acne today than they did in the past point to a pair of studies conducted by the University of Leeds in 1979 and 1996. The British researchers found that the incidence of serious acne among men stayed around 3 percent, but among women it increased from 10 percent, to 14 percent. The incidence of less severe acne in women rose to 54 percent from 35 percent, said Dr. Victoria Goulden, a dermatologist at the Skin Research Center in Leeds, who helped conduct the 1996 study.
But Dr. Goulden said the studies were not conclusive. Although they looked at people in a variety of jobs with a range of income and education, she said, they did not use a random sample.
If blemishes are on the rise, some dermatologists say the hormones released by increased stress may be at fault. Stress, Dr. Kligman said, stimulates the adrenal gland, which creates substances that give rise to androgens. Androgens are male hormones that stimulate oil production, helping to clog hair follicles and allowing the bacteria that cause acne to inflame the skin.
"There is no doubt women face more stressful circumstances, and women are making more androgen," Dr. Kligman said. 
Still, stressed-out people may just care about getting rid of acne more, said Dr. Mary Gail Mercurio, an assistant professor of dermatology at the University of Rochester Medical Center, who has written on the role hormones play in acne.
Some women are simply more sensitive to the hormones that cause acne, Dr. Mercurio said.
Plenty of dermatologists say the whole debate is not very relevant to patients.
"I am dealing with young professionals in New York," said Dr. Hilary E. Baldwin, a Brooklyn dermatologist who treats many adult professional women with acne. "If I tell them their condition is caused by stress, what are they exactly supposed to do?"
Since few people are likely to quit a good job to eliminate a blemish, the answer for many women lies in the dermatologist's office, pharmacy or department store beauty counter.
Many dermatologists who treat women prescribe Accutane, and last year sales reached $587 million, up 21 percent from the previous year, according to IMS Health. Although Accutane, made by Hoffmann-La Roche, has been found to cause birth defects and critics of the drug have linked Accutane with depression, many dermatologists say that it is the best way to eliminate the persistent acne that affects women. 
Dermatologists also prescribe an oral contraceptive, Ortho Tri-Cyclen, that has been approved to treat mild acne, and Johnson & Johnson, which owns the company that makes it, has aggressively promoted this use. Sales of Ortho Tri-Cyclen have more than doubled since J.& J. began running television ads citing its effectiveness against acne in 1998, rising from $225 million, to $493 million.
As for department stores, Clinique, the Estee Lauder unit with the largest share of acne medications sold in department stores, introduced its latest line of acne treatments in September 1999. Sales of those products have increased 73 percent since then, Lauder said. Women make up much of Clinique's market.
"The only thing worse than having a wrinkle is having a pimple and a wrinkle at the same time," said Nance Dickinson, senior vice president for marketing at Clinique.
Felicia Milewicz, the beauty and health editor at Mademoiselle magazine, argues that it is important to pay extra attention to skin because it is no longer fashionable to use heavy makeup. "The days are gone when you bought foundation to cover a blemish," she said. "Now there is a need for perfection. Skin is the mirror of our inside, so we want our skin to look beautiful."
That sort of pressure is enough to cause a breakout.

HEADLINE: Japan's New Cabinet Breaks Hold Of Traditional Political Factions 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 26 

 BODY:
The new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, made good today on his pledge to steer clear of the factions that have traditionally dominated Japanese politics, naming one of the most eclectic cabinets in the country's history and including a record five women.
 The woman widely regarded as Japan's most popular politician became the country's first woman to serve as foreign minister, while a political veteran with decades of experience but little economic background was given the crucial post of finance minister. 
 Mr. Koizumi's appointments immediately raised the prospect of trouble within his own party for breaking the longtime practice of distributing ministerial appointments on the basis of factional strength in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. 
Only 6 of the 17 cabinet members came from the three main factions that have dominated the party, which has governed Japan almost without interruption since 1955.
Mr. Koizumi's choices reflected a conspicuous outreach to new constituencies, including women, the private sector and younger Liberal Democratic politicians frustrated with the seniority system that has governed advancement in the party.
The first real glimpses of Mr. Koizumi's policy orientation came in his selections for minister of economic and fiscal policy, and finance minister. And many commentators said the conflicting signals from the appointments dampened expectations of sweeping policy changes.
Also widely remarked on was Mr. Koizumi's choice for foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, the daughter of the late prime minister, Kakuei Tanaka, the Liberal Democratic Party's most fabled power broker. 
Ms. Tanaka, who was an early supporter of Mr. Koizumi's campaign, holds her father's old parliamentary seat, but has shunned party factions, and shares the new prime minister's passion for change. She was expected to win a cabinet post, but the foreign minister's job came as a surprise to many because of her reputation for bluntness.
Ms. Tanaka -- who speaks English well, attended high school in Pennsylvania and at 57 is a relative youth in her party -- will have the task of handling the delicate relationship with Washington and Japan's ties with the rest of Asia. Japan's relations with its neighbors are often clouded by its behavior during World War II. South Korea, for example, recently recalled its ambassador from Tokyo to protest new school textbooks the Koreans feel gloss over Japan's harsh imperial occupation.
"Ms. Tanaka is regarded favorably, as pro-alliance, and is very outspoken," said Takashi Inoguchi, a professor of political science at Tokyo University. "She is very effective at carrying out an agenda, but she does not have much experience, just like Mr. Koizumi himself. Also, speaking and commenting on other people's negative sides as she does so often is not necessarily the best quality for a foreign minister."
As expected, Mr. Koizumi tapped Heizo Takenaka, a highly regarded economist at Keio University, as minister for economic policy. Mr. Takenaka is a vigorous advocate for fiscal reform, which was one of Mr. Koizumi's main campaign themes. 
Mr. Takenaka has advised previous administrations, but he has never been a government official. In the past, he has advocated cuts as steep as 80 percent in Japan's public works spending, which has been the governing party's preferred way of trying to stimulate the economy. That spending policy pleases the entrenched interests that finance the party, but it has failed to produce dynamic growth. Mr. Takenaka has also proposed an increase in the consumption tax, to help pay off the country's huge public debt. 
Mr. Koizumi's surprise choice for finance minister was Masajuro Shiokawa, 79, a veteran of several past governments, but with little economic policy experience. In his first news conference, Mr. Shiokawa said, "In the near term, the priority will be on an economic recovery."
Mr. Koizumi has virtually argued the opposite, saying during his campaign that Japan's recovery can take place only after fiscal changes.
Even analysts who praised the overall composition of the new economic team questioned Mr. Shiokawa's credentials. "If you are going to have any kind of serious reform, you need to have the ministry of finance marching to the tune of the finance minister, and it is not clear to me that Shiokawa has the background to make that happen," said Robert Feldman, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo. 
Other political analysts said the appointments of Mr. Shiokawa and Mr. Takenaka, along with a well-regarded holdover from the departing government, Hakuo Yanagisawa, might simply reflect Mr. Koizumi's efforts to reconcile his reformist views with those of faction leaders who oppose any sudden fiscal changes or austerity measures for fear they would choke the economy.
Mr. Koizumi's weakness within his party may have already tilted the balance against major changes in economic policy. One day after his appointment to what is effectively the No. 3 job in the Liberal Democratic Party, Taro Aso, one of Mr. Koizumi's rivals for the party leadership contest, said Japan must continue to prime the pump of its economy. "I have to think of additional stimulus measures," Mr. Aso said.
Indeed, some political analysts said they expected that for now Mr. Koizumi, who rode to power on stirring but vague promises of change, would probably stick to symbolic matters like breaking the stranglehold of factions, rather than try to tackle structural economic problems. Above all, he faces pressure to appear to be ushering in change before parliamentary elections in July, in which the Liberal Democrats are expected to fare poorly. Japanese analysts have speculated that if the election results do not favor the ruling party, the factions may turn on Mr. Koizumi and seek his ouster.
"He has got 90 days, and because expectations are so high he has to do something," said Shigenori Okazaki, chief political analyst at the investment bank UBS Warburg. "They want to make it through this election, and the closer you listen to what Koizumi and his people are saying, their real priority is party reform. I see very serious gridlock, with people in the Hashimoto faction and in the Eto-Kamei faction preparing to strike back at Koizumi." Ryutaro Hashimoto, and Takami Eto and Shizuka Kamei lead two of the three main factions. Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Kamei failed to beat Mr. Koizumi for the party presidency.
"They are already so peeved at Koizumi, especially Hashimoto and Kamei," said Kenji Kobayashi, a member of Parliament from the opposition Democratic Party. "They are really complaining. Just yelling at each other."

HEADLINE: Deal Is Signed To Take Over Trade Center 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Despite some missteps and a last-minute snag, a developer signed a contract yesterday to take control of the 110-story World Trade Center complex in a deal worth $3.2 billion, the largest real estate transaction in New York history.
 The completion of the deal is the end of an effort begun three years ago by Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Christie Whitman, then the governor of New Jersey, to privatize the huge 10.6-million-square-foot office complex. It was built 30 years ago by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to stimulate development in Lower Manhattan. The governors pledged to use the proceeds from the transaction for new transportation projects. 
 A group led by Larry A. Silverstein, a developer, and Westfield America Inc., an owner of shopping centers, signed a 99-year lease yesterday after working nearly 24 hours straight on the agreement. Still, the Port Authority delayed the start of its board meeting yesterday afternoon until the developer delivered a $100 million letter of credit, the first installment on a $616 million down payment. The group will then make annual rent payments to the Port Authority, manage and lease the complex and spend $200 million on capital improvements.
In recent weeks, the deal was beset by a series of problems -- ranging from the enormous difficulty of structuring such a complex deal within a short time to the sudden slowdown in the economy -- that scuttled negotiations with one bidder and nearly toppled Mr. Silverstein. 
The Silverstein group is scheduled to close the deal in July, although it has the option to extend the process for 30 days more.
"This agreement allows the private sector to bring its expertise to managing this landmark," Governor Pataki said in a statement yesterday, "and it frees Port Authority resources for improvements in airports, tunnels, bridges and other parts of the region's transportation network."
Mr. Silverstein was both tired and ebullient yesterday evening.
"I'm thrilled to pieces," he said yesterday. "I've been looking at the trade center for years, thinking what a great piece of real estate, what a thrill it would be to own it. There's nothing like it in the world."
Mr. Silverstein owns about 5.5 million square feet of office space downtown, including 7 World Trade Center, a 48-story tower that was built on land owned by the Port Authority.
Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority, said the bistate agency would negotiate with the city over payments in lieu of taxes for the property. The World Trade Center paid the city about $29 million last year, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has insisted that the number should be equal to full property taxes, about $100 million.
The Silverstein group was the second bidder to negotiate for the right to control the trade center complex and its effort nearly collapsed Wednesday, much like the first attempt last month by Vornado Realty Trust, and its chairman, Steven Roth. Worried about the financial viability of Mr. Silverstein's group, the Port Authority was preparing to break off negotiations on Wednesday, when Mr. Silverstein asked for a little more time. The board gave him until yesterday afternoon to come up with a $100 million check and sign 1,000 pages of contracts, leases and agreements.
"The time comes in every transaction when you have to put the pencils down and stop negotiating," said Cherrie L. Nanninga, director of real estate for the Port Authority.
In the end, she said, there were various trade-offs. The Silverstein group lowered its down payment from $800 million to $616 million but raised its annual rent payment. Mr. Silverstein also had to post a nonrefundable letter of credit, which had many Port Authority executives holding their breath until shortly after 3 p.m. yesterday.
The twin towers complex opened in the 1970's to poor reviews. But the vast complex soon found a place in the popular culture. King Kong climbed one tower in a remake of the movie classic. And in 1993, a terrorist bomb explosion killed six people and injured more than a thousand.
In recent years, the complex has filled up with tenants and revenues have improved significantly. Operating income is expected to be more than $200 million this year and continue rising through the decade. The annual rent for Dean Witter, which leases more than a million square feet, will jump by about $21 million starting in May.
It took New York and New Jersey officials several years even to agree on the decision to put the complex into private hands in 1998, when the Port Authority's advisers estimated that a sale might bring $1.5 billion.
More than 30 bidders competed for the site, before the Port Authority narrowed the list to three: Vornado, which bid $3.25 billion; the Silverstein group, which offered $3.22 billion; and a joint venture of Brookfield Financial Properties and Boston Properties.
Some Port Authority executives said that the Brookfield group was considered the strongest contestant but that its bid was the lowest at $3.1 billion. The bistate agency did not want to open itself up to criticism for favoritism, so it opened negotiations last month with Vornado. It gave the company 20 days to come to terms on a deal.
But when Vornado tried to change the terms of the deal at the last minute, Port Authority officials balked. It was an attractive offer, but the officials feared that the company, which had a reputation as a difficult negotiator, might be stalling for better terms. They did not want to get bogged down in endless rounds of discussion. Mr. Roth is expected to sign a deal with Bloomberg today to build a skyscraper on the Upper East Side after three years of talks.
"They negotiate to the point of nitpicking," one official said. "But they're a good organization."
Ultimately, the Port Authority turned to Mr. Silverstein, though they questioned whether his relatively small organization could handle as large a complex as the trade center. When the deal with Mr. Silverstein nearly collapsed on Wednesday, some commissioners at the Port Authority said they should take the property off the auction block because they had lost all leverage in a cooling real estate market.
Rather than suffer that embarrassment, one official said, they persevered with Mr. Silverstein.
"Despite the economy," said Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority, "this deal proves that World Trade Center is still the most unique property in the world."

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: EUROPE; 
EUROPE: INTEREST RATES STEADY

BYLINE:  By Edmund L. Andrews 

 BODY:
 The European Central Bank once again refused to reduce interest rates, turning aside pleas from some European political leaders and charting a staunchly separate course from that of the United States Federal Reserve. The central bank's decision was widely expected since its last meeting two weeks ago, when it surprised investors by holding rates steady and using unusually clear language to say that it was more worried about inflation risks than a severe slowdown.
 Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
WESTCHESTER HOME PRICES

BYLINE:  By Corey Kilgannon 

 BODY:
Despite the economic downturn, the price of homes in Westchester County has increased significantly this year, according to the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service. The service announced yesterday that purchase prices for homes in the county had risen 11 percent for the first quarter in 2001, compared with the same period in 2000. 
The median price of a single-family home in early 2001 was $412,500, up from $372,000 a year earlier. The 2001 price is the highest ever recorded in a first quarter, according to the listing service. Donna M. Tierney, president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, said that the stock prices had not affected the market. Ms. Tierney, a real estate broker specializing in Armonk and Chappaqua, said that buyers had been particularly interested in high-end homes ranging from $820,000 to $1 million. Corey Kilgannon

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Another Wachovia Suitor Disclosed in S.E.C. Filing
A day before Wachovia's board approved a $13 billion merger with First Union, two top executives were contacted by another financial institution interested in a deal, a Securities and Exchange Commission filing said.
 While the filing does not identify the institution, analysts think it was SunTrust Banks of Atlanta, one of the few remaining independent banks in the South. Page C3. 

British Telecom Chairman Resigns
Burdened by debt and assailed by disgruntled investors, British Telecommunications announced the resignation of its longtime chairman, Sir Iain Vallance. C2.

Sweetened Bid by Shell for Barrett
Royal Dutch/Shell raised its hostile offer for Barrett Resources to about $2 billion from $1.8 billion. The sweetened bid comes as rivals like Phillips Petroleum and Burlington Resources are considering entering the fray, executives close to the discussions said. Shares of Barrett rose $1.85, to $63.75. C12.

I.B.M. Creates Silicon Alternative
I.B.M. scientists have for the first time created a vast assembly of transistors using a new material only a few molecules wide, taking a significant step toward computers far tinier and more powerful than those used today. A1.

Scientists Give In to Music Industry
Bowing to pressure from the recording industry, a group of computer scientists who had defeated an industry copy-protection program abruptly withdrew their research paper from a scientific conference. C5.

Ad Agency Company to Be Unveiled
An advertising agency company, called 10 Worldwide, is to be introduced today by principals of two agencies based in Columbus, Ohio. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C3.

Microsoft Is in Alliance With Qwest
Microsoft announced an alliance with Qwest Communications to deploy a version of the Microsoft service over high-speed lines in the 14 states served by Qwest. C5.

Dow and S.& P. Up as Nasdaq Falls
Stocks were mixed as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 67.15 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,692.35, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.77 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,234.52. The Nasdaq composite index fell 24.92 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2,034.88. C6.

Nicky Oppenheimer, left, and his family, which controls De Beers, and its partners raised their bid to take De Beers private after several major shareholders said they would oppose the original offer. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
A new agency aims to help provide clients with a wide range of communications services.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
EXECUTIVES with experience in a variety of marketing fields are uniting to start an agency company meant to help provide clients a range of communications services as well as traditional advertising.
 The new enterprise, 10 Worldwide, is to be formally announced today by principals of two agencies based in Columbus, Ohio: HMS Partners and Resource Marketing. They are being joined by the former president and chief executive of the Lighthouse Global Network, a marketing services agency that the Cordiant Communications Group in London and New York acquired in September for $592 million. 
 Almost 400 employees will work for 10 Worldwide at offices in Columbus; New York; Orlando, Fla.; Pittsburgh; and Tampa, Fla. They will handle assignments in areas that will include off-line and online advertising, direct marketing, brand development strategy, public relations and customer relationship marketing. 
Among the clients of 10 Worldwide, with combined billings estimated at more than $350 million, are Deutsche Bank, the Fidelity Investments unit of FMR, Ford Motor, Hewlett-Packard, the Hoover unit of Maytag, Limited and Sony.
The move is indicative of the efforts being made by Madison Avenue to serve the continuously changing needs of clients better as they frenetically search for more effective alternatives to conventional pitches like television commercials and print advertisements.
Other recent examples include the formation of a multiple-services company by agencies including AKQA in London and Citron Haligman Bedecarre in San Francisco, which operates under the AKQA moniker, and the formation of a company, Carton Donofrio Partners in Baltimore, which bills itself as a "brand experience design" specialist, by the ad agency Richardson, Myers & Donofrio and the online agency Carton Donofrio Interactive.
"The idea is to build something that isn't just a holding company," said Martin J. Beck, the former top manager at Lighthouse, who becomes chairman and chief executive at 10 Worldwide, "but to build something holistic that maximizes the marketing spending of clients with what is appropriate for them, so they get the best return on investment."
"The economy presents an opportunity for a new company like ours," he added, "because this is a time when marketers are challenging their partners more than ever before, looking for world-changing ideas that will make a major difference for their businesses."
It was Mr. Beck who created the name, said Rick Milenthal, chief executive at HMS Partners, who becomes president and chief operating officer at 10 Worldwide.
"It's 10 because 9.9 isn't good enough," Mr. Milenthal said, "and 10 stands for the perfect connection between brand and customer."
Paging Bo Derek!
"Everything ought to be wrapped around creating a great experience for the consumer" with a product or service, Mr. Milenthal said, "and that should be seen as a marketing investment, not a marketing cost."
In addition to the unusual numerical name, a third top executive at 10 Worldwide has an unusual numerical title. She is Nancy Kramer, chief executive at Resource Marketing, which is best known for an innovative Webcast fashion show for the Victoria's Secret lingerie chain. Ms. Kramer becomes president and CC3 O at 10 Worldwide; "C3 " stands for clients, creative and culture.
"We're re-engineering -- though I hate that term -- organizations that are successful in their own domains," Ms. Kramer said, "to meet the needs of today's clients and consumers."
"Consumers are more demanding of brands than ever, and they're the ones dictating how and when they get messages" from marketers, she added. "Period. End of story."
Mr. Beck, 57; Ms. Kramer, 45; and Mr. Milenthal, 41, will also all be managing partners at 10 Worldwide. There will be two partners: David Milenthal, 53, chairman at HMS Partners and the brother of Rick Milenthal, and Bill Binstock, 48, chief executive at HMS Hallmark, the ad agency division of HMS Partners.
For the time being, the operating units of 10 Worldwide will continue using their current names: HMS Hallmark; HMS Success, the public relations division; Motivo, the digital division; and Resource Marketing.
That is likely to change, Ms. Kramer said, as 10 Worldwide reconfigures and grows, adding, "We are in discussion with other entities and hope to announce additional partners in the next few weeks" in areas like retail strategy and design and marketing strategy.
Before taking part in the formation of 10 Worldwide, HMS Partners had been on an acquisitions tear, buying Hallmark/Tassone in May, an ad agency with estimated billings of $100 million, and Workstate in June, an interactive technology agency in Columbus.
A deal two months ago to acquire Fahlgren, an ad agency in Dublin, Ohio, which was to have been merged with HMS Hallmark, was canceled over what were termed philosophical differences.

HEADLINE: Belgian Dispute on KPMG Audit 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, April 26 

 BODY:
Former senior managers of Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products today rejected a report from KPMG that asserts they withheld essential information during an audit.
 In letters to the Belgian daily De Financieel Economische Tijd, the founders, Jo Lernout and Pol Hauspie, and a fellow former board member, Nico Willaert, said they cooperated with KPMG and the firm was fully aware of the company's structure and its activities in South Korea. 
 The company is being investigated for possible fraud after admitting last year that there were accounting irregularities at its Korean unit. The fallout forced Lernout & Hauspie, a speech-recognition and translation-technology company, to seek bankruptcy court protection in Belgium and in the United States.
Mr. Lernout, Mr. Hauspie and Mr. Willaert were brought in for questioning today by the examining judge, Kristof Vulsteke, lawyers said. The prosecutor, Jean-Marie Coppens, said no decision had been made on whether they would be held in custody or released. 
Mr. Lernout and Mr. Hauspie were not expected at a special shareholders meeting on Friday in Ieper, where the new management and KPMG will explain the events that have led to the company's decline. 
The only vote scheduled is for new rules on how board members will be appointed. The three former directors have requested that their letters be read at the meeting. They blamed KPMG for some of the problems with the Korean operation.
A Lernout & Hauspie spokesman, Ron Schuermans, said the company had no immediate comment on the letters. A KPMG spokesman, Jonathan Hawker, said the firm would respond in full at the meeting to the charges in the letters.

HEADLINE: Looking for a Low Interest Rate? How About Zero? 

BYLINE:  By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
EVEN Alan Greenspan must be surprised by just how low some interest rates have fallen. Can you believe zero percent?
 That's the rate the Calpine Corporation, which owns power plants and has been getting rich off California's electricity problems, paid this week when it borrowed $850 million for 20 years. The bonds are convertible into Calpine stock at a 37 percent premium to Calpine's current price. 
 Another borrower, Stilwell Financial, did not get a zero rate. But Dan Carpenter, an executive vice president of Stilwell, the parent of the Janus mutual funds group, was still happy. "Our combination of a 1 percent yield and a 47.5 percent conversion premium is the best any issuer ever achieved," he exulted last night.
They are not alone. Since Tyco, a rapidly growing conglomerate, started the ball rolling last November, 25 zero-coupon convertibles with yields of 4 percent or less have raised $19.2 billion, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. Merrill Lynch leads the field, but most other big underwriters are also involved. Over all, including those with higher yields, more zero-coupon convertibles have been issued in 2001 than in any previous year.
How can this be possible? The government can't borrow money at those rates, and its credit is supposed to be better than any company's.
The answer hinges on volatility. The wild swings in stock prices may drive investors crazy, but they also make it cheaper for companies to borrow.
That is because a convertible bond can be seen as a combination of two securities: a bond and a long-term call option to buy the stock. The higher the volatility, the more the option is worth. So an investor pays for the option by taking a lower interest rate on the bond.
At first glance, it appears the company cannot lose. If the share price rises, it ends up selling stock at a price well above the current market price. If the stock price fails to rise, the company has borrowed money at a very low interest rate, so it wins there, too.
There is another neat trick here, one that may lead to misleading accounting. By carefully manipulating the terms of the bonds, companies believe they will not have to include the shares they will issue when calculating per-share earnings, even after the stock price has risen past the conversion price. That appears to conform to the precise wording of accounting rules, but perhaps not with the intent. The rules may need to be updated.
There is, however, one other feature that could yet blow up on a company or two. To make these bonds attractive to investors, they include put provisions allowing the investor to sell the bond back to the company on certain dates. If the stock falls sharply, the company will have to buy back the bonds.
If the company is still in good shape financially, it will be able to borrow other money to repay the bond. But a company could find itself forced to pay billions just when its finances are the most troubled. "As in many financial instruments, it works really well as long as the stock goes up," said Jonathan Glaser, whose JMG Capital Partners has bought several such issues. "If the stock plunges, potentially it's a death spiral."
No one seems very worried about that possibility now. With a recession possible, some creditors are frozen out of the credit markets. But those that can borrow, including some like Calpine that are rated just below investment grade, can get money at rates that are the lowest ever.
