HEADLINE: Bush Faces Senate Struggle On Rise in Rate of Spending 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26 

 BODY:
President Bush appears headed toward another setback on the budget, this time over his call to pare the growth of government spending.
 Having conceded that he would not get the full $1.6 trillion tax cut he had proposed, Mr. Bush was now seeking to undo at least part of the spending increases adopted by the Senate in its budget plan earlier this month. 
 The Senate plan would increase spending on general government programs at twice the rate sought by Mr. Bush. 
Although that figure is all but certain to be reduced in the next week or two as the Senate works out a compromise budget plan with the House, which adopted Mr. Bush's spending target, it is still likely to be far above what the White House wants. And recent history suggests that the spending limit set by the nonbinding budget plan will be ignored or sidestepped as Congress passes the bills that appropriate money to specific programs.
White House officials said the situation validated Mr. Bush's position that the only way to keep Congress from spending every penny on the table was to push through as big a tax cut as possible. If the rate of increase passed by the Senate were to be adopted each year, White House officials said, spending would double in nine years and the projected budget surplus of $5.6 trillion over the next decade would be reduced by $3 trillion.
Democrats said the situation showed that there was a broad consensus for increased spending on issues that were more important to most people than a big tax cut that would go disproportionately to the wealthy.
In any case, analysts said, the growth in spending is likely to continue as long as the government is running budget surpluses, regardless of which party occupies the White House.
"There's ample proof that the interest in higher spending comes from across the Congress and across party lines," said Stanley E. Collender, director of the Federal Budget Consulting Group at Fleischman-Hillard, the public relations firm.
Mr. Bush's budget proposed an increase in spending for the coming year of 4 percent on the array of general government programs for which Congress must set spending levels each year. That would be an increase sharply lower than in recent years, when that category of spending climbed about 6 percent to 8 percent a year.
The 4 percent sought by Mr. Bush translated into an increase in so-called discretionary spending of about $25.3 billion for next year, to $660.7 billion from $635.4 billion.
The budget resolution passed by the Senate this month, with support from all 50 Republicans and from 15 Democrats, called for an increase in discretionary spending of 8.3 percent for next year. Under the plan, spending on those programs would rise to $688.4 billion next year, an increase of $53 billion, or $27.7 billion more than sought by Mr. Bush.
As adopted by the Senate, the budget would increase military spending by 7.6 percent next year. For nonmilitary programs, the increase would be 9 percent.
The increases approved by the Senate included $294 billion over 10 years for education, another $70 billion over 10 years for special education and $64 billion over 10 years for agriculture. The Senate also approved increases of $700 million next year for the National Institutes of Health and $8.5 billion next year for the Pentagon.
Lawrence Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, said the spending levels approved by the Senate were "quite irresponsible."
Asked if Mr. Bush's goal of holding discretionary spending increases to 4 percent had been proven unrealistic by the Senate votes, Mr. Lindsey said: "Quite the contrary. It's what the House passed, and the House leadership has signaled that the House would have difficulty passing a budget with an increase of any more than that."
Republican leaders on Capitol Hill said it would be difficult for them to avoid a revolt by conservatives, especially in the House, if they tried to split the difference between the House and the Senate and adopt an increase of 6 percent. Yet Mr. Bush may need to trade promises of support for increased spending to win votes for his tax plan from moderate Democrats in the Senate.
As a political matter, Mr. Bush has always found that voters respond well to his argument that if families can get by with pay raises that are usually less than 4 percent a year, then the federal government ought to be able to hold spending increases to 4 percent annually.
"Four percent is a hefty increase, but for some in Washington, 4 percent is not enough," Mr. Bush told a crowd in New Orleans on Tuesday, prompting a wave of boos in support of his point.
Yet when voters are asked about specific programs rather than abstract spending levels, they tend to support spending increases. A poll released today by the Pew Research Center found that public support had grown substantially for increased spending on a wide array of initiatives, including environmental protection, health care, education and the military -- and that support for spending cuts had declined across the board.
In holding spending increases to 4 percent for next year while providing more money for education and a number of other areas, Mr. Bush had to propose measures of a type that Congress had rarely been willing to enact. They include financing increases below the level of inflation or outright cuts in programs like job training, low-income housing, health care and environmental protection.
"Bush's numbers are unrealistic, and you can see that based on what actually passed in the Senate," Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the senior Democrat on the Budget Committee, said.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS; 
The Mystery Behind 'Wide World' Is Solved

BYLINE:  By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
ABC's "Wide World of Sports" turns 40 years old on Sunday. But there have not been 40 full years of this seminal anthology series. The last "Wide World" was shown in 1998 and while a best-of version runs on ESPN Classic, its name has lived on as the umbrella title for some ABC Sports programming and as the Disneysports complex in Florida.
 ABC will celebrate the anniversary with a two-hour retrospective from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m. Eastern on Sunday (and yes, ABC will visit with Vinko Bogataj, the Yugoslav ski jumper whose horrific spill in 1970 came to symbolize the show's "agony of defeat"). The program offers a chance to recall how "Wide World of Sports" became an iconic show, with its eclectic mix of Acapulco cliff diving, boxing, baton-twirling, motorcycle jumping, chess, soccer, track and field, Evel Knievel, wrist wrestling, the Indianapolis 500, barrel jumping and figure skating. 
 The mists of history have bestowed creator's status on Roone Arledge, yet it was Edgar Scherick, his boss, who developed the concept. Scherick had hired Arledge, who was producing the puppeteer Shari Lewis's show on local New York television.
"I took an awful big chance on him," Scherick, a noted film producer, said yesterday. The risk worked out fairly well, as Arledge eventually ran ABC Sports, then became the president of ABC News.
Scherick was running Sports Programs Inc., a company that was eventually acquired by ABC and became its sports division. It was a frantic place and Scherick was a dynamic, forceful executive who frequently battled with the equally strong-willed Jack Lubell, a producer-director for S.P.I.
"It was originally just the three of us, Ed, Jack and me, and then we added people like Roone," said Chet Simmons, who would later run NBC Sports and ESPN. "One day, I went into Ed's office, and Jack had Ed pinned against the wall, and Ed's feet were off the ground. Ed looked over Jack's shoulder and said to me, 'Everything's O.K.' They went to war every day."
One of the problems in 1960 for ABC, and thus, for S.P.I., was that its baseball telecasts had to be blacked out in major league markets. 
"We needed something to go national with," Scherick said. "We needed sports events that weren't being shown, which were interesting viewing, which could be taped, and we could put on the air the next day. So out of economic need, we started buying rights. We went to the A.A.U. and negotiated contracts for all its events, including the Soviet-American track meet in 1961."
Scherick, who is sensitive to a lack of recognition for his role, credits Arledge with enormous creative contributions, but not with the initial concept. "Roone had nothing to do with the formation of 'Wide World,' " he said.
Jim Spence, a former senior vice president of ABC Sports, said: "Roone executed it, but he didn't create it. I think Ed's complaint has been that while Roone didn't take credit for creating it, he didn't deny it when someone else said he did." 
In an online recollection for ABC Sports.com, Arledge credits Scherick with discussing with him "something that we had to do that would be different" and for selling the advertising necessary for ABC-TV to put the newfangled show on the air.
With the Penn and Drake relays as its first events, the show made its debut on April 29, 1961, with Jim McKay as the host. He will also be the host for Sunday's two-hour program.
"Wide World" became the focus of ABC Sports, providing it with a platform to produce Olympic sports, which came in handy when it televised 10 of the 13 Olympics from 1964 to 1988. The show also trained scores of producers, directors, announcers and executives, three of whom, Dick Ebersol, Howard Katz and Sean McManus (McKay's son), now run NBC, ABC and CBS sports, respectively.
And it bore the Arledge imprint, in its daring and variety.
McKay recalled that he had never liked calling motorcycle jumping, and had wished Arledge would not assign him to it. "One time, we were doing ski jumping in St. Moritz," he said. "I was going to ski for four days, but he calls me up and says, 'You're going to Houston, to the Astrodome, to cover a motorcycle-jumping final.' I could have killed him." But he went.
McKay also recalled being at the 1961 U.S.-Soviet track championship where ABC's videotape equipment fascinated the fans at Lenin Stadium. "They had no video machines in the Soviet Union," McKay said. "And then they saw Valery Brumel high jump once, again and again." 
ABC recently shelved the idea of reviving "Wide World" because the slowing economy has dampened advertiser enthusiasm for it. But Katz still thinks the show can be revived.
"I think you can make it special enough so once a week people would like to see it," he said. "But you can't recreate what was."

AIRWAVES
BOB COSTAS's "On the Record" on HBO hits its pinnacle Wednesday night with a warm and marvelous segment on RAY CHARLES's appreciation of the musical cadences of VIN SCULLY, the Dodger announcer. What a delight. . . . Another delight can be viewed Sunday on Cinemax, at 7:30 p.m. Eastern, with the television premiere of the Oscar-nominated documentary "The Life and Times of Hank Greenberg," which explores how the Bronx-born Detroit Tiger slugger handled anti-Semitism and the impact he had on Jewish fans.

HEADLINE: Plan on California Energy Has No Shortage of Critics 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 26 

 BODY:
A novel plan by federal regulators to control California's runaway electricity prices is a messy, politically motivated compromise that may offer some relief to consumers but will do little to fix the state's dysfunctional energy market, analysts said today.
 The intervention, announced by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission on Wednesday night after much haggling, was dismissed by a wide range of critics today as a flawed effort that satisfies no one. 
 It fell short of the sweeping suspension of regional electricity deregulation that California officials and some energy experts had advocated. But it also crossed what has become a firm ideological line among Republican leaders, including President Bush, by imposing price controls on some electricity sales to utilities. 
Under the agency's order, which takes effect on May 1, California regulators can begin to impose price controls on power generators when electricity supplies fall to within 7.5 percent of consumer demand. The state is expected to face such shortages routinely this summer, and the order has the potential to shave billions of dollars off California's electricity bill if implemented fully, some people at the federal agency say.
"The president has a long-held belief that price caps don't work," the White House press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said today. "The last thing you want to do is create artificially increased demand and put in disincentives that harm the availability of supply."
Mr. Fleischer noted that the energy commission is an independent federal agency, adding that the Bush administration has no authority to countermand its orders.
But Mr. Bush did appoint the commission's chairman, Curtis L. Hebert Jr., a Republican. Like the president, Mr. Hebert has often insisted that price caps do no good. But he came under withering political pressure to abandon the agency's largely hands-off approach to the California crisis. Some of that pressure came from the two other commissioners at the agency, both Democrats, and Mr. Hebert wound up voting for the controls adopted on Wednesday night. 
The split with the Bush administration raises fresh questions about whether the president will seek to replace Mr. Hebert as chairman in coming weeks. Mr. Bush has nominated two Republicans to fill vacant slots on the commission, including Pat Wood, a longtime ally of the president who served as chief electricity regulator in Texas. Industry executives say they expect that Mr. Bush will eventually name Mr. Wood to the commission's top post.
In a reflection of how delicate the issue is, Mr. Hebert argued that the agency's action did not amount to imposing price caps. But his position appeared to rest on a semantic distinction between returning to cost-based electricity regulation (as some Californians favor) and the agency's decision to impose tactical price controls.
Among California officials, the dominant reaction was disappointment. Some state regulators and market experts said the agency was practicing upside-down economics: it has chosen to impose price limits during periods of severe scarcity, when prices theoretically ought to rise to encourage companies to build power plants and encourage people to use less electricity.
The agency, its critics argue, has chosen to ignore price abuses during times of relative abundance, when power generators, the critics say, have used artificial market power to earn high profits.
"They got it exactly wrong," said Frank Wolak, chief market supervisor for the California Independent System Operator, which runs the state's power grid. "It looks like they're doing something, but it doesn't work in real time."
Mr. Wolak has estimated that most overcharges by generators last year -- in amounts that he puts in the billions of dollars -- occurred when electricity supplies were not acutely short, meaning that the agency's price caps would have had no mitigating effect. 
The state is likely to face many emergency shortages this summer. But, Mr. Wolak said, generating companies have become adept at "gaming" the system. He predicted that they would find ways to continue to earn high profits in California.
One fear is that generating companies will arrange to sell their output to affiliates out of state. When California's transmission grid managers scramble to find supplies, the same companies will offer to sell the power back to the state, but only above the cap price. The agency's new order includes a provision that is intended to discourage this sort of abuse, known as megawatt laundering. But the agency has a weak record of enforcing such mandates, and California officials are skeptical.
The order also came under fire on other grounds. The commission said that price caps would be canceled unless California submitted a proposal to link its transmission grid to the one that serves the Western region, a priority of the agency that state officials have resisted. 
Linda Stuntz, an electricity industry lobbyist who is an expert on the agency, called that clause bizarre, arguing that it held the entire California market hostage to a technical filing requirement.
California politicians said they worried that even if the price caps were carried out as promised, relief would be too limited.
The price limits will be based on estimates of the highest operating costs of the least efficient generating plant in the state. The order as written means that companies that operate efficient generating plants could still sell power at large mark-ups during periods when caps are imposed. When the agency scrutinized the California market earlier this year, it found the high-cost generators to be justified in charging about $300 a megawatt hour for electricity, a price that is about 10 times as high as the state was paying for power a year ago.

HEADLINE: Depression's Lessons 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In "Purging the Rottenness" (column, April 25), Paul Krugman correctly advises Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, to inflate the yen. The Bank of Japan tries to expand the economy with a zero-interest-rate policy. 
The side effect has been to deflate the yen, which only the mild inflation Mr. Krugman suggests can cure. 
 Mr. Krugman errs, though, when he blasts Andrew Mellon, Herbert Hoover's Treasury secretary, for his 1930 advice on what was still a recession: "Liquidate labor, liquidate stocks, liquidate the farmers, liquidate real estate."
That was good advice, as Hoover's Smoot-Hawley Tariff had caused an "inventory recession." Goods already produced had piled up against the high tariff wall, as foreigners could not afford to buy them when they could no longer export to us. The inventories had to sell off, which meant that all factors had to become more liquid, a brief condition. Hoover instead raised taxes, producing the Great Depression. 

JUDE WANNISKI
Morristown, N.J., April 25, 2001

The writer is a political economist.

SECTION: Section C; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cutting Edge in aBackwater; 
Phone Company On Isle of Man Aims to Unite The Internet And Wireless

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: DOUGLAS, Isle of Man 

 BODY:
This blip of an island in the Irish Sea has muscled its way to a latter-day prosperity through such attractions as ever-lower taxes, offshore banking and motorcycle races around the twisting roads that gird its hilly interior. 
 Now the island's phone company, Manx Telecom, a unit of British Telecommunications, is racing forward in its own ambitious quest: to introduce the world's first phone network using the much-promoted new technology that European telecommunications operators have cast as their holy grail, uniting wireless mobility with the breadth of the Internet. 
 The battle had been viewed as a David-and-Goliath contest, stacked in favor of Manx's main rival, Japan's mighty NTT DoCoMo. But when DoCoMo announced on Tuesday that it would postpone its introduction of the so-called third-generation phones until October, the odds were reversed. "We might consider this to be good news -- we have now got more chance of being first," said Mark Briers, who is heading the Manx project. "But for the industry, it's a shame. And we still want to prove that third-generation works." 
Manx Telecom plans to begin distributing in May handsets capable of hooking up to the Internet at speeds far beyond those currently available on wireless devices, and of someday transmitting music, video, restaurant menus, games and e-mail along with the sound of the user's voice.
Yet the tiny scale of the project is as much a symbol of how all the hype surrounding third generation, or 3G, wireless technology has fizzled as it is an emblem of Europe's vaunted lead over the United States in wireless technology.
Unlike other European operators, Manx Telecom got its 3G license free, and the big players -- from Britain to Japan -- have all announced delays, in large part because handsets are in short supply and networks are still being built.
Only 200 of the wireless devices will be made available in the initial rollout on the Isle of Man -- and most of those will be given to a select band of pioneers -- for what is basically a pilot project that will allow British Telecom to iron out any glitches before the new technology is introduced across Britain and the Continent next year.
Manx Telecom said the phones, which are eventually supposed to provide novelties like video phone calls and Internet games across this island of just 227 square miles, with a population of 75,000, will not be available in larger volume for maybe another year. With a considerably larger market, NTT DoCoMo said initially that it would sell 10,000 handsets, but that has been scaled back to 4,000.
In what some analysts depict as one of Europe's biggest corporate missteps, the early mad dash to buy licenses and build networks has left telephone operators saddled with some $330 billion of debt. That has lowered their credit ratings and crimped their ability to invest in the networks they once portrayed as the way of the future. Some European operators are seeking changes in competition laws to allow them to share the cost of the networks.
Just a year ago, telecommunications operators were scrambling to buy a seat at the 3G table, paying a total of some $100 billion for the permits. In Britain, British Telecom, Vodafone and others paid some $35 billion for the 20-year licenses. Auctions in Germany followed, with the government there netting $46 billion. But investor confidence waned, as phone companies realized that the licenses committed them to spending much more to build networks than they were likely to earn from the new technology in the first few years. Indeed, some analysts say networks will not be built on the kind of scale that might coax forth a profit until 2005.
Auctions in Italy, Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands late last year were disappointing. In Belgium and France, according to a recent study by the European Commission, license sales attracted fewer buyers than the number of licenses on offer.
Companies that did bite have suffered. In the last year, British Telecom's stock has fallen by almost half -- a factor that contributed mightily to Thursday's ouster of its chairman, Sir Iain Vallance -- and Vodafone fell by a more than a third. With the fall in stock prices, operators cranked back the breakneck speed of acquisitions that culminated in Vodafone's $170 billion takeover of Mannesmann A.G. in 2000. In the Netherlands, Royal KPN's credit rating was cut to just two notches above junk status.
Handset manufacturers have also been feeling pain. Though Nokia of Finland, the world leader, remains strong, Ericsson of Sweden, a leader in 3G handset and network equipment orders, has announced plans to eliminate 12,000 jobs and Motorola has said it will shed 7,000 jobs as demand for the current digital wireless technology has softened.
The combination of debt and reduced expectations of income from the 3G phones has left phone companies in another bind: without the cash to buy large numbers of handsets at cheap prices, they cannot create a mass market, and that will further hinder their earnings ability. And troubled manufacturers like Ericsson do not want to build large numbers of devices for fear of creating warehouses full of phones.
"The risk is that you won't be able to get them out because there are so few networks," said Gunnar Liljegren, a director of corporate marketing at Ericsson. "There's a little bit of a Catch-22."
Such are the scaled-down expectations that both Vodafone and British Telecom plan to introduce a kind of halfway technology called General Packet Radio Service. G.P.R.S. will provide some improvements -- including relatively high-speed e-mail and data transfer -- over current wireless technology without the costs, and all the bells and whistles, of the full third-generation technology.
British Telecom says it will be the first to start selling G.P.R.S. next month in Britain. Vodafone says it will combine G.P.R.S. and third-generation phones on dual-use handsets when it introduces the fastest mobiles in the second half of next year. But even this technology is likely to be delayed, along with its potential for profits, some analysts say.
All these travails have left some denizens of the Isle of Man feeling pretty smug.
"We actually gave our license away" before Europe's first splurge of auctions, said David North, the minister of trade and industry for the island's largely autonomous government, which has even declined membership in the European Union. "At least, in our case, no one can claim that the cost of the license was prohibitive."
The third-generation phones will mix nicely with the island's cocktail of low taxes, offshore status and government grants to start-ups, providing a big lure to online businesses, said Tim Craine, the island's director of e-commerce, who has a $17 million annual budget to persuade Internet-related companies to do business here. As a very advanced part of the wired world, added Mr. North, the trade minister, "the water around the island disappears."
According to Mr. Briers, the British Telecom executive leading the Isle of Man project, the government's decision to grant the license "gave us six to eight months to get ahead of the game" by building a network, ordering handsets from NEC of Japan, creating a local Internet portal and setting up an innovative Web-linked billing system.
Of course, no one is pretending that this tiny island is much more than a test-bed where British Telecom and its partners can study some of the many 3G imponderables. At present, for instance, the technology does not allow users to "roam" from one European country to another as current mobile phones do. The transmission speeds, theoretically up to 40 times the speeds of current wireless devices, will not actually be nearly as quick, Mr. Liljegren of Ericsson said. Some analysts say the technology is far less developed than operators suggest. And most of all, no one is quite sure whether consumers really want the 3G services enough to make them profitable.
In part, wireless operators are banking on past success for future riches. At the beginning of the year, nearly 70 percent of the European Union's 350 million citizens had a mobile phone, according to the study from the European Commission. Mobile communications brought in some $170 billion last year, almost one-third of Europe's entire telecommunications market, and the cell phone business grew 12.5 percent -- five times the forecast rate for overall economic growth. And all this is happening in an industry whose prospects were initially treated with some of the same skepticism the new technology now generates.
"I think history is going to repeat itself on this," Mr. Briers said. At the rollout, 3G users here will be able to make voice calls to one another, he said, but that will soon expand into video calls, where callers can see each other on an add-on screen; online news and sports; and features based on satellite navigation to guide people around the island, from restaurants to, say, fairy glens and other idiosyncratic tourist sites.
But for all that the island may gain from new technology, such topics are lately well off the radar screen of many locals.
Instead, what is on people's mind here is the news that Isle of Man authorities just decided to cancel the decades-old, world-famous TT motorcycle race to prevent foot-and-mouth disease from spreading to the island via any of the 40,000 expected visitors. The two weeks of motorcycle trials and races, which were to begin May 28, represent by far the biggest income earner of the year for many low-tech businesses, from pubs and T-shirt vendors to taxicabs and campsites.
"It's very bad news for the island," said Alan Rogers, who runs a cab company, Motion Enterprises. "It's really looking like a bad year."
Will 3G help lift the gloom? "No one has seen any of the new phones yet," Mr. Rogers said. "There isn't much excitement about them."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Earnings Decline by 16% At Taiwan Semiconductor

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 27 

 BODY:
In a sign of how hard the slowdown in American technology spending has pinched Asian suppliers, Taiwan's largest chip maker, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, said today that its net income declined 16.6 percent in the first quarter.
 The company also said that it expected to use less than half its production capacity in the current quarter, which analysts say will be the nadir of the downturn. 
 Taiwan Semiconductor's results were below even the reduced expectations of analysts. And the company's report capped a week of dismal economic news from Taiwan, which reported sharply slowing growth and its highest unemployment rate since 1985. 
"All of us have been really stunned by the depth of this decline and how great the pain has been," said Matt Cleary, the newly appointed head of Asian technology research at Lehman Brothers in Taipei.
As the world's largest semiconductor foundry company -- supplying chips under contract to other manufacturers -- Taiwan Semiconductor is something of a bellwether for Asia's technology industry. The region's other chip and computer makers are reporting similarly steep declines in output.
Morris Chang, the chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor, said in a briefing for investors that the industry's prospects were still murky. But he predicted that the third quarter would be stronger than the second quarter.
In the meantime, Taiwan Semiconductor is halting its ambitious building program. Mr. Chang said the company would delay the construction of two chip factories in southern Taiwan.
The plunge in demand comes at an awkward time for Taiwan Semiconductor. It acquired several chip manufacturers last year to expand its production capacity to 3.2 million silicon wafers from 2.8 million.
In an interview early last year, Mr. Chang said that even with the greater capacity, Taiwan Semiconductor would not be able to keep up with demand. He estimated that demand would top 5.5 million wafers this year.
Yet in the first quarter, Taiwan Semiconductor used only 70 percent of its production capacity. And this quarter, Mr. Chang predicted that more than half the company's assembly lines would be idle.
Unlike other foundries, Taiwan Semiconductor does not try to keep its factories busy during slack times by churning out memory chips. Mr. Chang prefers to make only the more sophisticated logic chips.
"They're really exposed in terms of capacity," Mr. Cleary said.
In other ways, Taiwan Semiconductor's woes simply mirror the broader problems in the economy. Taiwan's government has scaled back its forecast for 2001 economic growth three times, to 5.25 percent. With technology exports continuing to fall, some economists said that number was optimistic.
Taiwan's output of technology hardware -- laptop and desktop computers, monitors and the like -- declined for the first time ever in the first quarter of this year, according to the Institute for Information Industry.
The statistics are so grim that they have spilled over into Taiwan's politics. The United States agreed earlier this week to sell Taiwan an array of weapons, including destroyers and submarines. But some politicians questioned whether Taiwan could afford to buy the arms being offered.
Mr. Cleary of Lehman Brothers sees a glimmer of hope amid the gloom. He noted that new technologies, like wireless Internet access, demanded high levels of microprocessing power on a mass scale.
"We've got a significant hangover to sleep off," Mr. Cleary said, but added that a company like Taiwan Semiconductor was "very well placed for this new world."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
A Rally as Growth Report Stirs Optimism

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, wiping out the Dow Jones industrial average's year-to-date loss, after a report that showed the economy grew faster than expected in the first quarter bolstered optimism that corporate profits would rebound.
 Intel, Wal-Mart Stores and Citigroup lifted the Dow, which had fallen as much as 13 percent for the year at its March 22 low. 
 VeriSign Inc., a manager of Web site addresses, climbed after saying it would meet second-quarter earnings forecasts. 
"There's a little more optimism that the economy is not as bad as we previously thought and that we'll skirt by a recession," said Jim Luke, who manages the $200 million BB&T Large Company Growth Fund in Raleigh, N.C. 
The Dow advanced 117.70 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,810.05, giving it a 0.2 percent gain in 2001. The last time it closed with a positive return for the year was March 8.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 40.80 points, or 2 percent, to 2,075.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 18.53 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,253.05.
Even after yesterday's gain, the Nasdaq had its first losing week in three, falling 4.1 percent. The S.& P. 500 rose 0.8 percent, while the Dow gained 2.2 percent for their third consecutive week of gains. For the year, the Nasdaq has lost 16 percent and the S.& P. index 5.1 percent.
Almost two stocks rose for every one that fell on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq. About 1.1 billion shares traded on the Big Board, 11 percent below the three-month daily average.
"People are beginning to feel a little more confident that the economy hasn't been going into a black hole and the worst in technology is behind us," said Jay Tracey, chief investment officer at Berger Associates Inc. in Denver, which oversees $7 billion. 
Intel, the biggest computer chip maker, gained $1.54, to $30.18. Other semiconductor companies advanced. Applied Materials jumped $3.05, to $53.89, and Texas Instruments rose $2.48, to $36.98.
Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, rose $1.59, to $52.83; Target, the third-largest discounter, climbed $1.61, to $39.16; and the nation's biggest department store company, Sears, Roebuck gained $1.92, to $37.60.
Citigroup, the largest United States financial services company, advanced $1.40, to $50.91; Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the biggest securities firm by market value, rose $2.44, to $65.30; and American Express, the fourth-largest issuer of credit and charge cards, gained $1.84, to $43.74.
VeriSign rose $5.69, to $51.91. The company said first-quarter sales rose more than sixfold as renewal rates for Web addresses beat its forecasts. Dana Evan, chief financial officer, said the company expected to meet analysts' forecasts for second-quarter earnings of 14 cents a share.
Treasury bond prices tumbled after the G.D.P. report dampened hopes for Federal Reserve interest rate cuts.
Bond investors "want validation that there's going to be a recession, and they were shocked when they didn't get it," said Robert Smith, chief investment officer at Sage Advisory Services in Austin, Tex., which has $1.7 billion in bonds.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 1 4/32, to a price of 97 18/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.32 percent from 5.17 percent on Thursday.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 14/32, to 94. Its yield rose to 5.80 percent from 5.70 percent.

HEADLINE: Kerrey's Role at New School Re-examined 

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The central patio of New School University was quiet yesterday, as if nothing momentous had occurred to shake the university. A handful of students sat in the warm sunshine, sipping coffee and catching up on homework and year-end projects. 
 But on the eighth floor, Bob Kerrey, the university's president, looking haggard and tired, was grappling with the enormous fallout from his disclosure in recent days that a mission he led in Vietnam for which he had been awarded a Bronze Star had killed more than a dozen unarmed women and children. 
 It was only a few months ago that many at New School celebrated their success at landing him as president: a Vietnam war hero, a successful businessman, a former senator and a possible presidential candidate. 
To many associated with the university, Mr. Kerrey, a liberal and a maverick, seemed just the person to tell the story of New School and its historic commitment to progressive ideals and the downtrodden.
They hoped that his celebrity status would bring attention and money to the 82-year-old university, which built its renowned graduate school -- formerly known as the New School for Social Research -- around the scores of intellectuals it helped escape from Hitler's Europe.
Now, however, students and faculty members are wrestling with what Mr. Kerrey's disclosures will mean for him and for them, and whether his role as front man will somehow be tainted.
"This whole event confirms my misgivings about the bad fit between Bob Kerrey and an institution that grew out of the antiwar movement," said Miguel Kanai, a student at New School's graduate school of management and urban policy, referring to the antiwar sentiments of some of its founders.
"I don't know what would be more harmful to the university, his resigning or not resigning." 
But his classmate, Christopher Portelli, disagreed, saying that the explosion over Mr. Kerrey's disclosures reflected America's problems with an unpopular war.
"Vietnam is still such a difficult thing for Americans to deal with," he said. "I don't see why it comes as any surprise that as a decorated soldier, he was associated with terrible events."
In the short time since February, when he was installed at Carnegie Hall as president of New School, Mr. Kerrey had begun to meet with faculty members and students; there are 7,000 students in degree programs and 25,000 in nondegree programs at the school.
Mr. Kerry also reached out to alumni and other potential donors. But that process was shattered this week as he turned his attention to the revelations about his role in Vietnam.
The university's board has strongly backed Mr. Kerrey. John L. Tishman, the board chairman, said yesterday that Mr. Kerrey's "character is impeccable and speaks for itself."
But Mr. Kerrey, during a brief interview yesterday in his office on West 12th Street in Greenwich Village, said it was too early to predict how events would unfold.
"I leave it to the board to decide whether or not my role here will be impaired," he said. "And I have said from the beginning that whatever the consequences, I'm prepared to tolerate them. I'm not uncomfortable."
The one thing he was certain of, he said, was that the events of the last few days would "unquestionably affect my role here." He plans to talk to students and faculty members next week, and said he hoped eventually to use the issues raised by his disclosures to encourage discussion of the war -- "to try to turn this into something good."
The disclosures have already prompted some discussion. On the patio steps Thursday evening, some students from the Actors Studio Drama School, a New School division, said they were saddened by the revelations but still admired Mr. Kerrey.
"In no way do I condone what happened," said Christopher, a third-year acting student, who spoke on the condition that his last name not be used. "But Vietnam is still a huge wound that we've never been able to fix."
He said he understood how Mr. Kerrey might not have been able to discuss what had happened during the raid since his father had also fought in Vietnam "and is still not able to talk about it and he still has nightmares."

HEADLINE: F.B.I. Warns That Chinese May Disrupt U.S. Web Sites 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27 

 BODY:
With tensions between China and the United States spilling into cyberspace, the F.B.I. warned on Thursday that Chinese hackers might mount strikes against American Web sites over the next week.
 And Pentagon officials, pointing to threats in public chat rooms as well as new defacements of American Web sites, ordered all their computer managers to take additional precautions to protect against any attempt by Chinese hackers to break into Defense Department systems. 
 "Hackers already have unlawfully defaced a number of U.S. Web sites, replacing existing content with pro-Chinese or anti-U.S. rhetoric," said the F.B.I. advisory.
But as in all conflicts, there are two sides to this latest one. 
While American officials complain that Chinese, possibly abetted by their government, are taking out their resentment on the Internet, independent monitors say the Chinese are responding to attacks on their own Web sites.
Michael Cheek, managing editor of publications for iDefense, a cyberintelligence company, said today that 302 of the 307 publicly known cyberattacks between the two countries were against Chinese Web sites and expressed pro-American stands. 
Most of those defacements of Chinese sites were slogans written in support of the 24 crew members of the American spy plane who were held on Hainan island earlier this month after a midair collision with a Chinese fighter jet. That standoff set off the latest diplomatic crisis between China and the United States.
Pro-Chinese messages appearing on American Web sites, including a Navy procurement site, carry more sophisticated messages, said James Adams, the chief executive officer of iDefense and a member of the advisory board of the National Security Agency.
"There is no question that China is sponsoring these attacks," said Mr. Adams. "The difference between American hackers and Chinese hackers is that the Chinese government has a pretty good history of sponsoring attacks using surrogates."
That history dates back to the 1996 presidential election on Taiwan, when Chinese hackers took aim at Taiwan sites. They repeated their attacks during the 2000 elections, but Taiwan threatened to unleash 7,000 viruses on Chinese government sites if the attacks continued. They ended.
Japan became a target last February, when Chinese hackers protested a Japanese conference on World War II that Chinese officials said amounted to a whitewash of Japan's role in the massacre of thousands of Chinese civilians at Nanjing in 1937.
"Basically, every time there is a national crisis, Chinese hackers will challenge the other country's Web sites," said Barrett McCormick Jr., a political scientist and China specialist at Marquette University.
With bravado, pro-Chinese hackers have said in chat rooms that they will attack American Web sites from next Monday through May 7. Those days include International Workers Day on May 1, China's Youth Day on May 4 and the anniversary of the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in 1999. 
These Chinese hackers, who have identified themselves as the "Hacker Union of China," could also unleash a computer virus, according to the F.B.I. advisory. The worm virus called Lion has already infected several computers in the United States and seems to be affiliated with an e-mail address in China.
"Chinese Web sites tend to be hot places, attracting the most militant people," said Edward Friedman, a China scholar at the University of Wisconsin. "Don't forget that during the recent crisis over Hainan island, the Chinese government tried to censor Chinese Web sites to prevent the militants from taking to the streets."
But defense and national security officials say that the current threats against American sites could be backed by the Chinese government, which has developed its own computer-warfare programs. 
The United States military, for its part, has held two training exercises to prepare defenses against a cyberattack. The fear is that a foreign power could disrupt the country's economic or defense chain by sabotage through the Internet.
But the threats are coming from drug dealers and shady businessmen as well as foreign governments and independent hackers. Already this year the F.B.I. has warned that Russian and Ukrainian hackers are targeting American sites for e-commerce and e-banking. 
Experts like Mr. Adams say it is nearly impossible at the moment to stop crime or deter foreign sabotage on the chaotic, borderless electronic battlefield.
"If they steal our money or shoot our people, we have the means to make them pay a price," Mr. Adams said. "But in the cyberworld they can do what they like, turn off their computers and go home to bed."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Germany Looks Like Europe's Weak Economic Link

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 27 

 BODY:
Germany is Europe's biggest economy by far, but it looks increasingly like its weakest link.
 German economic growth has lagged the European average for years now, not as strong in good times and slumping more seriously in bad times. While Europe as a whole has been creating jobs at a remarkable pace in the last few years, Germany still has a big pool of long-term unemployed workers. 
 And now, as Europeans nervously ponder their chances of escaping the worst effects of a slowdown in the United States, Germany is once again the Continent's biggest source of anemia. And because Germany amounts to a third of the economic output for the 12-nation euro-zone, its weakness drags down the entire region. 
Today, reluctantly acknowledging what most private economists have been saying for nearly two months now, the German government sharply cut its forecast for economic growth this year, to 2 percent from 2.75 percent. By contrast, the European Commission and most private experts predict that Europe as a whole will still expand about 2.5 percent. French growth is running closer to 3 percent this year, while smaller countries like Spain, Portugal, the Netherlands and Finland are even more dynamic.
But what is more striking is how Germany has been consistently slower to expand than most of its neighbors for at least the last five years. The country is still suffering from an economic hangover after the euphoric unification of East and West Germany in 1990. Despite hundreds of billions of marks in public money pumped into the east, joblessness still averages about 17 percent in the former Communist states.
And thanks to misconceived tax breaks to subsidize construction, the eastern states are still swamped with sparkling but under-used office buildings, shopping malls, industrial parks and apartment buildings. For the last four years, as the real estate market has worked through the imbalances, the German construction industry has been mired in a deep recession.
But those factors do not explain the whole problem, economists say. Germany has also been slowed by the lack of an overhaul of its economy. Its labor markets are still very tightly regulated, making companies hesitant to add to their work forces here and much more willing to shift their investment to Central Europe, Asia and the United States.
During the last decade, Germany's average annual growth rate has been just 1.5 percent. Its ability to generate new jobs has been about half that of Europe as a whole, which itself has been persistently slower than the United States. And while the country remains one of the world's biggest exporters of heavy machinery, automobiles and industrial equipment, German consumers have been plagued by rising taxes and anxiety about the future. Even last year, when the country had its best year in a decade and expanded by 3 percent, ordinary Germans held on to their wallets and showed little enthusiasm for celebrating.
"Europe is experiencing a slowdown, but the real problem is on our side," said Jurgen Pfister, head of economic research at Commerzbank in Frankfurt.
Though noting that the recession in German construction has been a problem for the last four years, Mr. Pfister said the broader problem was that Germany had deeply rooted difficulties in generating jobs.
German laws give workers extensive protection against being laid off. Industrywide collective bargaining agreements give companies little ability to negotiate better terms with labor unions. And new legislation aimed at giving workers more say on many management issues has added to the frustrations of employers who want more rather than less flexibility.
During the last five years, Mr. Pfister said, Germany has increased the overall number of jobs by only 0.7 percent a year -- less than half the rate for the rest of Europe and a tiny fraction of the rate in the United States. And many if not most of the new jobs were part time. The total number of hours worked in Germany barely increased at all.
That picture contrasts markedly with France and many other countries in Europe. French unemployment has plunged from more than 12 percent four years ago to about 8.8 percent today. Hundreds of thousands of jobs have been created in the last year alone. In the Netherlands, joblessness has sunk to just 2.4 percent, and the country is recruiting construction workers from eastern Germany.
But Germany has enjoyed only a small part of that European boom.
"The problem is that there is a mismatch in the labor market," said Reinhold Kudiss, an economist at the German Federation of Industry in Berlin. "Forty percent of the people who are unemployed are long-term unemployed, people who have no skills or who do not have the right skills." 
German corporations are desperately hunting engineers, managers and people skilled in information technology, but they are doing little hiring over all.
That is part of the reason that consumers have been so reluctant to spend money. But it is not the only one. Under relentless competitive pressure from other countries, which have drawn manufacturers by offering low-paid labor, German workers have settled for extremely modest wage increases for the last five years. Real wages, after accounting for inflation, have been stagnant since the mid-1990's. But taxes increased through much of that period, so disposable income for many workers actually declined.
Last year, in a bold break from past policies, the center-left government under Chancellor Gerhard Schroder pushed through a tax reduction that will total about $20 billion. But it also imposed a series of new "eco-taxes" on gasoline, which took effect just as oil prices were shooting to $30 a barrel last year.
The result, at least so far, is that consumers remained as cautious as ever about spending money. Apparently deterred by the sharp increases in gasoline prices, Germans bought far fewer cars last year even though the economy was doing well.
To be sure, many other European countries have high taxes and often rigid labor regulations. But even France, with its history of tough regulation and a socialist government in power, has given companies much greater flexibility by letting them hire workers on temporary contracts. The Netherlands has become one of the world's leading employers of part-time workers.
"In practice, things have been changing in other countries," said Willi Leibfritz, head of forecasting at the Ifo Institute for Economic Research in Munich. "When I look at France, I see things happening below the surface that are not officially labeled as flexibility but which have that effect."

HEADLINE: As Door to Amnesty Closes, Immigrants Rush to Qualify 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
The door is about to close on the opportunity of a lifetime for many illegal immigrants: the chance to become a legal permanent resident without first leaving their families and jobs in the United States.
 The deadline to apply for the benefit is Monday, and frenzy is in the air. 
 Legal aid groups, churches, law offices and community organizations that serve immigrants have been swamped for weeks. So have marriage license bureaus in New York City and across the country, as immigrants rush to marry in order to profit from having a spouse who can sponsor them for a green card, which confers legal residency. 
A toll-free hot line run by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, (800) 375-5283, has been getting an average of one million calls each month for the last three months, a big jump from the usual 750,000. And in March, the agency received well in excess of 130,000 applications for family reunification visas -- more than during any other month in its history.
The agency will not have exact figures on how many people applied to take advantage of the special immigration benefit for several months, said Bill Strassberger, a spokesman for the immigration service. At least 640,000 people nationwide are thought to be eligible.
The law that has so many thousands in a panic was passed at the end of last year, after advocates for immigrants were unable to convince Congress to extend a general amnesty to the estimated 6.5 million illegal immigrants around the country.
Instead, a more limited reprieve was offered to immigrants who would qualify for legal status were it not for the fact that they broke the law by entering or staying in the country without authorization.
Normally, American citizens and those with green cards can sponsor a close relative in another country to come and live with them. Employers in the United States can also sponsor a worker if they prove no American is available to take the job. But the foreign relative or worker has to remain outside the United States until a visa is issued.
The temporary benefit now on offer, referred to as 245(i), would permit those foreigners with family or employer sponsors to pay a $1,000 fine and apply to adjust their immigration status without having to leave the country. In most cases, they will not be able to work legally while they wait for their visas to be granted and, in theory, they remain at risk of being deported.
"We're telling people this is not a blanket amnesty," said Michael Amezquita, executive director of the Northern Manhattan Coalition for Immigrants Rights in Washington Heights. "Getting in your application before the April 30 deadline will not preclude your deportation if you are caught in a raid or something like that."
Nevertheless, response to the 245(i) opportunity has overwhelmed most of the organizations that provide immigrant services. And just as people wait until the last minute to file their taxes, many immigrants dawdled and now are scrambling to get help.
This week, Marvin Sacaza Ortiz, a 29-year-old Honduran immigrant, camped out on the doorstep of the Northern Manhattan Coalition at 4 a.m., hours before it was to open. That was the only way, he decided, to get an appointment with a counselor who could help him file the paperwork to sponsor his wife.
Even so, he was the third in line.
Mr. Ortiz has a green card, but his wife, Greicy Castillo, is here illegally. If she leaves, she would be penalized for staying without papers and barred from re-entry for 10 years.
"At the beginning, we didn't want to go through all this trouble," Mr. Ortiz said. "But then we started thinking that it would be worth it. When she has papers she can go back to school and she can travel to see her mother in Honduras."
Many public officials have argued that the 245(i) program should be offered for a longer period or made permanent. At least four bills are now before Congress that would extend the 245(i) filing period for up to one year.
Both Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki have urged Congress to extend the deadline. Mr. Giuliani, in a letter to House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, said he would like to see the 245(i) option made permanent.
"With so many immigrants contributing to our society and economy," the mayor's letter said, "the present requirement for those eligible for permanent resident status to return to their countries of origin creates an unnecessary burden on many businesses that depend on this work force."
But critics of national immigration policy said programs like this send the message that immigrants do not really have to worry about breaking the law.
Dan Stein, director of the Foundation for American Immigration Reform in Washington, which advocates a more restrictive immigration policy, called it "a thousand dollar loophole."
"Laws like 245(i) encourage illegal immigration," Mr. Stein said. "The evidence is all over the place."
Immigrants were offered the same benefit program a few years ago, with a three-year period from 1994 through 1997 in which to apply. It proved a bonanza for the immigration service, which collected more than $200 million through the fines that illegal immigrants paid. About 545,000 immigrants filed applications to adjust their status.
Advocates for immigrants maintain that most illegal immigrants are in the country because they wanted to join family members or because they found jobs that Americans did not want.
"The response to this law reflects an incontrovertible truth," said Mario Russell, director of immigrant and refugee services for Catholic Charities in New York. "We want these immigrants here to work, and we benefit from their being here."
Requiring people to be in their home country to apply for a family reunification visa, he added, has not driven illegal immigrants to leave the United States.
"Let's be frank," Mr. Russell said. "If you have someone who needs a job or you have spouses who are separated, they are just not going to think that way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marvin Sacaza Ortiz, left, sought help at the Northern Manhattan Coalition for Immigrants Rights with the paperwork to sponsor his wife, Greicy Castillo, for a green card before the Monday deadline. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Economic Growth Continues At an Annual Pace of 2%
The economy showed surprising resilience in the first three months of this year, growing at a 2 percent annual rate and extending the longest American expansion on record to a full 10 years, the government reported.
 Despite widespread concerns that a recession could be looming, overall economy activity accelerated in the first quarter. Page A1. 

Germany Is a Concern for Europe
German economic growth has lagged behind the European average for years now, not as strong in good times and slumping more seriously in bad times. And now, as Europeans nervously ponder their chances of escaping the worst effects of a slowdown in the United States, Germany is once again the Continent's biggest source of anemia. C2.

Dow Breaks Into Positive Territory
The Dow Jones industrial average wiped out its losses for the year, led by advances in Intel, Wal-Mart and Citigroup. The Dow rose 117.70 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,810.05, giving it a 0.2 percent gain in 2001. The Nasdaq composite index rose 40.82 points, or 2 percent, to 2,075.70. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 18.53 points, or 1.5 percent, to 1,253.05. For the year, the Nasdaq has lost 16 percent and the S.& P. 500 5 percent. C3.

More Discussion on Global Warming
In the wake of its rejection of an international treaty to curtail global warming, the Bush administration is seeking advice from a wide array of scientists, economists, business representatives and policy experts as it tries to forge a new approach. A10.

Poor Earnings for Taiwan Chip Maker
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing said its net income plunged 16.6 percent in the first quarter, below the reduced expectations of analysts. The results capped a week of dismal economic news from Taiwan and showed how hard the slowdown in American technology spending has pinched Asian suppliers. C2.

Strike Leads to Comair Layoffs
Comair, Delta Air Line's commuter airline, said it would lay off about 2,000 employees because of a strike by its pilots that began March 26. The layoffs affect about half of Comair's nonstriking employees, in all departments, the Cincinnati-based carrier said. C3.

$1.4 Million Investment at Airline
In a rare vote of confidence, Sir Christopher Bland, the newly appointed chairman of British Telecommunications, will invest about $1.4 million of his own money in the debt-ridden company. Sir Christopher will replace Sir Iain Vallance on Monday. C2.

An Under-40 Prize in Economics
The American Economics Association named Matthew Rabin of the University of California at Berkeley as the best economist in the United States under age 40. Mr. Rabin, 37, will receive the John Bates Clark medal, which the association awards every other year. He is the first winner to openly embrace behavioral economics, which attempts to incorporate psychology into standard economic theory. C14.

Greenspan Predicts Large Surpluses
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, predicted that the United States would produce large budget surpluses for some time, permitting it ultimately to pay off the publicly held portion of the national debt. He also offered reassurances on the effect of a dwindling supply of low-risk government debt. C3.

Software Maker to Sell Units
Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, which makes speech-recognition and translation software, has hired Credit Suisse First Boston to help it find buyers for its units as it tries to avoid insolvency, after having trouble in attracting interest, said Philippe Bodson, the company's new chief executive. C2.

HEADLINE: Many Pilots Do Not Like Their Union's DeltaAccord 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Air travelers, the management of Delta Air Lines and many local and national politicians were relieved earlier this week after Delta reached a tentative contract with its pilots, averting a strike that could have disrupted air service across much of the country. 
 But many Delta pilots are not happy with the agreement, which both Delta and some union leaders have described as the best in the industry. Some pilots are even predicting that the union's governing board, which meets in Atlanta starting today to decide whether to endorse the contract, will reject it before the union's 9,800 members have a chance to vote on it. 
 "We are aware that a lot of the membership is very unhappy," said one member of the union's board, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. He said that he would wait until he heard what the negotiating team had to say before casting his vote. 
Feelings were so strong at a meeting at Delta's pilot base in Orlando, Fla., earlier this week that a group of about 100 pilots overwhelmingly passed a nonbinding resolution opposing the agreement. 
"I know people are upset, but I am not so sure that they represent a majority," said Andrew M. Deane, a Delta 767 captain and spokesman for the union. 
Rejecting the agreement could be a risky move by the union.
If the two sides had not reached an agreement before the strike deadline this weekend, President Bush was expected to appoint a presidential emergency board -- delaying a walkout for another 60 days -- as he did last month in a contract dispute between Northwest Airlines and its mechanics. 
If the union leadership rejects the deal, the two sides would have only seven days to reach a new agreement before the union could walk out. Most experts believe that the White House would step in before then. If the two sides could not reach a new deal within 60 days, then Congress could vote to impose a contract on the union. 
"If we go down that road, some things that are very dear to the pilots would be at risk," said Robert Morus, a pilot and executive vice president of the union. 
The tentative agreement promises to raise the pilots' pay 24 percent to 34 percent over four years, 1 percent higher than the top pay rates negotiated by the pilots at United Airlines last summer. Most industry analysts have complained that the deal is too rich. Delta has said that the deal will raise its current pilot costs above $4 billion a year from $1.7 billion today. 
But opponents say that the union's negotiators reneged on their promise to deliver an industry-leading contract. "It's not the best contract in the industry, period," said one pilot, speaking on the condition of anonymity, who acknowledged that he was a strong opponent of the agreement. "They mask a substandard contract with superior pay rates." 
The new agreement allows Delta to fly up to 75 70-seat regional jets, while United's contract prohibits it from flying regional jets with more than 50 seats. United agreed to protect all its pilots from layoffs. The new Delta agreement protects only the pilots at the company on the date the agreement is signed. 
But perhaps the biggest complaint is that the union's negotiators did not end a lower wage scale for pilots at Delta Express, a low-fare unit within Delta intended to compete with Southwest Airlines. The new agreement gives Delta Express pilots a nearly 63 percent pay increase but still leaves them earning about 10 percent less than other pilots at the airline. 
"The bottom line is that we made a promise not to accept the economic apartheid of a two-tier wage scale," the opposing pilot said. "We cannot perpetuate something that every other airline has eradicated." 
The meeting today will start with the union's negotiators briefing the board, which is known as the master executive council, and answering questions. A vote by the 22 pilot representatives on the council could come as early as today. But Captain Deane, the union spokesman, said the meeting would probably last three days with a vote on Monday. If a majority of the council approves the contract, it is still subject to approval by the entire membership. 
Captain Morus said that many pilots could not appreciate the political situation negotiators faced. He said that the union worked hard to prevent the White House from announcing an emergency board before the strike deadline and that the union might lose important features of the tentative agreement, like retroactive pay, if Congress were forced to intervene. 
"We never laid out how bad the politics were because we were playing a game of poker and we had to play our cards face down," he said. After the board members learn the details, their perceptions may change, he added. 
Vetoing the agreement before the union's members have a chance to vote on it is also risky because it would make the leadership vulnerable to the charge that it did not let the members decide for themselves. 
But opponents said there was no risk in rejecting the agreement because every pilots' group that had voted down a tentative agreement had always ended up with a superior final contract. --------------------

Agreement on Union Fine
FORT WORTH, April 27 (Bloomberg News) -- American Airlines, a subsidiary of AMR, reached an agreement with its pilots union today on how the Allied Pilots Association will pay a $45.5 million fine for a 1999 job action that forced thousands of flight cancellations.
American received $20 million that the union earlier placed in escrow, plus interest, the company and union said. The remaining $25.5 million will be repaid, with interest, over 15 years, the company said. American agreed to dismiss remaining litigation with the union and to drop claims against 25 individual union officers and directors. 
Federal Judge Joe Kendall imposed the award after ruling that the union ignored his order to end the 11-day job action. 

CORRECTION-DATE: May 1, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about objections from some pilots at Delta Air Lines to their union's tentative contract agreement misstated its cost. If approved by the union, the contract would add a total of $2.5 billion to Delta's current pilot costs over five years, not yearly.

HEADLINE: ECONOMY'S GROWTH PROVES STEADFAST ALTHOUGH MODEST 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The economy showed surprising resilience in the first three months of this year, growing at a 2 percent annual rate and extending the longest American expansion on record to a full 10 years, the government reported yesterday.
 Even as the stock market fell and unemployment rose, consumers continued to spend more than they earned, increasing their debt levels to buy new homes, cars and other items. Their shopping slowed as the winter went on, but the solid increase was enough to overcome a sharp decline in companies' investments in new equipment. 
 Despite widespread concerns that a recession could be looming, overall economic activity accelerated in the first quarter of 2001. Still, after growing at a mere 1 percent rate in the fourth quarter of 2000, the economy has now posted its worst six months since 1995, and companies continue to cut jobs, threatening future growth, analysts said. 
Yesterday's report, said Richard D. Rippe, the chief economist for Prudential Securities, "certainly belies the notion of recession, but it also doesn't mean we're completely out of the woods."
Economists and government officials remain concerned that consumers will rein in their spending in coming months, as they began to do in February and March. At the same time, businesses could remain reluctant to buy new computers and machinery, or build communications networks and warehouses, having spent trillions of dollars expanding their operations in the 1990's.
For now, though, the evidence of stronger growth decreased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would continue the aggressive reduction of short-term interest rates that it has pursued since January, when it made the first of four recent cuts of half a percentage point each in its target rate. With inflation picking up to around 3 percent, the Fed may see less reason to encourage new spending, economists said.
Still, with the economy still sluggish, most expect the Fed to lower interest rates by at least another quarter-point at its meeting next month and quite a few remain convinced that the central bank will make another half-point reduction.
Major stock indexes rose yesterday, as investors' optimism about the economy's health seemed to outweigh their sense that the Fed might soon turn more conservative. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 117.70 points to close at 10,810.05, up 1.1 percent.
The Commerce Department, in estimating that the annual growth rate reached 2 percent in the January-March period, ignored changes in prices to come up with its best guess of the real economic output of the economy. Including price increases, the gross domestic product -- the value of all the goods and services produced in the United States -- rose to an annual level of $10.2 trillion in the quarter, according to the department's initial report for the period.
As more data trickle in, the department will issue several more reports on the quarter. On average over the last two decades, the final number for economic growth has changed by 1.4 percentage points between the initial report and the final one, suggesting even a fairly large downward revision would be unlikely to show a shrinking economy in this year's first quarter.
Consumer spending, a driving force of the economy, rose an inflation-adjusted 3.1 percent, led by a surge in car sales as automakers offered rebates on almost every type of vehicle. Government spending rose 4 percent, and a drop in imports also helped domestic growth. But business investment fell 11.5 percent as companies canceled expansion plans and cut production to clear out their inventories.
Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans called the economy's performance in the winter quarter an improvement over the recent past and said in a statement that the growth "confirms the fundamentals of our economy are sound."
One of the most encouraging signs in the report was the quickness with which businesses were able to reduce their excess inventories as the economy slowed in recent months. As companies cut production and consumers continued to spend, the value of the goods sitting on the companies' shelves, in their warehouses and on auto dealers' lots fell by $7.1 billion, the first decline since the summer of 1991, just after the last recession ended.
"The shelves are bare," said Diane Swonk, the chief economist at Bank One and one of the optimists who say the country is already emerging from its slowdown.
"It sets the stage for even stronger growth in the second quarter and second half" of the year, she added.
But the uneven growth of the last six months has also offered a number of troubling signs that suggest to others that the current slowdown is not following a typical pattern and may worsen before it improves. 
Normally, consumers are the first group to decide to pull back. Businesses, then selling fewer goods, begin to produce less. This is what happened at the start of the last three recessions -- two almost back-to-back in the early 1980's and one in 1991 -- and during the mid-1990's slowdown.
Over the last year, by contrast, businesses have begun abandoning plans to buy software and machines even as consumers have continued to spend their money at a fairly fast pace. As a result, companies like Cisco Systems and Oracle that sell mainly to other companies have suffered more than retailers or automakers.
"We may be experiencing the first postwar slowdown led and directed more by the business sector than the household sector," said James W. Paulsen, the chief investment officer of Wells Capital Management, an investment firm.
In the first quarter, business investment in new equipment and software fell 2.1 percent at an annual rate and has now dropped for two consecutive quarters, after not having declined once between 1991 and late 1999. Spending on information technology alone has reversed directions even more sharply. It fell 6.4 percent last quarter after growing an average of 24 percent each quarter during 1999 and 2000.
"That is a collapse of huge magnitude," said Allen Sinai, the chief global economist of Decision Economics. "It is a big deal," he added, because business spending on information technology now accounts for more than 7 percent of the economy, nearly double its portion a decade ago.
In addition, a slump in investment often lasts longer than a slowdown created by an inventory buildup because companies can sell excess products far more easily than they can sell an extra machine or warehouse, Mr. Sinai said.
The government's report offered other signs of weakness, as well. The savings rate of American households hit a new low, as people spent 1 percent more money than they earned. With debt levels already high, many economists say consumers will soon begin to reduce their spending to pay off mortgages and credit card bills.
This may already be happening. After rising at a healthy clip in January, according to estimates by Ian Shepherdson, the chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., consumer spending rose only slightly in February and stayed roughly constant in March.
