HEADLINE: A City Long Passionate About Its River Finds a Fondness for Its Flood Wall 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: HANNIBAL, Mo., April 27 

 BODY:
Here in the hometown of Mark Twain, life on this stretch of the flooding Mississippi is mostly high and still mostly dry these days. 
 While people upstream fortified their towns with sandbags and kept watch over dikes, people here came to the downtown earthen levees connected to a concrete flood wall and giant floodgates today, just to watch the swirling river. 
 The wall is a somewhat conspicuous structure of concrete, steel and dirt, but trees, grass, wooden benches and ornate lamps make it seem more like a park on a hill. Most of downtown, including Mark Twain's house, the town's museum with its 27 paintings by Norman Rockwell and all of the businesses in this historic district, are out of harm's way, protected by the flood wall. 
The wall, completed in 1992, just in time to shield Hannibal from the great flood that came a year later, is as much a part of this town as the river it loves.
So people came here to watch the Mississippi swell and roll while they stood safe on dry land throughout the warm afternoon. And while other riverside towns debate whether to build or not to build flood walls, people in Hannibal say theirs has stolen none of the river's might or mystique.
"For us people around here, it's still the same old river," said Donald Kempf, 62, who has lived in Hannibal all his life and who watched the river from the berm today with his friends Carl Vincent, 76, and Marietta Glasscock, 69.
Watching the river from atop the grassy mound, Dorothy Matson recalled that once on a trip to California she met a woman who bragged that Californians had the Pacific Ocean. Another woman, a New Yorker, bragged that she had the Atlantic. Ms. Matson told them that she had the Mississippi. That settled that.
"I couldn't feature life without the Mississippi," said Ms. Matson, who has lived in Hannibal all her 78 years. "I've lived with it so long I couldn't feature that."
The river rolls south, high and fast, an extension of the floods upstream. This afternoon, graying men and women, children dipping plastic spoons in ice cream cups and a couple lying on the berm watched the water roll by. 
"It's the mighty Mississippi and it's going to do what it's going to do," John Hark, the city's emergency management coordinator, said. Even so, the people here decided about a decade ago that they had to try to tame it to protect themselves.
The mystique of the river and the lure of the names Mark Twain, Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer draw about 520,000 tourists a year to this town of 18,000, city officials say. Visitors spend an average of $75 a day. That translates to about $38 million, a big part of the town's economy. 
There was considerable opposition before the town decided to construct the walls that now protect downtown, Mr. Hark recalled. People here did not want to lose their connection to the Mississippi; some thought a monstrous wall would block their view of the river. 
The flood walls and gates were built from 1991 to 1992 at a cost of $8 million, about 20 percent of which was paid by the city and the remainder by the federal government, Mr. Hark said. 
The combination wall and levee, which runs about 2,500 to 3,000 feet, also has several floodgates that are lowered when the river floods and removed when the water recedes. 
So, for much of the year, the river view is unobstructed and there is access to Kiwanis Park as well as the town's harbor. After years of putting up with flooding, many here say, a dry downtown when the river is raging is worth the occasional blocked view.
"It's pretty much not a panic thing anymore," said Mary Beth Baudendistel, the city clerk.
Others agreed. 
"I kind of like the levee because this was the only levee in '93 that held," Mr. Kempf said. "The rest of them broke."
"It's just nature and holding its water back," Mr. Vincent said of the levee, standing next to his friends. 
"It's the same old river," Mr. Vincent said. "She just ain't as fresh as she used to be. Used to be, when I was a kid, I wasn't afraid to go out there and drink a glass of it." He also used to drive a team of horses across it when it was frozen solid during winter. And men used to cut the ice and sell it for 50 cents a slab, he said. 
The river was expected to crest tonight at 23.5 feet, about 7 feet above flood stage, although still a good 8 feet below the earthen levees and concrete reinforced flood walls. Barge traffic on this seam of the Mississippi has been still for days now because of the swollen river. 
But the river is still right for cruising, said Steve Terry, captain of the riverboat Mark Twain. In 1993, the river's swell was 8 feet higher than it was today and his boat was out of business 47 days. He rode it out then. So this year's flood is a piece of cake.
"It makes it a little more of a challenge. It'll be a real quick trip downstream, and kind of slow coming back," said Mr. Terry, 41, as his crew readied the boat for the night's two-hour, eight-mile cruise, something Mr. Terry looks forward to even in flood season. 
"You talk to my wife and she'll tell you I have river water in my veins instead of blood," he said.
"He does," his daughter, Jenna, 14, whispered, lighting a candle on a table in the boat's cabin.
As the last rays of sun danced off the river, a man fingered a banjo, the crowd filled the cabin and the ship cast off on the swollen Mississippi.

HEADLINE: Just Ask Elmo: Is 'B' for Bite, or Byte? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Gail Collins complains about AOL Time Warner's sponsorship of "Sesame Street" (column, April 24). But there's a weakness in the argument about blurring boundaries between corporate media and education. Ms. 
Collins asks if Elmo's computer fixation is really product placement, without acknowledging the contribution of "Sesame Street" in helping children and their parents appreciate how the "knowledge economy" has made computer competence essential. 
 "Sesame Street" has corporate sponsors because media education is profoundly underfinanced. If tax dollars are not available to support such education, then I consider it part of the social responsibility of companies like AOL to help pay for it.

RENEE HOBBS
Wellesley, Mass., April 24, 2001

The writer is an associate professor of communication, Babson College.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
A War Against Ourselves

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
"They are killing us," the pilot of the small plane carrying an American missionary family said as a Peruvian Air Force fighter fired. Veronica Bowers and her 7-month-old daughter, Charity, died. 
 But the "they" in the pilot's words were not just the Peruvian gunners, and the "us" were not only Veronica and Charity Bowers. The ultimate cause of their death was U.S. drug policy, the war on drugs; and that war has damaged the lives of millions of Americans. 
 The attack on the Bowers family focused attention on an obscure part of the drug war: surveillance flights by C.I.A. contract employees who target suspected drug-smuggling planes for the Peruvian Air Force. President Bush ordered a temporary suspension of the program. And critics pointed to flaws in the way it is carried out.
For example, the C.I.A. employees who spotted the Bowers's plane tried to stop the Peruvian fighter from shooting at it before first checking its markings. But a tape of their communications showed that the Peruvian crew had trouble understanding them because the C.I.A. men spoke little Spanish. A former pilot in the C.I.A. operation told The Washington Post, "That's one of the fallacies of the whole program: the language barrier." 
But the real point is not a particular flaw like the C.I.A.'s idiocy in using English-speaking spotters. It is the futility of the whole operation.
The effort to stop cocaine exports from Peru has cut the flow from there substantially. But that reduction has been more than made up by a huge increase in coca cultivation and production in Colombia. As Plan Colombia, the military anti-drug program, gets under way there, production is reportedly beginning to shift to Ecuador. 
In the last 15 years, the United States has spent $30 billion, most of it in Latin America, trying to cut the supply of drugs from abroad. The costs to other societies have been severe: the rise of drug gangs, the suffering of peasants from crop eradication, the corruption of governments. Yet the amount of cocaine and heroin entering the United States is as great as ever.
To think that we can deal with our drug problem by limiting supply is irrational. Illegal drugs are an infinitesimal portion of goods entering this country, easy to conceal. And if cocaine were magically stopped, Americans who crave drugs would find some other chemical. 
The real need is to reduce the craving. Study after study has shown that treatment of drug abusers is the best and cheapest way to do that. Yet treatment funds are scarce, and the heavy emphasis of our drug policy is on criminal punishment. 
The costs to our society have been grievous. Long mandatory minimum sentences have filled our prisons with nonviolent drug offenders and made them, and their families, damaged beings for the rest of their lives. Prison-building is now one of the country's largest construction programs. 
The war on drugs is a testament to the human capacity for self-delusion. It is hard to change because even legislators who recognize its futility do not want to be seen as "soft on drugs." Yet around the country some politicians, and many members of the public, have begun to call for change. 
But not George W. Bush and his administration. Mr. Bush's reported choice as drug czar is John P. Walters, an all-out warrior who has spoken scornfully of drug treatment and wants to intensify the fight to cut off drug supplies abroad. 
The Bush administration has also started to enforce a little-known 1998 law that bars financial aid to students who have been convicted of even a minor drug offense. The result, defying reason, is to discourage one of the best routes to rehabilitation, higher education. 
The "war on drugs" is more than just a slogan. In war, collateral damage is often regarded as unavoidable. In any sane civilian policy, the collateral damage of the drug war to ourselves and our neighbors would long since have been found unacceptable. 
The result of the U.S. drug war, The Economist of London said last week, "is to undermine democracy, human rights and the environment in much of Latin America. A radical rethink of drug policy is long overdue."

HEADLINE: Japan's New Prime Minister Signals Peaceful Intentions 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 27 

 BODY:
In his first full day in office, Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, moved today to reassure neighbors about nationalist currents in his country, while reaffirming a campaign pledge to create a full-fledged army.
 At his first news conference since his confirmation by Parliament on Thursday, Mr. Koizumi said, "Saying the self-defense forces aren't an army is just a lie." He then added: "In the very worst case, if Japan is invaded, not being fully equipped and prepared is politically irresponsible." 
 Mr. Koizumi stressed, however, that the alliance with the United States remains the pillar of Japan's security policy, and said he hoped to meet President Bush as soon as possible. The new prime minister also said he favored a more active role for Japan in international peacekeeping, which is something the United States has long urged.
The comments were Mr. Koizumi's first confirmation since taking office of a campaign vow to seek changes to Japan's Constitution, written by Americans during occupation after World War II, to allow the country to organize a national army in the place of the current national self-defense force.
Japan's self-defense force boasts one of the world's largest military budgets, but is limited to defense by the Constitution's Article 9, which says, "The Japanese people forever renounce war as a sovereign right of the nation," and "land, sea and air forces, as well as other war potential, will never be maintained."
Many of Japan's neighbors, victims of this country's aggressive expansionism during the first half of the 20th century, have vigorously condemned perceived movements toward the fielding of a national army, and watch closely for any signs of renewed nationalism.
Mr. Koizumi himself fueled concerns about the rise of nationalism during his recent campaign, in which he joined with other conservative candidates of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party to pledge that he would visit a shrine to war veterans in Tokyo on Aug. 15, a national memorial day. The new prime minister renewed that pledge in his news conference today.
The shrine, Yasukuni, contains the remains of some of Japan's biggest war criminals, and most politicians have shied away from visiting in recent years out of concern of offending Japan's neighbors.
In a rare reference to Japan's wartime past by a sitting prime minister, Mr. Koizumi struck a resolutely pacifist tone. "Why did we get involved in that war?" he asked. "Because Japan became isolated from international society. What is most important is that we do not fight a war again, and do not again become internationally isolated."
Mr. Koizumi also balanced his potentially provocative comments about the Constitution and about the war memorial with a telephone call to South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, pledging to work with him to settle a controversy over government's recent approval of junior high school history textbooks that avoid mention of Japan's wartime atrocities.
Mr. Koizumi and Mr. Kim also agreed to coordinate their policies toward North Korea, together with the United States. 
Asked about Japan's perennially difficult relations with China, worsened this week by a visit by a former leader of Taiwan, Mr. Koizumi said, "There are various problems, but what is important is to understand each other's position."
In a busy first day for the new government, Mr. Koizumi's newly appointed foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, met with the governor of Okinawa, Keiichi Inamine, over the issue of American troops stationed on that island.
Mr. Inamine has recently demanded a reduction in the number of marines stationed on the island, and asked for Ms. Tanaka's "understanding" over the strains caused by the presence of the American troops. 
Shortly after her appointment on Thursday, Ms. Tanaka hinted that she would support a new, stricter status-of-forces agreement governing the behavior of American military personnel in Japan. The Marine presence in Okinawa has been a longtime irritant in relations between the two countries, because of a string of rapes, arsons and other crimes. 
Mr. Koizumi gave little indication about his economic policy intentions, other than to say that "economic recovery and rebuilding the economy are a top priority."
"The most crucial point for the implementation of policy is for citizens to trust politicians, and the prime minister in particular," said Mr. Koizumi, who during his campaign called for sweeping reform.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Forecasts an End to Treasury Debt 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, predicted today that the United States would produce large budget surpluses for some time, permitting it ultimately to pay off the publicly held portion of the national debt.
 "While the magnitudes of future federal unified budget surpluses are uncertain, they are highly likely to remain sizable for some time," Mr. 
Greenspan told the annual convention of the Bond Market Association. He addressed the meeting, which was in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., by satellite from Washington. 
 He did not mention the near-term outlook for the economy, except to note that the current slowdown would probably cause a weak spell for productivity gains.
But he said the long-term trend of rapid growth in productivity should remain intact, which bodes well for the government's balance sheet.
"Current forecasts suggest that under a reasonably wide range of possible tax and spending policies, the resulting surpluses will allow the Treasury debt held by the public to be paid off," Mr. Greenspan said.
While financial markets have worried about the potential loss of the Treasury debt market -- which serves as a benchmark for pricing private-sector debt -- Mr. Greenspan offered reassurances on the effect of a dwindling supply of low-risk government debt.
"I am confident that U.S. financial markets, which are the most innovative and efficient in the world, can readily adapt to a paydown of Treasury debt by creating private alternatives with many of the attributes that market participants value in Treasury securities," he said.
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that there would be transition costs, but he said those were likely to be outweighed by various benefits to the country.

HEADLINE: After Rejecting Climate Treaty, Bush Calls In Tutors to Give Courses and Help Set One 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
In the wake of its rejection of an international treaty to curtail global warming, the Bush administration is seeking advice from a wide array of scientists, economists, business representatives and policy experts as it tries to forge a new approach to the contentious issue.
 Most of those consulted, senior government officials said, are asserting that the science pointing to a serious problem is sound, and that there is need for concrete action to stem rising levels of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases emitted by smokestacks and tailpipes. 
 Although the new effort is mainly taking the form of cabinet briefings behind closed doors, it is widely seen as a substantial broadening of a process that until recently was so tightly controlled by a small circle of advisers that cabinet members themselves often gave conflicting accounts of President Bush's plans.
The broadening has elicited expressions of cautious relief from environmental campaigners and frustration by conservatives and skeptics about warming's dangers. But both sides said they could not predict how the review would influence the Bush administration, which is under pressure to devise an alternative to the rejected climate treaty. 
"This group is reaching out for a diversity of views on climate issues," said Ken Lisaius, a White House spokesman. "This is a very serious matter that the president takes very seriously."
At the briefings, held about once a week over the last month, half a dozen members of Mr. Bush's cabinet and, most of the time, Vice President Dick Cheney have spent a couple of hours in what amounts to Climate 101.
The list of speakers has been dominated by scientists and policy experts who believe that a recent global warming trend is at least partly caused by humans, poses serious risks and requires a significant response to stem the buildup of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. 
The presenters have included Dr. James E. Hansen, a government climate expert who in 1988 testified about the problem before the Senate at the invitation of Al Gore, then a senator from Tennessee, and Dr. Daniel L. Albritton, the head of a federal climate laboratory and a lead author of an international report pointing to serious risks from global warming for coming decades. 
The report, by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a United Nations group, was widely criticized by conservative groups as biased but has been held up by many others as strong new evidence justifying action.
The participants all declined to discuss the substance of the meetings at the request of the White House. But some said they saw the meetings as a sign of new openness on the issue. 
"It is encouraging that they are spending serious time gathering information and facts in the development of their policy," said Kevin Fay, a business official who was a presenter at the most recent briefing, on Tuesday.
Mr. Fay is the executive director of the International Climate Change Partnership, an organization representing what he calls "the progressive cowering middle of industry," businesses that seek to be environmental stewards, but with the bottom line in mind. 
Another sign of the administration's new tack in recent days is its recruitment of seasoned experts in climate issues from the ranks of various agencies as it assembles a team to come up with policy options, which officials plan to present to Mr. Bush by the end of May. 
Particularly urgent is an effort to come up with an alternative to the Kyoto Protocol, the treaty that was negotiated and signed by the Clinton administration and summarily rejected by Mr. Bush last month. Mr. Bush said that its binding limits on greenhouse gases could harm the economy and that it unfairly excluded fast-growing economic powers like China and India. 
That decision came shortly after Mr. Bush renounced a campaign pledge he had made to include mandatory carbon dioxide cuts in a cleanup of power plants.
Both announcements came after a flurry of lobbying by conservatives who have long opposed restrictions on carbon dioxide, which is, at least for now, a byproduct of almost every activity in modern industrial society. 
But the announcements produced a flood of bad press and the first bruises for Mr. Bush in some public opinion polls. 
With the dust settling, there is a growing realization at the White House that the blunt rejection of the treaty may have caused more problems than it solved.
"The decisions six weeks ago were made in an appalling vacuum of information," said a senior government official involved in the climate policy review, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity.
"A substantial portion of the people involved wish they had it to do over again," the official said. "They might still have rejected Kyoto, but probably in a different way. Now you're seeing a genuine effort to get a balanced perspective."
The briefings have been intimate affairs, officials said, including only a handful of White House staff members and a varying roster of cabinet members and government executives -- generally from the Departments of Agriculture, Commerce, Energy, Interior, State and Treasury, as well as the Environmental Protection Agency. 
The first two sessions, held at Commerce Department headquarters and then the headquarters of the Environmental Protection Agency, were strictly science. 
Dr. Albritton defended the international report he helped create. Dr. Ronald J. Stouffer, a designer of computer climate models at the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory, a government research center in Princeton, N.J., talked about the difficulties posed by clouds, which as yet cannot be modeled accurately and so hamper predictions of the local consequences of a general climate warming. 
There were props. Dr. Hansen used a one-watt Christmas-tree bulb to represent the extra energy beating down on each half-square-yard of the earth's surface as a result of the growing blanket of greenhouse gases. 
Dr. Hansen has been of particular interest to the White House because last year he proposed that the best short-term attack on warming might come by focusing not on carbon dioxide but on methane, a less common but more potent greenhouse gas, and soot, which is not mentioned in the Kyoto Protocol but is increasingly thought to contribute both to warming and to serious health problems. 
Dr. Hansen was invited back to the second session, where he was joined by a prominent skeptic, Dr. Richard S. Lindzen, a meteorology professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who has long held that any climate influence from human activities is inconsequential.
In the third session, focusing on economics, the administration stayed close to home, listening to Dr. Richard L. Schmalensee, the dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a member of the Council of Economic Advisers in the administration of Mr. Bush's father. Dr. Schmalensee and other M.I.T. economists have repeatedly asserted that the Kyoto pact is an overly costly insurance policy. 
On Tuesday, the pendulum swung to experts who support the general goals of the Kyoto treaty but who concede that the existing language is rife with problems. 
They included Mr. Fay, from the business group, and another former official from the first Bush administration, William K. Reilly, who is the president of the World Wildlife Fund and was administrator of the E.P.A.
Now the ball is in Mr. Bush's court, many observers say. The key question is whether he will choose some new way to get governments to agree to binding cuts in greenhouse gases or revert to the approach sought by his father, who at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio signed the Framework Convention on Climate Change, the treaty that preceded the Kyoto document but that called only for voluntary reductions in the gases. 
Some business groups that opposed the Kyoto treaty have greeted the chance for a fresh approach to the problem. But they also say there is danger in starting from scratch.
"We're not talking about totally erasing the blackboard," said Norine Kennedy, the vice president for environmental affairs of the United States Council for International Business, which represents several hundred companies. "There's a lot in the protocol that should be retained."

HEADLINE: Merger Blocked For Makers Of Baby Food 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 27 

 BODY:
A federal appeals panel blocked the proposed acquisition of one large maker of baby food by another today in a challenge filed by the Federal Trade Commission during the Clinton administration. 
 The challenge is based on a legal theory that has been criticized by President Bush's nominee to head the agency. 
 Soon after the panel announced its decision to issue an injunction against the deal, which reversed a lower court order approving it, H. J. Heinz announced it would abandon its plans to buy the Milnot Holding Corporation, maker of Beech-Nut, for $185 million. While not among the larger corporate acquisitions under scrutiny by the government, the case illustrates the stark differences between the antitrust approaches of Clinton and Bush appointees. 
Robert Pitofsky, the departing chairman of the F.T.C., said the decision was one of the most important antitrust cases during his six years leading the agency.
He said that had the decision gone the other way it would have encouraged other deals in highly concentrated industries.
The Bush nominee to lead the F.T.C., Timothy J. Muris, a law professor at George Mason University, worked on behalf of the two companies. He has been critical of the government for failing to consider the economic benefits of such mergers, and he is expected to be confirmed soon as the next chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.
In a speech late last year, Mr. Muris said that the case had presented the most powerful efficiencies he had ever seen, according to lawyers in the audience. He has told friends that several grounds even more compelling than the efficiency argument formed his conclusion that he would not have challenged the deal had he been at the F.T.C.
Mr. Muris has said that Gerber Products, the largest player in the industry, objected to the deal, suggesting that it would increase and not decrease competition. But retailers also supported it. 
The proposed deal had been attacked on the ground that it would have reduced the industry to two dominant players from three. Heinz and Milnot together control nearly 33 percent of the retail baby food market; Gerber controls 65 percent. 
Heinz and Milnot defended the deal on the ground that the economic efficiencies created by the merger would benefit consumers far more than they would be harmed by any potential anticompetitive effects.
The case has significant potential consequences for other deals in heavily concentrated industries now under review by the government, providing important legal ammunition if officials decide to challenge the deals.
This week, General Dynamics announced its intention to acquire Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. for $2.1 billion in a deal that would give the company control over the manufacture and maintenance of all nuclear-powered military ships.
The administration is also reviewing the acquisition of US Airways by the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines. 
But it is by no means clear that the new administration, which has criticized antitrust officials at the Justice Department and the F.T.C., will seek to apply the case to challenge other deals.
In siding today with the F.T.C., a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit concluded that the companies could use efficiency as a defense to a merger or acquisition in a highly concentrated industry but had failed in this instance to make their case.
"The high market concentration levels present in this case require, in rebuttal, proof of extraordinary efficiencies, which the appellees failed to supply," the court said in an opinion by Judge Karen L. Henderson and signed by Judges A. Raymond Randolph and Merrick B. Garland. The judges concluded that the companies had failed to demonstrate that the purported efficiencies could be accomplished only through a corporate acquisition.
Mr. Pitofsky said the opinion was "one of the two or three most important antitrust decisions of the Clinton years."
"If this deal got through you would have seen a land rush of 3-to-2 proposals," Mr. Pitofsky said in an interview today. "The court just knocked this one out of the park."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Reassessing an Era When Excess Was the Norm

BYLINE:  By AMEI WALLACH; Amei Wallach is president of the International Art Critics Association/U.S.A.

DATELINE: NORTH MIAMI, Fla. 

 BODY:
THE art world tends to clock itself in decades. But the 1980's were something else, a decade of bloated reputations, excessive prices, collective rapaciousness and some serious painting.
 How serious has been difficult to gauge in the morning-after years since the orgy. It is only lately that 80's painters are once again regularly to be found in galleries and museum retrospectives. And now in "Mythic Proportions: Painting in the 1980's," the Museum of Contemporary Art in North Miami is assessing the contribution of 80's painters as a group. 
 The 50's belonged to Abstract Expressionism; the 60's to Pop Art and theory-driven minimalism. In the 70's, myriad styles proliferated: earth art, conceptual art, performance art, language-based art -- anything sufficiently unwieldy, difficult, challenging or dry to escape contamination by the marketplace. The point was not to be subsumed by the military-industrial economy, not to make anything that could be mistaken for a commodity. 
From the middle of the 60's on, the big debate was: is painting dead? Any artist worth his -- almost always his -- avant-garde credentials who painted under these circumstances did so according to the precepts of the enormously influential critic Clement Greenberg. According to Greenberg's theory of progress, art must become increasingly self-referential, increasingly reduced to the truth of the materials out of which it was made -- meaning flat canvas and paint. It must avoid "illusionism," meaning not just subject matter, but also any discernible break between background and foreground.
And then came the 80's. The paintings of Julian Schnabel, David Salle, Eric Fischl, Anselm Kiefer, Francesco Clemente, Enzo Cucchi and Georg Bazelitz were enormous, bumptious, anything but flat. And, worst of all, they told stories.
These painters ransacked history for subject matter (Mr. Kiefer and Mr. Clemente), layered contemporary porn with pop images and snippets out of the past (Mr. Salle), exposed the sex and drugs on the other side of the American dream in a style resembling the Socialist Realism usually associated with the Soviet dream (Mr. Fischl). Mr. Schnabel affixed broken plates and tree branches to his paintings; Mr. Kiefer covered straw with paint, tar and painted words. 
It was all bold, excessive, rule-breaking and for sale! Collectors, too long on a starvation diet, went into a feeding frenzy. Shows sold out before they opened. The collectors, not critics or curators, set the agenda. The great white male painters ruled the galleries, leaving very little room for other artists to be noticed at all.
And then, on Oct. 19, 1987, the market crashed, and the decade was as good as over. The moment had come for other artists of every ideology, sexual persuasion and nationality working in forms as varied as video, installation and the Web. The reputations of many of the big 80's painters plummeted as fast as they had climbed. In the 90's, painting of the 80's was dissed as avidly as it had been praised.
Through May 13, the North Miami museum has rounded up all the usual suspects for a recount of the hyperbolic era. And Bonnie Clearwater, the director of the museum and curator of the exhibition, has tried to recreate the feel and meaning of a whole decade through 62 paintings.
There isn't a painter in the exhibition who comes as a surprise. That's irritating, but it isn't her enterprise to fill in gaps or right wronged reputations. Ms. Clearwater spent a large part of her career at the Lannan Foundation in Los Angeles, and she's vigilant about the dead weight of New York opinion-making. She often mounts shows that reposition the work of an artist whom we thought we knew well, like Frank Stella, but who might look different from a different perspective.
Her case in the "Mythic Proportions" catalog is that 80's painting is misunderstood because at the time the art world was too busy navel-gazing to recognize that important art was being made in Europe. She argues that European art -- by Mr. Kiefer, Gerhard Richter, Mr. Clemente and Sigmar Polke -- influenced many of the Americans and that California teaching, especially by John Baldessari at Cal Arts in Valencia, trained others.
It's not an altogether new point, and it's not successfully made visually in the show, despite the presence of the Germans and the Italians. But it's the kind of investigation that needs to begin if we are going to get the meaning of 80's painting right. Now that the attraction and repulsion phases are over, what is there that counts? What's the context? How does it all fit into the greater dialogue of art?
In "Mythic Proportions," Elizabeth Murray and Susan Rothenberg get rightful credit for showing the big boy 80's painters how to smash the rules. The exhibition begins with Ms. Murray's 1981 "Heart and Mind," in which a canvas shaped like a cartoony cloud but painted with a lightning bolt intersects a canvas shaped like a lightning bolt but painted to contain a cartoony cloud. The message is that Ms. Murray's messy inclusion of the real world supplied the lightning that ignited the decade.
Unfortunately, as forerunners, Ms. Murray and Ms. Rothenberg get only one early painting each in the exhibition. Mr. Schnabel gets three, including the 19-foot-long "The Walk Home" (1984-85), which steals the show, as much by the wide-screen ambitions of its size as by its theatricality and the range of crockery and appendages attached to it. It's also a painting that debunks Mr. Schnabel's icon-smashing reputation and places him in a continuum from Jackson Pollock's "Blue Poles" through Robert Rauschenberg's combines. And Kenny Scharf bases his 1982 "The Jungle," in which the Jetsons encounter dread in psychedelic color, on the classic Greek statue of Laocoon.
Unfortunately, Ms. Clearwater allows the big boys once again to muscle other painters out of the way. In theory she is showing paintings from the years when the painters first emerged. But, hey, Mr. Schnabel was top box office by 1985. The rules are applied so unevenly that Terry Winters, Donald Baechler, Mr. Kiefer, Mr. Richter, Mr. Polke and Jean-Michel Basquiat get short shrift. 
That's bad news, because the only way to reassess 80's painters is to look at their work on equal terms. Or, as museums have been doing lately, to consider it in terms of similar ideas in other mediums. 
The final section of the exhibition focuses on the theory-based art of the Neo-Geo artists -- Peter Halley, Sherrie Levine, Allan McCollum, Richard Prince, Christopher Wool -- many of whom emerged as full-grown art stars from the collection of Charles Saatchi, beginning with their first exhibition at the Sonnabend Gallery in 1986.
Neo-Geo artists, and Mr. Halley in particular, paid the French philosophers Jean Baudrillard, Roland Barthes and Michel Foucault the kind of heed that Greenberg commanded two decades before. The new theories questioned the possibility of originality in a world controlled by systems of power and polluted with an overflow of images.
And so the decade that had begun by deposing one theoretical orthodoxy ended with another.
Mr. Schnabel is making movies now. And painting itself is neither dead nor the only game in town.

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
In Tune With the New Feminism

BYLINE:  By ANN POWERS 

 BODY:
BECOMING the Ultimate Woman is a goal most sensible women reject somewhere between their first diet and their last bikini. Yet feminism's gains have not allowed women to relax. They have only fed the pressure to stand out, and the path to success grows increasingly intricate.
 The May issue of Glamour magazine features a 28-year-old editor's account of enduring "Power Lipo" or surgical fat-reduction, to reduce her waist from 29 to 27 inches. There's also an article on laser treatments and gel injections for young women fighting skin imperfections. The April issue of Allure similarly considers wrinkle fillers like Botox, noting that "For the 35-and-under set in particular, the prospect of inheriting their parents' skin-sagging tendencies -- or worse, looking 'surgical' -- seems much scarier than, say, paralyzing a frown muscle with a tiny amount of poison." 
 These slick women's bibles make the pursuit of beauty seem like preparation for med school, with each woman as her own experimental subject. Yet these urgings toward cybernetic self-mastery are oddly countered with calls for a return to old-fashioned, curvy womanliness. Alongside the blueprints for flesh-toning are articles like "Start Loving Your Body," from the May issue of Self, which exhorts women to accept their cellulite. 
Romance earns similar mixed signals. New Age gurus advise going natural, body and soul, while their gimmick-happy counterparts hawk ab machines and Machiavellian seduction methods. Femininity has always been a high stakes game in a hall of mirrors, but now the ideal has grown so complex that, from puberty on, girls get dizzy making choices. Behind all these options, there's still a sense that one of them, to just be the plain you, is unacceptable. 
As America's reigning girl group, Destiny's Child is in the thick of this post-feminine revolution. From the Shirelles to TLC, girl groups have helped women hash out the differences between good and bad, liberation and entrapment, love and dependency. Since hip-hop's rise, girl groups have grown even tougher. En Vogue's lethal deployment of old-fashioned dazzle and TLC's forceful reimagining of the streetwise, regular girl made the space for Beyonce Knowles and her lieutenants in Destiny's Child, Kelly Rowland and Michelle Williams, to take on the predicaments of womanhood with the determination of warriors.
The overwhelming appeal of Destiny's Child is based on seriousness, not charm. The group's second album "The Writing's on the Wall," has had sales of more than seven million since its release in 1999, mostly on the strength of the sharp musical arrangements and stern reprimands of the hits "Say My Name" and "Bills, Bills, Bills."
The group's no-nonsense stance was further cemented last summer with the theme song to the "Charlie's Angels" film, "Independent Women Part I," a snarl about economic autonomy given a dazzling remix on "Survivor" (Columbia 61063), the group's new album, which will be released on Tuesday. The trio's hits gained a personal dimension as conflicts arose among members, and its line-up changed as Ms. Knowles emerged as an unusually authoritative teenage star. At 19, Ms. Knowles, who co-produced "Survivor" and co-wrote nearly every track, is as successful, and as resolute, as the middle-aged women who spent decades in power suits.
"There's plenty of people who don't like me, but there's 10 times more who love me, and I love myself," Ms. Knowles snaps in the caffeinated "Happy Face" from "Survivor." It's the kind of pep talk millions of women have given themselves before confronting the boss, or acting the boss with a problem employee. The song's mix of hyper-rhythms and floating melody, culminating in a delirious vocal run based around the phrase "I'm flying," captures just how crazy gaining authority can make women feel.
Women have long relished control, but femininity is still being reconfigured to make sense when they show such strength. It can seem as if a woman needs superpowers to lead in public, then to be able to melt in the arms of Mr. Right when he finally gets past her receptionist. Telepathy may help a woman trying to read whether a male coworker is attracted or repulsed by her assertiveness. Serious muscle is required to compete for the limited, if increasing, spots women still can claim.
Female action heroes have become the rage because their extremism seems necessary to kick womanhood into a new shape. Sometimes these fighters are sweet fantasies, like those Angels and the adorable cartoons the Powerpuff Girls. Often, though, they are lonely knights: Buffy the Vampire Slayer, who would like to just go dancing but has to save the world, or the self-sacrificing martial artists of "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," a career woman's tale transformed into myth. The winners in these popular fables have mixed feelings about their victories.
Back in the realm of beauty, goals pursued are also impossibly demanding. A woman like Pamela Anderson, who to many defines female sexuality, resembles a "Twilight Zone" fembot even after she has had her breast implants removed. Women must become technological experts just to look their best today, scientifically processing themselves while maintaining the veil of the natural.
Destiny's Child embodies this paradox of innocent expertise. The group's sound is fresh and emotional, yet its supremacy is not based on vocal gifts or beauty: it is grounded in the fact that these ladies have the best mixes, the savviest samples and especially the most happening beats. Like Charlie's Angels with their tricky weapons, Destiny's Child wields the technology of hip-hop soul with a professionalism that startles the boys.
It may seem strange that a woman not yet 20 would consider herself a survivor, but Ms. Knowles's image suits both the times and her personal life. The alleged story behind "Survivor" involves those former members ousted after they opposed Beyonce's father, Matthew Knowles, who is also Ms. Rowland's legal guardian and the group's manager. Lawsuits, one still pending, may have informed the album's sometimes bitter lyrics. But those personal details don't matter that much, because the drama is enmeshed within music that says more.
What intrigues is the way Destiny's Child makes fractured female identity its base and source of strength. This feat begins where it must in modern rhythm and blues, in the very rhythm of each track. Destiny's Child has worked with a top bunch of producers, including Anthony Dent, Poke and Tone, and Falonte Moore, to make "Survivor" its most aggressive disc yet. These men have steered other singers, but most gained credibility with hardcore rappers like Jay Z, Bone Thugs-N-Harmony and the Treacherous Three. 
On "Survivor's" best tracks, Destiny's Child taps into the energy of those rough rappers as well as songbirds like Mariah Carey and En Vogue, pushing uber-yin against uber-yang until the elements burst. "Apple Pie a la Mode" enacts a seduction that's part Andrews Sisters-style flirtation, part panther attack. "Sexy Daddy" is a loose call to party, honed with a laser-edged, techno-style beat. Beneath the Disney-soundtrack effects on "The Story of Beauty," a sad fairy tale of sexual abuse, the bass line taps along like a steel hammer on an assembly line.
Ms. Knowles's voice, which still stands out alongside her newly more prominent mates, adds more stimulating tension. Like Britney Spears, Ms. Knowles aims for drama but dwells on control, pulling her phrases forward with precision and rarely just riding a melody. 
Such young singers have absorbed the lessons of show-stoppers like Whitney Houston and Ms. Carey but turn their self-confidence toward competitiveness instead of noblesse oblige. Ms. Houston might have written the title track on "Survivor" as a self-help anthem, perhaps hinged on a failed romance. Ms. Knowles aims it at her litigious ex-vocal partners. The song's intensity is not that of heartbreak but that of a Stairmaster on 10. "I'm not going to stop, I'm going to work harder," the women sing while merciless violins nip at their heels.
"Survivor" has bland moments. The slow-dance blueprint "Brown Eyes," co-written by Walter Afanasieff, who has applied the same wash of emotion to songs for Celine Dion and Barbra Streisand, could become the group's most ordinary hit. There's also a gospel medley, partly based on a Kirk Franklin song, giving the thanks to Jesus that's become obligatory for the openly devoted Ms. Knowles.
Ms. Knowles and her collaborators are also not too skilled at integrating lyrical inconsistencies, most jarringly when the blatant "Bootylicious" is followed by "Nasty Girl," which chides a wayward sister for wearing skimpy clothes. But even on these painfully awkward moments, the sounds, and the emotions they generate, which collide on "Survivor," increase the group's relevance in this era of mixed signals.
Some might say Destiny's Child's attempt to be everything at once is hypocritical. But the paradoxes let some humanity slip into the highly constructed contemporary girl-group sound. In the gap between the flawlessness sought by ultimate women like Destiny's Child and the ambition and fear that drives them toward it, femininity changes. And that's where the real women live.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
Sharing the Stage With August Wilson

BYLINE:  By DON SHEWEY; Don Shewey is the author of the biography "Sam Shepard" and a theater critic for The Advocate.

 BODY:
THE young crowd filling the room for MTV's in-house multicultural speaker series one recent lunchtime had clearly turned out to hear August Wilson, whose plays chronicling the experience of black Americans in the 20th century have won a bushel basket of awards, including two Pulitzer Prizes. But they also got an unexpected jolt of energy and eloquence from the tall stocky man with the graying goatee, black turtleneck and fedora who shared the platform with the writer. That would be Marion McClinton, the director of Mr. Wilson's new play, "King Hedley II," which opens tonight at the Virginia Theater. 
 As the MTV employees, many of whom had seen "King Hedley II" in previews, fired questions at them, the playwright and the director took turns answering. Mr. Wilson beamed while Mr. McClinton held forth on subjects ranging from the interpretation of God by the "King Hedley" character Stool Pigeon to the mythological significance of a blood sacrifice to the production's use of songs by N.W.A. and Public Enemy, whom the director referred to as "warrior rappers." 
 "I've worked on Shakespeare, Beckett and Genet, and they were a walk in the park compared to this play," Mr. McClinton told the audience. "Sometimes it feels like Muhammad Ali fighting Joe Frazier -- he keeps coming at you!" 
The production of "King Hedley II" is a landmark for Mr. McClinton. It is at once his debut as a director on Broadway and the culmination of a 25-year theatrical career that has gotten increasingly hotter. Two years ago he directed "Jar the Floor," Cheryl West's comedy about four generations of black women, to good reviews and enthusiastic audiences at the Second Stage Theater Off Broadway. And last year his production of "Jitney," Mr. Wilson's dramatic comedy about a company of gypsy cabdrivers, wound up a four-year tour of regional theaters with a triumphant Off Broadway run that earned Obie Awards for the ensemble cast and for Mr. McClinton as director. 
As soon as "King Hedley II" opens, Mr. McClinton goes into production for Kia Corthron's "Breath, Boom" at Playwrights Horizons. And Disney has hired him to develop a musical called "Hoopz" about the Harlem Globetrotters, with a book by Suzan-Lori Parks, which will begin workshops next spring. 
"King Hedley II" stars Brian Stokes Mitchell as the title character, who has recently served seven years in prison and is trying to get on his feet financially by selling stolen refrigerators. It is 1985, and the economic boom of Reaganomics has not trickled down to the Hill District of Pittsburgh, where Mr. Wilson's plays are set. More than his other plays, this one explicitly refers to previous episodes in the cycle. King's mother Ruby (portrayed by Leslie Uggams) and Stool Pigeon (also known as Canewell and played by Stephen McKinley Henderson) were characters in "Seven Guitars," which opened on Broadway in 1996. And the play includes the offstage death of the 366-year-old Aunt Esther, a mythological figure on whom Mr. Wilson's next play will be centered.
Like all of Mr. Wilson's plays, "King Hedley II" has had a long gestation. It began in a workshop at the Seattle Repertory Theater two years ago, and Mr. McClinton has worked closely with the playwright on its several incarnations. 
Aside from the fact that it crams into three hours as much material as "The Sopranos" does in a 13-week season, what made "King Hedley II" such a challenge for the director? 
"It operates on so many levels at the same time," Mr. McClinton said. "It operates in the language of August Wilson, the blues idiom, the gospel idiom, the idiom of the black church, it operates out of classic Western theater -- the Greeks, in particular 'Oedipus.' And it operates in the land of Yoruba myth and religion, which is the hardest one to actualize but the one that gave the play its bed to ground it. In particular, we looked at the story of Ogun, the god of iron. The image of the barbed wire that King puts around the garden could be a crown of thorns or a circle of iron. It's a complicated play, with an enormous number of allusions, out of which he creates a new legend, a new fable, a new mythological figure, a Messiah of the 20th century."
Mr. Wilson seems both amused and awed by Mr. McClinton's dedication. "Marion will go home after rehearsal and read the script every night," he said, smoking a cigarette after the MTV forum. "I honestly don't know anyone more passionate than he is about the theater."
Although he had already begun directing plays, Mr. McClinton was primarily an actor when he and Mr. Wilson met at a poetry reading in 1978 in St. Paul, Minn., where they both were living. "I had wanted to be an actor since I was 6," he said. "In one weekend I saw 'On the Waterfront,' 'A Streetcar Named Desire' and 'The Wild One' on TV. After having grown up watching movies with John Wayne, who was John Wayne in every movie, this Brando guy was something else. What he did was exciting, it was real. Around the same time, Sidney Poitier won an Oscar for 'Lilies of the Field,' and I thought, 'This is something I could do.' " 
The first live play that made an impression on him was a production of "The Great White Hope" starring Ernie Hudson as the boxing champion Jack Johnson. "That floored me with the power of theater," Mr. McClinton said. "I understood Jack Johnson's anger, his pride, his arrogance. So I was pulled into theater by something that gave a voice to stuff I was feeling inside." 
At 21, he quit the University of Minnesota and joined the newly formed Penumbra Theater, a black theater company whose ensemble members were young and high-spirited. "Very much like Steppenwolf, except that where they were rock-and-roll, we were the bebop theater," Mr. McClinton said. "Our style of acting was based on rhythm." He played the narrator in Mr. Wilson's first professional production, a musical satire called "Black Bart and the Sacred Hills," and he took the role of the alcoholic Fielding in the very first incarnation of "Jitney" at Penumbra in 1985. 
Mr. McClinton began writing his own plays in 1989. The first, "Walkers," got slammed when it was produced at the Hudson Guild Theater Off Broadway. "Police Boys" had a better reception when it opened at Playwrights Horizons in 1995 after productions in Baltimore and Pittsburgh. He considers writing his loneliest occupation and acting his most satisfying, but directing is what allowed him to earn a living and have a stable home life with his wife and son. 
An associate artist at Center Stage in Baltimore, he has directed at theaters all over the country and made his New York directorial debut at the Public Theater in 1994 with Eugene Lee's "East Texas Hot Links." He has spent three of the last four summers at the Sundance Theater Lab in Utah. "Marion has been a favorite mentor for writers and directors because he understands the process from the inside," said Robert Blacker, the artistic director of the lab. 
Mr. McClinton believes he has done his best work as a director at Penumbra, with actors he has known for 15 years or more. Specifically, his 1993 staging of "The Piano Lesson," the first August Wilson play he directed, altered his relationship with the writer forever. 
"I'd taken some liberties with the play, and I was petrified that he would hate it," Mr. McClinton said. "I remember the day August saw it. I wasn't there. It was the day of my first interview with George Wolfe, who was fresh into his job at the Public. Another daunting figure! That night I saw a play by Athol Fugard, who'd been a major part of my acting career, and I got to meet him afterward. I went back to my hotel and called home and asked, 'What'd he think?' They said, 'He loved it, he was on his feet clapping at the end, came up onstage with the actors, took us out, told us it was the best production he'd ever seen.' "
He paused, remembering the emotions of that day. "I was staying at the Empire Hotel, and when I hung up the phone I opened the drapes and looked out the window at New York, and thought: 'Well, you kicked my butt the first time I was here, and there will be some butt-kickings to come, and embracings to come, but maybe I should stick around.' It was a very moving day. I thought as an artist I had arrived. I thought as an artist I belonged, and I had something of value to give, to share."
Mr. Wilson remembers that production of "The Piano Lesson" vividly. "It blew me away," he said. "I saw a director who was willing to try very bold things. Most directors don't trust themselves. Instead of coming up with a concept for the play, they would just duplicate Lloyd's production."
The collaboration between August Wilson and Lloyd Richards, which began in 1983, is one of the most fruitful in American theater. As a director with a Broadway track record (he staged the original 1959 production of Lorraine Hansberry's "Raisin in the Sun") and the dean at the time of the Yale Drama School, Mr. Richards was the most powerful African-American in the theater. When he selected Mr. Wilson's "Ma Rainey's Black Bottom" for development at the O'Neill playwrights conference in Connecticut, directed it at the Yale Repertory Theater and brought it to Broadway, he singlehandedly put the playwright on the map. 
Mr. Richards went on to stage the first productions of Mr. Wilson's subsequent plays: "Fences" (which won a Pulitzer), "Joe Turner's Come and Gone," "The Piano Lesson" (another Pulitzer), "Two Trains Running" and "Seven Guitars." Along the way, he and the managing director of the Yale Rep at the time, Benjamin Mordecai, established a system of developing important, literary but commercially risky plays like Mr. Wilson's by refining them at a series of nonprofit regional theaters before mounting them in the high-stakes arena of Broadway. 
By 1996, when "Seven Guitars" opened on Broadway, Mr. Richards was 74 and had retired from Yale. When Mr. Wilson decided to return to "Jitney," a script he had been rewriting on and off since 1979, he tapped Mr. McClinton, who is 46, to stage the show. Mr. Wilson described the difference between the two directors as generational. "The period of time Lloyd came into directing defined him as a director, and the same goes with Marion," he said. 
While Mr. Richards's productions reflected a solid grounding in classic naturalistic drama of the postwar era, Mr. McClinton is willing to be more theatrical with his use of music and set design. For instance, his decision to give his production of "Jitney" a soundtrack of songs by Marvin Gaye at his prime nimbly conveyed the cultural and emotional climate of the mid-1970's for urban black men. And David Gallo's stylized set for "King Hedley II" embeds symbolic references to past Wilson plays in what looks like a realistic Pittsburgh backyard.
"My productions were more muscular, more musical than Lloyd's," Mr. McClinton said. "I stretched more toward the poetry. But working with August, I started to realize a lot of things that Lloyd brought that you couldn't see onstage but in the rehearsal room were essential. Such as fidelity to the text. Maybe some of the choices I made in some of those productions were exciting -- I'm thinking of 'Two Trains Running' in Baltimore, which the audience loved. But the ending he'd written was darker, more revolutionary, and I basically sabotaged it. Working with August directly, I realized that sometimes your improvements aren't improvements, they're a contradiction of what he's saying. So what I've learned is: follow the text."
He has also been learning some things about the economics of Broadway. While a team of producers devoted to Mr. Wilson's work, headed by Mr. Mordecai, has been able to raise the financing to put "King Hedley II" on Broadway with a theater star, Mr. Mitchell, they were unable to do so for "Jitney," which played an extended run at the Second Stage and then moved to the Union Square Theater Off Broadway.
And despite its good notices and enthusiastic audiences, "Jar the Floor" was not able to manage a commercial transfer at all, which continues to irk Mr. McClinton. " 'Jar the Floor' should have played Broadway," he said flatly. "It had the perfect demographic audience, and a major performance by Lynne Thigpen, who I believe got cheated out of a Tony last year. There's a sector that believes that black plays don't work on Broadway unless there's singing and dancing. Sometimes I believe that's a self-fulfilling prophecy. For anything to work on that street it has to be supported with financing, advertising, publicity. I'm not sure exactly how it all broke down between the money people and the theater owners. All I know is that the theater we were looking at was the Longacre, and that 'Taller Than a Dwarf' went in there" -- a short-lived play from last season. "I do believe 'Jar the Floor' would have done better."
Robyn Goodman, who was one of the producers trying to move "Jar the Floor," said that, "Getting a Broadway house is a political thing. It's a matter of who carries the most weight with the theater owners." 
According to Elizabeth I. McCann, who would have been the lead producer for the Broadway transfer, the Shubert Organization had promised a theater to Julian Schlossberg, a producer of "Taller Than a Dwarf." Ms. McCann said, "It came down to who the Shuberts thought had a better chance of running through the summer, and they picked Elaine May and Matthew Broderick over Cheryl West and Lynne Thigpen." 
At the MTV forum, Mr. McClinton echoed Mr. Wilson's famously argued conviction that for black theater to survive and thrive it can't depend on the white theater establishment.
He brought up the recent closing of the Crossroads Theater, the well-respected nonprofit black theater company in New Jersey, and said, "Michael Jordan could make sure the Crossroads Theater didn't go down with the money he'd bet on a golf game." Furthermore, "Michael Jordan or Oprah Winfrey could have gotten 'Jar the Floor' on Broadway. I believe the money's out there. Why doesn't it happen? It goes back 150 years. Some people are still trying to buy their freedom. The question is, how much do we value our art?"

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
Kings Point Is the Latest to Get a New Village Hall

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE 

 BODY:
AFTER 33 years, history is repeating itself in the construction of a new village hall for Kings Point.
 The architect for the new building is Marc B. Spector, whose grandfather Charles S. Spector designed the renovations for the original village hall in 1968. The mayor at that time was Benjamin Kalnick, father of the current mayor, Michael Kalnick. 
 Directly west of the rambling new building is the old village hall, originally the home of the daughter of the automobile magnate Walter Chrysler.
The 100-year-old two-story white Dutch colonial sits on the edge of Steppingstone Park, which faces Long Island Sound with a view of the Manhattan skyline. The United States Merchant Marine Academy, on what was once the site of the Chrysler estate, is across the road to the south of both old and new village halls. 
"When we approached the Spector Group, we told them we wanted a building that would blend in with the community," Michael Kalnick said. "That is a combination of traditional-old and contemporary. Structurally, this new building looks like the limestone of the many buildings at the Merchant Marine Academy. It is set back, well-landscaped and on one floor, so there is no impact on the community."
The new Kings Point building is the latest completely new village hall to be built on Long Island as villages upgrade facilities or construct new ones in which to conduct official business. For years, many of the island's 95 incorporated villages have held their meetings and kept records in temporary quarters, including a mayor's basement, or in aging buildings that have become expensive to maintain. 
The original Kings Point village hall -- which will be demolished to make way for a park or for overflow parking for Steppingstone Park -- "was rotting away, and only one floor of its three were being used," the mayor said. "It was totally inefficient, and was cheaper and more economical to build new. "
The $4.9 million new building, scheduled to open in May, is on 4.3 acres of village-owned property. It includes six attached one-story pavilions with individual copper-painted pitched roofs in a parklike setting of wide lawns that will be edged with trees, bushes and flowering perennials.
"The landscaping will be residential in feeling, since the village is known for its free-flowing English gardens," Mr. Spector said. His firm, the Spector Group, has an office in North Hills about five miles from Kings Point.
The 13,750-square-foot building includes a 2,100-square-foot courtroom, which extends behind the 1,600-square-foot lobby that is in the center of the building. The courtroom, which will also serve as a public hearing room, seats 137 people, 80 percent more than in the old building. It has an open ceiling with exposed cherry-wood beams and is topped with a short windowed tower at the peak. To the right of the lobby are three attached pavilions with cherry-wood accents and deep blue and beige carpets.
The individual pavilions range from about 950 square feet to almost 1,400 square feet and will house the village offices, including the building and highway departments. A wing on the left and at a right angle to the lobby includes two 980-square-foot pavilions that will house the police department with its separate entrance and a 1,800-square-foot pavilion, which will include the court clerk's office and a chamber shared by the mayor and judge, both of whom are part-time officials . Behind this wing are the parking lots, with 16 spaces for police cars and 50 for the public.
The exterior of the building is maintenance-free, Mr. Spector said. The copper-painted roofs, which change shades depending on the angle of the sun, will not oxidize and turn green, and the natural-colored concrete walls will not require painting.
The project was in the talking stages for about 15 years, said Kenneth G. Olsen, former president of the Kings Point Civic Association.
"The original plans were all marble and granite, and the building would have looked like a federal courthouse," he said. "A good portion of the civic association opposed it as too boxy. They wanted it more sprawling."
PROBABLY about 80 percent of the community is happy with the new building, Mr. Olsen said. "There are some who are unhappy that any money was spent at all, but if it had been done four years ago, it would have been half as much. But the mayor held off for more community input."
According to the village attorney, Stephen Limmer, the $4.9 million bond will increase taxes this year by 2.4 percent to $17.29 per $100 of assessed valuation from $16.80. 
Asking prices for a Kings Point house range from $800,000 for a small older house on a small lot to $10 million for a waterfront estate, according to Lee Rothleder, president of sales and marketing at the Great Neck office of Goodstein Realty. This year, home sales in the village , which is located on four square miles at the tip of the Great Neck peninsula, have averaged $1.8 million for a four-bedroom house with two or more bathrooms on three quarters of an acre or more.
"Kings Point is an extremely high-demand and prestigious area," Ms. Rothleder said.
Nassau County has 64 incorporated villages. According to Dolores Sedacca, executive director of the Nassau County Village Officials Association, some new village halls have been built over the past few years, including in Saddle Rock and Roslyn. 
Lake Success, a community of 827 houses, recently passed an $8.5 million bond issue for a new village hall. Officials are currently using the second floor of a community center that is "falling apart and becoming a money pit," Mayor Robert Bernstein said. The old building will be razed and the new hall built in a similar style on the site, which is part of the Deepdale Country Club.
Suffolk County has 31 incorporated villages. New village halls have been built in the last 10 years in North Haven, Islandia, Shoreham and the Village of the Branch, according to Mark Grossman, executive director of the Suffolk County Village Officials Association.
In some cases, like Old Westbury in Nassau County and Head of the Harbor and East Hampton in Suffolk, village halls located in historic buildings have been modernized, with their historic elements kept intact.
For example, Old Westbury's village hall was initially a country store. Several years ago it was expanded and the exterior refinished in the original natural cedar-shake style with white trim, according to the village clerk, Ken Callahan.
Daniel Shybunko, mayor of Head of the Harbor since 1994, said his village, which is in the town of Smithtown, got its first village hall seven years ago, when it remodeled a 150-year-old caretaker's cottage that was part of the county-owned Deepwells Estate. Before that, village business had been conducted in the former mayor's basement, Mr. Shybunko said. The new project cost more than $400,000 and added about 1,000 square feet to the original 800-square-foot, two-story white frame cottage. It now contains village offices, a main meeting hall and the police department.
Officials in the Village of the Branch, a one-mile-square community in the heart of the town of Smithtown, had worked out of the mayors' homes for generations. Four years ago, Sunrise Assisted Living requested permission to build a facility in the village for older people who need some assistance with personal and health care. Invoking the state's Incentive Zoning Law, which permits developers changes of zoning if they give something back to the community, the village received its first village hall. 
In exchange for a special exception permit in a restricted business zone, Sunrise donated a half-acre of its five-acre property and a gray saltbox-style, one-story 1,500-square-foot furnished building that it had constructed for temporary use as a sales office.
"We negotiated a nice deal, and two years ago we moved in," Mayor Irene Kissane said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marc B. Spector, left, the architect, and Mayor Michael Kalnick at the new Kings Point village hall. (Richard Lee for The New York Times) Map of Kings Point highlighting site of new village hall.

HEADLINE: A Funding Shift and Towns Try to Make Do 

BYLINE:  By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
AN unpleasantly tight budgeting season is under way for cities and towns across the state, the first in several years, and the local difficulties are aggravating political differences between the Democratic-controlled State Legislature and the governor over the state budget.
 For example, New Haven's Mayor, John DeStefano Jr., said this was "the hardest budget year" of his eight years in office. He has had to deal with tough binding arbitration demands from city unions, citizen demands for more services or lower taxes, and increasing difficulty in squeezing more tax revenues out of his city's tax base. 
 The problem for some of these cities is that Gov. John Rowland proposed a budget for the coming year that shifts a portion of casino revenues from a local tax relief program to the state's primary education aid program. While that gives more money to the schools, it reduces the amount municipalities receive from the state for general budget purposes. 
Local officials said that while it sounds like money is going from one of their pockets to another, it's not that simple. Because of differences in the allocation formulas of the two aid programs, some municipalities will be receiving less money under the shift, making their budgets that much harder to balance.
Even though some school districts are getting budget increases while other municipal department budgets are being cut, the heads of some districts also said they are being short-changed. They said they need to hire more teachers because their enrollments are increasing, and they are under pressure to improve teacher training and remedial help for failing students, but they are not getting the money they need.
"The broad issue here is you can't separate the revenue stream of the cities and towns from the state, because the cities and towns have only one place to go," Mr. DeStefano said. That place, he said, is property taxes.
Mr. Rowland argued that he has to comply with the state's spending cap, added to the constitution when the state approved its income tax in 1991, which limits state budget increases to 4 to 5 percent a year. His spokesman, Dean Pagani, said the complaints by local officials should also be considered in light of the governor's sensitivity to municipal budget concerns in the past.
"The governor feels he has been very generous to cities and towns on tax relief, education spending, economic development and school construction over the six years that he's being in office," Mr. Pagani said. "The governor has to make choices, and the cities and towns have to make choices."
Timing has complicated those choices. Municipal budgets have to be approved by early May, while the state budget isn't approved until about a month later. Local government leaders have to choose whether to base their budgets on the proposal of the governor, a Republican, or on the expectation that the Democrats that control the Legislature will be more generous.
"My impression is that the governor's proposal will not be successful," said Mayor Daniel P. Malloy of Stamford, "and I budgeted as if it wasn't going to be successful."
In fact, the legislature's Appropriations Committee has recommended a package that would undo Mr. Rowland's funding shift, restoring or increasing the major tax relief grants to municipalities and increasing the educational cost sharing grant.
The governor's office said the economic slowdown that has affected the stock market has not been a factor, but that could change. Mr. Pagani said both the Office of Policy and Management and the legislature's Office for Fiscal Analysis have predicted that the economy would slow in the coming year, which could reduce state tax revenues.
When Mayor Joseph Ganim of Bridgeport presented his city's budget to the aldermen at the beginning of this month, supporters of the city's public schools greeted it with angry denunciations. Bridgeport's new school superintendent, Sonia Diaz Salcedo, said she was disappointed with the mayor's budget.
Bridgeport's school budget is about half of the city's $431 million budget. The Board of Education recommended a 14 percent increase, while Mr. Ganim recommended an increase of just under 9 percent.
Dr. Diaz Salcedo said the extra $8.3 million the mayor proposes for the schools falls short of the $9.9 million she needs just to stay even with rising fixed costs. Rising insurance benefit costs alone will eat up about $3.5 million, she said.
She recently introduced herself to Mr. Rowland on the telephone, "and the first thing I said to him was we need more money." She said the governor told her that he would have been disappointed if she hadn't made the request, but he didn't promise anything.
Julian Stafford, the school superintendent of New London, said his school board asked for a 9 percent budget increase, but the city's proposed budget gives the schools slightly less than 2 percent instead.
"This is going to be catastrophic to the New London public schools," he said.
Dr. Stafford said if the schools don't get more than that, he'll have to lay off employees, possibly even teachers, increase class size, and cut the gifted and talented program.
City Manager Richard Brown noted that the rest of New London's budget will be cut by 6 percent to give Dr. Stafford's schools even that 2 percent increase.
New London did a revaluation of its taxable property last year. Although properties near its waterfront increased in value, it saw a net decrease overall from its last revaluation 10 years ago. It received more than $60 million from the state in economic development assistance, but its new development was in special enterprise zones where tax incentives bring in no taxes for the first two years and reduced revenues for the next five.
New London approved a tax increase last year, but Mr. Brown said it will not raise taxes this year.
The differences between what school boards ask for and what city officials, who must raise that money through property taxes, feel is affordable is nothing new. Several mayors said they were critical of what they feel were unreasonable demands by school officials.
"In Connecticut, unfortunately, urban school districts and municipalities are sometimes put at odds because of the way the funding structure is put in place," Mr. Ganim said.
State grants and cost-sharing aid pays for more than 80 percent of Bridgeport's school spending, making school budget increases highly dependent on increases in state aid. Anything above the state funding must come from cuts in city services or tax increases.
Mr. Ganim said it was "ridiculous" for Bridgeport's school board to ask for a 14 percent increase. "Not that they don't need it, but nobody is going to support that kind of funding increase."
Urban mayors, who in Connecticut are almost all Democrats, blamed the Republican governor's shift of money from the casino revenues fund to the educational cost-sharing fund for much of the problem.
"That's a shell game," Mr. Ganim said.
Since the casino revenues fund was established in 1994, a decreasing portion of it has been used for local tax relief -- 78 percent the first year, dropping to about 40 percent this year -- while casino revenues have tripled, from $113 million to $336 million, said Kevin Maloney, a spokesman for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities. The governor's proposal lowers the local tax relief share to 31 percent next fiscal year and to 23 percent the year after. The governor's proposed budget shifts $25 million from the gaming revenues fund to the education fund next year, and another $25 million the year after.
State Representative Robert M. Ward, the Republican minority leader, said some of the local budget anguish was because the casino revenues fund and the educational cost-sharing fund have different formulas. Some communities get more money because of the shift and some get less. 'It creates winners and losers," he said.
Republicans said it was the Democrats who forced it, by insisting that the educational cost-sharing aid program be fully funded. By law, the state should pay for half of the cost of public education, and the cost-sharing program is the largest portion.
Mr. Malloy said Stamford is a loser with either formula, because they tend to put more weight on wealth than on need. Stamford is wealthy, but also has thousands of poor residents. Gene Enriquez, mayor of Danbury, said his city is also affected this way.
Mr. Ward said most affluent Republican communities, such as North Branford, one of the towns he represents, are losers, but only slightly because they didn't get much anyway.
He said the problem is caused by flaws and inequities in the educational cost-sharing formula, a complicated calculation based on 58 factors, and not in the governor's decision to shift the money.
Mr. Ward said he thought the formulas should be replaced with new ones that are fairer and less political, and that Democrats such as Mr. Malloy, Mr. Enriquez and Mr. Ganim should join the Republicans in calling for this.
The Appropriations Committee recommendation would provide some relief for local taxpayers and additional money for schools, but Mr. Pagani said it would also put the state budget out of balance. He predicted that the final budget would require a compromise between Mr. Rowland and the legislature's Democrats.
Furthermore, the Appropriations Committee did not address the question of the educational cost sharing grant formula.
"That will be hotly debated in the next few weeks," Mr. Maloney said.
