HEADLINE: The Track Has Run Its Course 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: CHERRY HILL 

 BODY:
CIGARETTE butts pepper the floor, and pages of newspaper swirl outside like bands of mad pigeons. Stables that once housed the greatest thoroughbreds are empty, paint peeling and door hinges rusting. The grandstands that once held 30,000 bettors -- often fashionably dressed -- for a Saturday race card now have a couple of hundred simulcast watchers like Thomas Wilson, most of them older and presumably retired.
 This recent day had been a grim one for Mr. Wilson. The young spring sun was finally shining, to be sure. But as he looked over the infield of Garden State Park from his grandstand perch, he was despondent. The last few races simulcast to the track from Aqueduct Raceway had treated him well enough; it was the impending demise of his favorite track that had him down. 
 "This had been such a wonderful place," said Mr. Wilson, who has been coming to Garden State since he was a boy in the 1940's. "I can't believe it is going away." 
On May 3, just shy of 59 years after it was dedicated as the finest racetrack in the world, Garden State will run its last race.
Oddly, the Garden State's Web site (www.gspark.com) still has cheery, multicolored animated horses and a sparkling photo captioned "Garden State Park at night -- elegant, dazzling, exciting, fun!"
The reality is far different.
At a time when casinos and legalized numbers playing -- otherwise known as the lottery -- are flourishing, horse racing is finishing a distant third. After all, Atlantic City Race Course has been running two-week live racing seasons merely to meet the state's requirements to have simulcasting at the track. Pennwood Racing, which operates Garden State and Freehold Raceway, has seen its total betting handle at Freehold decline from $44.9 million in 1995 to $29.8 million in 1999, the last year for which the state has complete figures.
At the Meadowlands, which is run by the quasi-public New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, thoroughbred racing dates shrunk from 66 days to 51, while harness dates were whittled down to 145 in 1999 from 181 in 1995. And at the Monmouth Park Jockey Club, also run by the Sports and Exposition Authority, attendance is up slightly, but the amount bet is down significantly, to $87.1 million in 1999 from $116.5 in 1995.
As for the fate of Garden State, there will still be some simulcasting after the final thoroughbred meet is over. But then the sprawling 223-acre property will be largely demolished and over the next few years converted to a mixed office-retail-residential development. While some regulars like Mr. Wilson lament the track's fate, many nearby residents can't wait for something new.
"For people who have been here since the 1940's and 1950's, it was really something in those days, so they have nostalgia about it," said Mayor Susan Bass Levin of Cherry Hill. "But it has been a long time since Garden State has been anything special."
Ms. Levin lamented: "It's very creepy there now. There aren't horses boarded and a lot of jobs have left anyway."
There have been complaints from neighbors in recent years about storm-water runoff, infestations of flies and general uncleanliness from the track that weren't there in Garden State's glory years. In addition, its owners have filed tax appeals four times in the last 12 years, trying to avoid payment.
"I feel bad that the racing industry won't be here anymore and that some people will lose jobs, but it's time for something more vibrant here," she said.
To Michael Vukcevich, the deputy director of the New Jersey Racing Commission, "it depends on what you call healthy." 
"What has happened over the last several years is a decline in live racing dates and an increase in simulcasting," Mr. Vukcevich said. "And in any case, it has been the survival of the fittest.
"The New Jersey legislature has worked hard to promote the racing industry here," Mr. Vukcevich added. "But the situation in New Jersey is not unique. Simulcasting, while it has brought more fans to racing, inevitably cuts down on live racing. If you go into a racetrack with $100 in your pocket, would you rather spread it over a half-dozen live races or have the chance to bet on 30 races around the country?"
The state has given its surviving thoroughbred tracks, Monmouth and the Meadowlands, an infusion of $11.7 million for prize money, or purses as it is called in horse-racing parlance. That will improve the daily payout to winners at the two tracks to $300,000, a figure racing people feel will bring in better horses. (An additional $6.3 million will go to Freehold Raceway, which runs only harness racing.)
"Racing has taken a huge step backwards in New Jersey, and we are happy to see that the State Legislature has recognized it and wants to bring things back," said Frank X. Keegan Jr., a horse owner who is president of the New Jersey Thoroughbred Horsemen's Association. "Hopefully, this will attract better horses running for better purses for people who want to go to the races and play."
The dominant image of the horse player most likely arises from the musical "Guys and Dolls," in which streetwise guys check their tout sheets every day and head to the track.
In truth, this was probably never an entirely accurate picture -- and certainly is not one now. In Garden State Park's heyday, the 1950's and 1960's -- when it attracted 12,000 people a day during the week and double that on Saturdays, it did so because it was open for racing only 25 days in the spring and 25 more in the fall. Fans came because it was a seasonal event. A regular was someone who might have come four or five times a season.
Today, because of simulcasting, the televised viewing of -- and betting on -- races from tracks around the country is a daily practice. On the other hand, there are fewer people doing it.
The National Thoroughbred Racing Association, a trade organization made up of breeders, tracks, trainers and jockeys, undertook studies last year that showed there was a core of about three million horse racing fans who visited a track or off-track betting facility at least five times a year and accounted for the majority of the nation's betting dollars.
On the other hand, the study found five million of what it called lapsed fans, those who used to be regulars but now visit a track only occasionally. Further, the racing association said it found there were 18 million of what it called light fans -- people who might watch the Kentucky Derby on television but rarely come to the track.
"You have to figure that a lot of this comes from the vast array of other alternatives, from time to other sports to casinos," said Wes Patterson, a Florida sports psychologist who is writing a book about the psychology of horse-racing enthusiasts. "People don't have the time or desire to spend six hours at the track for nine races anymore. And the proliferation of casinos and lotteries have changed how people who do bet, bet with their money."
Marc Falcone and Jason N. Ader, equity experts for Bear Stearns, wrote an extensive in-house analysis of the nation's horse racing industry last December, and the two generally found the sport ready for a rebound, though only under certain terms.
The authors discovered that attendance for racing in general was going down at a steady pace, but it was up on days when there were special events. For instance, when the Belmont Stakes, the third leg of the famed thoroughbred Triple Crown, was run on Long Island, the track saw a 10 percent increase in attendance each year
In addition, Mr. Falcone and Mr. Ader said there was room for growth in the industry through consolidation. Interestingly, they said, as fewer tracks were owned or operated by fewer organizations, individual races would increase in value. Better horses, if fewer -- running in races with better purses -- would help increase attendance, they said. Compared with baseball, for example, this would be the equivalent of ridding the Major Leagues of perennial losers like the Montreal Expos or the Kansas City Royals, thus allowing more games between strong teams like the New York Mets and Atlanta Braves.
Indeed, that is a blueprint for the Sports and Exhibition Authority at the Meadowlands.
"We have the most racing dates and offer the highest purses," said Chris McErlean, vice president and general manager of the Meadowlands Race Track. "That's how you get better horses.
"One of the things that will be the core of our ongoing business is to have our focus on showcase events," Mr. McErlean added. "Our major races -- the Meadowlands Pace and Hambletonian and the Breeders Crown --those are where we focus to make our track nationally and internationally known."
Mr. McErlean said the Meadowlands might have a weekday crowd of 5,000 or 6,000, but when the Hambletonian, a $1 million race, is run in August, 30,000 people flock to the track. Similarly, even on weekends, the average attendance at Monmouth may only reach 11,000, but when the big race of the summer, the $1 million Haskell, is run, as many as 40,000 come through the gates.
"Frankly, the Meadowlands is the mecca of our sport," said Paul Ramlow, a publicist for the United States Trotting Association, a trade organization based in Columbus, Ohio. "They created a racetrack with a large purse structure, the best drivers and some of the most prestigious races in the sport. Garden State was a nice companion to it when it ran a fall harness season, but I think New Jersey will weather that loss."
Mr. Ramlow said that harness trainers liked to send their horses to Garden State, a one-mile track, rather than Freehold, which was a half mile. The longer the track, the fewer and easier the turns, putting less stress on the horse.
"Still, I can see Freehold making up some of those dates," he said. "New Jersey is a strong breeding state. The tracks are there and the history of breeding is there. The whole state is entwined with racing, and it is important for the economy. So I think it will stay healthy."
Most observers agree that the decline at Garden State, and the horse racing business in New Jersey in general, came with the advent of casino gambling in Atlantic City.
"A lot of the people who used to go to Garden State and Atlantic City racetracks certainly started to go to the casinos," said Mr. Vukcevich of the New Jersey Racing Commission. "It tended not to be as great a decline in the northern New Jersey tracks, but it still hurt them somewhat." 
But Mr. Keegan of the New Jersey Thoroughbred Horsemen's Association said that the downturn in horse racing in the state came a bit earlier, with the advent of the New Jersey Lottery in 1969.
"Historically, Garden State ran a spring meet, Monmouth raced in early summer with Atlantic City, and then you went back to Garden State for the fall," he said. "Then everyone went to Florida for the winter. But then the lottery came and people stopped following racing everywhere. And when casino gambling came in, the floor fell through. You can only have so many delicatessens on the corner before someone has to go to work for the other guy."
Though the demise of Garden State had been expected for years, Mr. Keegan and other horse people said it was a wake-up call for the state to shore up its horseracing industry.
"This is an important segment of the economy here," said Mr. Keegan. "Breeding is important, too, in that it keeps open space in a crowded state. A healthy racing game produces farms that stop urban sprawl. It's not just a few old guys betting on bad horses."
Mr. Falcone and Mr. Ader, the Bear Stearns analysts, suggested that New Jersey would continue to lose racing fans either to casinos or to other states like New York or Delaware if it did not add extra inducements at the tracks.
Delaware, for instance, has allowed its tracks to have slot machines, with some of the profits going to bigger purses. Phone betting or off-track betting parlors have had proponents as well. In fact, Pennwood is keeping a few acres at Garden State in the hope that legislation allowing off-track betting will become law in New Jersey.
"I'm a horse guy, not a casino person," said Mr. McErlean of the Meadowlands. "But people feel casinos are nonstop action and horse racing is not fast-paced enough. Delaware has slots and it doesn't take as much effort to pull a lever as to handicap a race.
"For the past two years, especially on the harness side, Ontario has been a major competitor for us because of slot machines at the tracks there," he added. "They put some of that money back into purses, so better horses and thus better races go there."
Mr. McErlean said he would welcome either slot machines or some other type of betting mechanism at his tracks.
"We're already set up to handle gambling anyway," he said. "We are under heavy regulations and know how to deal with them. It can only help the racing industry here." 
But for Mr. Wilson, who was standing forlornly at the grandstand at Garden State, he is not sure what all of this will mean for him.
"Slot machines, ugh!" he said. "Even simulcasting. I don't know. It used to be such a fun way to spend a day, looking at the horses, standing by the rail, cheering as they go around. But I guess everyone wants faster action these days." 
Then he laughed uncomfortably and said, "I liked losing my money a lot more slowlythan that."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Have Rate Cuts Lost Their Magic?

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE Federal Reserve is clearly willing. Cutting interest rates comes easy these days, and if a few more cuts will arrest a slowdown that the Fed's policy makers never anticipated, then they will surely oblige. But stopping this slowdown and reviving the economy may be beyond the Fed's powers.
 The current downturn differs significantly from nearly all of those since World War II. The Fed provoked the earlier contractions by raising interest rates to slow the economy and reduce inflation. This time, higher rates played almost no role, and the downturn caught Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, by surprise. He and his colleagues are hastily cutting rates to encourage a rebound -- if one is out there. 
 Much hope exists, particularly on Wall Street, that the economy will recover on its own by the end of the year, and that companies will resume their purchases of new equipment, particularly computers and communications gear, and stock prices will stabilize, restoring confidence that family wealth will survive intact. But there is wide recognition that the Fed alone cannot make this happen. The business cycle proceeds unharnessed. And the Fed, for all its theatrical rate cuts, is more spectator than master of ceremonies.
Janet Yellen, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley and a former Fed governor, expresses as well as anyone the concern that Fed monetary policy -- lowering interest rates to encourage borrowing and spending -- lacks its usual curative power. "I am not saying that monetary policy does not work," Ms. Yellen said. "I am saying that we have negative shocks here that require a lot of work from monetary policy," perhaps more than is possible.
The chief negative shock involves capital spending. This is the investment in machinery, computers, software, factories, desks -- all the tools used to produce the goods and services that consumers then buy. Much attention is paid to consumers and the danger to the economy when they reduce their spending. Here, monetary policy does have leverage. Lower rates have helped to maintain spending, at least for homes and cars. Capital investment, on the other hand, is not very responsive to interest rates, yet it has just as powerful an influence on the economy. Huge capital outlays, particularly for computers and software, accounted for most of the rapid economic growth in recent years, and the collapse in capital spending starting last spring brought on the downturn. That is what makes this slowdown different than others.
The power of capital investment lies largely in its multiplier effect. The millions of workers who make the capital goods are consumers themselves, until layoffs or fewer hours cut into their spending. The companies that buy all the new equipment, particularly the high-technology equipment, become more efficient and productive. Their rising profits and the expectation of more to come helped to levitate stock prices, which then financed more capital investment, not to mention the encouragement that the booming market gave to consumers.
SIMPLY put, expectations and optimism got out of hand and excesses developed. Now companies find themselves with more capital goods than they need for a slowing economy. And recovery seems to ride on the answer to this question: When will the promise of rising profits again seem firm enough to justify the purchase of capital goods? In this calculation, interest rates play only a minor role. 
Some experts, like Kermit L. Schoenholtz, chief economist at Salomon Smith Barney and Citibank, argue optimistically that the capital equipment glut is not as great as some people believe. If consumer spending holds up, with help from lower interest rates, then the prospect of rising profits will revive capital spending before this year ends. Others, like Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant, say the sluggish economic growth of the last six months will persist for many months. The economy expanded at an annual rate of only 2 percent in the second quarter, the Commerce Department announced on Friday.
History and theory "support the view that an extended period of time will be required before American corporations will regenerate sustained vigorous rates of earnings growth," Mr. Bernstein writes in a newsletter going out this week. 
If so, then Mr. Greenspan led us astray. As a champion of the new economy, he praised the huge corporate outlays for high-technology equipment and the rising productivity that helped to explain the ever-fatter profits. In his many public statements, he did not focus public attention on the potential excesses in capital spending or the danger to profits. Monetary policy, he suggested, could deal with whatever lay ahead. But that may not be the case.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Andrea Lans, Thomas Donahue

 BODY:
Andrea Elisabeth Lans, the daughter of Shirley Johnson Lans and Asher Bob Lans, both of New York, was married last evening to Thomas Raymond Donahue, a son of Donald J. Donahue of Hobe Sound, Fla., and the late Mary Meyer Donahue. The Rev. Dr. 
Thomas F. Pike officiated at Calvary Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Stephen S. Garmey, the vicar of the church and the bride's godfather, took part in the ceremony, as did the Rev. Mark C. Hallinan, a Roman Catholic priest. 
 Mrs. Donahue, 31, is the director of special events for the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust in New York, a fund-raising arm of the Royal Academy of Arts in London. She is also a board member at the Sheltering Arms Children's Service in New York. She graduated magna cum laude from Barnard College. 
 Her father is of counsel to Jackson & Nash, a New York law firm, and director of the Gramercy Neighborhood Association, of which he was president from 1998 to 2000. Her mother is a professor of economics at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and a former board member of the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority. 
Mr. Donahue, 39, is a managing director of Inter-Atlantic, a venture capital firm in New York, where he oversees the selection and monitoring of investments. He graduated cum laude from Georgetown University and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. His father retired as the chairman of the Magma Copper Company, a mining company in San Manuel, Ariz., and was a chairman of the trustees at Georgetown University. The bridegroom is a stepson of Carol Pascal Donahue. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

SECTION: Section 14; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 7

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LONG ISLAND CITY; 
Making the Citicorp Tower Less Lonesome

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
The Citicorp tower, which reaches 50 lonely stories into the sky above Long Island City, is by far the tallest building on Queens Plaza. But after more than a decade, it may get some company of comparable stature.
 The Department of City Planning is considering a proposal to rezone 37 blocks around Queens Plaza from mostly light industrial use to mixed commercial, residential and industrial use. The plan is designed to attract office tenants who might otherwise decamp to Jersey City, in the hope that Long Island City will realize its long-predicted emergence as an alternative to Midtown. 
 "It's 10 minutes away by subway, and it's just sitting there," said Jeffrey A. Bernstein, a managing director at Insignia/ESG, a real estate company.
Still, many worry that an influx of high-paying office tenants will destroy the manufacturing businesses that thrive in the neighborhood.
City officials emphasize that the redevelopment zone was carefully drawn to protect major manufacturing areas. "It is not a blanket rezoning," said Hardy Adasko, senior vice president of the Economic Development Corporation.
But Jonathan Bowles, research director of the Center for an Urban Future, said that without specific initiatives for manufacturers, high real estate prices will spill over into adjacent areas, forcing out industrial tenants. "Scores of printers, bakers, woodworkers, garment makers and other manufacturers have been squeezed out of industrial enclaves of Manhattan and north Brooklyn as a result of the same real estate pressures that could soon take place in Long Island City," Mr. Bowles said.
The New York Industrial Retention Network, an advocate for city manufacturers, estimated that more than 15,000 manufacturing jobs, many held by minority workers, were at risk.
Dakota Jackson, who designs and manufactures furniture, owns a factory in the heart of the proposed rezoning district, where he employs 140 people of more than 30 nationalities. "I've always believed that one builds and develops a business within the region that one lives and supports the community that way," Mr. Jackson said. "I would be forced to rethink." ERIKA KINETZ
